('3', 0, 1, 2, 39) 1. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE
('3', 0, 2, 3, 66) AGAKHAN’S BUILDINGS, 2ND FLOOR, OPPOSITE HIGH COURT, BOMBAY, FORT, August 1, 1902
('3', 0, 3, 4, 148) DEAR PROF.
('3', 0, 3, 5, 159) GOKHALE, I think I have told you that if I receive the funds expected from Natal, I would settle in Bombay.
('3', 0, 3, 6, 267) Having received over Rs. 3000, I have opened an office here and propose giving a year’s trial to this place.
('3', 0, 3, 7, 376) I need hardly repeat the assurance that you could command me at any time.
('3', 0, 3, 8, 450) I hope you are doing well constitutionally.
('3', 0, 4, 9, 494) I remain, yours truly, M. K. GANDHI
('3', 0, 5, 10, 530) From the photostat of the original: G.N. 3717.
('3', 0, 6, 11, 577) 2. LETTER TO DEVCHAND PAREKH 1
('3', 0, 7, 12, 608) OPPOSITE HIGH COURT, BOMBAY, FORT, August 6, 1902
('3', 0, 8, 13, 658) MY DEAR DEVCHANDBHAI, I did not wish to suggest that Mr. Indrajit should be given any responsible work at all.
('3', 0, 8, 14, 769) His wish is to act as junior counsel in addition to your paid junior.
('3', 0, 8, 15, 839) All he wants, I suppose, is to be able to say that he appeared as Junior Counsel in a Privy Council case and possibly to gain some practical knowledge.
('3', 0, 8, 16, 991) I have taken up a room from Payne, Gilbert, Sayani and Moos for office, and a part of Keshavji Tulsidas’ Bunglow in Girgam Back Road for residence.
('3', 0, 8, 17, 1139) That is all the progress I have made so far.
('3', 0, 8, 18, 1184) I have just finished the welcome draft work that Shukla sent me while I was in Rajkot, and am now free to lounge about the High Court letting the Solicitors know of an addition to the ranks of the
('3', 0, 9, 19, 1381) 1 A friend of Gandhiji who later gave up legal practice to join States politics and Gandhiji’s constructive work.
('3', 1, 0, 1, 1495) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 1, 1, 2, 1535) briefless ones.
('3', 1, 1, 3, 1551) Mehta, on my going to him for a blessing, gave me a curse which as he said might prove a blessing.
('3', 1, 1, 4, 1650) He thought, contrary to my expectations, that I would be foolishly wasting away in Bombay my small savings from Natal.
('3', 1, 1, 5, 1769) Wachha, I have not yet been able to see.
('3', 1, 1, 6, 1810) Gokhale is not here.
('3', 1, 1, 7, 1831) The Solicitors, whom I have seen, say that I would have to wait long before I could get any work from them.
('3', 1, 1, 8, 1939) The Chief Justice is very anxious for the advancement of the junior barristers and only last week established a moot society for their benefit.
('3', 1, 1, 9, 2083) Such briefly are the circumstances under which I find myself.
('3', 1, 1, 10, 2145) The work is uphill.
('3', 1, 1, 11, 2165) But I do not despair.
('3', 1, 1, 12, 2187) I rather appreciate the regular life and the struggle that Bombay imposes on one.
('3', 1, 1, 13, 2269) So long, therefore, as the latter does not become unbearable, I am not likely to wish to be out of Bombay.
('3', 1, 1, 14, 2376) I am very glad to learn that Manilal is doing so well.
('3', 1, 1, 15, 2431) It is true that my nephew at first sent disappointing reports from Benares: that they provide only two meals per day does still appear to me to be a drawback.
('3', 1, 1, 16, 2590) But it is yet too soon to pass judgment one way or the other.
('3', 1, 1, 17, 2652) He will be able to send me more reliable reports after he has become used to his totally new surroundings.
('3', 1, 1, 18, 2759) If the rains fail in Kathiawar this time also, the outlook must bevery serious.
('3', 1, 1, 19, 2839) I am afraid the joshis 1 and other weather prophets are good only for evil reports.

('3', 2, 1, 2, 3065) 3. LETTER TO D. B. SHUKLA
('3', 2, 2, 3, 3091) AGAKHAN’S BUILDINGS, OPPOSITE HIGH COURT, BOMBAY, November 3, 1902
('3', 2, 3, 4, 3158) MY DEAR SHUKLA, I have your letter.
('3', 2, 3, 5, 3194) Yes, I received a cablegram from Natal asking me if I could go to London and thence to the Transvaal.
('3', 2, 3, 6, 3296) I replied saying no unless it was absolutely necessary.
('3', 2, 3, 7, 3352) Just then my children were ill and in any case I do not yet feel strong enough for the mental strain a visit to London and South Africa would require.
('3', 2, 3, 8, 3503) I have not yet heard in reply to the cable from me.
('3', 2, 3, 9, 3555) I cannot yet say, I have begun to feel my way about here.
('3', 2, 3, 10, 3613) I am not, however, anxious about the future.
('3', 2, 3, 11, 3658) So far the office work has paid my expenses which I see will reach a higher figure than we thought there.
('3', 2, 3, 12, 3764) I am very glad you have been retained for the prosecution in the Najawala case.
('3', 2, 3, 13, 3844) For more reasons than one, I hope you will succeed in securing a conviction.
('3', 2, 3, 14, 3921) I do not know whether letter heads for a Barrister are in good taste.
('3', 2, 3, 15, 3991) Whether they are or not, mine are a present from Durban and I have been using them though not yet for office work.
('3', 2, 3, 16, 4106) The Plague must have changed the face of Rajkot.
('3', 2, 3, 17, 4155) I hope it is now on the wane.
('3', 2, 4, 18, 4185) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('3', 2, 5, 19, 4215) From the photostat of the original: G.N. 2329.
('3', 3, 0, 1, 4262) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 3, 1, 2, 4302) 4. LETTER TO D. B. SHUKLA
('3', 3, 2, 3, 4328) AGAKHAN’S BUILDINGS, OPPOSITE HIGH COURT, BOMBAY, November 8, 1902
('3', 3, 3, 4, 4395) MY DEAR SHUKLA,
('3', 3, 4, 5, 4411) I have received a message 1 with funds requesting me to sail for Natal at once.
('3', 3, 4, 6, 4491) As I have not left in me sufficient energy to cope with the difficulties there, I have asked certain questions before deciding to leave, so that my way may be Rs smooth as possible under the circumstances, so far at any rate as the internal management is concerned.
('3', 3, 4, 7, 4757) 99 chances to 1, I will have to leave and that too on the 19th instant.
('3', 3, 4, 8, 4829) This therefore may be my last letter to you in India.
('3', 3, 4, 9, 4883) I have not the time to write to Devchand Parekh separately; kindly therefore show this to him.
('3', 3, 4, 10, 4978) If he is ready to go, or if Vanichand, of whom he talked to me, is ready to go, I shall be prepared to do all I can.
('3', 3, 4, 11, 5095) South Africa can accommodate 6 Indian Barristers, if not more, and if some, of course of the right stamp, were to come with one eye on their living and the other on public work, much of the burden may be distributed —not to speak of the relief in the pressure here.
('3', 3, 4, 12, 5361) I am corresponding with another party too.
('3', 3, 4, 13, 5404) Now for self; whether Mrs. Gandhi accompanies me or not will be decided after I receive the reply from Durban.
('3', 3, 4, 14, 5515) But whether; she does or not, I propose to leave the two boys Gokaldas and Harilal here.
('3', 3, 4, 15, 5604) They would go to Rajkot as soon as it is free from plague.
('3', 3, 4, 16, 5663) Benares I have tried but it would not suit.
('3', 3, 4, 17, 5707) Gondal has no special attractions.
('3', 3, 4, 18, 5742) The best thing therefore to do is to put them in the Kattywar High School and to keep a trustworthy, paid man who would look after their education.
('3', 3, 4, 19, 5890) All I have to say to you, then is, please look after the boys, look them up now and then, induce them, if you have no objection, to use your tennis court.
('3', 3, 4, 20, 6045) I might have also to trouble you to find out the right man for them if I fail in doing so myself.
('3', 3, 5, 21, 6143) 1 The following cable had been sent to him from Durban: “Barrister Gandhi, Rajkot.
('3', 3, 5, 22, 6226) Committee requests fulfil promise.
('3', 3, 5, 23, 6261) Remitting.” (S. N. 4013).
('3', 4, 0, 1, 6287) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 5
('3', 4, 1, 2, 6326) How is the plague going on there now?
('3', 4, 2, 3, 6364) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('3', 4, 3, 4, 6394) From the photostat of the original: G.N. 2330.
('3', 4, 4, 5, 6441) 5. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE
('3', 4, 5, 6, 6468) OPPOSITE HIGH COURT, BOMBAY, November 14, 1902
('3', 4, 6, 7, 6515) DEAR PROF.
('3', 4, 6, 8, 6526) GOKHALE, When I was just feeling that I had settled down in Bombay, I received a message from Natal asking me immediately to go there.
('3', 4, 6, 9, 6661) From the cablegrams exchanged between our people in Natal and my self, I think it is in connection with Mr. Chamberlain’s approaching visit to South Africa that I am required there.
('3', 4, 6, 10, 6843) I propose to leave by the first steamer available.
('3', 4, 6, 11, 6894) That would be probably the 20th instant.
('3', 4, 6, 12, 6935) I wish I could meet you before my departure.
('3', 4, 6, 13, 6980) But that seems impossible.
('3', 4, 6, 14, 7007) I hope you will keep an eye on the Indian question in South Africa.
('3', 4, 6, 15, 7075) So long as I am there, I would deem it my duty to keep you informed of the position.
('3', 4, 6, 16, 7160) I consider Lord George Hamilton’s reply to be rather hopeful.
('3', 4, 6, 17, 7222) And if the movement in India were well directed, I feel sure that much good will be done to the cause.
('3', 4, 6, 18, 7325) I hope you are keeping good health.
('3', 4, 6, 19, 7361) Mr. Wachha told me sometime ago that you were going to Mahabaleshwar for a change.
('3', 4, 7, 20, 7444) I remain, yrs truly, M. K. GANDHI
('3', 4, 8, 21, 7478) From the photostat of the original: G.N. 2245.

('3', 5, 2, 4, 7632) 182, CONGRESS HALL, DURBAN, December 25, 1902
('3', 5, 3, 5, 7678) DEAR MR. MAYOR, There is an insuperable difficulty in the way of the Indian deputation waiting on the Right Hon.
('3', 5, 3, 6, 7791) Mr. Chamberlain tomorrow, as it is a Friday, and as it is just the very time for prayer which most of the gentlemen, who are to form the deputation, would be quite unable to forgo.
('3', 5, 3, 7, 7972) Under the circumstances, I shall be very much obliged if you will be good enough to fix some time on Saturday for the Indian deputation.

('3', 5, 6, 10, 8195) 7. PETITION TO CHAMBERLAIN 1
('3', 5, 7, 11, 8224) DURBAN, December 27, 1902
('3', 5, 8, 12, 8250) TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN HIS MAJESTY’S PRINCIPAL SECRETARY OF STATE FOR THE COLONIES DURBAN
('3', 5, 9, 13, 8360) RIGHT HONOURABLE SIR, We, the undersigned, representing and on behalf of the British Indians residing in the Colony of Natal, respectfully venture to draw your attention to the following statement of the legal disabilities under which Indian subjects of His Most Gracious Majesty the King Emperor are labouring.
('3', 5, 9, 14, 8672) The Dealers’ Licenses Act, which was promulgated on the 29th
('3', 5, 10, 15, 8733) 1 The petition was presented by the deputation of Natal Indians which waited on the Secretary of State for the Colonies during his visit to Durban.
('3', 5, 10, 16, 8881) Gandhiji led the deputation.
('3', 6, 0, 1, 8910) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 7
('3', 6, 1, 2, 8949) day of May, 1897, giving as it does practically absolute power to the Licensing Officer appointed thereunder to grant or refuse applications for licenses to shopkeepers or hawkers, is an engine of very great oppression, and affects a large body of the most respectable and the wealthiest portion of the Indian community in the Colony.
('3', 6, 1, 3, 9284) There is a right of appeal against the decisions of the Licensing Officers to the local Corporations, Boards or Licensing Boards, as the case may be.
('3', 6, 1, 4, 9434) It deprives the Supreme Court of its inherent jurisdiction over the judgment of these popular bodies in this matter, and we need hardly point out how popular bodies at times abuse powers vested in them.
('3', 6, 1, 5, 9637) In course of our previous representations on the subject, we had the honour to draw your attention to cases of real hardship caused by the operation of the Act.
('3', 6, 1, 6, 9798) Indirectly, it checks a great amount of Indian enterprise, the poorest trader not even venturing to make an application for a license, and all Indian traders remaining under suspense from year’s end to year’s end, for these licenses have to be renewed every year, and are liable under the Act to be refused any year.
('3', 6, 1, 7, 10115) In response, we believe, to a representation from you to the Natal Government when most Local Boards threatened to wipe out Indian traders wholesale, one Corporation at first refusing all Indian applications, the Natal Government wrote to them saying that, unless they exercised the arbitrary power given by the law to them in a judicial and fair manner, it might have to be revoked.
('3', 6, 1, 8, 10499) Since then, we must confess, as a rule, the old licenses have not been touched; but it is a law that may involve at any time many an Indian merchant in ruin, and so long as it remains unmodified, it is difficult for us to be at ease.
('3', 6, 1, 9, 10733) We would venture to quote an instance of gross injustice committed under it.
('3', 6, 1, 10, 10810) One Mr. Amod Ebrahim, who is able to read, write and speak the English language fluently, a merchant of 17 years’ standing in the Colony, held a trading license for over six years in Greytown.
('3', 6, 1, 11, 11003) This year, his application, although backed by 138 residents for the transfer of his license from an old building to a new and more suitable one, has been refused without any reasons being given therefor.
('3', 6, 1, 12, 11208) The Greytown Board passed last year the following resolution in respect of the Indian merchants there:
('3', 6, 2, 13, 11311) That the licenses held by the present Arabs, at the pleasure of the Board, will
('3', 6, 3, 14, 11391) only be renewed as long as the Arabs hold same, but no fresh licenses will be
('3', 6, 4, 15, 11469) issued for other Arab tenants for vacated premises.
('3', 6, 4, 16, 11521) The same merchant has also been refused a license in respect of
('3', 7, 0, 1, 11585) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 7, 1, 2, 11625) his own land in Greytown.
('3', 7, 1, 3, 11651) The matter was brought before His Excellency the Governor, who has declined to interfere.
('3', 7, 1, 4, 11741) All that we ask for is a restoration to the Supreme Court of its jurisdiction over the decisions of the bodies above mentioned, who, very often, being traders, are interested parties.
('3', 7, 1, 5, 11925) We have exhausted every means in our power, having gone as far as the Privy Council which has decided that, under the Act, the Supreme Court is powerless to grant substantial relief.
('3', 7, 1, 6, 12108) We think the Indian community, as has often been acknowledged by the Licensing Officer in Durban, as well as the Sanitary Inspector, is always ready to comply with the sanitary requirements of the law, and we fee] it very keenly that, even when all these have been fulfilled, we may not get licenses to trade merely because of the colour of our skin.
('3', 7, 1, 7, 12459) The Immigration Restriction Act, which was promulgated on the 8th day of May, 1897, directly affects many British Indians intending to emigrate to the Colony and indirectly affects those already settled in it.
('3', 7, 1, 8, 12669) The clause which tells rather hardly on intending settlers is one imposing the education test whereby a knowledge of one of the European languages is insisted upon.
('3', 7, 1, 9, 12834) A merchant, well versed in an Indian language, would, under the laws, be a prohibited immigrant.
('3', 7, 1, 10, 12931) Where, however, it becomes most irksome is when the settlers in the Colony intend to bring out storemen, salesmen, assistants, clerks, cooks and other domestic servants.
('3', 7, 1, 11, 13101) It is not always possible to draw upon the men previously domiciled in the Colony, who under the law are free to enter it whether they have a knowledge of the English language or not.
('3', 7, 1, 12, 13285) Applications have often been made to the Natal Government to allow facilities for admitting such persons for local requirements, but they have been invariably refused, with very rare exceptions.
('3', 7, 1, 13, 13480) Moreover, a person domiciled in the Colony is unable to have his parents or his other relations with him, except his wife and minor: children, although they may be dependent upon him.
('3', 7, 1, 14, 13664) The possibilities for grave mischief under the law are very numerous.
('3', 7, 1, 15, 13734) To take only one instance: during the war, hundreds of Indian refugees from the Transvaal found themselves unable even to pass through the Colony, unless they could deposit £10 each.
('3', 7, 1, 16, 13917) The matter became very serious.
('3', 7, 1, 17, 13949) The Government were twice approached.
('3', 7, 1, 18, 13987) But it was only when His Excellency the High Commissioner intervened that permission was granted to these refugees to pass through the Colony.
('3', 7, 1, 19, 14130) That British subjects, neither criminals nor paupers, should find it difficult to enter
('3', 8, 0, 1, 14218) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 9
('3', 8, 1, 2, 14257) any part of His Majesty’s dominions is a thing very difficult to understand.
('3', 8, 1, 3, 14334) The question of Indian education is becoming day by day more serious.
('3', 8, 1, 4, 14404) At the same time, we are not blind to the fact that the Government have to contend against great popular prejudice.
('3', 8, 1, 5, 14520) Be that, however, as it may, it is respectfully submitted that the Indian popu lation in the Colony, which contributes its quota to its general revenue, is fairly entitled to reasonable facilities for educating the Indian youths who are born in Natal, and to whom Natal is their only home.
('3', 8, 1, 6, 14810) Gentlemen occupying responsible positions under the Government, living entirely in the European style, as many Indian youths having English as their mother tongue, were debarred, in spite of re presentations to the highest authorities, from sending their children to the ordinary Government schools.
('3', 8, 1, 7, 15110) Government have been pleased lately to open two Higher Grade Indian schools, one in Durban and the other in Maritzburg, where elementary education is being given, but there are no facilities, after an Indian boy leaves these schools for further education.
('3', 8, 1, 8, 15366) That the indentured Indians, upon whom depends the prosperity of this Colony, after the completion of their indentures, have to pay a polltax of three pounds sterling every year, if they decide to remain in the Colony, is, in our humble opinion and as has been admitted by His Excellency Lord Elgin, bad enough.
('3', 8, 1, 9, 15678) But now a Bill has passed through the Natal Parliament imposing the tax on their children above the age of thirteen years in the case of girls and sixteen years in the case of boys.
('3', 8, 1, 10, 15860) That Bill is now before you for consideration.
('3', 8, 1, 11, 15907) All that could be said on it has been said in our memorial laid before you thereon, and seeing that it is so manifestly against British traditions, we feel confident that it will not receive the Royal assent.
('3', 8, 1, 12, 16116) There are other disabilities of perhaps minor importance which we do not propose to dwell upon: for instance, the vexatious Pass Restrictions, both during day time and night time, and alike in country places as in towns.
('3', 8, 1, 13, 16337) We recognise that so long as there is indentured Indian population in the Colony, some Pass law is necessary, and the remedy probably lies in the judicious administration thereof.
('3', 8, 1, 14, 16517) Respec table people, men and women, were only’ lately arrested under the suspicion that they were indentured Indians; one man was out in search for a doctor for his wife who was in labour.
('3', 8, 1, 15, 16706) Bail was refused for them.
('3', 8, 1, 16, 16733) The matter was duly brought before the Government, who
('3', 9, 0, 1, 16788) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 9, 1, 2, 16829) advised legal steps!
('3', 9, 1, 3, 16850) We are engaged in an incessant struggle for existence in the Colony.
('3', 9, 1, 4, 16919) We never know when the finality in the list of our disabilities will be reached.
('3', 9, 1, 5, 17000) There is a serious talk about compelling the time expired indentured Indians to return to India, and about pre venting the Indian residents from buying land.
('3', 9, 1, 6, 17158) The Indian comm unity is practically without any political power, nor does it aspire to any.
('3', 9, 1, 7, 17251) When years ago we protested against disfranchisement, we did so because of the degradation it involved, and because it was admittedly an earnest of anti Indian legislation which was to follow.
('3', 9, 1, 8, 17444) The Honou rable Sir John Robinson, at the time of introducing the disfranchising measure, in reply to the fear above referred to, said that no such fear was to be entertained as, after disfranchisement, it would be the special duty of the Legislature to look after the interests of the disfranchised.
('3', 9, 1, 9, 17745) The disabilities narrated above show how unavailing the Honourable Gentleman’s assurances have been.
('3', 9, 1, 10, 17846) The colour prejudice born of unreasonable fear of trade competition has been too strong.
('3', 9, 1, 11, 17935) The first two enactments have received the Royal assent, but we trust it will not on that account appear out of place for us to refer to them, seeing that they are a source of constant irritation to us.
('3', 9, 1, 12, 18138) Nor are we unaware of the slightness of the check that is exercised by the Home Government on the Self governing Colonies.
('3', 9, 1, 13, 18261) But we venture to trust that the question now brought before you is of such importance as to belong to the category of those which call for the exercise of whatever power the Home Government may possess over the Self governing Colonies.
('3', 9, 1, 14, 18498) Ours is not, after all, a question that affects only a few thousand Indians but it is that of the status of His Majesty’s Indian subjects.
('3', 9, 1, 15, 18637) In the words of the late Sir W. W. Hunter [writing in the London Times]:
('3', 9, 2, 16, 18710) May the British Indians, when they leave India, have the same status before the law as other British subjects enjoy?
('3', 9, 2, 17, 18827) May they, or may they not, go freely from one British possession to another, and claim the rights of British subjects in allied States?
('3', 9, 3, 18, 18963) Regarding Natal, Lord Ripon assured us in one of his despatches that:
('3', 9, 4, 19, 19033) It is the desire of Her Majesty’s Government that the Queen’s Indian subjects should be treated upon a footing of equality with all Her Majesty’s other subjects.
('3', 10, 0, 1, 19195) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 11
('3', 10, 1, 2, 19235) Locally, we have been doing our utmost to deserve a better treatment, as we doubt not the Ministers will inform you.
('3', 10, 1, 3, 19352) The Protector of Indian Immigrants, although he deals only with the lowest, or rather, the poorest, of our countrymen, in his last Report says:
('3', 10, 2, 4, 19496) On the whole, the Indian immigrants resident in this Colony, I am happy to say, still form an orderly, law abiding and respectable element of the community, and may be considered as generally prosperous.
('3', 10, 2, 5, 19700) We need hardly add more.
('3', 10, 2, 6, 19725) We know we have your sympathy, and we pray that you will be graciously pleased to exercise your great influence in our behalf.
('3', 10, 3, 7, 19852) We have the honour to remain,
('3', 10, 4, 8, 19882) Your most obedient and humble servants, M. K. GANDHI
('3', 10, 5, 9, 19935) AND FIFTEEN OTHERS
('3', 10, 6, 10, 19954) Colonial Office Records: Petitions and Memorials, 1902, C.O. 529/1.
('3', 10, 7, 11, 20022) 8. LETTER TO COLONIAL.
('3', 10, 7, 12, 20045) SECRETARY
('3', 10, 8, 13, 20055) 338, PRINSLOO STREET, PRETORIA, January 2, 1903
('3', 10, 9, 14, 20103) TO THE HONOURABLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA
('3', 10, 10, 15, 20153) SIR, It is the wish of the British Indian community in the Transvaal to lay before the Right Honourable Mr. Joseph Chamberlain its views on the legal disabilities it is labouring under in the Colony as well as the Orange River Colony.
('3', 10, 10, 16, 20388) I have the honour on behalf of the community to enquire whether the Right Honourable Gentleman will be pleased to receive a deputation in the matter and, if so, when.
('3', 10, 10, 17, 20555) From 1894 to the middle of 1901, my countrymen here have been guided by the advice of Mr. Advocate M. K. Gandhi by whom were also prepared most of the representations submitted to the Colonial Office during that time.
('3', 10, 10, 18, 20773) The Honourable the Assistant Colonial Secretary, on whom I
('3', 11, 0, 1, 20832) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 11, 1, 2, 20873) and our secretary, Mr. Hajee Habib, waited this morning, as also did Mr. Gandhi, says that he (Mr. Gandhi) not being a resident of the Transvaal will not be allowed to represent us before Mr. Chamberlain.
('3', 11, 1, 3, 21078) But as we have not among us one who has studied and knows anti Indian laws of the late Republic as Mr. Gandhi has and does, and as he has been specially sent for from Bombay, I am to beg respectfully to ask for permission for Mr. Gandhi to accompany the deputation above referred to if the Right Honourable Gentleman graciously consents to receive it.
('3', 11, 2, 4, 21430) I have the honour to remain, Sir, your most obedient servant, TAYOB HAJEE KHAN MAHOMED
('3', 11, 3, 5, 21517) From the photostat of the office copy: S.N. 4023.
('3', 11, 4, 6, 21567) 9. LETTER TO THE TRANSVAAL GOVERNOR
('3', 11, 5, 7, 21603) CALCUTTA HOUSE, PRETORIA, January 6, 1903
('3', 11, 6, 8, 21645) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE GOVERNOR PRETORIA
('3', 11, 7, 9, 21710) SIR, I had the honour on the 2nd inst., as Chairman of the British India Committee, to write to the Honourable Colonial Secretary enquiring whether the Right Honourable Mr. Joseph Chamberlain would graciously receive a British Indian deputation in connection with the disabilities of my countrymen residing in the Colony, and protesting against the refusal of the Assistant Colonial Secretary to allow Mr. Advocate M. K. Gandhi to be the spokesman of the deputation.

('3', 11, 7, 12, 22392) I have the honour now to repeat the request for permission for Mr. Gandhi to be our spokesman.
('3', 11, 7, 13, 22487) The refusal seems to my

('3', 12, 1, 3, 22671) As His Excellency is probably aware, Mr. Gandhi has been hitherto allowed to represent the British Indians here before British officers; as, for instance, he represented us on several occasions before His Honour the British Agent at Pretoria, as well as the British Vice Consul at Johannesburg, before the war broke out.
('3', 12, 1, 4, 22992) Hostile as the late Republican Government was to our interests, he was moreover allowed to represent us before its members.
('3', 12, 1, 5, 23116) My Committee also desires me to enter its respectful protest against the Supervisor of Asiatics being imposed upon us as our interpreter and spokesman.
('3', 12, 1, 6, 23268) We have always understood that the Right Honourable Gentleman’s wish is to receive deputations from representatives without any official restraint and the presence of that officer is hardly likely to carry it out.
('3', 12, 1, 7, 23482) I am to request you to place this communication before His Excellency, and I venture to trust that His Excellency will be pleased to give my Committee directions in the matter.

('3', 13, 0, 1, 24440) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 13, 1, 2, 24481) subjects of His Most Gracious Majesty the King Emperor, respectfully venture to draw your attention to the following statement of the legal disabilities under which our countrymen are labouring in the Colony.
('3', 13, 1, 3, 24690) According to the laws of the late Republic, the British Indians:.
('3', 13, 1, 4, 24756) (1) cannot own landed property.
('3', 13, 1, 5, 24788) except in Locations, (2) are bound to have their names entered in a separate register within eight days of their arrival and pay therefor the sum of £3, stg., (3) must trade and reside only in Locations, (4) cannot be out after 9 P.M., except on special permission, (5) cannot travel on the railways except third class, (6) cannot walk on the footpaths in Johannesburg and Pretoria, (7) cannot, in Johannesburg and Pretoria, drive in hire vehicles, (8) cannot own native gold or take out diggers’ licences.
('3', 13, 1, 6, 25295) Such, so far as we have been able to ascertain, is the anti Indian legislaton inherited by the Imperial Government from the late Republic and [it] remains still unrepealed.
('3', 13, 1, 7, 25468) Of these laws and bye laws, the curfew, the railway travelling, the footpath and the cab regulations, although they were strictly enforced soon after the war, have been latterly considerably relaxed; at the same time, so long as they remain unrepealed, they are apt, at any moment, to be enforced strictly and, in any case, put an unnecessary affront on the Indian community.
('3', 13, 1, 8, 25844) As is well known, the whole of the anti Indian legislation of the late Boer Government is due to their classing us with the natives of South Africa.
('3', 13, 1, 9, 25993) Soon after the passing of the London Convention, that Government interpreted the term “Natives of South Africa” to include British Indians.
('3', 13, 1, 10, 26133) Against such interpretation and the treatment based thereon, there was on the part of Her late Majesty’s Government, with one unfortunate vacillation arising from a mis understanding, a continued protest.
('3', 13, 1, 11, 26338) Then, what is more, there was the constant, wholesome fear of the intervention of the British Government in our behalf.
('3', 13, 1, 12, 26458) The result was that, although the principal law against us was passed in 1885, and although we had to remain in a state of great suspense and uncertainty, most of us were able to ward off the final blow.
('3', 13, 1, 13, 26662) But, now, the laws stand without such consoling circumstances surrounding them.
('3', 13, 1, 14, 26742) The sole duty of the Asiatic Department is to enforce the laws
('3', 14, 0, 1, 26805) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 15
('3', 14, 1, 2, 26845) affecting us, and to say who shall receive the permits to enter the Colony.
('3', 14, 1, 3, 26921) While, therefore, the Europeans, whether British subjects or otherwise, get permits practically for the asking, the Indian refugees have to apply to the Supervisor of Asiatics who decides whether he would allow the Permit Officer at the Cape, Natal, or Delagoa Bay, as the case may be, to issue particular permits or not.
('3', 14, 1, 4, 27243) And, as if this were not enough, the Indian refugees after their arrival are expected to take out what are called residential passes, although these are now no longer necessary for the rest of the inhabitants.
('3', 14, 1, 5, 27453) Whereas, under the lax Boer Administration, many Indians traded without paying for their licences with full knowledge of the authorities, under the vigilant British Administration such a thing is naturally impossible.
('3', 14, 1, 6, 27671) You, Sir, when appealed to in our behalf, were pleased to say that, although our complaint was admittedly just and that we had your sympathy, you were then powerless to do anything further than making friendly representations to the late South African Republic.
('3', 14, 1, 7, 27933) Moreover, when war came, it was declared officially that the disabilities of the British Indians were one of its causes.
('3', 14, 1, 8, 28054) With the end of the war, therefore, we thought that our difficulties would be over.
('3', 14, 1, 9, 28138) But, so far, unfortunately, the hope has not been realized.
('3', 14, 1, 10, 28198) The laws above referred to, which are manifestly un British, are now, as a rule, being enforced with British regularity.
('3', 14, 1, 11, 28319) The curfew and the other laws which have been relaxed were never rigidly enforced even under the old regime.
('3', 14, 1, 12, 28428) There has been established what is known as the Department of Asiatic Affairs which, however well intentioned its institution may have been, has been, in practice, an innovation on the old system very much to our disadvantage.
('3', 14, 1, 13, 28655) When it was inaugurated, we respectfully protested; but it was understood that it was only a temporary department, to be withdrawn on regular business being resumed.
('3', 14, 1, 14, 28821) Under the old regime, there was no separate department with only Indian matters to attend to.
('3', 14, 1, 15, 28915) There are now, therefore, fewer Indian merchants and storekeepers than before, and the tendency is towards greater strictness.
('3', 14, 1, 16, 29042) Some licences were issued at the commencement of the British occupation to those who did not hold the same before the war.
('3', 14, 1, 17, 29165) The Government have notified their intention not to issue licences to such people.
('3', 14, 1, 18, 29248) Thus, many of us, who traded before the war without a
('3', 15, 0, 1, 29302) 16 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 15, 1, 2, 29343) licence and had licences issued to us last year, are new confronted with the prospect of our licences being stopped.
('3', 15, 1, 3, 29460) In Pietersburg, notice has already’ been issued to such holders that they would receive only temporary licences for three months to enable them to sell off their stock.
('3', 15, 1, 4, 29629) The resident Magistrate of Wakkerstroom has informed the Chamber of Commerce that the existing Indian licences will not be renewed this year.
('3', 15, 1, 5, 29771) Our proper course, we know, is, in such matters, to approach the higher authorities here before appealing to you.
('3', 15, 1, 6, 29885) We men tion them only to show how we are at present worse off than before and that it is an incident of the separate administration of Asiatic Affairs, which, moreover, tends to accentuate the distinction between classes.
('3', 15, 1, 7, 30107) To show further how our position is for the time being worse than before, it may be stated that the children of a Government Offi cer,who were allowed under the Boer regime to attend an ordinary Eu ropean school, have been, after British occupation, removed from it.
('3', 15, 1, 8, 30374) Just before the outbreak of the war, the Boer Government were trying to remove the present Indian Location at Johannesburg to a place far away from town.
('3', 15, 1, 9, 30528) A protest was lodged.
('3', 15, 1, 10, 30550) 1 Mr. Evans, the then Vice Consul, intervened on our behalf, and the matter was allowed to remain in abeyance.
('3', 15, 1, 11, 30661) Now, however, it has progressed far enough to fill its residents with alarm.
('3', 15, 1, 12, 30738) We know that the present medical officer has condemned it in unmeasured terms.
('3', 15, 1, 13, 30817) But, if it is in an insanitary condition, from what he states, apparently the fault is not one fourth that of the residents.
('3', 15, 1, 14, 30942) Its requirements were neglected under the Boer regime.
('3', 15, 1, 15, 30997) The charge of insanitation against the Indian community has been fully discussed and, we hope, thoroughly refuted in our previous memorials.
('3', 15, 1, 16, 31138) 2 We venture to quote below two medical certificates by practitioners of standing.
('3', 15, 1, 17, 31221) Dr. H. Prior Veale, B.A., M. B. B. C. (Cantab), certifies as follows:
('3', 15, 2, 18, 31291) I have generally found them (Indians) cleanly in their persons and free from the personal diseases due to dirt and careless habits.
('3', 15, 2, 19, 31423) Their dwellings are generally clean and sanitation is willingly attended to by them.
('3', 15, 2, 20, 31508) Class considered, I should be of opinion that the lowest class Indian compares most
('3', 15, 3, 21, 31592) 1Vide “Letter to British Agent”, July 21, 1899. 2Vide “ Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies” 15 3 1897
('3', 16, 0, 1, 31707) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 17
('3', 16, 1, 2, 31747) favourably with the lowest class white, that is, the lowest class Indian lives better and in better habitation and with more regard to sanitary measures thanthe lowest class white.
('3', 16, 1, 3, 31928) I have further found that, during the period that small pox was epidemic in the town and district, and it is still epidemic in the district, although every nation nearly had one or more of its members at some time in the Lazaretto, there was not a single Indian attacked.
('3', 16, 1, 4, 32200) Generally, in my opinion, it is impossible to object to the Indian on sanitary grounds, provided always, the inspection of the sanitary authorities is made as strictly and regularly for the Indian as for the white.
('3', 16, 1, 5, 32415) Dr. F. P. Marais, M. D. (Edin), certifies:
('3', 16, 2, 6, 32458) Having a very extensive practice among these people, I can speak from personal experience, and repeat that they are more cleanly than the poor whites, and if the coloured people were to be moved on account of want of cleanliness, then some of the poor whites will have to suffer the same fate.
('3', 16, 2, 7, 32752) But we need not labour the point any further, in view of the fact that you were pleased, in reply to our memorial, to declare yourself satisfied that restrictions on our liberty were an outcome of trade jealousy.
('3', 16, 2, 8, 32965) Nor, perhaps, is it necessary for us to refer to the White Leagues that have been formed in some parts of the Colony.
('3', 16, 2, 9, 33083) It is a strange irony of fate that, when the famous Uitlander petition was sent to the Home Government, we were invited as brethren to join in protest against the Boer misrule and were told how our disabilities were sure to be removed as soon as the Imperial rule was established.
('3', 16, 2, 10, 33364) Now, these gentlemen are passing resolutions asking the Imperial Government to keep the very disabilities afoot.
('3', 16, 2, 11, 33477) If it is permissible to refer to the anti Indian legislation in the Orange River Colony, we beg to summarize it below.
('3', 16, 2, 12, 33596) Chapter 33 of 1890 prevents any Asiatics from: (1) remaining in the state for more than two months without permission from the President, (2) owning landed property, (3) trading or farming, and Chapter 10 levies a poll tax of 10 shillings per year when permission has been granted subject to the restrictions above named.
('3', 16, 2, 13, 33918) Out of the many Indian traders who were settled there, three who struggled for existence up to the last moment were by the late Government expelled from the country under the ordinance referred to, at a loss to them of over nine thousand pounds.
('3', 17, 0, 1, 34164) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 17, 1, 2, 34205) Amid all these difficulties, we have been able to derive consolation from the fact that they have engaged the close and sympathetic attention of yourself and His Excellency the High Commissioner.
('3', 17, 1, 3, 34401) His Majesty the King Emperor, according to the newspaper reports, in his message to the people of India at the great Delhi Durbar renews his assurance of his regard for their liberties, rights and welfare.
('3', 17, 1, 4, 34607) And now, Sir, that you have come to study the Indian Question among many others in the new Colonies, may we hope that, in the near future, the gracious assurance will be translated into an act of freedom for us, in common with other British subjects, to earn ourlivelihood in the new Colonies without being subjected to the indignities and restraints such as have been above described.
('3', 17, 2, 5, 34993) We have the honour to remain,
('3', 17, 4, 6, 35023) your most obedient and humble servants

('3', 17, 6, 8, 35137) 11. PETITION TO LORD CURZON
('3', 17, 7, 9, 35165) DURBAN, NATAL, January [?], 1903 1
('3', 17, 8, 10, 35200) TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE RIGHT HONOURABLE THE LORD CURZON, OF KEDLESTON, P.C., G.M.S.I., G.M.I.E., &C., &C., VICEROY AND GOVERNOR GENERAL OF INDIA, CALCUTTA
('3', 17, 9, 11, 35354) THE HUMBLE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED, REPRESENTING THE BRITISH INDIAN COMMUNITY RESIDING IN THE COLONY OF NATAL
('3', 17, 10, 12, 35468) RESPECTFULLY SHOWETH THAT: Your Excellency’s petitioners hereby beg to approach Your Excellency with reference to a Commission that has just set out from Natal With a view to induce the Government of India to sanction the compulsory return of the indentured Indians who go to Natal after the expiry of their indentures.
('3', 17, 11, 13, 35788) 1 The original did not specify the date.
('3', 18, 0, 1, 35829) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 19
('3', 18, 1, 2, 35869) Your Petitioners draw Your Excellency’s attention to the fact that, in 1894, the Natal Government deputed two gentlemen to confer With the Indian Government with the same object in view, and they su cceeded in persuading your predecessor, much against his will, to approve of a condition in the contracts of indentured Indians whereby they undertake, during their stay in the Colony, to continue to serve under indentures, or to return to India, or to pay an annual Poll tax of £3. The Commissioners, after their return to Natal, reported that though the Government of India had not accepted the proposal for compulsory return, their mission might be regarded as successful in that “so far, no second term of indenture has been agreed to in the case of any country to which coolies emigrated, although the consent of the Government of India had been frequently asked for, and in no case had the condition of compulsory return at the end of the indenture been sanctioned.” Seeing, therefore, that the Government of India went as far as it did in 1894, with so much reluctance, your petitioners have every confidence that the Commission that has proceeded to India this year will not receive countenance tom Your Excellency.
('3', 18, 1, 3, 37092) Your Petitioners will, however, crave leave to take a brief survey of the situation in Natal and contemplate the results of the drastic pro posals about to be submitted to Your Excellency by the Commission.
('3', 18, 1, 4, 37299) The last Report of the Protector of Indian Immigrants em phasises the fact that the demand for Indian labour is day by day increasing.
('3', 18, 1, 5, 37434) Mr. T. L. Hyslop, President of a Farmers’ Association in Natal, in his annual address last year, is reported to have said as follows:
('3', 18, 2, 6, 37568) We at times hear a great outcry against the introduction of Indians into the Colony.
('3', 18, 2, 7, 37653) We may as well look the fact in the face that, however much we would like to do without the coolie, any attempt to stop his introduction here would paralyse every industry in the country.
('3', 18, 2, 8, 37841) There is much talk amongst badly informed people that we should do this, that, and the other thing with the Indians, but there is no use blinking the fact that we are very much in the hands of the Indian Government in regard to this question.
('3', 18, 2, 9, 38084) I believe it is a fact that recent legislation in this Colony, and still more, ill advised speeches by some of our legislators, have occasioned considerable irritation in India, and it is useless for us to appeal for further concessions at present.
('3', 18, 2, 10, 38333) I understand that the proposal to have the indentures of Indians to terminate in India has no
('3', 19, 0, 1, 38427) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 19, 1, 2, 38468) chance of being listened to by the Indian Government.
('3', 19, 1, 3, 38522) The Natal Mercury, in a leader commenting on Mr. Hyslop’s speech, says:
('3', 19, 2, 4, 38594) The Indian Government have to consult the well being of the people under their care more than our convenience, and if crude legislation is passed by Parliament, and ill advised speeches are made by Members, we may find ourselves very seriously hampered in getting the labour we need from India.
('3', 19, 2, 5, 38889) At one time, it was only the sugar planter that made much use of the Indian labourer.
('3', 19, 2, 6, 38975) Now the up country farmer is quite as much in need of his services, and not only the farmer, but the mine owner, the contractor, the manufacturer and the merchant.
('3', 19, 2, 7, 39139) It is thus clear that the more thoughtful among the leaders of public opinion in Natal realise the unfairness of the proposal, and do not expect the Indian Government to countenance it.
('3', 19, 2, 8, 39325) But, were it otherwise, in your Petitioners’ humble opinion, there can be no two opinions about the Indian view of the question.
('3', 19, 2, 9, 39454) If the labourer is to be forced back to India, the very object with which the Emigration Act was passed in India would be frustrated.
('3', 19, 2, 10, 39588) It was for the protection and the benefit of the emigrants from India that it was passed, and not for the benefit of the Colonies.
('3', 19, 2, 11, 39719) As it is, in your Petitioners’ humble opinion, Natal already enjoys the most favourable terms.
('3', 19, 2, 12, 39814) It has more than a lion’s share in the partnership and now it wants to go many steps further.
('3', 19, 2, 13, 39908) The goal of its ambition is either “the coolie must remain under bondage in the Colony, or must return to India if he wants to remain free.” That in returning to India he might have, in the words of the late Mr. Saunders, a legislator of Natal, “to face starvation” is a matter of no consideration for the Colony.
('3', 19, 2, 14, 40222) The main argument used to justify the proposal of compulsory return is that there cannot be any hardship in the conditions of a contract a party willingly undertakes to perform.
('3', 19, 2, 15, 40400) The late Right Honourable Mr. Harry Escombe, sometime Prime Minister of Natal, in his evidence before a Commission appointed by the Natal Government, said as follows:
('3', 19, 3, 16, 40567) A man is brought here, in theory with his own consent, in practice very often without it.
('3', 19, 3, 17, 40657) He gives the best 5 years of his life, he forms new ties, forgets the old ones, and he cannot, according to my view: of right and wrong, be sent back.
('3', 19, 3, 18, 40808) The Indian Government by the very act of prohibiting the emi gration of such men, except under State supervision, have answered
('3', 20, 0, 1, 40936) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 21
('3', 20, 1, 2, 40976) the argument by implying that they are in a state of pupillage and, therefore, incapable of understanding their own interests.
('3', 20, 1, 3, 41103) Your Petitioners would respectfully refer Your Excellency to the petition addressed to your predecessor with reference to the sanction of a £3 Poll tax 1 hereinbefore referred to, wherein is collected evidence to show how the matter was exhaustively gone into, in 1887, by a Natal Commission, and how it reported against the proposal of compulsory return.
('3', 20, 1, 4, 41459) But, even if every one in Natal thought otherwise, your Petitioners venture to trust that Your Excellency will not allow Indian labour to be exploited for the one sided benefit of Natal.
('3', 20, 1, 5, 41646) Your Petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that if the Colony is not prepared to grant the indentured Indians the elementary rights of British citizenship, viz., freedom of settlement in the Colony, Your Excellency will be graciously pleased to advise the Colony to discontinue importing Indian labour.
('3', 20, 1, 6, 41947) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioners, as in duty bound, shall for ever pray, &c.
('3', 20, 2, 7, 42047) From the photostat of an original, printed copy: S.N. 4031.

('3', 21, 1, 3, 42902) From what Lord George Hamilton has said to you at the deputation, it is to be hoped that the Bill will be rejected.
('3', 21, 1, 4, 43018) He 1 seems to share the fear of the Colonists that, unless the immigration of free Indians is checked, and indentured Indians are driven back to India on the termination of their indentures, this sub continent will be swamped by the Indians.
('3', 21, 1, 5, 43260) In a way he seemed to justify the attitude of the Colonists.
('3', 21, 1, 6, 43321) I was present when he addressed the deputation in Durban.

('3', 21, 1, 9, 43657) Recently, the Natal Government has sent a commission to India to secure the termination of indentures in India, so that the indentured Indians may not have the opportunity of settling in Natal.
('3', 21, 1, 10, 43851) This, of course, would be the climax in injustice, if it is at all countenanced by Lord Curzon.
('3', 21, 1, 11, 43947) There is absolutely no precedent for it and it would be unadulterated slavery for a term of years.
('3', 21, 1, 12, 44046) That, after the preaching of Imperial patriotism by Mr. Chamberlain, Natal should still make an effort to exploit Indian labour for its sole benefit, in total disregard of reasonable principles of contract, passes comprehension, and shows that the Colony has not in the least degree changed its hostile attitude towards British Indians.
('3', 21, 1, 13, 44383) This is further confirmed by the fact that the Maritzburg Town Council is endeavouring to debar Indians from owning land.
('3', 21, 1, 14, 44505) The solution is simple and most effective, viz., prohibition of indentured emigration to Natal, as suggested by Lord George Hamilton.

('3', 22, 1, 2, 44766) 13. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('3', 22, 2, 3, 44798) JOHANNESBURG, Thursday, February 5, 1903
('3', 22, 3, 4, 44839) DEAR CHHAGANLAL, Though I am at the above mentioned place, write to me at Durban only.
('3', 22, 3, 5, 44926) Received your long letter.
('3', 22, 3, 6, 44953) Maganlal 1 and Anandlal 2 have opened a shop.
('3', 22, 3, 7, 44999) 3 So I do not think he 4 will come here.
('3', 22, 3, 8, 45040) I have written to himto come if he so desires.
('3', 22, 3, 9, 45087) There are good prospects of employment.
('3', 22, 3, 10, 45127) If ever I have to stay here, there is a good chance to secure him a job.
('3', 22, 3, 11, 45200) Even then I have left it to him.
('3', 22, 3, 12, 45233) He had a slight fever on board the ship.
('3', 22, 3, 13, 45274) But that was not a matter to be communicated to you.
('3', 22, 3, 14, 45327) There is a great uncertainty about me.
('3', 22, 3, 15, 45366) Despite my best efforts, I am not in a position to give you more satisfactory news.
('3', 22, 3, 16, 45450) If it is not possible to stay on here, I may leave in March.
('3', 22, 3, 17, 45511) If I have to stay on, it will be possible to bring you all after six months.
('3', 22, 3, 18, 45588) There is no chance of getting you here immediately; if it does not involve breach of duty, I shall make every possible effort to return home.
('3', 22, 3, 19, 45730) It’s no bed of roses here.
('3', 22, 3, 20, 45757) I cannot offer more definite news.
('3', 22, 3, 21, 45792) I shall wire if I am to come.
('3', 22, 3, 22, 45822) If my staying on is decided upon, even then I shall send a wire if only for the satisfaction of you all.
('3', 22, 3, 23, 45927) I do not mind [paying] Manilal’s fees, but he must be sent to learn instrumental music.

('3', 23, 3, 4, 46691) 14. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY
('3', 23, 4, 5, 46724) P. O. BOX 299, JOHANNESBURG, February 18, 1903
('3', 23, 5, 6, 46771) TO THE HONOURABLE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA
('3', 23, 6, 7, 46817) SIR, In accordance with the desire expressed by His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor 2 and yourself, I beg to record the Indian view of the proposed institution of Bazaars in the principal townships of the Colony.
('3', 23, 6, 8, 47033) Such an institution would, in my humble opinion, be acceptable to the Indian community provided that: 1. the Bazaar (or Bazaars) is situated within the town limits in a business portion usually frequented by all classes including Europeans; 2. there should be no legal obligation on the part of the Indian community to reside or trade in the Bazaar; 3. in any case, the Indian merchants and traders, at present residing and(or)trading in towns, and those who traded or re sided within town limits in any township in the Colony before the war, should not be expected to reside or trade in Bazaars; 4. the Indian community should be allowed to purchase Stands in any such Bazaars subject to the buyer’s acceptance of the Building and Sanitary Regulations that may be imposed by the Government.
('3', 23, 7, 9, 47825) 1 The reference is to the chambers rented by Gandhiji while he practised in Bombay.
('3', 23, 7, 10, 47909) 2 Gandhiji had interviewed the Lieutenant Governor.
('3', 24, 0, 1, 47961) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 25
('3', 24, 1, 2, 48001) If Bazaars are established on the above principle, I venture to think that the Indian community would respectfully co operate with the Government in making the institutions a success.
('3', 24, 1, 3, 48185) The drifting Indian population mentioned by His Excellency would gladly avail itself of cheap and comfortable dwellings that will naturally be erected in any such Bazaars.
('3', 24, 1, 4, 48357) If any further information, or my presence, is required, I shall be happy to supply it, or wait on you, as the case may be.
('3', 24, 2, 5, 48481) l have the honour to be,
('3', 24, 4, 6, 48506) your obedient servant, M K. GANDHI
('3', 24, 5, 7, 48541) Pretoria Archives: File Lt.
('3', 24, 6, 8, 48569) 15. THE INDIAN QUESTION 1
('3', 24, 7, 9, 48595) BOX 299, JOHANNESBURG, February 23, 1903
('3', 24, 8, 10, 48636) A SHORT STATEMENT OF THE INDIAN QUESTION IN THE TRANSVAAL AND THE ORANGE RIVER COLONIES
('3', 24, 9, 11, 48724) Mr. Chamberlain will probably sail for England this week, but the position of the Indians remains unchanged.
('3', 24, 9, 12, 48833) A small deputation waitedon His Excellency the Lieutenant Gov ernor of the Transvaal 2 and he said the whole question will be consider ed en bloc when the enlarged Legislative Council was formed.
('3', 24, 9, 13, 49029) He was very courteous.
('3', 24, 9, 14, 49052) Mr. Chamberlain is said to have told an anti Indian deputation that it was a question which will have to be submitted to the Cabinet at Home when it will be finally decided.
('3', 24, 9, 15, 49226) Putting together this reply and His Excellency’s reply above quoted, it would appear that Mr. Chamberlain, after consultation with the Home Government, would cable here a scheme of legislation which would be submitted to the Legislative Council.
('3', 24, 9, 16, 49472) Against such
('3', 24, 10, 17, 49485) 1 The statement was sent to Dadabhai Naoroji, who forwarded it to the Secretary of State for India; a copy sent to Sir William Wedderburn was forwarded by him to the Viceroy of India.
('3', 24, 10, 18, 49669) 2Vide “Letter to Colonial Secretary”, February 18, 1903.
('3', 25, 0, 1, 49726) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 25, 1, 2, 49767) legislation, after it is passed, there would be practically no appeal, if it is found to be against Indian interests.
('3', 25, 1, 3, 49885) Hence the great need for concentration of efforts upon the proposed legislation in the new Colonies.
('3', 25, 1, 4, 49986) What the anti Indian legislation is has been clearly set forth in the statement placed before Mr. Chamberlain, 1 copies of which have already been forwarded to the friends in England.
('3', 25, 1, 5, 50170) From one responsible source comes the information that the Government, being over anxious to please the Colonists, are going to sell the Indians and propose legislation that would go further than the Cape and Natal, even Australia.
('3', 25, 1, 6, 50402) From another equally responsible source comes the information that the legislation will be adopted on the Natal lines of anti Asiatic legislation.
('3', 25, 1, 7, 50549) Mr. Chamberlain said to the Indian deputation somewhat as follows: “What is the use of my passing such legislation now as would be repealed on my granting responsible Government in two or three years?
('3', 25, 1, 8, 50750) You must, therefore, try to conciliate public opinion and work with the authorities in the Transvaal.” He is said to have told the anti Indian deputation “Indians are our fellow subjects, and are entitled to fair and honourable treatment.
('3', 25, 1, 9, 50989) At the same time, I would be prepared to sympathise with you in your opposition to unrestricted influx of millions from India who may easily swamp you.
('3', 25, 1, 10, 51141) I would, therefore, recommend restriction on further immigration in undue numbers, but cannot undertake to place disabilities on those that are already settled in the Colony.” If Mr. Chamberlain has spoken to the anti Indian deputation in the above terms, it is very satisfactory.
('3', 25, 1, 11, 51422) Indians cannot swamp the Colony.
('3', 25, 1, 12, 51455) They would not emigrate in such large numbers.
('3', 25, 1, 13, 51502) There are not more than 12,000 Indians in the Transvaal as against nearly 100,000 Europeans in Johannesburg alone.
('3', 25, 1, 14, 51617) But, if the Government wish to give legislative recognition to the fear of swamping, the utmost that we can agree to, if that is to say the Indian voice is to be heard, is legislation on Natal lines with modifications.
('3', 25, 1, 15, 51836) In Natal, there is legislation of a general character applicable to all whereby intending settlers not formerly domiciled in Natal, unless they are wives or minor children of domiciled men in the
('3', 25, 2, 16, 52032) 1Vide “Address to Chamberlain”, January 7, 1903.
('3', 26, 0, 1, 52081) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 27
('3', 26, 1, 2, 52121) Colony, are not allowed to enter the Colony unless they have a knowledge of one of the European languages.
('3', 26, 1, 3, 52228) If instead of European languages, “any language used or spoken in His Majesty’s Dominions” were inserted, it will then leave room open for the respectable merchants, etc., and yet shut out the illiterate millions.
('3', 26, 1, 4, 52442) There should also be a clause added that special permission would be granted to those who may be bona fide required in the interests of the domiciled community, such as domestic servants, cooks, &c., who are, illiterate but are absolutely required for the old settlers.
('3', 26, 1, 5, 52712) Moreover, any such legislation should not affect those domiciled in South Africa.
('3', 26, 1, 6, 52794) I need not repeat that it is the wretched anti Indian legislation inherited from the Republics that we are struggling against—not its operation.
('3', 26, 1, 7, 52939) I, therefore, do not burden these notes with the numerous instances of injustice that are happening daily.
('3', 26, 1, 8, 53046) To have that alone remedied would be to lop off the branches; we, therefore, ask that the tree itself should be uprooted.
('3', 26, 1, 9, 53168) For, what is the use of palliatives in the shape of instructions from Home to the effect that the laws, in themselves bad, are not to be enforced strictly?
('3', 26, 1, 10, 53324) I hope there would be no acceptance of the principle of Locat ions as was hinted at in Lord George’s remarks to the Deputation.
('3', 26, 1, 11, 53452) They are not in vogue in the self governing Colonies of the Cape and Natal.
('3', 26, 1, 12, 53528) Can they then be in the Crown Colonies of the Transvaal and Orange River?
('3', 26, 1, 13, 53602) I hope that the Joint Committee 1 that waited on Lord George will ask for information as to when the legislation is to be passed repealing the old and on what lines.
('3', 26, 1, 14, 53768) It is very necessary to hasten it.
('3', 26, 1, 15, 53803) The difficulties the people have to go through are very great owing to the presence of some very unsympathetic officials who are administering Indian affairs.
('3', 26, 1, 16, 53962) If it takes long, it might be necessary to draw the attention of friends to some very typical cases of hardship.
('3', 26, 1, 17, 54075) At present, we are trying to get justice locally.
('3', 26, 1, 18, 54125) M. K. GANDHI
('3', 26, 2, 19, 54138) India Office: Judicial and Public Records, 402.
('3', 26, 3, 20, 54186) 1 The British Committee and the East India Association had set up a joint body to deal with matters concerning Indians in South Africa.

('3', 29, 11, 12, 56808) 20. INDIAN POSITION 1N NEW COLONIES 1
('3', 29, 12, 13, 56846) JOHANNESBURG, March 16, 1903
('3', 29, 13, 14, 56875) A SHORT STATEMENT REGARDING THE INDIAN POSITION
('3', 29, 14, 15, 56923) IN THE NEW COLONIES The developments taking place daily are filling the Indian residents with alarm.
('3', 29, 15, 16, 57024) THE TRANSVAAL There is yet no knowing when the promised changes in the existing anti Indian legislation will be made.
('3', 29, 15, 17, 57142) In the meanwhile, the following events have happened.
('3', 29, 15, 18, 57196) The store of Hoosen Amod, a merchant of ten years, standing in Wakkerstroom, has been forcibly closed and a trading license has been refused to him.
('3', 29, 15, 19, 57345) His is the only Indian store in that town.
('3', 29, 15, 20, 57388) It has now remained closed for over two months.
('3', 29, 15, 21, 57436) Suliman Ismail, who had a license issued to him last year, has
('3', 29, 16, 22, 57499) 1 This statement with some verbal changes and omissions was published in India, 17 4 1903.
('3', 30, 0, 1, 57590) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 31
('3', 30, 1, 2, 57630) been refused his license this year, and his store 1 has now remained closed for over a month.
('3', 30, 1, 3, 57724) Both the above merchants have a large stock.
('3', 30, 1, 4, 57769) They have already suffered great loss, and, if they are not allowed to open their stores, it would mean ruin to them.
('3', 30, 1, 5, 57887) Transfers of licenses from one store to another or from one person to another are being refused.!
('3', 30, 1, 6, 57985) An Indian trades in a place rented by him.
('3', 30, 1, 7, 58028) The landlord gives notice to quit.
('3', 30, 1, 8, 58063) The Indian wants to remove to another place.
('3', 30, 1, 9, 58108) The Licensing Officer would not allow this.
('3', 30, 1, 10, 58152) The man must either go to a Location or close altogether.
('3', 30, 1, 11, 58210) Another Indian wants to retire.
('3', 30, 1, 12, 58242) An old resident of the Colony is prepared to buy the business as a going concern.
('3', 30, 1, 13, 58324) The licensing officer would not transfer the license to the buyer.
('3', 30, 1, 14, 58391) The original owner can, therefore, only sell out by auction.
('3', 30, 1, 15, 58452) It follows that no new licenses are being granted.
('3', 30, 1, 16, 58503) The Asiatic Office is a terror to the people.
('3', 30, 1, 17, 58549) Its business is to invent new engines of torture.
('3', 30, 1, 18, 58599) Those who want to leave the country with the intention of returning must take out passes on which are to be affixed their photographs.
('3', 30, 1, 19, 58734) Thus, the Indians are to be treated as criminals.
('3', 30, 1, 20, 58784) Of course, the idea is to prevent the passes from being unlawfully used.
('3', 30, 1, 21, 58857) So, the whole community is to be branded for the sake of some who would make a fraudulent use of their passes.
('3', 30, 1, 22, 58968) The introduction takes no note of the religious objection on the part of the Mahomedans to have themselves photographed at all.
('3', 30, 1, 23, 59096) The Chairman of the British Indian Association, managing partner of the premier Indian firm in South Africa, Messrs N. C. Cumroodeen and Co., was ordered last week to get out of a foot path in Johannesburg.
('3', 30, 1, 24, 59303) He stood his ground and would not.
('3', 30, 1, 25, 59338) All the same, he had to suffer much indignity.
('3', 30, 1, 26, 59385) The matter is now engaging the attention of the Police Commissioner.
('3', 30, 1, 27, 59454) The thing is that, so long as the foot path bye law remains on the statute book, so long must such cases occur.
('3', 30, 1, 28, 59566) There is a slight outbreak of plague in Natal.
('3', 30, 1, 29, 59613) The authorities have made this an excuse for stopping the entry of Indians from that Colony.
('3', 30, 1, 30, 59706) The result is that even the refugee Indians, those who have to prove their claims here, are shut out, whereas Europeans and Kaffirs are allowed to come in freely.
('3', 30, 1, 31, 59869) Let it be noted that the plague has
('3', 30, 2, 32, 59905) 1 Situated in Rustenburg.
('3', 31, 0, 1, 59931) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 31, 1, 2, 59972) attacked all classes.
('3', 31, 1, 3, 59994) The above is merely a selection from the long catalogue of Indian grievances.
('3', 31, 1, 4, 60072) There is no sentiment about them.
('3', 31, 1, 5, 60106) They are real and substantial.
('3', 31, 1, 6, 60137) They represent a life and death struggle.
('3', 31, 1, 7, 60179) And yet when we sank the differences and formed the Volunteer Ambulance Corps at the time of the war, we were “sons of the Empire, after all”.
('3', 31, 1, 8, 60322) Our grievances were one of the causes of the war and made Lord Lansdowne’s blood to boil.
('3', 31, 1, 9, 60412) Nor is there here a question of future immigrants.
('3', 31, 1, 10, 60463) It is that of the residents who, Mr. Chamberlain assured the Indian deputation, were “entitled to fair and honourable treatment”.
('3', 31, 1, 11, 60593) There is no hesitation in saying that, in the darkest days of the community under the old republican regime, it was not subjected to the treatment it is now undergoing.
('3', 31, 1, 12, 60762) And what is more, then the British Government served as an effective shield against any serious wrong doing.
('3', 31, 1, 13, 60871) But, where are we now to find a shield against attacks from the very quarters which erstwhile afforded protection?
('3', 31, 2, 14, 60986) ORANGE RIVER COLONY The old drastic legislation remains in force in this Colony.
('3', 31, 2, 15, 61067) There is no relaxation.
('3', 31, 2, 16, 61091) The Government refuse to grant any exemptions and decline to say when the legislation will be modified or repealed.
('3', 31, 2, 17, 61207) Even the Indians who, before the legislation, traded in the Colony are not allowed to trade there.
('3', 31, 3, 18, 61306) CAPE COLONY: EAST LONDON
('3', 31, 4, 19, 61331) The Indian community there being small has requested the Committee here to help them.
('3', 31, 4, 20, 61417) The Muncipality of the Borough of East London received in 1895, when there was a very small Indian population there, power to pass bye laws preventing Coloured people from walking on the foot paths.
('3', 31, 4, 21, 61616) This law, for the reason above stated, passed unnoticed.
('3', 31, 4, 22, 61673) Last month, under the power vested in it, the Municipality passed a bye law, and now the Indian community there finds itself face to face with the humiliation of having to abandon the foot paths.
('3', 31, 4, 23, 61869) Registered owners or occupiers of landed property in the Borough of the value of £75.0.0 are exempt from the law.
('3', 31, 4, 24, 61983) As soon as the Indians heard of the law, they approached the Governor, who says they were too late.
('3', 31, 4, 25, 62083) What are they to do now?
('3', 31, 4, 26, 62108) They have addressed another representation to the Governor and cabled to the friends in London.
('3', 31, 4, 27, 62204) The bye law has its origin in the alleged or real, impudent
('3', 32, 0, 1, 62264) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 33
('3', 32, 1, 2, 62304) and, in some cases, indecent behaviour of the Kaffirs.
('3', 32, 1, 3, 62359) But, whatever the charges are against the British Indians, no one has ever whispered that the Indians behave otherwise than as decent men.
('3', 32, 1, 4, 62498) But, as it is the wont in this part of the world, they have been dragged down with the Kaffir without the slightest justification.
('3', 32, 2, 5, 62629) NATAL Contrary to expectations, the Natal Bill taxing the children of indentured parents has received the Royal assent.
('3', 32, 3, 6, 62749) NOTE As regards the Transvaal, it may be mentioned that the community has approached the Governor in the various matters mentioned.
('3', 32, 3, 7, 62881) H. E. is now considering them.
('3', 32, 4, 8, 62912) India Office: Judicial and Public Records, 402.
('3', 32, 5, 9, 62960) 21. LETTER TO “THE VEGETARIAN”
('3', 32, 6, 10, 62991) BOX 299, JOHANNESBURG, [post March 21, 1903]
('3', 32, 7, 11, 63036) TO THE EDITOR The Vegetarian [LONDON]
('3', 32, 8, 12, 63074) SIR, Regarding the information wanted by your correspondent“K” in your issue of the 21st.
('3', 32, 8, 13, 63164) ult., the following may be of some use to him: Except mealie meal, which is South African produce, every necessary of life in South Africa is dearer than in England.
('3', 32, 8, 14, 63330) The cost of fairly decent living for a bachelor may be put down at at least £15 per month.
('3', 32, 8, 15, 63421) A single bedroom fetches £4 per month easily.
('3', 32, 8, 16, 63467) A fairly good board would cost nothing less than £l2 monthly.
('3', 32, 8, 17, 63529) Some vegetarian specialities are imported by a grocer in Natal, but so far as I am aware, no one imports them in the Orange River Colony.
('3', 32, 8, 18, 63667) Your correspondent will do well to keep a small stock of these with him.
('3', 32, 8, 19, 63740) There is a well managed vegetarian restaurant in Johannesburg, conducted on the principles laid down by Kuhne.
('3', 32, 8, 20, 63851) I may add that fruit
('3', 33, 0, 1, 63872) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 33, 1, 2, 63913) being very plentiful in this country, there is no difficulty about the vegetarian diet.
('3', 33, 1, 3, 64001) It may not be superfluous to warn your correspondent against building hopes of prospects in South Africa for earning a living.
('3', 33, 1, 4, 64128) There is everywhere a great pressure of population.
('3', 33, 1, 5, 64180) The number of unemployed is very great, business is dull, and people do not know what will happen if the mining labour problem is not solved in the near future.
('3', 33, 2, 6, 64341) I am etc., M. K. GANDHI
('3', 33, 3, 7, 64365) THE VEGETARIAN, 25 4 1903

('3', 36, 15, 18, 68654) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge your telegram of yesterday’s date, informing the Association that His Excellency has been pleased to instruct the Magistrate at Rustenburg to grant the licence to Suleman Ismail 1 but that the Magistrate at Wakkerstroom has properly refused the licence to Hoosen Amod 2 as there is a Location in Wakkerstroom.
('3', 36, 16, 19, 69002) 1Vide “Telegram to Bhownaggree”, 30 8 1898. 2 ibid.
('3', 37, 0, 1, 69054) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 37, 1, 2, 69095) I am to tender the Association’s respectful thanks to His Excellency for granting relief to Mr. Suleman Ismail.
('3', 37, 1, 3, 69207) As to Mr. Hoosen Amod my Committee is enquiring into the condition and position of the Location at Wakkerstroom but in the meantime my Committee would humbly draw His Excellency’s attention to the fact that the principle that the decision seems to lay down is fraught with very serious consequences to the whole body of Indian traders.
('3', 37, 1, 4, 69543) For the Licensing Officers may refuse licences to old Indian traders to continue to trade in towns where there are Locations set apart for Indians.
('3', 37, 1, 5, 69691) Almost in every township of importance, the Indian merchants are liable to be compelled to trade in Locations.
('3', 37, 1, 6, 69802) This would virtually mean that Indian merchants now trading in towns may at any time have to close business altogether.
('3', 37, 1, 7, 69922) For the trade in towns is by no means always of the same description as in Locations.
('3', 37, 1, 8, 70008) Hoosen Amod’s case, in my Committee’s humble opinion, is probably the strongest that could be imagined.
('3', 37, 1, 9, 70112) He has been trading in Wakkerstroom for over ten years under licence granted in his ownname, a privilege that very few Indians enjoyed during the old regime.
('3', 37, 1, 10, 70270) He is the only Indian merchant in the midst of many European merchants trading in towns.
('3', 37, 1, 11, 70359) He held a licence up to the outbreak of War.
('3', 37, 1, 12, 70404) Almost every Indian occupying a similar position has been granted a licence.
('3', 37, 1, 13, 70481) This case was brought before Mr. Chamberlain’s notice on the strength of a newspaper report that his licence was to be refused for this year.
('3', 37, 1, 14, 70623) The Right Honourable gentleman was not disposed to credit the report.
('3', 37, 1, 15, 70693) Hoosen Amod brought out from Durban Mr. Goodricke, a solicitor, who waited on the Assistant Colonial Secretary who, my Committee understands, assured Mr. Goodricke that at least temporary permission would be granted to Hoosen Amod to open his store pending consideration of his case as to a full license on its merits.
('3', 37, 1, 16, 71012) My Committee, therefore, respectfully requests His Excellency to reconsider the decision and order the licence to be granted to Hoosen Amod, if only temporarily pending final decision.
('3', 37, 2, 17, 71197) I have the honour to be, Sir, Your obedient servant,
('3', 37, 3, 18, 71250) ABDOOL GANI

('3', 40, 1, 2, 74323) In Pietersburg (please read the reference to the matter in the Statement submitted to Mr. Chamberlain 1), some Indians, Who did not trade there before War, were last Bar granted licenses to trade in Town.
('3', 40, 1, 3, 74528) They have imported large stock.
('3', 40, 1, 4, 74560) Last December the Magistrate gave them notice that, after 31st March, they would not receive licenses to trade except in Location.
('3', 40, 1, 5, 74691) It was brought to Ma Chambelain’s notice, but the Supervisor of Asiatics said to him that he had seen the Magistrate and that the notice will not be acted upon.
('3', 40, 1, 6, 74852) Despite the assurance, the Magistrate insisted on giving the above notice to every Indian who applied for a renewal of his license.
('3', 40, 1, 7, 74984) The matter was, therefore, brought to the Supervisor’s notice, who repeated what he had said before Mr. Chamberlain, but said he was helpless, as the Assistant Colonial Secretary was against the applicants.
('3', 40, 1, 8, 75191) The matter was, thereupon, taken to the Colonial Secretary by Mr. Lunnon, a well known At solicitor of Pretoria, as also by Mr. Gandhi.
('3', 40, 1, 9, 75327) The Colonial Secretary assured them that, even if the Magis trate made it a condition before granting a quarterly license that he should give notice as aforesaid, he, the Colonial Secretary, would see that the licenses were renewed.
('3', 40, 1, 10, 75560) The matter there ended for the time being.
('3', 40, 1, 11, 75603) In February last, the quarterly licenses were issued.
('3', 40, 1, 12, 75657) The Magistrate did not give any notice.
