('3', 42, 7, 10, 79159) 31. INDIANS IN THE TRANSVAAL 1
('3', 42, 8, 11, 79190) THE INDIAN CASE
('3', 42, 9, 12, 79206) The Indians are entitled to equal privileges with Europeans in this British Colony, on the ground, firstly, that they are British sub jects, and, secondly, that they are in every way desirable citizens.
('3', 42, 9, 13, 79409) No matter what part of the world they have gone to, Mr. Gandhi said to the representative of The Star, they have proved themselves amenable to control, never interfering with the politics of the country, and besides they are industrious, frugal and sober.
('3', 42, 9, 14, 79665) Speaking as to the desirability of according them full citizenship, Mr. Gandhi said he knew that their alleged insanitary habits were put forward as a ground for their exclusion, but he con tended that a real study of the situation would disclose the facts that Indians were not so insanitary as to be beyond improvement, and that the authorities were responsible for the insanitation that existed in their abodes and habits.
('3', 42, 9, 15, 80091) [In] any community which was entirely neglected in that direction, a proportion of it would drift into a condition which would be objectionable.
('3', 42, 9, 16, 80236) The strongest point he is urging and devoting his attention to at
('3', 42, 10, 17, 80302) 1 This is an extract from a report originally published in The Natal Witness and reproduced in The Times of India.
('3', 43, 0, 1, 80417) 44 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 43, 1, 2, 80458) present is the abolition of what he calls “class legislation”, which is reflected in the restrictions imposed by the Supervisor’s Office and by the Town Council.
('3', 43, 1, 3, 80620) To his mind there is absolutely no chance of a great influx of Asiatics into.
('3', 43, 1, 4, 80698) South Africa.
('3', 43, 1, 5, 80712) Immigration is restricted by the Immigration Restriction Act, which has been rightly enforced in Natal against the Indian.
('3', 43, 1, 6, 80835) An Act framed on similar lines came into operation in the Cape Colony, and the Delagoa Bay authorities have enforced regulations which are still more severe in their application.
('3', 43, 1, 7, 81014) Under these Acts, an immigrant must prove that he was previously domiciled in the country, or he must be able to read and write one of the European languages before he will be allowed to disembark.
('3', 43, 1, 8, 81212) The laws in this regard are not solely applied to Indians, and as an enactment is bound to be put on the statute book, Mr. Gandhi has been forced to accept the situation, and he suggests local legislation should be on the lines of the Natal Act, with slight modifications.
('3', 43, 1, 9, 81485) He will urge the removal of the regulations, which will provide the Locations for Indians and in support of this, he argues that the poorer class of Indians would of their own free will reside in any place set apart for them, while only a few more wealthy and prosperous merchants would live in the town itself.
('3', 43, 1, 10, 81797) As the Transvaal is a Crown Colony, he is pressing on the Government the desirability of removing the restrictions governing the issue of trading licenses to Indians.
('3', 43, 1, 11, 81964) Natal and Gape Colony are self governing, and can make their own laws affecting internal affairs, but the Imperial Government, he contends, must apply its general policy of freedom in trade and action to the subjects of the Crown in the Transvaal.
('3', 43, 2, 12, 82212) The Times of India, 6 4 1903
('3', 44, 0, 1, 82241) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 45
('3', 44, 1, 2, 82281) 32. LETTER TO P. S. TO LT. GOVERNOR, TRANSVAAL
('3', 44, 2, 3, 82328) BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION, BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, April 11, 1903
('3', 44, 3, 4, 82395) TO PRIVATE SECRETARY
('3', 44, 4, 5, 82416) TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR PRETORIA
('3', 44, 5, 6, 82467) SIR, (1) The Committee of the Association ventures respectfully to approach His Excellency regarding the Government Notice No.
('3', 44, 5, 7, 82594) 356 of 1903 1 published in the newspapers.
('3', 44, 5, 8, 82637) (2) It appears to be in reply to the various matters submitted to His Excellency by the deputation that waited on him at Johannesburg on the 12th February last.
('3', 44, 5, 9, 82798) It has filled the Indian community with sorrow and alarm.
('3', 44, 5, 10, 82856) (3) His Excellency was pleased to assure the deputation that as soon as the enlarged Legislative Council was formed, suitable legislation replacing the old anti Asiatic legislation would be introduced.
('3', 44, 5, 11, 83058) The Notice in question would appear to disappoint the hopes based on the above assurance.
('3', 44, 5, 12, 83148) (4) His Excellency has been pleased to order licences to be renewed for the current quarter to all the Indian traders who, though they were not trading on the outbreak of hostilities, were granted licences last year.
('3', 44, 5, 13, 83365) The Notice is silent as to whether the renewals will be continued or not.
('3', 44, 5, 14, 83439) The matter is of such serious importance that, my Committee submits, a definite pronouncement is necessary.
('3', 44, 5, 15, 83547) (5) His Excellency was pleased to say to the deputation that if any officers had refused transfers of licences, either for other places in the same town, or to other persons, he would see that relief was granted.
('3', 44, 5, 16, 83760) Contrary to my Committee’s expectations, therefore, the statement that no transfers of licences would be granted has come as a great shock.
('3', 44, 5, 17, 83900) And the publicity thereof is likely to ruin many Indian merchants, unless relief is soon granted.
('3', 44, 5, 18, 83998) For landlords will not be slow
('3', 44, 6, 19, 84029) 1Vide “Letter to H.V. Vora ”, June 30, 1903
('3', 45, 0, 1, 84073) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 45, 1, 2, 84114) to take advantage of the Notice and to raise rents of premises occupied by Indian merchants to a prohibitive extent.
('3', 45, 1, 3, 84231) If the Government would fully respect vested interests, transfers, in my Committee’s humble opinion, are absolutely necessary.
('3', 45, 2, 4, 84358) (6) The last clause of the Notice, while it is no doubt intended to
('3', 45, 3, 5, 84426) confer benefit on the Indian community, impliedly casts a slur on the great race to which we belong, in that it assumes every Indian to be unfit to inhabit civilized townships unless he proves to the contrary.
('3', 45, 3, 6, 84636) My Committee with the greatest deference submits that, barring popular prejudice born of trade jealousy, the whole of the evidence that could be collected in South Africa, would go to show that British Indians have everywhere been found to be amenable to the general sanitary laws of the place of their domicile.
('3', 45, 3, 7, 84949) Only a few weeks ago, the Sanitary Inspector of Johannesburg reported that he had no fault to find with the manner in which the dwellings of Indians were kept in Market Street.
('3', 45, 3, 8, 85126) My Committee would gladly co operate with the Government in promoting a voluntary settlement of the poorer class of Indians in localities where suitable dwellings can be procured for cheaper rents.
('3', 45, 3, 9, 85324) But my Committee ventures respectfully to protest against a compulsory removal to Locations or Bazaars—a principle against which Her Late Majesty’s Government fought strenuously, when it was sought to be established by the Boer Government.
('3', 45, 4, 10, 85564) My Committee therefore ventures to hope that His Excellency
('3', 45, 5, 11, 85624) will be pleased to grant relief in the following matters:
('3', 45, 6, 12, 85682) (a) Whether an early alteration in existing anti Indian laws is
('3', 45, 7, 13, 85746) contemplated on the enlarged Legislative Council being formed.
('3', 45, 8, 14, 85809) (b) Whether the renewal will be granted in the cases
('3', 45, 9, 15, 85862) mentioned in paragraph (4) here of.
('3', 45, 10, 16, 85898) (c) Whether transfers to places or persons will be authorized.
('3', 45, 10, 17, 85961) (d) Whether the principle of compulsory segregation will be
('3', 45, 11, 18, 86021) removed.
('3', 45, 12, 19, 86030) If further discussion of the above points is desired by His
('3', 45, 13, 20, 86090) Excellency, a small deputation will wait on His Excellency.
('3', 45, 14, 21, 86150) I have the honour to be, Sir,
('3', 45, 15, 22, 86180) Your obedient servant
('3', 45, 16, 23, 86202) ABDOOL GANI
('3', 45, 17, 24, 86214) CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('3', 45, 18, 25, 86251) Pretoria Archives: LG.

('3', 46, 1, 2, 86342) 33. BRITISH INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA 1
('3', 46, 2, 3, 86380) JOHANNESBURG, April 12, 1903 The present position regarding British Indians in the Transvaal is as follows.
('3', 46, 2, 4, 86488) The foot path grievance in Standerton has been temporarily removed, the Government having instructed the Commandant not to enforce the bye law against well dressed and well behaved Asiatics.
('3', 46, 2, 5, 86679) The enclosed Government Notice shows the position regarding licences.
('3', 46, 2, 6, 86749) It has filled the community with alarm because: (1) it seems to shelve indefinitely the question of repealing the anti Indian legislation of the old Government; (2) it leaves in suspense the Indian traders who were not trading on the outbreak of war, but who were granted licences last year, licences which Mr. Chamberlain said could not be touched; (3) while pretending to respect the vested interests of those who were trading on the outbreak of war, it deals a death blow to them in that it prohibits transfers of licences from one place to another, and thus leaves the store keepers to the mercy of their landlords, and from one person to another, and thus prevents the store keepers from ultimately realising profits by selling their business as going concerns; (4) it casts a slur on the whole race in that it impliedly assumes every Indian to be unfit to reside in civilised townships, unless he proves the contrary.
('3', 46, 2, 7, 87673) These points have, after the publication of the Notice, been urged on the attention of His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor, and a reply is awaited With regard to Pietersburg, the Government have, after much difficulty, given a general decision: (i) that all existing Indian licences will be provisionally renewed for the current quarter; (ii) that no new licences will be granted to the Indians, whether they traded before the war or not; (iii) that existing licences will not be transferred to other
('3', 46, 3, 8, 88177) 1 This was published in India as “From a Correspondent”.
('3', 47, 0, 1, 88234) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 47, 1, 2, 88275) premises or other names, pending consideration of the whole question.
('3', 47, 1, 3, 88345) Thus, there is again another period of suspense and anxiety.
('3', 47, 1, 4, 88406) The existing licences may or may not be renewed after the expiry of the current quarter.
('3', 47, 1, 5, 88495) Mr. Chamberlain has definitely assured us that vested rights will not be touched.
('3', 47, 1, 6, 88577) The outcome of the decision embodied in the last two statements above is that, if a landlord gives notice to quit, the store keeper must necessarily close his business, and since his licence cannot be transferred to another person, he cannot sell it as a going concern.
('3', 47, 1, 7, 88847) The District Commandant has issued the following notice to the Indian community there:
('3', 47, 2, 8, 88934) All coolies, being holders of licences, can obtain permits to walk on the foot path in the town of Standerton, by applying to the police office.
('3', 47, 2, 9, 89079) Any coolie or other coloured person found walking on the foot paths in Standerton, not being in possession of a permit after April 1, will be prosecuted according to law.
('3', 47, 2, 10, 89250) Mark the contempt and utter disregard of the Indian feeling that are implied in the application of the term “coolie” to all Indians.
('3', 47, 2, 11, 89383) During the Boer regime, Indians were not at all interfered with while walking on the foot paths, much less were they required to carry permits of exemption.
('3', 47, 2, 12, 89540) When such an attempt was made to enforce the bye law, the British Government promptly intervened and stopped it.
('3', 47, 2, 13, 89653) A protest against the above notice has been sent to the Government.
('3', 47, 2, 14, 89721) There are isolated cases of the bubonic plague in Durban and Maritzburg, in Natal.
('3', 47, 2, 15, 89804) Kaffirs are the most largely attacked.They and the Europeans, who are also attacked, are allowed to enter theTransvaal from Natal, free of any restrictions.
('3', 47, 2, 16, 89961) But the Indian immigration from Natal, not merely the infected towns, is totally pro hibited.
('3', 47, 2, 17, 90055) The Indian refugees, too, are not allowed to enter the Colony from Natal.
('3', 47, 2, 18, 90129) Indians here are, according to Mr. Chamberlain’s advice, patiently trying to get redress from the local authorities.
('3', 47, 2, 19, 90246) And it is but fair to mention that H. E. the Lieutenant Governor is inclined to hold the scales even between the conflicting interests.
('3', 47, 2, 20, 90382) As to East London (Cape Colony), the foot path grievance still remains without redress.
('3', 47, 2, 21, 90470) H. E. the Governor has not yet replied to the last communication.
('3', 47, 2, 22, 90536) The bye law is not being enforced rigorously.
('3', 47, 3, 23, 90582) [Enclosure]
('3', 48, 0, 1, 90594) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 49
('3', 48, 1, 2, 90634) GOVERNMENT NOTICE
('3', 48, 2, 3, 90652) 356 OF 1903
('3', 48, 3, 4, 90664) It is hereby notified for general information that His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor, in Executive Council, has decided that in the disposal of applications made by Asiatics for licences to trade, the provisions of Law NO.
('3', 48, 3, 5, 90892) 3 of 1885, as amended by Executive Council Resolution, Article 164, of the 12th August, 1886, which was adopted by the Volksraad on the 12th August, 1886, by Resolution, Article 1419, shall be enforced, with due regard to the vested interests of those Asiatics who were trading outside Bazaars at the commencement of the late hostilities, and has resolved accordingly:
('3', 48, 4, 6, 91261) 1. That the Government take immediate steps to have Bazaars in every town set apart in which alone Asiatics may reside and trade; the Colonial Secretary shall be charged with the duty of defining such Asiatic Bazaars in consultation with the Resident Magistrate, or where such exists in the Town Council or Health Board.
('3', 48, 5, 7, 91582) 2. No new licences to trade shall be granted to any Asiatic except to carry on his business in Bazaars set apart for the purpose.
('3', 48, 6, 8, 91712) 3. In the case of Asiatic traders who held licences at the commencement of the late’ hostilities to trade in places not specially set apart by Government, licences may be renewed to trade under the same conditions during the residence in this Colony of the licensee, provided that such licences shall not be transferable and that, no licensee shall be entitled to hold more licences in any one town than were held by him at the commencement of hostilities.
('3', 48, 7, 9, 92169) With regard to the residence of Asiatics, which by the Law above mentioned is confined to those streets, wards and locations which may be set apart for the purpose, His Excellency has decided that an exception shall be made in favour of those whose intellectual attainments or social qualities and habits of life appear to entitle them to it, and has accordingly resolved that any Asiatic who shall prove to the satisfaction of the Colonial Secretary that he holds any higher educational certificate from the Education Department in this or any other British Colony or Dependency, or that he is able and willing to adopt a mode of living not repugnant to European ideas, nor in conflict with sanitary laws, may apply to the Colonial Secretary for a letter of exemption which shall enable him to reside elsewhere than in a place specially set apart for Asiatics.
('3', 48, 7, 10, 93031) W. H. MOOR (Assistant Colonial Secretary) Colonial Secretary’s Office, Pretoria, April 8, 1903. India, 15 5 1903

('3', 49, 1, 2, 93185) 34. LETTER TO P. S. TO LT. GOVERNOR, TRANSVAAL
('3', 49, 2, 3, 93232) BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION, BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, April 20, 1903
('3', 49, 3, 4, 93299) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY
('3', 49, 4, 5, 93324) TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR PRETORIA, TRANSVAAL
('3', 49, 5, 6, 93386) SIR, Your letter dated 31st March and numbered LG2131 was delivered only today as the wrong box was marked on the envelope.
('3', 49, 5, 7, 93510) The objection referred to in the letter under reply has been fully answered by my letter of the 2nd 1 instant which still remains unanswered.
('3', 49, 5, 8, 93652) The affidavit of the ex Manager of the National Bank at Wakkerstroom shows conclusively that Hoosen Amod’s store was not closed in July 1899, but that owing to the War he closed it himself on the 2nd day of October 1899. His store was never closed by the Landdrost, and he could not do so because Hoosen Amod held his licence for the full year 1899, and not a quarterly licence as now.
('3', 49, 5, 9, 94038) The statement that Hoosen Amod’s lease has not expired is, my Committee is informed, quite correct.
('3', 49, 5, 10, 94138) His lease is and has been, my Committee is informed, in the possession of the Magistrate, and the Lessor is prepared to make an affidavit confirming the statement.
('3', 49, 5, 11, 94302) Hoosen Amod informs the Committee that some interested store keepers in Wakkerstroom have thoroughly prejudiced the Magistrate against him, and given him false information regarding the alleged closing of the store by the Landdrost.
('3', 49, 5, 12, 94535) Objections have been raised against him one after another as the previous ones failed not to allow an answer.
('3', 49, 5, 13, 94645) He has been put to considerable loss for no fault of his own.
('3', 49, 5, 14, 94707) Many Indians not having half his claims are now trading, and Hoosen Amod, a store keeper of ten years’ standing, backed by
('3', 49, 6, 15, 94830) 1Vide “Telegram to Colonial Secretary" November 3, 1898
('3', 50, 0, 1, 94886) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 51
('3', 50, 1, 2, 94926) non interested Europeans in Wakkerstroom and in possession of a long lease still in existence, finds his store forcibly closed.
('3', 50, 1, 3, 95054) The Notice lately issued protects those occupying his position.
('3', 50, 1, 4, 95118) My Committee respectfully submits that the injustice he is labouring under is manifest beyond doubt and craves justice at His Excellency’s hands.
('3', 50, 2, 5, 95264) I have the honour to remain,

('3', 50, 4, 7, 95301) Your obedient servant,

('3', 50, 7, 10, 95405) 35. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY
('3', 50, 8, 11, 95438) THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('3', 50, 9, 12, 95469) BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, April 25, 1903
('3', 50, 10, 13, 95508) TO THE HONORABLE THE COLONIAL SECRETARY PRETORIA
('3', 50, 11, 14, 95557) SIR, I venture to bring to your notice the following translated extract from a letter addressed to the British Indian Association by the Indian residents of Heidelberg, and dated the 23rd instant.
('3', 50, 12, 15, 95754) This morning, at 5.30, the police constables surrounded every store, opened the doors and entered in and woke up all the people sleeping in the rooms, and struck terror into the people by shouting ‘Come out, come out.’ They did not allow them to wash their hands and faces, or to take tea or other tiffin.
('3', 50, 12, 16, 96060) Many opened their shops at 6 o’clock, thinking that two or three might remain in the shops, while the others accompanied the police.
('3', 50, 12, 17, 96193) But the masters were taken beforehand.
('3', 50, 12, 18, 96232) On the men declining to close the shops, the police closed the doors themselves, drew the men out, handed the keys to them, and marched them out.
('3', 50, 12, 19, 96378) Thus, every man was arrested as if he was a criminal.
('3', 50, 12, 20, 96432) The only difference was that we were not handcuffed.
('3', 50, 13, 21, 96485) Thus were all the people brought to the Charge Office at 8 a.m.
('3', 50, 13, 22, 96549) and kept under custody.
('3', 50, 13, 23, 96573) Each man was separately taken into the office room, asked to
('3', 51, 0, 1, 96634) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 51, 1, 2, 96675) produce his permit or proof of his former domicile, and new permits were issued to those who could establish their claim.
('3', 51, 1, 3, 96797) Then each was dismissed through the front door.
('3', 51, 1, 4, 96845) Even these were at first detained after the permits were issued, but when we protested, they were allowed to go.
('3', 51, 1, 5, 96958) Those that were thus freed were not allowed to hold any conversation with those that were detained, so the men who have been kept under custody since morning, hungry and thirsty as they are, had not been discharged up to 12.30 p.m.
('3', 51, 1, 6, 97190) This letter is being written at 12.30 p.m.
('3', 51, 1, 7, 97233) Still there are some merchants under custody.
('3', 51, 1, 8, 97279) The spectacle of respectable Indian store keepers being arrested early in the morning and marched through the streets has become the topic of general conversation in the town.
('3', 51, 2, 9, 97455) Thus, the police rudely and without permission entered all the rooms and did not quite mind our warning that some of the rooms contained Zanana ladies.
('3', 51, 2, 10, 97607) When asked by what order we were being arrested, the reply was ‘By order of the captain; we are going to take every one except women and children, and if you do not come willingly, we will force you.’ The written order was asked for.
('3', 51, 2, 11, 97841) They declined.
('3', 51, 2, 12, 97856) Such is the account of the police proceeding in Heidelberg.
('3', 51, 2, 13, 97916) I may state that a similar occurrence happened in Johannesburg.
('3', 51, 2, 14, 97980) The matter was brought to Captain Fowle’s notice, and it was thought thatthe procedure would not be repeated.
('3', 51, 2, 15, 98090) It was, however, repeated in Potchefstroom.
('3', 51, 2, 16, 98134) It was still allowed to slide down.
('3', 51, 2, 17, 98170) But it has now become impossible for my committee to remain silent.
('3', 51, 2, 18, 98238) In the darkest days of our time under the old regime, we were not subjected to such physical ill treatment.
('3', 51, 2, 19, 98346) The community has, so far as my committee is aware, committed no crime, and yet it has not only to face popular prejudice and its effects, but has now to face ill treatment from those who are expected to protect us.
('3', 51, 2, 20, 98562) My committee humbly request an enquiry and an expression of opinion from the Government as to the proceeding of the police above referred to.
('3', 51, 3, 21, 98704) I have the honour to remain,
('3', 51, 5, 22, 98733) your obedient servant, ABDOOL GANI, CHAIRMAN, [THE] BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION The Rand Daily Mail, 28 4 1903
('3', 52, 0, 1, 98843) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 53
('3', 52, 1, 2, 98883) 36. TREATMENT OF INDIANS
('3', 52, 2, 3, 98908) THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('3', 52, 3, 4, 98939) BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, April 27, 1903
('3', 52, 4, 5, 98978) TO THE EDITOR The Rand Daily Mail JOHANNESBURG
('3', 52, 5, 6, 99025) SIR, I beg to enclose herewith a copy of a letter 1 addressed to the Government for publication.
('3', 52, 5, 7, 99122) The letter refers to the treatment by the police at Heidelberg of the British Indian residents there.
('3', 52, 5, 8, 99224) Comment on the letter is superfluous.
('3', 52, 5, 9, 99262) Whatever may be the policy of your paper on the question of the status of the British Indians in the Colony, I ven ture to trust that you will be able to sympathise with my countrymen in the physical ill treatment alluded to in the letter.
('3', 52, 5, 10, 99502) If there is one thing that is dearly cherished by the British Constitution, it is the respect for personal liberty the meanest of the King’s subjects, whether white or black.
('3', 52, 5, 11, 99677) This evidently is at stake in the Colony, as far as the British Indians are concerned.
('3', 52, 6, 12, 99764) I have the honour to remain, Sir, your obedient servant, ABDOOL GANI, CRAIRMAN, [THE] BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('3', 52, 7, 13, 99877) The Rand Daily Mail, 28 4 1903

('3', 53, 1, 2, 99975) 37. LETTER TO P. S. TO LT. GOVERNOR, TRANSVAAL
('3', 53, 2, 3, 100022) BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION, BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, April 27, 1903
('3', 53, 3, 4, 100089) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR PRETORIA
('3', 53, 5, 5, 100165) I have the honour to acknowledge your letter of the 22nd of April received on the 24th instant.
('3', 53, 5, 6, 100261) My Committee tenders its respectful thanks to His Excellency for the reply which shows that he is anxious to do justice to the Indian Community, in that it puts a liberal construction on the Government Notice No.
('3', 53, 5, 7, 100474) 356 of 1903. But the reply has deeply grieved the community, in that it is, in my Committee’s humble opinion, a departure from the declarations before War, of Her Late Majesty’s Government, as well as the assurances since given by His Majesty’s Government, that the existing Law would be reconsidered.
('3', 53, 5, 8, 100776) My Committee will therefore be obliged later to revert to the general question.
('3', 53, 5, 9, 100856) In the meanwhile, I am to request information on the following further points that ariseout of the Notice and your letter under reply.
('3', 53, 5, 10, 100991) Indians who did not hold licences before War and yet were granted them last year were not informed that they were temporary.
('3', 53, 5, 11, 101116) The first information given to such effect was last year and it was repudiated by the Right Honourable Mr. Chamberlain as soon as it was brought to his notice.
('3', 53, 5, 12, 101276) Such store keepers have in some instances gone to the expense of building substantial structures.
('3', 53, 5, 13, 101374) Others hold long leases and all have built up a fair custom which is likely to increase as time goes on.
('3', 53, 5, 14, 101479) It will be, therefore, in my Committee’s humble opinion, unjust to require them to remove to Bazaars.
('3', 53, 5, 15, 101581) The removal, as a rule, cannot be effected without a heavy loss, no matter how well situated the proposed Bazaars may be.
('3', 53, 5, 16, 101703) The Notice in question refers to renewals of licences outside
('3', 54, 0, 1, 101765) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 55
('3', 54, 1, 2, 101805) Bazaars to those who were trading on the outbreak of War.
('3', 54, 1, 3, 101863) The letter under reply mentioned “trading before War”.
('3', 54, 1, 4, 101918) Is my Committee right in understanding that all Indians who were trading before War, whether on the outbreak or not, will have their licences renewed?
('3', 54, 1, 5, 102069) If not, an Indian who opened a store in 1899 outside Locations would be entitled to a renewal where as one who traded for fifteen years and went to India for a trip, closing his business in August 1899, would be disentitled, thus causing [sic] manifest injustice.
('3', 54, 1, 6, 102333) The enforcement of the whole Law would seem to imply a continuance of the prohibition to British Indians to hold landed property except in Locations or Bazaars.
('3', 54, 1, 7, 102494) There are some Indians who hold landed property in the names of white persons.
('3', 54, 1, 8, 102573) Most of these cases are already before His Excellency for consideration, more especially the three mosques in Johannesburg, Pretoria and Heidelberg.
('3', 54, 1, 9, 102722) Law 3 of 1885 and its amendment contemplated a registration fee of £ 3 on every Indian—a clause that was formerly as a rule enforced only in the case of storekeepers and hawkers and because the Receivers of Revenue would not grant licences without the production of the Registration Certificate.
('3', 54, 1, 10, 103018) A large number, however, never paid the fee nor were they ever called upon either to register themselves or to pay the fee.
('3', 54, 1, 11, 103142) My Committee has seen the Notice appointing Captain Fowle 1 as the Registration Officer for Asiatics, but my Committee respectfully hopes that it is not the intention of the Government to enforce the provision which was notenforced during the old regime and which can have nothing to do with the Anti Asiatic agitation on the part of the public at large.
('3', 54, 1, 12, 103497) My Committee, therefore, requests information (a) Whether His Excellency will be pleased to respect the vested interests of all existing licensees, whether they were trading before the War or not.
('3', 54, 1, 13, 103694) (b) Whether licences will be granted to those who were trading before War outside Locations whether on the outbreak thereof or earlier.
('3', 54, 1, 14, 103830) (c) Whether Law 3 of 1885 as amended in 1886 is to be enforced as to the prohibition to hold landed property, and if so whether permission will be granted for the transfers of those properties which are held by Indians in the name of white persons.
('3', 54, 2, 15, 104079) 1 Hamilton Fowle
('3', 55, 0, 1, 104096) 56 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 55, 1, 2, 104137) (d) Whether it is the intention of the Government to enforce payment of the registration fee of £ 3 in terms of the Law.
('3', 55, 2, 3, 104258) I have the honour to remain,
('3', 55, 3, 4, 104287) S i r ,
('3', 55, 4, 5, 104295) Your obedient servant,
('3', 55, 5, 6, 104318) ABDOOL GANI CHAIRMAN, BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION

('3', 56, 1, 2, 105001) 39. LETTER TO LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR 1
('3', 56, 2, 3, 105037) THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, May 1, 1903
('3', 56, 3, 4, 105104) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR PRETORIA
('3', 56, 4, 5, 105180) SIR, Mr. William Hosken and other leading residents of Johannesburg, whose names appear at the foot of the enclosed petition 2 addressed to His Excellency, have entrusted the Association with the task of submitting same to His Excellency, which, on behalf of the Association, I do hereby.
('3', 56, 4, 6, 105469) In doing so, I may state that the petition owes its origin to the request of the Association to the gentlemen in question to put their views before the Government regarding the notice No.356 of 1903 and to express their opinion generally regarding the Indian question.
('3', 56, 4, 7, 105738) This they have gladly done.
('3', 56, 4, 8, 105766) I may be permitted to mention that, with very few exceptions, all the Europeans with whom we have come in contact have expressed sentiments similar to those of the petitioners.
('3', 56, 4, 9, 105943) A few have approved of the notice in ignorance of the state of the law which it is intended to enforce, as also owing to misunderstanding as to the real scope of its meaning.
('3', 56, 4, 10, 106118) As to the subject matter of the petition, my committee would be prepared to agree to the principle of the legislation, submitted as model by the petitioners, with slight modifications.
('3', 56, 4, 11, 106303) It would generally meet the object sought to be served by the notice in question and cannot fail to regulate the granting of licenses to the satisfaction of the most vehementopponent of the British Indian, in that, subject to the control, in extreme cases, of the Supreme Court, the popularly elected
('3', 56, 5, 12, 106604) 1 Gandhiji sent a copy of this letter to Dadabhai Naoroji to be forwarded to the Secretary of State for India.
('3', 56, 5, 13, 106715) 2Vide enclosure on the following page.
('3', 57, 0, 1, 106754) 58 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 57, 1, 2, 106795) bodies would regulate the granting of new licenses and would, at the same time, remove from the statute book the existing legislation which puts an unnecessary affront on His Majesty’s loyal Indian subjects.
('3', 57, 1, 3, 107003) The proposed legislation would moreover regulate the future immigration which the notice does not do.
('3', 57, 1, 4, 107105) In talking to the European gentlemen, my committee has also found that their opposition is not so much against the Indians as against the Chinese.
('3', 57, 1, 5, 107252) To quote one glaring instance, when the statement dealing with Asiatics, made in the pamphlet published by the Joh annesburg branch of the South Africa League, was brought to the notice of the executive of the League, they admitted at once that the use of the term Asiatic was an error.
('3', 57, 1, 6, 107539) Their objection was entirely against the Chinese and not at all against the British Indians.
('3', 57, 2, 7, 107632) I have the honour to remain,
('3', 57, 4, 8, 107661) your obedient servant, CHAIRMAN, [THE] BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('3', 57, 5, 9, 107727) India Office: Judicial and Public Records, 402. [Enclosure] 1
('3', 57, 6, 10, 107789) The following is the text of the petition signed by W. M. Hosken and others, referred to in the above memorial of the British Indian Association:—
('3', 57, 8, 11, 107936) HIS EXCELLENCY THE LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR OF THE TRANSVAAL PRETORIA
('3', 57, 9, 12, 108001) THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED, RESIDING IN THE COLONY
('3', 57, 10, 13, 108057) OF THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 57, 11, 14, 108074) HUMBLY SHEWETH—
('3', 57, 12, 15, 108090) Your petitioners have read the Government Notice recently published in the papers regarding the Asiatics, and would venture respectfully to express their opinion on the question as follows: 1. Your petitioners regard it as necessary that the immigration of Asiatics into the Colony should be regulated by law, and would, therefore, suggest that in the place of the existing anti Asiatic legislation, the Natal Act or the Cape Act may be copied with advantage.
('3', 57, 12, 16, 108550) It would do away with race or colour question, while setting at rest any fear of an influx of undesirable people of any nationality.
('3', 57, 13, 17, 108683) 1 This was published in India, 25 9 1903.
('3', 58, 0, 1, 108725) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 59
('3', 58, 1, 2, 108765) 2. But the notice in question, if it is meant to be permanent, appears to your petitioners to be in conflict with the declarations before the war of Her late Majesty’s Government, in that they were then opposed to the anti Asiatic laws of the late Republic so far as British Indians were concerned, and protested against their enforcement.
('3', 58, 2, 3, 109105) 3. While, as stated above, your petitioners would object to an unrestricted influx into the Colony of the Indian population, in their humble opinion the present population is entitled to fair and honourable treatment.
('3', 58, 3, 4, 109323) 4. The refusal to transfer existing licenses from one person to another or from one place to another would be tantamount to requiring the present holders to close their businesses sooner or later, and then at a heavy loss.
('3', 58, 4, 5, 109546) 5. The notice in question is not clear whether all existing licenses will be renewed from time to time.
('3', 58, 4, 6, 109650) It would be unjust to withhold licenses to trade outside Bazaars from those Indians who obtained them last year from British officers.
('3', 58, 5, 7, 109785) 6. In your petitioners’ humble opinion the best solution of the intricate question will be in Town Councils or Health Boards being granted powers, as in Natal, to refuse or grant licenses to new applicants, subject to safeguards against abuse thereof in the shape of the right, to the aggrieved party, of appealing to the Supreme Court against their decisions.
('3', 58, 5, 8, 110146) The renewals of existing licenses, too, should be subject to the sanitary report from year to year.
('3', 58, 6, 9, 110246) 7. In your petitioners’ humble opinion the British Indians resident in the colony are an orderly, law abiding and useful section of the community, and are quite equal in honesty and sobriety to others who are not British subjects, and yet enjoy full trading and other rights.
('3', 58, 7, 10, 110522) 8. It is evident that the Indian supplies a felt want, because the general public support him.
('3', 58, 8, 11, 110617) Your petitioners, therefore, pray that the notice in question will ‘be reconsidered in view of the points herein submitted, or such other relief will be granted to His Majesty’s Indian subjects as may seem meet.
('3', 58, 9, 12, 110829) And for this act of justice and mercy, your petitioners as in duty bound shall for ever pray, etc., etc.
('3', 58, 9, 13, 110934) Johannesburg, April, 1903 W. M. HOSKEN, L. W. RITCH [AND SEVERAL OTHERS]

('3', 61, 6, 14, 115880) As to Bazaars, not an Indian has accepted the principle of compulsory removal to Bazaars, but we are ready to co operate with the Gover nment in making the Bazaar system a success, if it is applied to new applicants.

('3', 62, 7, 19, 117652) Under it many white aliens have been turned away.

('3', 62, 7, 24, 118049) The Cape Act was drafted so as to include Indian languages but it was amended in Committee.

('3', 62, 7, 26, 118289) You will find the full text of these laws in the papers sent before.
('3', 62, 7, 27, 118358) If your health is good & if time permits it, please study the question & direct the movement in India against it.
('3', 62, 7, 28, 118472) The more I observe the effect of emigration of our people on their character, the more convinced I become that, if an open door is kept for us to

('3', 63, 6, 7, 118883) POSITION IN THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 63, 7, 8, 118909) BOX 6523, JOHANNESBURG, May 16, 1903 Hardly has the ink dried on the pen when information is officially received that it is the intention of the Government to enforce the £3 registration tax in terms of Law 3 of 1885. The information received from friends in London goes to show that the Law is to be altered.
('3', 63, 7, 9, 119219) If so, it is difficult to imagine why it is now proposed to collect the registration tax of £3. It was never compulsorily collected during the Boer rule.
('3', 63, 7, 10, 119373) It is inconceivable why the very tax from which we were protected by the British Government should now be collected in its name.
('3', 63, 7, 11, 119502) And there is not even the excuse of popular prejudice in favour of the tax.
('3', 63, 7, 12, 119578) The agitation from the Europeans is against trading licenses.
('3', 63, 7, 13, 119640) No one at any of the anti Asiatic meetings has ever whispered a word as to the collection of the tax.
('3', 63, 7, 14, 119742) We have sent a respectful protest to His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor and it is unlikely that the collection of the tax would be suspended before this reaches London.
('3', 63, 7, 15, 119915) But the situation has become so critical that it has been thought advisable to pass on to London any developments in the position.
('3', 63, 8, 16, 120046) India Office: Judicial and Public Records, 402.
('3', 63, 9, 17, 120094) 45. THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION AND LORD MILNER
('3', 63, 10, 18, 120145) His Excellency Lord Milner has forwarded to the Press the following account of his interview with the deputation of the British
('3', 64, 0, 1, 120273) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 65
('3', 64, 1, 2, 120313) Indian Association on the 22nd ultimo.
('3', 64, 1, 3, 120352) Present: His Excellency the Governor of the Transvaal, and Messrs.
('3', 64, 1, 4, 120419) M. K. Gandhi, Abdul Gani, Haji Habib, H. O. Ally, S. V. Thomas, and Imam Shekh Ahmed.
('3', 64, 1, 5, 120505) Mr. M. K. Gandhi said that, on behalf of the deputation, he wished to thank His Excellency for receiving them.
('3', 64, 1, 6, 120616) They wished to discuss the £3 tax and the general question.
('3', 64, 1, 7, 120676) When they read His Excellency’s address to the Municipal Congress, they felt obliged for the sentiments which he had expressed, and thought that they saw the end of their troubles.
('3', 64, 1, 8, 120857) But the following morning they received a letter from His Excellency the Lieut. Governor of the Transvaal, from which it appeared that the Government were going to enforce Law No.
('3', 64, 1, 9, 121037) 3 of 1885, and that it would not be altered at all.
('3', 64, 1, 10, 121089) It was quite true that this tax had been paid by some of the Asiatics to the old Government.
('3', 64, 1, 11, 121182) Indeed, they could not get a license to trade unless they had previously paid this tax.
('3', 64, 1, 12, 121270) But it was never regularly enforced.
('3', 64, 1, 13, 121307) In 1885, when this law was passed, complaints from British Indians poured in, and there was a good deal of correspondence with the Colonial Office on the subject of the right of the Boers to impose this tax, and to pass the law.
('3', 64, 1, 14, 121536) Finally, the late Government agreed to arbitration.
('3', 64, 1, 15, 121588) But the decision 1 went against the British Indians.
('3', 64, 1, 16, 121641) However, Mr. Chamberlain said that he reserved to himself the right to make friendly representations to the Transvaal Government.
('3', 64, 1, 17, 121771) Mr. Chamberlain also told them that he heartily sympathised with the British Indians.
('3', 64, 1, 18, 121857) In the end, the law was never wholly enforced.
('3', 64, 1, 19, 121904) In 1899, when an attempt was made to enforce the Location Law, a deputation waited upon Sir Conyngham Greene and Mr. Emrys Evans.
('3', 64, 1, 20, 122034) The latter afterwards saw Dr. Krause, who was then the Public Prosecutor, who assured him that he had received no instructions to prosecute in cases where the people refused to go into Locations.
('3', 64, 1, 21, 122230) But now the position was absolutely changed, and they were to be compelled to pay the tax and to go to Bazaars.
('3', 64, 1, 22, 122342) He ventured to submit that the tax would be a grievous burden to the Indian community.
('3', 64, 1, 23, 122429) Large numbers of Indians were employed as house boys, domestic servants and waiters, and their wages were about £3 per month.
('3', 64, 1, 24, 122555) Thus, they would have to pay one twelfth of their wages by way of a tax.
('3', 64, 1, 25, 122628) It was also a kind of a penal measure, for, if they did not pay, that law provided that a fine of
('3', 64, 2, 26, 122726) 1Vide “Open Letter”, before 19 12 1894 & “Letter to Europeans” 19 12 1894
('3', 65, 0, 1, 122800) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 65, 1, 2, 122841) from £10 to £100 could be imposed or, in default, fourteen days’ to six months’ imprisonment.
('3', 65, 1, 3, 122935) His Excellency: Is this an annual tax?
('3', 65, 1, 4, 122974) Mr. Gandhi said it was not, and had only to be paid once.
('3', 65, 1, 5, 123032) It was intended to act as a deterrent to Indian immigration.
('3', 65, 1, 6, 123093) That such pay ment should now be enforced against those already in the country came as a great surprise to them.
('3', 65, 1, 7, 123206) As to passes, Mr. Gandhi said that originally, after refugees were permitted to return to the Transvaal, permits held by Indians were taken away from them by the Asiatic Office, and temporary passes were granted.
('3', 65, 1, 8, 123419) Passes were further necessary if an Indian wanted to visit a friend in another part of South Africa.
('3', 65, 1, 9, 123520) These passes were made out for as many days as the issuing officer chose.
('3', 65, 1, 10, 123594) There was, besides, a vast amount of unnecessary trouble.
('3', 65, 1, 11, 123652) Later on, these passes were again exchanged for permits, and instead of a notice being put in the papers to this effect, Indians were brought to the office simply to be told about it.
('3', 65, 1, 12, 123836) In one case, some Indians were dragged out of their homes at four o’clock in the morning, and kept waiting at the office till 9.30, simply to be told that their passes were no longer of any use, and had to be changed for permits.
('3', 65, 1, 13, 124066) The community needed rest from these constant changes of passes and permits.
('3', 65, 1, 14, 124143) That was their position, and they had come to His Excellency to pray for relief, both as regards the present permit system and the £3 tax.
('3', 65, 1, 15, 124282) This law was most painful to them—all the more so, as the enforcing of it now showed the intention of the Government to perpetuate it.
('3', 65, 1, 16, 124417) It had been publicly declared that the refusal of the late Government to repeal that law was one of the causes of the war.
('3', 65, 1, 17, 124540) But what did they find?
('3', 65, 1, 18, 124564) That the new Government was going to enforce Law No.
('3', 65, 1, 19, 124617) 3 of 1885 as it had never been enforced by the late Government.
('3', 65, 1, 20, 124681) That being so, it followed that they would never be allowed to hold property in the Transvaal, except in Bazaars and Locations.
('3', 65, 1, 21, 124809) He respectfully submitted that that was quite contrary to the principles of the British Constitution, and that it was not in vogue in any other British Colony.
('3', 65, 1, 22, 124969) Now, a new Crown Colony was leading the way in this direction.
('3', 65, 1, 23, 125032) In this connection, he would like to mention another difficulty.
('3', 65, 1, 24, 125097) The sites where stood the Mosques in Pretoria and Johannesburg had been purchased many years ago, but owing to this law, they could not be transferred to them.
('3', 65, 1, 25, 125257) And there was the same difficulty regarding the Mosque at Heidelberg.
('3', 65, 1, 26, 125327) Lord Roberts, when
('3', 66, 0, 1, 125346) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 67
('3', 66, 1, 2, 125386) approached, pointed out that military law was still in force, but added that he hoped that, as soon as the civil administration was established, al; British subjects would be treated alike.
('3', 66, 1, 3, 125576) Yet this very law was being enforced against them by the present Government.
('3', 66, 1, 4, 125653) Then there was the trouble about photographs on visiting passes.
('3', 66, 1, 5, 125718) If an Indian wished to visit friends in another Colony, he had to send three photographs to the Asiatic Office before he could get a pass to leave the Colony and return.
('3', 66, 1, 6, 125888) Such a course might be necessary to prevent a fraudulent use of such permits, but he ventured to submit that it was not fair to assume that, because some Indians might make a fraudulent use of a permit, all Indians were criminally inclined.
('3', 66, 1, 7, 126129) Those who were should surely be caught and severely punished.
('3', 66, 1, 8, 126191) They had frequently protested against this and the way the Asiatic Office was carried on.
('3', 66, 1, 9, 126281) The officer there was reported to have said, in the course of an interview which appeared in the Star, that it was intended to advance the views of the White League and not to watch over the interests of Asiatics.
('3', 66, 1, 10, 126495) When Mr. Chamberlain was here, he received a Deputation of British Indians, and he told them that they should make it their duty to agree with the sentiments of the European population, so long as these sentiments did not interfere with their rights.
('3', 66, 1, 11, 126746) They had taken that advice to heart, but now the White League demanded that they should be sent out of the country altogether.
('3', 66, 1, 12, 126873) He could assure His Excellency that they had all been trying to follow the advice of Mr. Chamberlain, in so far as it was consistent with their self respect.
('3', 66, 1, 13, 127031) He did not think he need add anything more than to remind His Excellency that Mr. Chamberlain had said that those Indians already in the country would receive fair and honourable treatment, and that was what they now asked for.
('3', 66, 1, 14, 127259) H. O. Ally complained that they were not allowed to trade where they liked, and that they could not get transfers of licences.
('3', 66, 1, 15, 127386) Imam Shekh Ahmed stated that, some months ago, he applied for a permit for a Mohammedan priest, but it was refused point blank.
('3', 66, 1, 16, 127514) Surely no country could refuse to allow a priest to enter it for the purpose of ministering to a section of the inhabitants of that country.
('3', 66, 1, 17, 127655) He had always found that great difficulties were put in their way when they went to any of the Government offices to see the officials.
('3', 66, 1, 18, 127791) He could never, for instance, get in to see the Colonial Secretary.
('3', 66, 1, 19, 127859) His Excellency: I think what has just been said is rather an
('3', 67, 0, 1, 127920) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 67, 1, 2, 127961) illustration of the necessity of having an Asiatic Department.
('3', 67, 1, 3, 128024) It is quite possible that the present Asiatic Office, which is a new institution, may not work very well.
('3', 67, 1, 4, 128130) But my idea is that it would be an immense advantage for the Asiatics in this country if they had a special member of the Government to whom they could go about their affairs, instead of having to compete with so many other bodies for the attention of a very much overworked office like that of the Colonial Secretary.
('3', 67, 1, 5, 128449) I admit that this special officer should not regard himself as a man merely to enforce the law with regard to Asiatics, but as a man to look after their interests, and by whom they should be well received when they have any complaint to make.
('3', 67, 1, 6, 128692) I think such an Asiatic Department is very desirable, and its establishment is in your own interest.
('3', 67, 1, 7, 128793) The discussion to day has turned largely upon the £3 tax.
('3', 67, 1, 8, 128851) It seems to be rather a small point among many big ones.
('3', 67, 1, 9, 128908) The only reason for pressing for the £3 tax, which, I may tell you, I consider a very fair one in any case, is that it is part of the existing law.
('3', 67, 1, 10, 129056) We are enforcing the laws as we find them.
('3', 67, 1, 11, 129099) But I may say at once that we do not consider Law No.
('3', 67, 1, 12, 129153) 3 of 1885 a perfect one at all.
('3', 67, 1, 13, 129185) I have always maintained that it was necessary to deal with the position of Asiatics in this country by special law, but the law, under which I think they should be dealt with, would be materially different from Law No.
('3', 67, 1, 14, 129405) 3 of 1885. I do not know that we should altogether agree as to what the provisions of such special law should be, but while I should not agree with you in all respects, neither should I agree with much I hear said, and with what I read in the newspapers with regard to the treatment of Asiatics.
('3', 67, 1, 15, 129701) I think we have a perfect right to restrict Asiatic immigration, and any other immigration for that matter, for the general good of the community,—that is a right inherent in every State which cannot for a moment be disputed—but I think that those As Asiatics who are already here, and whom we may hereafter admit, should be well trea ted and feel that their rights are guaranteed.
('3', 67, 1, 16, 130083) I hoped that ere now a new law of a permanent character would have beer passed, so that a British Indian, or anyone else, could say to himself: “I know that, if I go to the Transvaal, I must abide by certain conditions, and, that being done, I shall be all right,” while those already in the country would be protected in their acquired rights.
('3', 67, 1, 17, 130428) But, unfortunately, delays have occurred, and you see for yourselves what the difficulties are in passing a law dealing with this matter.
('3', 67, 1, 18, 130566) I have a great faith in the effect of time, discussion and
('3', 68, 0, 1, 130625) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 69
('3', 68, 1, 2, 130665) consideration to bring conflicting views closer together.
('3', 68, 1, 3, 130723) But at present, such a law as I should propose might not have the consent of the Government of Great Britain, and might cause protest from the Government of India: and, on the other hand, any law, which the Home Government suggested.
('3', 68, 1, 4, 130957) to us, might not meet with public assent here, and, even if passed, might make your position worse by stimulating the opposition to you, and would then, on the establishment of self government, almost certainly be repealed at once.
('3', 68, 1, 5, 131189) It is no use trying to force the position here against the overwhelming body of white opinion.
('3', 68, 1, 6, 131284) I think a reasonable law is possible—not a law which will give you all you want, but one which will give you a great deal; not a law which will altogether please the “White League”, but one which will do much to conciliate the reasonable members of the white population.

('3', 69, 1, 3, 133348) As to Bazaars, continued His Excellency, would it not be better for.

('3', 69, 1, 5, 133534) I must say that I think once they are properly established, it would be a distinct advantage tothe Indian community to occupy them, instead of causing general opposition to themselves by settling down here, there, and everywhere among people who do not want them.

('3', 72, 3, 20, 141978) 46. POSITION IN THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 72, 4, 21, 142008) [JOHANNESBURG, May 24, 1903]
('3', 72, 5, 22, 142037) THE POSITION IN THE TRANSVAAL FOR WEEK ENDING 23RD MAY, 1903 The Law 3 of 1885 as amended in 1886, it will be remembered, requires from every Indian settling in the Colony a registration fee of £3. The Government, having decided to enforce the above Law, notified that the Indians who had not paid £3 tax during the old
('3', 73, 0, 1, 142357) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 73, 1, 2, 142398) regime were to pay it forthwith.
('3', 73, 1, 3, 142431) The community, therefore, appealed to Lord Milner for protection on the following grounds: (1) The Law 3 of 1885 was never approved by the British Government and it remained on the statute book only after diplomatic representations had failed.
('3', 73, 1, 4, 142675) (2) The tax was never regularly enforced during the late regime.
('3', 73, 1, 5, 142740) (3) The Law, the removal of which was one of the causes of the war, should not be enforced.
('3', 73, 1, 6, 142832) (4) The Indian community needs rest from the constant change of passes and officers.
('3', 73, 1, 7, 142917) The Asiatic Office, under whose yoke it is groaning, took away the permanent permits held by the Indians and granted temporary passes, for which there was no legal authority.
('3', 73, 1, 8, 143092) These passes were changed for permits, and hardly has the police prosecution been effaced from the mind of the Indian community, when comes the proposal for registration certificates for which £3 have to be paid.
('3', 73, 1, 9, 143305) (5) The payment would be a crushing burden to poor Indian hawkers and others to whom the sum of £3 is not a joke.
('3', 73, 1, 10, 143419) (6) Unlike other personal taxes in the Colony, failure to pay the tax renders a man liable to the penalty of £10 to £100 fine and, in default, 14 days’ to six months’ imprisonment.
('3', 73, 1, 11, 143600) The other taxes in the Colony are recoverable only by civil writ.
('3', 73, 1, 12, 143666) (7) The tax is not meant for the purposes of revenue but as a deterrent to future immigrants.
('3', 73, 1, 13, 143760) But, seeing that bona fide refugees only are allowed to enter the Colony, there is no necessity for a deterrent.
('3', 73, 1, 14, 143873) (8) The £3 tax is merely a penalty for wearing the brown skin and it would appear that, whereas Kaffirs are taxed because they do not work at all or sufficiently, we are to be taxed evidently because we work too much, the only thing in common between the two being the absence of the white skin.
('3', 73, 1, 15, 144169) (9) The strangest part of the thing is that there is no demand on the part of the White Leagues for the enforcement of the payment.
('3', 73, 1, 16, 144301) The only thing they want is the banishment of the Indians, if not out of the country altogether, certainly to Locations outside townships.
('3', 73, 1, 17, 144440) His Excellency received a deputation in the matter and gave it a
('3', 74, 0, 1, 144505) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 75
('3', 74, 1, 2, 144545) very long, patient and courteous hearing, but said that he saw no valid reason, in all the grounds enumerated above, for not enforcing the pay ment, that the Government were not unfriendly to the Indians, that while future immigration will most certainly be restricted, he considered that the present population were entitled to fair treatment.
('3', 74, 1, 3, 144890) Replying to other matters raised by the deputation, His Excellency said he was considering in what way the existing law could be replaced, and he could see nothing wrong in a separate Asiatic Office) which was really (he added) in the interests of the Indians.
('3', 74, 1, 4, 145151) His Lordship advised us not to resist payment of the tax and [to] bow to the inevitable.
('3', 74, 1, 5, 145240) Although we respectfully differ from His Excellency regarding the payment of the tax, we have decided to obey His Excellency’s advice, (1) because we are anxious to fall in with the Government whenever it is possible, and (2) because we think that our energy and that of the friends in London should be concentrated on one central point, namely repeal of the existing law.
('3', 74, 1, 6, 145613) As to the Asiatic Office, while His Excellency’s.
('3', 74, 1, 7, 145663) views are very soling as to its being in our interests, so far, in practice, it has proved a veritable yoke since its establishment.

('3', 74, 2, 10, 146080) The foot path bye law is, therefore, in full working order and has naturally created consternation among the Indians in East London.
('3', 74, 2, 11, 146213) It was hoped from the tone of the Town Council’s reply to the Indian protest that the law would not be sys tematically enforced and that cleanlydressed Indians at any rate would not be molested.
('3', 74, 2, 12, 146408) The Secretary of the East London Indian Association has, however, been politely asked by the police to keep off the foot path on pain of being arrested.
('3', 74, 2, 13, 146561) The situation is most cruel.
('3', 74, 2, 14, 146590) Even if Mr. Chamberlain cannot officially interfere with the working of the existing legislation in East London, or the legislation itself, the people there are hoping that he will be graciously pleased to make friendly representations and use his great influence.
('3', 74, 2, 15, 146855) with the Colonists in persuading them to desist from the irritating prosecutions for which there is no justification whatsoever.
('3', 74, 2, 16, 146984) In the meanwhile, the most res

('3', 77, 8, 16, 150892) From the photostat of the original: S. N. 2257.
('3', 77, 9, 17, 150940) 50. OURSELVES 2
('3', 77, 10, 18, 150956) We need offer no apology for making an appearance.
('3', 77, 10, 19, 151007) The Indian community in South Africa is a recognised factor in the body politic, and a newspaper, voicing its feelings, and specially devoted to its cause, would hardly be considered out of place: indeed, we think, it
('3', 77, 11, 20, 151225) 1Vide the preceding item 2 This was Gandhiji’s unsigned editorial in the inaugural issue of Indian Opinion.
('3', 78, 0, 1, 151333) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 79
('3', 78, 1, 2, 151373) would supply a longfelt want.
('3', 78, 1, 3, 151403) The Indians, resident in British South Africa, loyal subjects though they are of the King Emperor, labour under a number of legal disabilities which, it is contended on their behalf, are undeserved and unjust.
('3', 78, 1, 4, 151613) The reason of this state of affairs is to be found in the pre judice in the minds of the Colonists, arising out of misunder standing the actual status of the Indian as a British subject, the close relations that render him kin to Colonists, as the dual title of the Crowned Head so significantly pronounces, and the unhappy forgetfulness of the great services India has always rendered to the Mother Country ever since Providence brought loyal Hind under the flag of Britannia.
('3', 78, 1, 5, 152091) It will be our endeavour, therefore, to remove the misunderstanding by placing facts in their true light before the public.
('3', 78, 1, 6, 152215) We are far from assuming that the Indians here are free from all the faults that are ascribed to them.
('3', 78, 1, 7, 152318) Wherever we find them to be at fault, we will unhesitatingly point it out and suggest means for its removal.
('3', 78, 1, 8, 152427) Our countrymen in South Africa are without the guiding influence of the institutions that exist in India and that impart the necessary moral tone when it is wanting.
('3', 78, 1, 9, 152593) Those that have immigrated as children, or are born in the Colony, have no opportunity of studying the past history of the nation to which they belong, or of knowing its greatness.
('3', 78, 1, 10, 152774) It will be our duty, so far as it may be in our power, to supply these wants by inviting contributions from competent writers in England, in India, and in this subcontinent.
('3', 78, 1, 11, 152948) Time alone will prove our desire to do what is right.
('3', 78, 1, 12, 153002) But we can do very little unaided.
('3', 78, 1, 13, 153037) We rely on generous support from our countrymen; may we hope for it from the great Anglo Saxon race that hails His Majesty Edward VII as King Emperor?
('3', 78, 1, 14, 153188) For, there is nothing in our programme but a desire to promote harmony and good will between the different sections of the one mighty Empire.

('3', 78, 2, 16, 153355) 51. THE BRITISH INDIAN IN SOUTH AFRICA
('3', 78, 3, 17, 153394) The question which we propose to discuss in these columns for the next few weeks is a very large one.
('3', 78, 3, 18, 153496) It is daily growing in importance.
('3', 78, 3, 19, 153531) As with social questions, so with this, it will be readily admitted that prejudice has played not an inconsiderable part: it will be our duty then to steer clear of it, and to deal with the situation
('3', 79, 0, 1, 153731) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 79, 1, 2, 153772) without any bias, and with strict adherence to proved facts.
('3', 79, 1, 3, 153833) No politician worthy of the name can afford to ignore this matter.
('3', 79, 1, 4, 153900) The presence of nearly 100,000 Indians in British South Africa cannot but affect the sub continent for good or for evil.
('3', 79, 1, 5, 154021) What to do with them is a problem on the correct solution of which depends their happiness, and in which every householder is undoubtedly concerned.
('3', 79, 1, 6, 154170) Let us then see what the position is to day.
('3', 79, 1, 7, 154215) In Natal, the Immigration Restriction Act effectually prohibits
('3', 79, 2, 8, 154279) the entry of immigrants unless they have been formerly domiciled in the Colony, or unless they can read and write one of the European languages.
('3', 79, 2, 9, 154424) The Dealers’ Licences Act 1 places the trading class at the mercy of licensing officers who have practically absolute discretion either to grant or withhold trading licences which have to be taken out every year.
('3', 79, 2, 10, 154637) Then there are the vexatious laws about passes 2 under which even respectable persons?
('3', 79, 2, 11, 154724) men and women, may be arrested, during day time or night time, and alike in country places as in towns.
('3', 79, 2, 12, 154828) The question of education is growing in seriousness.
('3', 79, 2, 13, 154881) Public schools are no longer open to Indian children.
('3', 79, 2, 14, 154935) The Government has lately opened two Higher Grade Indian schools, one in Durban and the other in Maritzburg, but the education given there is elementary, and there are no facilities for further studies after the youth has finished his school course.
('3', 79, 2, 15, 155185) In the Capital of the Colony, the Town Council has passed a resolution prohibiting alienation or leasing of townlands to the Indian subjects of His Imperial Majesty the King Emperor.
('3', 79, 2, 16, 155368) And the Prime Minister has sent the Durban Town Council a copy of the recent Transvaal Government Notice No.
('3', 79, 2, 17, 155477) 356 of 1903, dealing with the trading licences and residence of “Asiatics”: 3 this is ominous.
('3', 79, 2, 18, 155572) The presence of a large indentured population further complicates the situation.
('3', 79, 2, 19, 155653) The lot of this population is harder still.
('3', 79, 2, 20, 155697) After it becomes free at the end of full five years’ indenture, it is subject not only to the general laws of the Colony, but also to some special ones.
('3', 79, 2, 21, 155850) Thus, it must either enter into a series of fresh indentures, or return to India, or pay an annual tax, a poll tax, euphemistically described by the legislature as a licence, of £3. A recent Act imposes this hardship also on the major children of indentured immigrants,

('3', 80, 1, 2, 156369) i.e., on girls of 13, and boys of 16 years of age.
('3', 80, 2, 3, 156420) The Cape Colony passed in February last an Immigration Act
('3', 80, 3, 4, 156479) which goes further than the Natal Act in that the education test is so severe that it is possible for an officer to reject even well educated Indians, though it is liberal in another respect in that it keeps the door open for people domiciled not only in the Cape Colony, but in any part of South Africa.
('3', 80, 3, 5, 156784) The Town Council at East London has passed a legislation prohibiting Indians, not owners or occupiers of landed property of the Corporation value of £75, from walking on foot paths, and [conferring] powers to restrict them to Locations.
('3', 80, 3, 6, 157021) In fact, the Municipal Act classes the Indian with the Native of South Africa.
('3', 80, 3, 7, 157100) In the two new Colonies His Majesty’s Government has
('3', 80, 4, 8, 157153) inherited the legislation of the late Republics, which is naturally very drastic.
('3', 80, 4, 9, 157235) It is now being reconsidered, and the whole of it will be recast in the not very distant future.
('3', 80, 4, 10, 157332) However, as the yoke falls most heavily upon Indians in the newly annexed territories, it is worthwhile recapitulating the Republican legislation.
('3', 80, 4, 11, 157479) In the Transvaal, the Indian cannot trade, or reside, or own landed property, except in Locations set apart for him.
('3', 80, 4, 12, 157596) He must pay a registration fee of £3. He may not be out after 9 P.M., and may not walk on the footpaths.
('3', 80, 4, 13, 157701) These are the principal disabilities.
('3', 80, 4, 14, 157739) The licensing measure is being enforced with a severity unknown before.
('3', 80, 4, 15, 157811) In the Orange River Colony, the Indian has no footing except as
('3', 80, 5, 16, 157875) purely and simply a labourer.
('3', 80, 5, 17, 157905) There is this marked distinction, worthy of note, between the Cape Natal legislation and the Republican legislation, namely, that while the former, in theory, is applicable to all nationalities, the latter is especially directed against the Asiatics as such.
('3', 80, 5, 18, 158164) Strong popular prejudice has practically kept the Indian from the other parts of British South Africa.
('3', 80, 5, 19, 158267) Socially and popularly, the Indian is a pariah—in some places less so than in others.
('3', 80, 5, 20, 158353) He is nicknamed “coolie”.
('3', 80, 5, 21, 158379) In fact, popular prejudice has portrayed him as a “filthy being”, without any virtue.
('3', 80, 5, 22, 158465) The prejudice, it must be confessed, has become much toned down in Natal.
('3', 80, 5, 23, 158539) And though the differences between the two communities

('3', 81, 3, 5, 158975) 52. IS IT FAIR?
('3', 81, 4, 6, 158991) If a European commits a crime or a moral delinquency, it is the individual: if it is an Indian, it is the nation.
('3', 81, 4, 7, 159105) This statement has been recently verified in the case of a certain Indian who has seen fit to let houses, taken by him on lease, for immoral purposes.
('3', 81, 4, 8, 159256) For conduct such as this there is absolutely no defence.
('3', 81, 4, 9, 159313) But it is one thing to condemn the individual, and another to justify and advocate res trictions on a whole nation, as the usually sober “Man in the Moon” of Mercury Lane 1 and our esteemed evening contemporary 2 have done, because of the acts of the man referred to above.
('3', 81, 4, 10, 159587) And let it not be forgotten that it is a European landlord who has leased the premises to the Indian in question.
('3', 81, 4, 11, 159701) But the incident ought to serve as a lesson to our countrymen.
('3', 81, 4, 12, 159764) Like Caesar’s wife we must all be above suspicion.
('3', 81, 4, 13, 159815) Living as we are in a country where somehow or other everything against us is immensely magnified, the least of us have to be careful as to what we may do, lest we may stultify the whole community.
('3', 81, 4, 14, 160013) Indian Opinion, 4 6 1903
('3', 81, 5, 15, 160038) 53. VIRTUOUS INCONSISTENCY
('3', 81, 6, 16, 160065) Foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds, said Emerson.
('3', 81, 6, 17, 160133) Evidently the Transvaal Government thinks that uniform treatment during a plague scare would be ‘foolish consistency’.
('3', 81, 6, 18, 160252) Therefore it has ruled that no Indian from Natal is to enter the Transvaal, while Europeans and Kaffirs are allowed in without res trictions, despite the fact that the plague has not respected persons, and has been foolishly consistent in attacking all the three races inhabiting Natal.
('3', 81, 6, 19, 160539) The Indian may be forgiven if, therefore, he arrives at the conclusion that the embargo placed on him is more in the nature of a
('3', 81, 7, 20, 160668) 1A weekly columnist of The Natal Mercury: 2The Natal Advertiser.
('3', 82, 0, 1, 160733) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 83
('3', 82, 1, 2, 160773) political closure than a precaution in the interests of public health.
('3', 82, 1, 3, 160844) During the first stages of the scare, perhaps the restriction was excusable, in view of the popular prejudice.
('3', 82, 1, 4, 160955) But a deliberate prohibition against Indians only, without the option of temporary quarantine, in the face of the fact that the plague is now, let us hope so, dying out, and that it has not progressed in all these months beyond the Capital, may be virtuous inconsistency, but to the victims of the embargo it becomes a very serious matter indeed.
('3', 82, 1, 5, 161302) Refugees, and others who have connection with the Transvaal, suffer great loss and inconvenience.
('3', 82, 1, 6, 161400) May we appeal to the local Government to obtain some measure of relief from such manifest injustice against a portion of the inhabitants of Natal, Indians though they may be?
('3', 82, 1, 7, 161575) Fair play is the great characteristic of the British race; and we ask every true Britisher to say whether the onesided treatment described above is a sample of fair play.

('3', 84, 3, 5, 165731) 56. MINUTE BY THE MAYOR
('3', 84, 4, 6, 165755) The statement 3 made by the Mayor of Durban in Committee of the Whole Council on Tuesday last, which we reproduce below, seems to be a premature effort to introduce into Natal the repugnant old laws temporarily revived in the Transvaal, regarding Asiatic segregation, laws that roused the righteous indignation of the British Government before the War, and are being considered by the Imperial Govern ment.

('3', 84, 5, 8, 166362) THE MINUTE
('3', 84, 6, 9, 166373) The Hon.
('3', 84, 6, 10, 166382) the Prime Minister has been good enough to forward copy of resolution passed by the Transvaal Executive Council, prescribing the principles to be adopted in dealing with applications for trading licences by Asiatics, which may be summarised under four headings, viz., (I) to provide for the allocation of Asiatics for trading and residential purposes in bazaars; (2) to restrict all new licences to premises in such bazaars; (3) to provide that existing licences outside the bazaars shall not be transferred to any other Asiatic trader, and that the holders of such licences shall not have more licences in any one town than they hold on a given date; and (4) permitting Asiatics, under certain circumstances in regard to method of living, to reside outside such bazaars.
('3', 84, 7, 11, 167154) We have now had six years in which to prove the success or failure in this borough of the legislation introduced in 1897, and I regret to have to confess that we have not experienced the benefits that were anticipated from that legislation —I refer to the Immigration Restriction Act, 1897, and’ Act 18 of 1897, “To amend the law relating to licences to wholesale and retail dealers.”
('3', 84, 8, 12, 167539) During the past six years, there have been very marked increases in the number of licences held by Asiatics, and we now find that in the main streets of the borough,
('3', 84, 9, 13, 167705) 1Vide the succeeding item.
('3', 84, 9, 14, 167732) 2Vide “The Lion and the Lamb”, 11 6 1903. 3 The reference is to the minute which follows this editorial note by Gandhiji.
('3', 85, 0, 1, 167854) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 85, 1, 2, 167895) large blocks of valuable property are held by Asiatics, that they are daily acquiring other properties, and that many new buildings are being erected for trade purposes by Asiatics, which buildings under the existing laws will, in all probability, be licensed, because such laws will not permit of applications for licenses being arbitrarily refused.
('3', 85, 2, 3, 168246) It is impossible to overlook the fact that, by permitting these people to reside and carry on business in every part of the borough, we are perpetuating a very serious menace to the health of the community.
('3', 85, 2, 4, 168453) In this connection, I need only refer to the preponderance of cases of bubonic plague, which have occurred amongst Indians, to prove that the habits of these people are not conducive to the health of the borough.
('3', 85, 2, 5, 168666) I find that out of the 160 cases of plague to date, no fewer than 93 were Asiatic cases.
('3', 85, 2, 6, 168755) Although the leading representatives of the Indian community have rendered very great assistance to the Health Department duing the outbreak of plague, yet, owing to the customs of the race, considerable difficulty has been experienced in carrying out sanitary requirements, and these difficulties would, to a large extent, be overcome, if all Indians living in the town were required to reside in a given area.
('3', 85, 2, 7, 169167) I do not anticipate any grave trouble in selecting a suit.
('3', 85, 2, 8, 169226) able neighbourhood as an Asiatic quarter.
('3', 85, 3, 9, 169268) The Asiatic owners of premises in West Street, Smith Street, Pine Street, Commercial Road, Railway Street, and elsewhere, have no vested right in the licences under which they trade, as, for good and sufficient reasons, these and other licences might not be renewed at the end of any given year.
('3', 85, 3, 10, 169564) So, far from being a hardship, I consider it would be an advantage to the Indians themselves if their business premises and habitations were congregated together in a special area, instead of being distributed over the whole length and breadth of the borough, as at present.
('3', 85, 3, 11, 169839) It might be somewhat harsh if existing licences were cancelled forthwith, but by permitting the present licensees to continue to hold licences for the same premises at present occupied during their lifetime, subject, of course, to their being kept in a thoroughly sanitary condition, I think justice would be done them.
('3', 85, 3, 12, 170159) Under no circumstances, however, should the existing licences be transferred to other Indians, and, to secure this, it would be necessary to have a proper register kept of all Indians in the borough.
('3', 85, 4, 13, 170359) After giving the matter very careful consideration, it appears to me that the time has arrived when this Council should petition Government to introduce legislation, on somewhat similar lines as the laws in force in the Transvaal, in order to safeguard the health and trade interests not only of Durban, but of the whole Colony, and I would urge that no time be lost in approaching Government, as it is only to be expected that the effect of the new Transvaal regulations will be to encourage Asiatics to leave that Colony in favour of Natal, where they may, under
('3', 86, 0, 1, 170924) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 87
('3', 86, 1, 2, 170964) present conditions, conduct their businesses and reside in any part of the borough they may choose.
('3', 86, 1, 3, 171064) Should Government be prepared to introduce the necessary legislation to put the Colony upon an equal footing with the Transvaal in the method of dealing with Asiatics, I would suggest that the Bill should provide:
('3', 86, 2, 4, 171278) 1. For the registration of all Asiatics in boroughs or townships in a similar manner, as provided by the Transvaal Law 3 of 1885.
('3', 86, 3, 5, 171408) 2. That Asiatic bazaars (or locations) be set apart by the municipal authorities in which shall reside all Asiatics, other than domestic servants in the employ of Europeans, or employees of Government, corporations, or firms providing suitable barrack accommodation.
('3', 86, 4, 6, 171675) 3. That no new licences shall be granted to Asiatics except to carry on business in such bazaars.
('3', 86, 5, 7, 171773) 4. That existing licences held by Asiatics be not transferred to other Asiatics, but on the decease of present licensees they be cancelled forthwith.
('3', 86, 6, 8, 171923) 5. That no Asiatic shall be permitted to hold more licences than held by him on the date of the promulgation of the Bill.
('3', 86, 7, 9, 172045) 6. That any Asiatic who shall prove to the satisfaction of the Colonial Secretary that he holds any high educational certificate from the Education Department in this or any other British Colony or dependency, or that he is able and willing to adopt a mode of living not repugnant to European ideas, nor in conflict with sanitary laws, may apply to the Colonial Secretary for a letter of exemption which shall enable him to reside elsewhere than in a place specially set apart for Asiatics.
('3', 86, 8, 10, 172536) Legislation on these lines would not have the effect of at once removing Asiatic businesses from our main streets, but it would preclude additional licences being granted there, and, if, simultaneously with the provision of native locations, we are enabled to compel all Asiatics to reside in bazaars (irrespective of where their business premises may be situated), we shall have accomplished an end which will be the means of improving the sanitary condition of our borough to a greater extent than is possible under any other conditions.
