('3', 89, 0, 1, 177154) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 89, 1, 2, 177195) 59. PETITION TO TRANSVAAL GOVERNOR
('3', 89, 2, 3, 177230) THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('3', 89, 3, 4, 177261) 25 & 26, COURT CHAMBERS, RISSIK STREET, JOHANNESBURG, June 8, 1903
('3', 89, 4, 5, 177328) TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE GOVERNOR OF THE TRANSVAAL JOHANNESBURG
('3', 89, 5, 6, 177414) SIR, This Association ventures to approach His Excellency regarding the various points submitted to His Excellency by the Deputation which he was graciously pleased to receive on the 22nd May last.
('3', 89, 5, 7, 177612) The Committee of the Association feels that during the time that was at its disposal the Deputation could not sufficiently explain some of the points, nor could it give a humble reply to His Excellency’s address.
('3', 89, 5, 8, 177825) Before proceeding to discuss those points, the Committee of the Association begs respectfully to thank His Excellency for the long, patient and courteous hearing that His Excellency was pleased to grant to the Deputation, and for His Excellency’s sympathetic reply.
('3', 89, 6, 9, 178091) I THE ASIATIC OFFICE With the greatest deference to His Excellency, my Committee still ventures to think that, as at present worked, it constitutes a heavy burden on the Indian community, and an unnecessary tax on the revenues of the Colony.
('3', 89, 6, 10, 178333) In making remarks about its working, my Committee disclaims any intention to reflect on any of the Supervisors.
('3', 89, 6, 11, 178445) (a) The Asiatic Office has caused a great deal of hardship in the matter of permits.
('3', 89, 6, 12, 178530) His Excellency was pleased to say that at one time too many permits were being issued to Indians.
('3', 89, 6, 13, 178628) But my Committee begs to say that, with perhaps isolated exceptions, permits have never been so far granted to non refugee Indians.
('3', 89, 6, 14, 178760) During a few days after the passing of the Peace Preservation Ordinance, the Railway Authorities, thinking
('3', 90, 0, 1, 178867) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 91
('3', 90, 1, 2, 178907) that there were no permits compulsorily required, issued railway tickets without production of permits, and there was no inspection thereof on the border towns.
('3', 90, 1, 3, 179068) The result was that several Indians, quite unconscious of the fact that they were committing a breach of the law, were able to enter the Colony.
('3', 90, 1, 4, 179213) These have been prosecuted and given notices to depart from the Colony.
('3', 90, 1, 5, 179285) The entry of the Indians in the above manner, therefore, does not affect the question of the harsh working of that office.
('3', 90, 1, 6, 179408) Unlike Europeans, owing to the establishment of the Asiatic Office, the Indians cannot obtain permits unless they apply nominally to the Colonial Secretary, but virtually to the Asiatic Office.
('3', 90, 1, 7, 179602) But the Supervisors of these offices have no power to grant the permits.
('3', 90, 1, 8, 179675) They merely recommend them.
('3', 90, 1, 9, 179703) The General Permit Officers then, but not till then, grant the permits thus recommended, at the coast towns.
('3', 90, 1, 10, 179812) The evidence as to the bona fides of the applicant produced before the Asiatic Office is exactly the same that would be produced before the General Permit Officer at the coast.
('3', 90, 1, 11, 179989) The difference is that the officer on the coast can see the applicant face to face and weigh the evidence he may produce.
('3', 90, 1, 12, 180111) Not so the Supervisor who has to judge from a distance of several hundred miles.
('3', 90, 1, 13, 180192) The procedure, without being of any use, involves an unnecessary waste of time.
('3', 90, 1, 14, 180272) It takes, as a rule, three months before an Indian applicant has his permit granted.
('3', 90, 1, 15, 180357) In several cases, a month has been known to elapse before the permits were granted after recommendation.
('3', 90, 1, 16, 180462) If, therefore, the Office is in the interests of the Indian community, it has evidently not fulfilled its purpose so far as permits are concerned.
('3', 90, 1, 17, 180609) It has meant a great deal of worry and legal expense.
('3', 90, 1, 18, 180663) (b) The Asiatic Office introduced a system of passes which has been proved to be utterly useless.
('3', 90, 1, 19, 180761) The Asiatic Office, having no jurisdiction over the Indians save such as it could invent for itself, instituted quite gratuitously a system of passes.
('3', 90, 1, 20, 180912) Every Indian who arrived in the Colony was.
('3', 90, 1, 21, 180956) deprived ofhis permit and was given an Asiatic pass, the only use of which was to have the name of every Indian arrival on the register of the Office, which, as a matter of fact, it already had, in that the permits were issued after its recommendation.
('3', 90, 1, 22, 181209) Whereas the permits were and are of a permanent character, entitling the holder to move about freely and leave and re enter the Colony, the passes were of a temporary duration
('3', 91, 0, 1, 181385) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 91, 1, 2, 181426) and of no effect for the purpose of leaving and re entering.
('3', 91, 1, 3, 181487) Thus, as soon as the Indian entered the Colony, he found: his freedom of movement much curtailed.
('3', 91, 1, 4, 181585) Unscrupulous Indians and Europeans were not found wanting to take advantage of the pass system; and abuse resulted very largely.
('3', 91, 1, 5, 181714) As soon, therefore, as the Ordinance to amend the Peace Preservation Act was passed, the Chief Secretary for Permits issued instructions that the Asiatic passes were to be exchanged for permits.
('3', 91, 1, 6, 181909) While the intention of granting permits was in itself good, the way in which it was carried out amounted to a cruel persecution of thousands of Indians in Johannesburg, Potchefstroom and Heidelberg.
('3', 91, 1, 7, 182108) My Committee need not dwell on it, as it is occupying the attention of the Colonial Secretary.
('3', 91, 1, 8, 182203) The point is that, but for the existence of the Asiatic Office, such a thing would have been an impossibility.
('3', 91, 1, 9, 182314) And now, notwithstanding the existence of that Office, the Government have found it necessary—my Committee knows not why—to appoint a new Registrar of Asiatics independent of the Asia tic Office.
('3', 91, 1, 10, 182510) His Excellency was pleased to say, in justifying the registration tax, that registration was useful.
('3', 91, 1, 11, 182611) My Committee has loyally accepted His Excellency’s advice and does not now wish to re open it, save in so far as it is necessary to illustrate the present argument.
('3', 91, 1, 12, 182776) As a matter of fact, then, registration was once made, as said ‘above, by the Asiatic Office.
('3', 91, 1, 13, 182870) It was made for the second time, as also said above, by the Chief Secretary for Permits.
('3', 91, 1, 14, 182959) It is now being done for the third time.
('3', 91, 1, 15, 183000) The enforcing of the Law 3 of 1885 does not, in my Committee’s humble opinion, necessitate the elaborate registration that has now been undertaken.
('3', 91, 1, 16, 183148) The £3 could have been collected without it from those that did not pay the amount during the old regime.
('3', 91, 1, 17, 183254) But a separate Office has given rise to the arrangements made on the large but, in my Committee’s humble opinion, useless scale.
('3', 91, 1, 18, 183383) (c) The Asiatic Office has unnecessarily interfered with the Licensing Office.
('3', 91, 1, 19, 183462) An Indian trader or hawker may not take out his license without the recommendation of the Asiatic Office.
('3', 91, 1, 20, 183568) There is nothing in the law to justify it.
('3', 91, 1, 21, 183611) But departmental instructions seem to have been issued to Revenue Officers not to issue them without such recommendations.
('3', 91, 1, 22, 183734) Why the recommendation is required, my Committee is at a loss to understand.
('3', 91, 1, 23, 183811) The applicant in any case produces his permit and makes
('3', 92, 0, 1, 183867) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 93
('3', 92, 1, 2, 183907) the usual declaration before he is granted his license.
('3', 92, 1, 3, 183963) If it is intended to identify the applicant with the permit and his declaration, the Asiatic Office is in nobetter position than the Revenue Officers to do so.
('3', 92, 1, 4, 184123) Fraud in such cases is in the very nature of the thing practically impossible.
('3', 92, 1, 5, 184202) (d) The Asiatic Of/ice is responsible for the institution of photographic passes.
('3', 92, 1, 6, 184284) As if the hold of that Office on the Indian were incomplete, the system of visiting passes has been lately instituted, which interferes with the movement of the Indian—a system, moreover, for which there is no warrant in law.
('3', 92, 1, 7, 184510) The above completes the functions of the Asiatic Office.
('3', 92, 1, 8, 184567) (e) The Asiatic Office is an unnecessary burden on the Revenue.
('3', 92, 1, 9, 184631) That the Office is an unnecessary waste of public money will have been seen from the foregoing.
('3', 92, 1, 10, 184727) For, if the authorised number of permits could as well, if not better, be issued by the officers at the different coast towns without the recommendation of the Asiatic Office, if the Revenue Officers could be trusted to issue licenses to British Indians in the usual manner, there is nothing left for the Asiatic Office to do.
('3', 92, 1, 11, 185054) (f) Such a Department does not exist either at the Cape or Natal, where there is a far larger Indian population.
('3', 92, 1, 12, 185167) Moreover, no such Office has been found necessary at the Cape or Natal, where there is a far larger Indian population than in the Transvaal.
('3', 92, 1, 13, 185308) In Natal there is an Office of the Protector of Indian Immigrants, but that office has jurisdiction only over the indentured Indian population, and has absolutely no control over the free Indian population.
('3', 92, 1, 14, 185515) And what is perhaps more, such a want was never felt by the old Government of the Transvaal.
('3', 92, 1, 15, 185608) (g) The Asiatic Office does not do away with the approach to the other ordinary Departments.
('3', 92, 1, 16, 185701) His Excellency was pleased to say that the Asiatic Office was necessary, in order that the Indians may have an easy access to officers who were solely devoted to Asiatic affairs, and might avoid having to go to other offices at all.
('3', 92, 1, 17, 185934) Such, however, is not the case, for the intervention of the Asiatic Office is merely an additional burden, and does not in any case do away with the approach to the other
('3', 93, 0, 1, 186105) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 93, 1, 2, 186146) officials.
('3', 93, 1, 3, 186157) My Committee, therefore, ventures to hope that it has succeeded in convincing His Excellency that the Office is unnecessary in every way.
('3', 93, 1, 4, 186295) Indeed, when it was first established, it was intended to be a temporary institution, and in any case it would have little left to do, as soon as the permit system is abolished.
('3', 93, 2, 5, 186473) II THE BAZAAR NOTICE
('3', 93, 3, 6, 186494) The Association is grateful for the liberal construction that has been put upon the Notice No.
('3', 93, 3, 7, 186589) 356 of 1903, which lays down the principle of Bazaars.
('3', 93, 3, 8, 186644) But the notice, it is respectfully submitted, is still open to objection on two grounds: (1) Because it implies compulsory segregation and restriction on trade merely to Bazaars.
('3', 93, 3, 9, 186823) (2) Because in its working it will give rise to great hardships.
('3', 93, 3, 10, 186888) As to the first ground, the Association would humbly point out that compulsion of any kind is contrary to the principles of justice, when it is intended to restrict freedom.
('3', 93, 3, 11, 187062) It has been often said that the Indians ought not to object to Bazaars, because they are used to them in India.
('3', 93, 3, 12, 187174) With deference, the Association would draw His Excellency’s attention to the fact that an Indian bazaar is situated in the very heart of a town and is the busiest portion of it, and, in any case, there is no compulsion on any man to trade in bazaars.
('3', 93, 3, 13, 187425) Needless to say, an Indian bazaar is never a place of residence.
('3', 93, 3, 14, 187490) In fact, any place where trade is carried on is called a bazaar, and is by no means restricted to a particular class.
('3', 93, 3, 15, 187608) Under the notice in question, the Bazaar is merely a euphemism for the Location, and is meant both for trade and residence.
('3', 93, 3, 16, 187732) That the Government themselves do not consider the Bazaars to be of much respectability or consequence is evidenced by the fact that the pre war Indian traders are not to be compelled to remove to Bazaars, and that Indians of education and position may be exempted from having to reside in them.
('3', 93, 3, 17, 188028) Nor will the Transvaal Bazaars, unlike the bona fide bazaars of India, be centrally situated.
('3', 93, 3, 18, 188122) That the Bazaars are to be located within town limits would not, the Association may be pardoned for saying, be in any way a lenient construction of the existing law, for it clearly contemplates the setting aside of streets and wards which could only be in towns.
('3', 93, 3, 19, 188386) Again, the streets, wards, or Locations are, according to the law, to be set apart for
('3', 94, 0, 1, 188473) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 95
('3', 94, 1, 2, 188513) residence.
('3', 94, 1, 3, 188524) Trade is not mentioned in it at all.
('3', 94, 1, 4, 188561) It is, therefore, the Association submits, a strained construction to confine Indian trade to Bazaars only.
('3', 94, 1, 5, 188669) The Association is aware that the High Court of the late Republic has laid down that the term “residence” shall include “trade” also for the purpose of construing the law.
('3', 94, 1, 6, 188841) That decision was not unanimous—Mr. Justice Morice being the dissenting judge.
('3', 94, 1, 7, 188920) And the Association submits that it is hardly a lenient interpretation of the statute to enforce the above decision, in view as well of the fact of the dissent as of the fact that the British Government always protested against any such interpretation even when they felt compelled to accept the law itself.
('3', 94, 1, 8, 189228) His Excellency was pleased to say that new legislation is under consideration.
('3', 94, 1, 9, 189307) If so, the Association fails to see any occasion for enforcing the law at present.
('3', 94, 1, 10, 189390) Very few Indians are being allowed to enter the Colony.
('3', 94, 1, 11, 189446) Those who traded before the war are to have the right to trade outside Locations renewed.
('3', 94, 1, 12, 189536) The new applicants, therefore, may be treated as the Government may think fit, pending legislation.
('3', 94, 1, 13, 189636) The White League has taken strong exception to the Bazaars being established within town limits.
('3', 94, 1, 14, 189733) If it is wrong to issue trading licenses to Indians in towns generally, it is none the less wrong be cause it is issued in a portion of the town which is called a Bazaar.
('3', 94, 1, 15, 189904) The Association, therefore, fears that if the Bazaars are established accor ding to the intention of the Government in accessible parts of towns, the agitation against Indians would continue.
('3', 94, 1, 16, 190096) The Association, therefore, submits that, looked at from any point of view, the principle of the Bazaar is unsatisfactory.
('3', 94, 1, 17, 190219) While the Association does not admit that there is any fear of overtrading on the part of the Indians, the best solution of the difficulty would be in powers being given to the municipalities to control the granting of new licenses to trade, subject to revision of their decision by the Supreme Court.
('3', 94, 1, 18, 190521) Thus, the existing licenses, so long as the law as to sanitation, proper book keeping, etc., is observed, would be untouched by them, and the granting of new licenses, whether European or Indian, would practically depend upon the municipality, which represents the will of the people.
('3', 94, 1, 19, 190806) With such a law, without any competition, each community would be automatically separated in distinct localities.
('3', 94, 1, 20, 190920) The class of buildings could be improved from year to year, and the whole tone of the community
('3', 95, 0, 1, 191016) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 95, 1, 2, 191057) raised and no offence given to any portion of it.
('3', 95, 1, 3, 191107) For the Association firmly believes that, if a good portion of a town were selected and Indians given the choice of going there, a large number would be found willing to avail themselves of the choice without any compulsion.
('3', 95, 1, 4, 191332) Coming to the second ground, the notice in question seriously affects the vested interests which the Government intend to protect, in that (1) it does not respect all the existing Indian licenses; (2) it does not give the right of transfer of licenses from man to man outside Bazaars; (3) it is not clear whether only those who held licenses to trade outside Bazaars are alone to have their licenses renewed, or all who traded outside Bazaars before the war whether with or without licenses; (4) it is not clear whether, in the case of a firm trading before war outside Bazaars, all the partners are to be entitled to a renewal or only one of them; (5) it contemplates exemption only in respect of residence.
('3', 95, 1, 5, 192041) The Association would crave leave to discuss shortly all the points mentioned above.
('3', 95, 1, 6, 192126) (1) It does not respect all the existing Indian licenses.
('3', 95, 1, 7, 192184) Too much stress cannot be laid on this point, which practically means a matter of life and death to many present license holders.
('3', 95, 1, 8, 192314) Some Indian refugees who returned to the Transvaal with permits received licenses to trade in towns in which they were not trading before.
('3', 95, 1, 9, 192453) These they received from British Officers for the full year without condition.
('3', 95, 1, 10, 192532) But towards the end of last year, in some towns, the magistrates gave notices that such licenses would not be renewed.
('3', 95, 1, 11, 192651) The matter was specifically brought to Mr. Chamberlain’s notice by the Indian Deputation that waited on him.
('3', 95, 1, 12, 192760) And he emphatically assured it that such licenses would be respected and renewed.
('3', 95, 1, 13, 192842) Yet, the notice in question would relegate all such traders to Bazaars at the end of the year.
('3', 95, 1, 14, 192937) The matter was brought by the Deputation to His Excellency’s notice, who was pleased to say that he would consider the point.
('3', 95, 1, 15, 193063) In the opinion of the Association, such traders with, in some cases, long established businesses, having entered into long leases of premises and built upon them, never suspecting that, under British
('3', 96, 0, 1, 193263) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 97
('3', 96, 1, 2, 193303) rule, their tenure of licenses could be assailed, are entitled, if possible, to greater consideration than those old license holders who have not yet returned to the Colony, but whose rights are respected because they traded outside Bazaars before the war.
('3', 96, 1, 3, 193560) In the one case, the new man has an established business; in the other, the man, though an old trader, has to.
('3', 96, 1, 4, 193671) start de novo.
('3', 96, 1, 5, 193686) The Association, therefore, trusts that, irrespective of any decision His Excellency may arrive at on the other points, this at any rate will be decided favourably to the men in question.
('3', 96, 1, 6, 193874) (2) It does not give the right of transfer of licenses outside Bazaars.
('3', 96, 1, 7, 193946) The notice respects the rights of those who traded before the war, and it does not; for it authorises a renewal up to the time of the residence of the holder.
('3', 96, 1, 8, 194105) As soon as he thinks that his business is in a flourishing condition, he has established a goodwill and may well retire, the full fruition of honest labour is snatched from the lips.
('3', 96, 1, 9, 194288) He cannot sell his business, as his license is not transferable, as a going concern.
('3', 96, 1, 10, 194373) What the deprivation of this simple right of a tradesman means, it is unnecessary for the Association to dwell upon.
('3', 96, 1, 11, 194490) If the vested interests are, therefore, to be really respected, the Association ventures to think that the right of transfer should be recognised.
('3', 96, 1, 12, 194637) The point has been brought out by Mr. William Hosken and other European gentlemen of standing, who have presented a petition to His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor on the Notice, and which is hereinafter more fully referred to, and a copy of which is attached hereto.
('3', 96, 2, 13, 194908) (3) It is not clear whether only those who held licenses to trade outside Bazaars are alone to have their licenses renewed, or all who traded outside Bazaars before war, whether with or without licenses.
('3', 96, 2, 14, 195112) This is an important point.
('3', 96, 2, 15, 195140) There were many Indians who, though they traded before the war, had no licenses issued to them.
('3', 96, 2, 16, 195236) Very few held licenses.
('3', 96, 2, 17, 195260) Many traded on the tender of license money, and some in the name of white men—all with the knowledge of the authorities.
('3', 96, 2, 18, 195381) Such a state of things was tolerated because of the pressure from the British Govornment.
('3', 96, 2, 19, 195471) Now the preamble of the Notice says “with due regard to the vested interests of those Asiatics who were
('3', 96, 3, 20, 195575) 1 This is not given here; vide “Letter to Lieutenant Governor”1 5 1903
('3', 97, 0, 1, 195646) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 97, 1, 2, 195687) trading outside Bazaars at the commencement of hostilities”.
('3', 97, 1, 3, 195748) But the 3rd Clause speaks of Asiatic traders “who held licenses at the commencement’,, etc.
('3', 97, 1, 4, 195840) Many Indians, therefore, would suffer if the exception is restricted to those only who held licenses before the war, as distinguished from those who traded before war.
('3', 97, 1, 5, 196008) (4) It is not clear whether in the case of a firm trading before waroutside Bazaars, all the partners are to be entitled to a renewal or only one of them.
('3', 97, 1, 6, 196163) This point is left open by the Notice.
('3', 97, 1, 7, 196202) It would be manifestly unjust to allow a license to one partner who may come first, and refuse it to another or others.
('3', 97, 1, 8, 196322) All traded before the war, and if a license was issued, all had an equal right to it.
('3', 97, 1, 9, 196408) (5) It contemplates exemption only in respect of residence.
('3', 97, 1, 10, 196468) To the Indian community, the whole principle of exemption is a sore point.
('3', 97, 1, 11, 196543) Why an Indian should have to take out an exemption and thus pose as superior to his other countrymen, before he can reside anywhere he likes on British soil, is difficult to understand.
('3', 97, 1, 12, 196729) But, accommodating oneself to such (if the Association may be excused the use of the term) an offensive principle for the sake of argument, the exemption only applies to residence.
('3', 97, 1, 13, 196910) His Excellency was inclined to think that the exemption extended to trade as well as residence.
('3', 97, 1, 14, 197006) But the Notice clearly limits it to residence.
('3', 97, 1, 15, 197053) There would be some value in it, if it was meant to be an exemption from the whole Law 3 of l 885 .
('3', 97, 1, 16, 197153) But the Association is anxious not to labour the point.
('3', 97, 1, 17, 197209) Its respectful protest is against the whole Notice.
('3', 97, 1, 18, 197261) In its opinion, it is a departure from the Declaration of Her late Majesty’s Government, is unnecessary in view of impending new legislation, is full of ambiguity and leaves the Indian community in practically the same state of suspense under which it has been for the last 15 years, and from which it had a right to be free on the establishment of the British Government, which entered on the costly war, if mainly for the redress of the grievances of the European Uitlander, not a little also for the redress of those of the Indian.
('3', 97, 2, 19, 197796) III PROHIBITION TO HOLD LANDED PROPERTY SAVE IN LOCATIONS
('3', 97, 3, 20, 197854) The Law 3 of 1885 prevents Indians from owning landed property in the Colony except in streets, wards and Locations pointed out by Government.
('3', 97, 3, 21, 197997) The Association respectfully considers the
('3', 98, 0, 1, 198040) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 99
('3', 98, 1, 2, 198080) prohibition a serious hardship and injury to the loyal British Indians.
('3', 98, 1, 3, 198152) That a British subject cannot buy a piece of land where he likes in British territories is a thing extremely difficult to understand.
('3', 98, 1, 4, 198286) The Association is hoping that this disability would be removed by the new legislation that is now being considered and, therefore, refrains from making any further remarks on the question.
('3', 98, 2, 5, 198476) IV His Excellency was pleased to say that every State had a right to choose its citizens, a principle which the Association has always admitted, and still does admit.
('3', 98, 2, 6, 198643) But, in the opinion of the Association, there is no fear of an Asiatic influx into the Colony.
('3', 98, 2, 7, 198738) There are very stringent restrictive laws in force in the maritime Colonies of South Africa.
('3', 98, 2, 8, 198831) That fact, coupledwith the disinclination of the ordinary Indian to emigrate from India, are a substantial bar to any undue influx of Indians.
('3', 98, 2, 9, 198974) But the European Colonists think otherwise.
('3', 98, 2, 10, 199018) The chief reason for coercive legislation is this fear of the influx.
('3', 98, 2, 11, 199088) The Association, therefore, would accept without demur any legislation of a restrictive character which is applicable to all, does not recognise colour distinc tion, and leaves the door open for a respectable class of Indians, and such Indians as may be necessary for the business of Indians established in the Colony.
('3', 98, 2, 12, 199407) In the petition horeinbefore referred to, Mr. William Hosken and the other petitioners have suggested the adoption of the Natal or the Cape Immigration Restriction Act, with certain modifications.
('3', 98, 2, 13, 199604) The Association would gladly accept the solution proposed by the gentlemen, provided that the educational test recognises a knowledge of the principal Indian languages, and the Law gives authority to the officer to grant special permission to servants, managers and others, even if it be for a limited term, who may be required for the local Indian merchants.
('3', 98, 3, 14, 199964) CONCLUSION The welfare of the British Indians in South Africa is in His Excellency’s hands.
('3', 98, 3, 15, 200056) The Bazaar Notice is already having a far reaching effect in other parts of South Africa, and if the rights of the Indians are curtailed, or legislation on colour distinction is introduced in this Crown Colony, and that at the hands of His Excellency, holding the dual position of High Commissioner and Governor, and occupying a very large place in the hearts of the people of South Africa, the self governing Colonies of the Cape of
('3', 99, 0, 1, 200490) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 99, 1, 2, 200532) Good Hope and Natal will not be slow to copy any such legislation.
('3', 99, 1, 3, 200599) In the humble opinion of the Association, it is only partially true that this country has been won by the white man.
('3', 99, 1, 4, 200716) The arrival of the Indian Contingent at the nick of time was no mean contribution to the war from India.
('3', 99, 1, 5, 200821) Nor did the Contingent consist wholly of white men; it had a large number of dhooley bearers and other followers who were just as useful, and who braved the perils just as much as the soldiers.
('3', 99, 1, 6, 201015) The local Indians were not behindhand in doing their duty.
('3', 99, 1, 7, 201074) Indian soldiers are fighting the Empire’s battles in many parts of the world.
('3', 99, 1, 8, 201152) The Indians are taught from their infancy the principle of equality between British subjects in the eye of the law.
('3', 99, 1, 9, 201268) The people of India received their charter of liberty in 1857, 1 after the termination of a sanguinary strife, in which, it has often been acknowledged, the sterling loyalty of the people at large, put to a most severe test, saved India for the Empire.
('3', 99, 1, 10, 201521) What the British Indians pray for is very little.
('3', 99, 1, 11, 201571) They ask for no political power.
('3', 99, 1, 12, 201604) They admit the British race should be the dominant race in South Africa.
('3', 99, 1, 13, 201677) They admit the principle of restricting the influx of cheap labour, no matter from which source it may come.
('3', 99, 1, 14, 201786) All they ask for is freedom for those that are now settled and those that may be allowed to come in future to trade, to move about, and to hold landed property without any hindrance save the ordinary legal requirements.
('3', 99, 1, 15, 202006) And they ask for abrogation of legislation that imposes disabilities on them because they wear a brown skin.
('3', 99, 1, 16, 202115) The white inhabitants, or a portion of them, do indeed ask for drastic legislation against the Indians, and they are strong.
('3', 99, 1, 17, 202240) The Indians are weak.
('3', 99, 1, 18, 202262) But the British Government has always been known to protect the weak.
('3', 99, 1, 19, 202332) The Association humbly appeals to His Excellency to extend that pro tection to the community and grant its prayer.
('3', 99, 2, 20, 202447) I have the honour to remain, Sir, your obedient servant, ABDUL GANI, CHAIRMAN, [THE] BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION From the photostat of the original printed copy: C. W. 2940, India Office: Judicial and Public Records, 402, and Indian Opinion, 18 6 1903.

('3', 100, 1, 2, 202803) 60. PETITION TO NATAL LEGISLATURE
('3', 100, 2, 3, 202837) THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION 25 & 26, COURT CHAMBERS, RISSIK STREET, JOHANNESBURG, June 10, 1903
('3', 100, 3, 4, 202936) TO THE HONOURABLE THE PRESIDENT AND MEMBERS OF
('3', 100, 4, 5, 202983) THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL OF THE COLONY OF THE TRANSVAAL PRETORIA
('3', 100, 5, 6, 203047) THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED ABDUL GANI IN HIS CAPACITY AS CHAIRMAN OF THE BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION
('3', 100, 6, 7, 203152) HUMBLY SHEWETH THAT, Your Petitioner is the Chairman of the British Indian Association which represents the British Indians residing in the Transvaal.
('3', 100, 6, 8, 203303) Your Petitioner, on behalf of the Association above named, res pectfully protests.
('3', 100, 6, 9, 203386) against the amendment made in clause No l1 of the Draft Ordinance for Elective Municipal Councils now under con sideration by this Honourable House.
('3', 100, 6, 10, 203535) The amendment, imposing as it does a disqualification from becoming Voters at the election of Town Councillors on the British Indians among others, casts a slur on the ancient and loyal Indian race.
('3', 100, 6, 11, 203734) The Indian community has followed, not without a great deal of pain, the debate in this Honourable House on the clause in question, in that they have been treated on a footing of equality with the Natives of South Africa.
('3', 100, 6, 12, 203956) Your Petitioner begs leave respectfully to remind this Honourable House that the Indian nation has been used to Municipal self government for ages past, as the following from Sir Henry Sumner Maine’s works would show.
('3', 100, 7, 13, 204174) It does not appear to me a hazardous proposition that the Indian and the ancient European systems of enjoyment and tillage by men grouped in village communities are in all essential particulars identical.
('3', 100, 8, 14, 204379) No Indian phenomenon has been more carefully examined, and by men more thoroughly in earnest, than the village community.
('3', 100, 8, 15, 204501) For many years past
('3', 101, 0, 1, 204521) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 101, 1, 2, 204563) the discovery and recognition of its existence have ranked among the greatest achievements of Anglo Indian administration.
('3', 101, 1, 3, 204686) If very general language were employed, the description of the Teutonic or Scandinavian village communities might actually serve as a description of the same institution in India.
('3', 101, 1, 4, 204866) .The description given by Maurer of the Teutonic Mark of the Townships as his researches have shown it to him, might here again pass for an account, so far as it goes, of an Indian village.
('3', 101, 1, 5, 205056) At the present day in India, there are hundreds of Municipalities which are managed by Indian Councillors.
('3', 101, 1, 6, 205163) Many Indian residents in the Transvaal have exercised the Municipal franchise in India.
('3', 101, 1, 7, 205251) Nor do the articles of Surrender referred to as the Treaty of Vereeniging, in your Petitioner’s humble opinion, affect the position of the British Indians since they apply only to the Natives, as will appear from clause 8 thereof which provides that “the question of granting the franchise to natives will not be decided until after the introduction of self government”.
('3', 101, 1, 8, 205622) The question, therefore, of the kind of franchise does not arise in the case of the British Indians The dominance of the British race in South Africa, in your Petitioner’s humble opinion, would not be affected by granting the Municipal franchise to such British Indians as may be otherwise fitted for its exercise.
('3', 101, 1, 9, 205937) The distinction of colour, although legally made and recognised by the late Government, is repugnant to the British Constitution and your Petitioner respectfully submits, subversive of the broad foundation on which the British Empire is built.
('3', 101, 1, 10, 206181) The amendment in question, your Petitioner submits with deference, disregards the feelings of the British Indians altogether.
('3', 101, 1, 11, 206307) Your Petitioner, therefore, humbly prays that this Honourable House would reconsider the amendment and extend justice to the loyal British Indians or grant such other relief as to this Honourable House may seem meet.
('3', 101, 1, 12, 206524) And for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioner shall, as in duty bound, for ever pray.
('3', 101, 1, 13, 206619) ABDOOL GANI, CHAIRMAN, [THE] BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION India Office: Judicial and Public Records, 402.
('3', 102, 0, 1, 206723) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 103
('3', 102, 1, 2, 206764) 61. THE BRITISH INDIAN IN SOUTH AFRICA
('3', 102, 2, 3, 206803) (TRANSVAAL)
('3', 102, 3, 4, 206815) In the last issue we gave a bird’s eye view of the legal disabilities of the British Indians in South Africa.
('3', 102, 3, 5, 206925) The Transvaal deserves more than passing attention.
('3', 102, 3, 6, 206977) There, as our readers will recollect, the struggle is most acute.
('3', 102, 3, 7, 207043) The restrictions are most galling.
('3', 102, 3, 8, 207078) What adds to the difficulty is the utterly unsympathetic attitude of the officials who are in charge of the Asiatic Department.
('3', 102, 3, 9, 207206) Under the Boer rule, while the laws were very harsh, the administration was as lax as it well could be.
('3', 102, 3, 10, 207310) The officials who had to enforce the laws did not share the prejudice that gave birth to them.
('3', 102, 3, 11, 207405) The Government was by no means over anxious to drive the Indian traders who had a large number of Boer customers into Locations; and, if it ever showed signs of activity, the protecting hands of the British Agent were stretched forth to stay it.
('3', 102, 3, 12, 207651) We cannot but recall with deep gratitude the encouragement given by the then Vice Consul, Mr. Emrys Evans, who, when he heard that the British Indians had received peremptory notice to go into Locations, said in effect: ‘Ignore the notice, and if any force is attempted, I will protect you’.
('3', 102, 3, 13, 207943) Naturally then, although the position was undoubtedly one of suspense and uncertainty, Indians traded in the Transvaal practically without any molestation.
('3', 102, 3, 14, 208099) Many traded on the strength of tenders of license money, others in the names of Europeans.
('3', 102, 3, 15, 208190) And all this was done openly.
('3', 102, 3, 16, 208220) The Government knew it, and connived at it.
('3', 102, 3, 17, 208264) An attempt to enforce the foot path bye laws was met by a severe protest from the then High Commissioner; and Dr. Leyds conveniently disclaimed any knowledge of the attempt, and assured Her late Majesty’s Government that it was not the intention of the Boer Government to enforce the byelaws against the Asiatics.
('3', 102, 3, 18, 208578) Of course, the immigration was totally unrestricted.
('3', 102, 3, 19, 208631) But now the position is entirely changed.
('3', 102, 3, 20, 208673) There is no more any laxity, no more connivance.
('3', 102, 3, 21, 208722) Some of the officials are sorry for past mildness which prevents them from enforcing the legislation as they would.
('3', 102, 3, 22, 208838) There is no effectual protest against their acts.
('3', 102, 3, 23, 208888) The result is that justice is unattainable, unless our countrymen approach His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor who, we are aware, is anxious to hold the scales evenly.
('3', 102, 3, 24, 209059) After British occupation, the policy of the
('3', 103, 0, 1, 209103) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 103, 1, 2, 209145) Government was to respect the position that the Indians held before the war, pending new legislation on the question.
('3', 103, 1, 3, 209263) Most of the few refugees who were fortunate enough to reach the Colony during the first few months were, therefore, allowed licenses to trade in townships.
('3', 103, 1, 4, 209419) At present, however, that policy has been set aside in favour of one of severity.
('3', 103, 1, 5, 209501) An Indiantrader is not allowed to have his licenses transferred to another person.
('3', 103, 1, 6, 209584) He cannot, therefore, sell his business as a going concern.
('3', 103, 1, 7, 209644) There was no such difficulty during the Boer rule.
('3', 103, 1, 8, 209695) Attempts are being made by the local authorities in different parts of the Colony to enforce the foot path bye laws.
('3', 103, 1, 9, 209812) Immigration has for the present been virtually stopped.
('3', 103, 1, 10, 209868) The Plague scare has provided a good excuse for prohibiting it altogether from Natal.
('3', 103, 1, 11, 209954) And it is after great difficulty that Indian refugees get permits to return to their homes from Delagoa Bay or Cape Town.
('3', 103, 1, 12, 210076) Contrast this with the almost unrestricted immigration of the European newcomers who are not British subjects.
('3', 103, 1, 13, 210187) The institution of the Asiatic Offices has filled the cup of woe, and has marked a sharp distinction in the eye of the law between Europeans and Indians.
('3', 103, 1, 14, 210341) The division is, therefore, not between British subjects and non British subjects, which would be a natural division, not between the civilized and the uncivilized, as Mr. Rhodes 1 laid it down, but it is the most unnatural, namely, between the white people and the coloured people.
('3', 103, 1, 15, 210624) Such, in brief, is the dark cloud that hangs over our countrymen in the Transvaal.
('3', 103, 1, 16, 210707) But we do not despair.
('3', 103, 1, 17, 210730) We have unfailing faith in British Justice.
('3', 103, 1, 18, 210774) And we hope and believe that the present situation is but a storm before a calm.
('3', 103, 1, 19, 210855) We know Mr. Chamberlain’s advocacy of our countrymen’s cause in South Africa during their troubles under the late foreign rule; we have read his address to the Colonial Premiers laying down the rule as to immigration; we have also the speeches of the Imperial Ministers on the outbreak of war as an earnest that we would not be thrown overboard; and last, but not least, we believe in the watchfulness of the All Wise Providence who dispenses Justice with an unerring hand.
('3', 103, 2, 20, 211329) Indian Opinion, 11 6 1903
('3', 103, 3, 21, 211355) 1 Cecil Rhodes.
('3', 104, 0, 1, 211371) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 105
('3', 104, 1, 2, 211412) 62. THE LION AND THE LAMB
('3', 104, 2, 3, 211438) Once upon a time a lamb was drinking from a sparkling stream when a lion, so the story says, came upon the scene.
('3', 104, 2, 4, 211552) Wanting to find some pretext for devouring the lamb, he muddled the water, and saddling the responsibility upon the lamb began abusing him.
('3', 104, 2, 5, 211692) “Sire,” said the lamb, “the water is running from your side, so I could not have dirtied it”.
('3', 104, 2, 6, 211786) “Shut up,” said his lionic majesty, “if it is not you, it must be your father”.
('3', 104, 2, 7, 211866) “But my father is dead,” gently pleaded the lamb.
('3', 104, 2, 8, 211916) “Stop all that nonsense, it must be some kinsman of yours, then,” and so saying, the lion made short work of the lamb.
('3', 104, 2, 9, 212035) This was in the immortal Aesop’s days.
('3', 104, 2, 10, 212074) In our days, the European lion wishes to repeat the feat on the Indian lamb.
('3', 104, 2, 11, 212151) He, therefore, says in effectto the Indian, “I will have none of you, for you dwell in shanties, and live on the smell of an oil rag”.
('3', 104, 2, 12, 212286) The poor Indian pleads, “But won’t you look at the fact that all these years I have been trying to live as you do?
('3', 104, 2, 13, 212401) In the whole of Grey Street, for instance, I have been replacing the shanties by substantial buildings, and the process is slowly but surely going on.” “So much the worse for you then,” roars the European lion.
('3', 104, 2, 14, 212612) “How dare you build such palaces and encroach on my preserves?
('3', 104, 2, 15, 212675) You are certainly doomed now.” Such is the gist of the minute presented by His Worship the Mayor of Durban on the proposed Asiatic Bazaars.
('3', 104, 2, 16, 212815) Like the boy in the tub in a well known pictorial advertisement, the Europeans won’t be happy till they have “got it”—namely, the extinction of the free Indian.
('3', 104, 2, 17, 212976) The fact that some Indians have prospered during the last few years, bought landed property, and built substantial structures, for which they have put thousands of pounds into European pockets, is too much for the Europeans.
('3', 104, 2, 18, 213201) But we had expected better things from the sober minded, patriotic and just Mr. Ellis Brown 1. We venture to say that his Bazaar proposal is neither sober nor patriotic, and the manner in which he has seen fit to support it is hardly just.
('3', 104, 2, 19, 213441) The proposal cannot be sober, because it is not considered final in the land of its birth, and is now being reconsidered.
('3', 104, 2, 20, 213563) It is not patriotic, because it has been made irrespective of what his fellow British subjects would think of it.
('3', 104, 2, 21, 213677) As to the manner in which it has been supported, the less said about it the better.
('3', 104, 2, 22, 213761) That a gentleman occupying the civic chair of
('3', 104, 3, 23, 213807) 1 The Mayor of Durban.
('3', 105, 0, 1, 213830) 106 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 105, 1, 2, 213872) the Borough should make random statements which cannot bear the searchlight of facts is very distressing indeed.
('3', 105, 1, 3, 213985) We can only hope that under the spell of Lord Milner’s authority, and in the hurry of the modern rush, having no time to study the subject, the injustice done to the Indian community has been unconsciously done.
('3', 105, 1, 4, 214197) For he who runs may read that the Immigration Restriction Act has not proved a failure from the anti Asiatic standpoint, and that the Indian community has been groaning under the weight of the system of certificates and passes issued under the law, and the police supervision exercised on every ship bringing Indian passengers.
('3', 105, 1, 5, 214525) We commend to our readers’ attention the latest Report of the Immigration Restriction Officer.
('3', 105, 1, 6, 214620) As to the Dealers’ Licenses Act, unless His Worship accuses the Town officers in the Colony of not carrying out their duties conscientiously, a material increase in the Indian licences is impossible, if only because traders are absolutely at the mercy of the licensing officers.
('3', 105, 1, 7, 214899) We ask for figures.
('3', 105, 1, 8, 214919) One of the most potent causes of the revival of the anti Asiatic feeling is the continued increase of indentured labour from India.
('3', 105, 1, 9, 215051) We read that the Immigration Trust Board is unable to cope with the ever increasing applications.
('3', 105, 1, 10, 215149) But the Colony persists in committing that sin, and wishes to avoid the consequences.
('3', 105, 1, 11, 215235) We say with all the earnestness we can command: stop the indentured immigration, and you will soon see the number of Indians in the Colony materially diminishing as years roll by.
('3', 105, 1, 12, 215415) It would furnish a practical demonstration as to whether the Colony can or cannot dispense with such labour.
('3', 105, 1, 13, 215524) If it can, well and good.
('3', 105, 1, 14, 215550) If it cannot, then it will be a potent reason for stopping the ‘pin prick’ policy towards a the Indians.
('3', 105, 2, 15, 215655) Indian Opinion, 11 6 1903
('3', 105, 3, 16, 215681) 63. LORD MILNER ON THE ASIATIC QUESTION
('3', 105, 4, 17, 215721) His Excellency the High Commissioner for South Africa has boldly spoken out against the “savagery of the opposition” to the Asiatic.
('3', 105, 4, 18, 215854) He would have none of the colour distinction.
('3', 105, 4, 19, 215900) ‘Equal rights for all civilized men South of the Zambesi’, is His Lordship’s motto, as it was that of the late Mr. Rhodes.
('3', 105, 4, 20, 216023) His Lordship repeated the sentiments to the British Indian Deputation that waited on him on the 22nd ultimo.
('3', 105, 4, 21, 216132) He further assured it that the Government had no
('3', 106, 0, 1, 216181) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 107
('3', 106, 1, 2, 216222) prejudice against the Indians, and that it did not like the laws of the late Republic as affecting them.
('3', 106, 1, 3, 216327) For all this and much more in his reply to the Deputation, we are deeply thankful to His Excellency.
('3', 106, 1, 4, 216428) But when Lord Milner descended to particulars and the practical appli cability of his propositions, we confess to a feeling of disappointment.
('3', 106, 1, 5, 216571) Take the Asiatic Office.
('3', 106, 1, 6, 216596) The officers are all estimable men, and we should be sorry indeed if they were not provided for in the event of the disestablishment of that Office.
('3', 106, 1, 7, 216745) And vet, what good has it done?
('3', 106, 1, 8, 216777) Let us consider His Lordship’s justification.
('3', 106, 1, 9, 216823) A member of the Deputation said that he could not see the Colonial Secretary: therefore, said His Excellency, the Asiatic Office was a necessity; the Indian could have his grievances heard there.
('3', 106, 1, 10, 217019) The Indian does not find it so.
('3', 106, 1, 11, 217051) The Asiatic Officer at present is merely a conduit, and a very faulty one because of the constitution of his office.
('3', 106, 1, 12, 217168) In not a single instance is the Indian able to avoid having to see the regular officers whenever he has any business to do: such is the report that reaches us from the Transvaal.
('3', 106, 1, 13, 217347) Having nothing of importance to engage his attention, he ‘finds some mischief still to do’.
('3', 106, 1, 14, 217439) For, is it not the Asiatic Office that has invented the system of taking photographs and branded its protege as a criminal?
('3', 106, 1, 15, 217563) With due respect to His Excellency, we do think that the man who has the practical experience is a better judge of the usefulness or otherwise of the thing experienced.
('3', 106, 1, 16, 217732) His Excellency is emphatic on the £3 tax.
('3', 106, 1, 17, 217774) Our countrymen in the Transvaal have thought fit, and we think wisely, to bow to His Excellency’s decision, and not to appeal to Mr. Chamberlain.
('3', 106, 1, 18, 217920) At the same time, itdoes appear inconsistent to a lay mind that His Excellency should in theory object to colour distinction, and in practice justify the imposition of a penalty on colour.
('3', 106, 1, 19, 218109) For to us, it is not the amount but the principle that is objectionable.
('3', 106, 1, 20, 218182) A Kaffir is tobe taxed because he does not work enough: an Indian is to be taxed because he works too much, as Sir Hiram Maim would say.
('3', 106, 1, 21, 218319) The only thing in common between the so is that they do not wear a white skin.
('3', 106, 1, 22, 218398) His Excellency justifies the Bazaars on much the same ground: namely, that of colour.
('3', 106, 1, 23, 218484) The Deputation very reasonably suggested that the removal to Bazaars should be left optional; it would be found that the poorer class of Indians would go to Bazaars of their own accord.
('3', 106, 1, 24, 218670) But His Lordship could not see his way to do that Why?
('3', 106, 1, 25, 218725) Because the Indian is a coloured man!
('3', 106, 1, 26, 218763) There is no law to force the poor whites to
('3', 107, 0, 1, 218807) 108 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 107, 1, 2, 218849) the particular quarter.
('3', 107, 1, 3, 218873) The idea of compulsion is hateful to the Englishman, as applied to himself.
('3', 107, 1, 4, 218949) An erudite Bishop once said that he Would see the whole English nation rather free and drunken than bound and sober.
('3', 107, 1, 5, 219066) The Indian may not go the same length with the learned divine, but it may be permitted to him to resent compulsion when its effect is to degrade him.
('3', 107, 1, 6, 219216) But there is consolation in the thought that the bazaar Notice against which the Deputation protested is merely temporary, and that His Excellency is now considering new legislation.
('3', 107, 1, 7, 219399) We only hope and pray that Providence will so guide His Excellency that he will bring out legislation that will put to an end once and for all the eternal anxiety and stress under which the Indian has been groaning in the Transvaal.
('3', 107, 1, 8, 219632) Indeed, it is time that the Indian had rest from the pin pricks to which he been subjected there for the past eighteen months at least more than during the old regime.

('3', 107, 4, 11, 219855) We request His Excellency Lord Milner to ponder over the verse we have adopted as the heading of this note.

('3', 108, 2, 4, 221375) 65. THE BRITISH INDIAN IN SOUTH AFRICA
('3', 108, 3, 5, 221414) ORANGE RIVER COLONY 1
('3', 108, 4, 6, 221436) We reproduce in another column the full text of the anti Asiatic law of the late Orange Free State.
('3', 108, 4, 7, 221536) That law allows no footing to the Indian.
('3', 108, 4, 8, 221578) He may be allowed to remain in the State practically as a labourer, pure and simple, and that, too, not without the permission of the State President.
('3', 108, 4, 9, 221729) Should he be found with this permission, he is liable to pay a fine of £25, or to go to prison for 3 months.
('3', 108, 4, 10, 221838) He must pay a poll tax of ten shillings per annum.
('3', 108, 4, 11, 221889) Curiously enough, the law does not apply to the Malays from the Cape Colony.
('3', 108, 4, 12, 221966) This law is allowed to blot the statute book of this British Colony of Orange River, though over two years have elapsed since the British occupied the country.
('3', 108, 4, 13, 222126) The history of the legislation is briefly this.
('3', 108, 4, 14, 222174) There were in the Colony, before 1890, a iv Indian merchants who so roused the ire of the European merchants that the latter presented a petition to the President making all sorts of charges against the entire Indian race, one of which was that it considered women as soulless, 2 and another was that it introduced all kinds of loathsome diseases into the State.
('3', 108, 4, 15, 222537) There was no convention with Britain enabling it to stop the then President from complying with the wishes of the good merchants who were afraid of the entry of the people with no sense of morals and tainted with horrible diseases.
('3', 108, 4, 16, 222769) The law in question was, therefore, passed.
('3', 108, 4, 17, 222813) Indian merchants were hounded out of the State without compensation.
('3', 108, 4, 18, 222882) The British Government was approached, but it felt powerless.
('3', 108, 4, 19, 222944) It had no jurisdiction.
('3', 108, 4, 20, 222968) So the merchants had to suffer losses to the extent of nearly ten thousand pounds sterling.
('3', 108, 4, 21, 223060) The question naturally arises, has the British Government any jurisdiction now?
('3', 108, 4, 22, 223140) Two of the old merchants, we understand, have already tested it and got a reply in the negative.
('3', 108, 4, 23, 223237) Under the existing law, the Colonial Government says, it cannot grant them permission to
('3', 108, 5, 24, 223326) 1 The name given to the Orange Free State on its annexation by the British.
('3', 108, 5, 25, 223402) 2Vide “Notes on the Grievances of the British Indians in South Africa”, September 22, 1896
('3', 109, 0, 1, 223493) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 109, 1, 2, 223535) resume their trade.
('3', 109, 1, 3, 223555) Asked when the law with be repealed or modified, it has no knowledge.
('3', 109, 1, 4, 223625) The British Government, therefore, has either no jurisdiction or no willingness to rescind or alter the law.
('3', 109, 1, 5, 223734) It has changed and abrogated many laws in that Colony, but not this.
('3', 109, 1, 6, 223803) It was said in the early days of British occupation, that the law could not be even modified until civil government was established.
('3', 109, 1, 7, 223936) When civil authority did take the place of the military, Mr. Chamberlain’s visit was to be awaited.
('3', 109, 1, 8, 224036) Mr. Chamberlain has come and gone, and yet nothing is done—why?
('3', 109, 1, 9, 224100) Before the war, everybody was agreed that, as soon as it was over, all British subjects would be free in the two Republics.
('3', 109, 1, 10, 224224) May we not appeal to every true Britisher and ask whether he approves of the above law?
('3', 109, 1, 11, 224312) The Indians have no desire to flood that Colony, or, for that matter, any other.
('3', 109, 1, 12, 224393) But loyal as they are, we think that they are perfectly justified in asking that the law may be brought into harmony with the British sense of right and justice.
('3', 109, 1, 13, 224555) Every Indian child is taught to sing, before he reaches Standard IV of his vernacular school in India, that under the British rule there is no inequality, the lion cannot hurt the lamb—all are free and well protected.
('3', 109, 1, 14, 224773) Having been nurtured in such sentiments, we find it hard to understand the practical working of that mighty Government in this sub continent.
('3', 109, 1, 15, 224915) The European lion bids fair to swallow up the Indian lamb in British South Africa, while the arbiter at Downing Street is looking on!
('3', 109, 2, 16, 225049) Indian Opinion, 18 6 1903
('3', 109, 3, 17, 225075) 66. IS IT IMPERIAL OR EMPIRICAL?
('3', 109, 4, 18, 225108) The debate in the newly formed Legislative Council of the Transvaal on the Elective Municipalities Ordinance would be an extremely interesting reading if it were not painful.
('3', 109, 4, 19, 225283) How the non official members of the Council argued themselves into the belief that it was strictly just to debar all coloured people from the exercise of the Municipal franchise, whether they were British subjects or aliens, passes our understanding.
('3', 109, 4, 20, 225534) Indeed, if we did not know that Sir George Farrar 1 voted against the Government clause, we would have considered him to be a champion of the reasonable rights of coloured
('3', 109, 5, 21, 225706) 1A nominated member of the Legislative Council of the Transvaal.
('3', 110, 0, 1, 225771) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 111
('3', 110, 1, 2, 225812) British subjects.
('3', 110, 1, 3, 225830) For, we read that Sir George Farrar twitted Mr. Harry Solomon for his volte face; in fact, before the war, he was always inclined to treat coloured people justly; and that, now that the British Government was established, he disregarded them entirely as members of the Empire to which he and they belong.
('3', 110, 1, 4, 226135) Sir George Farrar admitted that it would be very offensive to the coloured people if they were debarred from the municipal franchise, because they happened to wear a brown skin, but as he was only a nominated member, Sir George thought that he could not possibly vote in favour of the Government clause.
('3', 110, 1, 5, 226439) Now, what is the Government clause?
('3', 110, 1, 6, 226475) It provided that all who could read and write, to the satisfaction of the officer, either English or Dutch, and possessed certain property qualifications, were entitled to be placed on the voters’ roll.
('3', 110, 1, 7, 226678) Every member admitted that under that clause hardly a few coloured men would be able to have their names placed on the voters’ roll.
('3', 110, 1, 8, 226811) So, evidently, the question, as Mr. Loveday frankly and bluntly put it, was purely and simply “one of colour”.
('3', 110, 1, 9, 226922) It was not, then, as Sir Percy Fitzpatrick would have us believe, a question of keeping up the dominance of the British race.
('3', 110, 1, 10, 227048) Indeed, it is assured beyond a doubt and, if we may put it with due deference to Sir Percy, we think that the action of the non official members has certainly contributed to weaken the hold of the Empire on a portion of loyal British subjects.
('3', 110, 1, 11, 227292) The argument was strong, also from the articles of Surrender, to the effect that if the articles were not broken to the letter by this Government clause, they were certainly broken in spirit, in that the Boers could not draw a distinction between municipal and political franchise!
('3', 110, 1, 12, 227574) Now the clause of the article referred to by the honourable members says: “The question of granting the franchise to natives will not be decided until after the introduction of self government’?.
('3', 110, 1, 13, 227770) Even assuming that there is any force in the argument, it evidently does not apply to coloured people other than the natives of South Africa, and, therefore, certainly not to the British Indians, with whom alone we are at present concerned.
('3', 110, 1, 14, 228011) If the action of the non official members was surprising and painful, what shall we say of that of the Government which, after making a most able defence of their clause, and after having a majority in favour thereof, had to yield to the non official members?
('3', 110, 1, 15, 228271) We make bold to say that this is really going too far; and it very much appears as if the Transvaal was going not only to rule the whole of South Africa, but to trample under foot all that is most dearly cherished by the British Constitution, and that has stood the test
('3', 111, 0, 1, 228542) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 111, 1, 2, 228584) of time.
('3', 111, 1, 3, 228593) Sir Richard, in announcing the decision of the Government to yield to the wishes of the thirteen non official members, said that, on a question of that kind, the Government did not intend to override the feeling of the non official members.
('3', 111, 1, 4, 228834) We, in our simplicity, would have thought that it would be exactly on a question of that kind that the Government would stand firm.
('3', 111, 1, 5, 228966) Why should a few, no doubt very influential, men be able to dictate a material change in the funda mental policy of the British Government, it is difficult for us to un derstand.
('3', 111, 1, 6, 229145) Perhaps, the remarks made by the non official members to the effect that the measure in question was only temporary, and that there was no reason why within a few years a change should not be made in the clause admitting coloured people to the franchise, weighed with the Government.
('3', 111, 1, 7, 229429) We have come to think that all such promises are absolutely vain.
('3', 111, 1, 8, 229495) We do not believe that when self government is granted, the prejudice against colour would be removed at a stroke of the pen.
('3', 111, 1, 9, 229621) On the contrary, the action of the Government during the transition stage would be quoted as a precedent for future restrictive legislation; and that by that time the prejudice, having been fed, as it were, by the Government, would have hardened so much as to be ineradicable.
('3', 111, 1, 10, 229898) The cloud, however, is not without its silver lining.
('3', 111, 1, 11, 229952) Although itwas a voice in the wilderness, it was that of Mr. William Hosken, who was the only non official member who spoke out his mind boldly and fearlessly en favour of justice and humanity.
('3', 111, 1, 12, 230146) If the other non official members had no respect for the feelings of those whom by their action they were insulting, and if the Government in their wish to please them gave up the bare rights of the coloured people, Mr. Hosken at any rate showed by his action that he was not going to be a party to any such thing.
('3', 111, 1, 13, 230461) One thing we may venture to remind the honourable members of, viz., that the British Indians have known the privilege of municipal government for ages past.
('3', 111, 1, 14, 230618) We have the authority of Sir Henry Maine, the late Sir William Wilson Hunter, the official historian of India, and a host of other eminent writers, for saying that India enjoyed municipal self government long before even the Anglo Saxon race.
('3', 111, 1, 15, 230861) And, though we admit that the great race has now left India behind it in ad vancement, we hope the honourable members do not think that the instinct of self government has so far forsaken us as to make us un worthy of the municipal franchise in the Transvaal.
('3', 112, 0, 1, 231121) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 113
('3', 112, 1, 2, 231162) Mr. Chamberlain came to South Africa as the apostle of Imperial unity.
('3', 112, 1, 3, 231233) We well remember the occasion of the great meeting in the Wanderers’ Hall; how every sentence of Mr. Chamberlain’s speech was applauded; and how the Imperial spirit, as distinguished from the parochial, pervaded that great assembly.
('3', 112, 1, 4, 231466) Is it, then, Imperial to “cast a slur” on millions of His Majesty’s subjects simply for the sake of gratifying a bit of prejudice, or, as we have asked in the heading, is it Empirical?
('3', 112, 2, 5, 231651) Indian Opinion, 18 6 1903

('3', 112, 4, 13, 232619) In discussing the Mayor’s Minute on the Bazaars 1, the Town Councillors showed great anxiety for the welfare of the Indian residents, and they were good enough to argue that it was really in the interests of the Indians themselves that Bazaars were necessary for their residence.

('3', 112, 4, 15, 233172) It is all very well to say that effective supervision is not possible when Indians are scattered about, and when their habits are so different from those of the Europeans.

('3', 113, 1, 2, 233584) their habits have really very little to do with sanitary control, because, the latter can be most effectively exercised in keeping with the Borough bye laws, in spite of any habits to the contrary.

('3', 113, 2, 7, 234370) 68. WHAT IS IT ALL COMING TO?
('3', 113, 2, 8, 234400) It looks as if the Government of the Orange River Colony has not the remotest intention of altering or amending the drastic and un British anti Asiatic laws which it has inherited from the old Re publican Government.
('3', 113, 2, 9, 234617) For, one reads in the Government Gazette Extraordinary dated 19th May, a draft ordinance to provide for an increased Poll tax on coloured persons outside public diggings.
('3', 113, 2, 10, 234788) If, as was hoped at the time of the war, and as is hoped even now by British Indians, that the British Government would repeal the laws referred to, we do not understand this proposal to increase the poll tax.
('3', 113, 2, 11, 234998) We are aware that there is hardly any Indian population in that Colony.
('3', 113, 2, 12, 235070) But we are trusting that, at no distant date, the door will be opened for reasonable immigration of British Indians into that Colony.
('3', 113, 2, 13, 235204) Lord Milner is now supposed to be considering in what way and to what extent the anti Asiatic legislation of the late South African Republic would be changed.
('3', 113, 2, 14, 235363) Are we to suppose that, because there is no Indian population in the Orange River Colony, the door is for ever to remain closed against British Indians?
('3', 113, 2, 15, 235516) We remember the time when, in reply to the protest by the British Indians against the laws of the Orange Free State, the Colonial Secretary said that it was an absolutely independent Republic, and that, much as he would like to help the British Indians, he was powerless.
('3', 113, 2, 16, 235788) The Colonial Secretary is not now powerless.
('3', 113, 2, 17, 235833) He has the control in his own hands.
('3', 113, 2, 18, 235870) Will he exercise it on behalf of Right and Justice, or is he to be powerless against a new obstacle in the shape of downright trade jealousy and colour prejudice?

('3', 114, 1, 2, 236100) 69. A STUDY IN FACTS
('3', 114, 2, 3, 236121) Sir Mancherji, to whom the whole of the Indian community in South Africa is beholden for his great advocacy, in season and out of season, of their cause, has put a question to Mr. Chamberlain to which the right honourable gentleman is reported to have replied as follows: “So far as Indians in the Transvaal were concerned, the old Law had not been enforced with its former rigour; indeed, considerable modifications had been introduced.” We give below, in parallel columns, the facts of the matter, and make bold to say that the old laws are being enforced with a rigour unknown during the old regime.
('3', 114, 3, 4, 236724) BEFORE WAR NOW
('3', 114, 4, 5, 236739) “The Indians were not compelled to pay the £3 registration fee.” “Every Indian has now to take out his registration on pain of being fined from £10 to £100, or on failure, being imprisoned from 14 days to six months.” “Any Indian could trade in any part of the Transvaal without a license, in most cases simply as against tender of license money; and this because of the protection of the British Government.”
('3', 114, 5, 6, 237149) “Every Indian must remove to Bazaars for trade, except those who held licences to trade in town before War.”
('3', 114, 6, 7, 237258) “Any Indian could live in any part of the Transvaal without molestation and without having to apply for exemption.”
('3', 114, 7, 8, 237374) “No Indian, unless he receives a special exemption from the Colonial Secretary, may live in towns: but all Indians must remove to Locations, now to be called Bazaars.” “Indians could hold landed property, if only in the names of white people.” “It is extremely difficult for Indians to hold landed property now in the names of white people.” “Indians held 99 years’ Leases in Johannesburg, under the old Government, for landed property in the Indian Location there.”
('3', 114, 8, 9, 237841) “This land is now being taken away from them under ‘,Unsanitary Area Commissioners Report.’ There is no gua rantee that they will receive an equal title to land elsewhere in Johannesburg in a suitable place.”
('3', 115, 0, 1, 238050) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 115, 1, 2, 238092) “Indians were free to enter the Transvaal without any restrictions whatsoever.” “Even bona fide Indian refugees are only sparingly allowed to enter the Colony, and then after nearly 3 months’ delay after application.” “There was no separate Asiatic Department for Indians, with its passes and permits.
('3', 115, 1, 3, 238394) “The Asiatic Department has become a painful fact with the Indian community in the Transvaal, with its inconveniences which are now occupying Lord Milner’s attention.” “Vested interests were never touched by the Transvaal Government, because of the mighty protection that was ever affored to the Indians during the Republican regime by British Consuls.”
('3', 115, 2, 4, 238748) “Some present ‘licensees’ possessing thousands of pounds’ worth to stock are under notice to shift to Location at the end of the year; although they received the licenses from British Officers.” The above is merely a sample of what is now happening to the British Indians in the Transvaal.
('3', 115, 2, 5, 239038) After two years’ British occupation, they are unable to say what definitely their position is under the flag whose protection they have been taught to rely upon from childhood.
('3', 115, 2, 6, 239215) What was running in Mr. Chamberlain’s mind when he allowed himself to make the statement above referred to, we do not know.
('3', 115, 2, 7, 239339) Sir Mancherji would be rendering a great service if he would press for a definite reply to the indictment drawn up above.

('3', 116, 11, 14, 240736) THE PETITION OF THE UNDERSIGNED REPRESENTING THE
('3', 116, 12, 15, 240785) BRITISH INDIANS RESIDING IN THE COLONY OF NATAL
('3', 116, 13, 16, 240833) HUMBLY SHEWETH: That your Petitioners respectfully approach this Honourable House with reference to the Bill to place closer restrictions on Immigration, now before this Honourable House for consideration.
('3', 116, 13, 17, 241039) Your Petitioners, while accepting the principle of the Bill, beg to submit that further restrictions which are now sought to be imposed by the Bill in question are, in your Petitioners’ humble opinion, unnecessary.
('3', 116, 13, 18, 241254) They are: The raising of the educational test by sub section A of Section 5 Fixing the age of majority at sixteen under sub section F of Section 4.
('3', 117, 0, 1, 241402) 118 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 117, 1, 2, 241444) The necessity for an applicant for a visitor’s pass to attend before the Immigration Restriction Officer, or other Officers thereto appointed under Section 23. The requiring of a residence in Natal for a period of not less than three consecutive years under Section 32, to entitle an applicant to claim the benefit of sub section F of Section 4. The denial of the benefit of domicile to indentured Indians in spite of at least five years’ service in the Colony.
('3', 117, 1, 3, 241906) Your Petitioners would venture to discuss seriatim the clauses referred to above: According to the last report of the Immigration Restriction Officer at Durban of the working of the present Act, it appears that only one hundred and fifteen Asiatics entered the Colony having passed the education test.
('3', 117, 1, 4, 242208) Your Petitioners submit, with due deference to the officer who has, in spite of the above figures, advised a higher education test, that the number that has entered the Colony under the test is very insignificant, and does not justify a higher test.
('3', 117, 1, 5, 242458) In fact, the opening remarks of the Immigration Officer would go to show that the Act has worked very satisfactorily, and that it has to a very great extent answered the purpose for which it was framed.
('3', 117, 1, 6, 242661) But if this Honourable House is of opinion that the education test should be raised, your Petitioners humbly submit that this would be a suitable opportunity for granting the request of the Indian community that was made to this Honourable House when the present Act was introduced, namely, that the education test should recognise the principal Indian languages.
('3', 117, 1, 7, 243025) Your Petitioners would then cheerfully submit to a higher educational test all round.
('3', 117, 1, 8, 243111) It may be mentioned that millions in India are totally illiterate, and they would, therefore, be still.
('3', 117, 1, 9, 243215) prohibited immigrants under the Law.
('3', 117, 1, 10, 243252) Such a test, moreover, will free the Act from the appearance of being offensive to the Indian nation.
('3', 117, 1, 11, 243354) The fixing of the age of majority at sixteen will, your Petitioners submit, be a very great hardship to those who are entitled to immigrate to the Colony, more so to the Indians.
('3', 117, 1, 12, 243533) As this Honourable House is aware, Indian children are not withdrawn till after they have reached the age of over twenty one years from parental control, and it will be a most serious thing for a domiciled Indian in the Colony to contemplate the abandoning of his children while they are yet hardly sixteen years; how close the family tie is in India, your Petitioners
('3', 118, 0, 1, 243902) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 119
('3', 118, 1, 2, 243943) need hardly point out.
('3', 118, 1, 3, 243966) Your Petitioners trust that the requiring of the attendance of an applicant for a visiting or an embarkation pass before an officer is merely an oversight.
('3', 118, 1, 4, 244122) An applicant may be resident in any place, and it is hardly to be expected that the Government would make provision for stationing Officers at each and every place out of the Colony.
('3', 118, 1, 5, 244305) It would, therefore, be manifestly impossible that an appli cant could always attend before Officers appointed under the Act for passes.

('3', 118, 1, 8, 244713) Your Petitioners humbly think that even that period is too long, but to raise it to three years would prevent many members of the Indian community from returning to Natal, although they may have businesses and connections in the Colony.

('3', 118, 1, 14, 245935) In conclusion, your Petitioners hope that this Honourable House would take this humble Petition under favourable consideration and grant the relief prayed for herein, and for this act of justice and mercy, your Petitioners, as in duty bound, shall for ever pray, etc.
