('3', 182, 11, 19, 388326) 117. MR. CHAMBERLAIN’S DESPATCH
('3', 182, 12, 20, 388358) The despatch of Mr. Chamberlain addressed to Lord Milner on the question of indentured Indian labour for the Transvaal is of mo mentous interest to the Indian community.
('3', 182, 12, 21, 388528) It may be divided into three heads: First: Mr. Chamberlain refuses to even think of sanctioning theintroduction of Asiatic labour into the Transvaal in any shape or form until he is clearly satisfied that it is the wish of the majority of the white population of the Transvaal.
('3', 182, 12, 22, 388806) Secondly: That even if it is made clear, it is a question whether indentured Indian labour with a view ultimately to repatriation of the labourers would be sanctioned so far as India was concerned.
('3', 182, 12, 23, 389004) Thirdly: That before he could say yes or no, the conditions laid down by the Indian Government would have to be satisfied, namely, that the existing legislation should be so modified as to remove the special tax of £3 for registration and abrogate the Location regulations, except for those for whom they may be necessary on sanitary grounds, to include freedom to trade outside Locations, freedom to hold property except for speculative purposes, and to remove all special restrictions against the better class of Asiatics.
('3', 182, 12, 24, 389529) Now with reference to the first point, every right minded man
('3', 183, 0, 1, 389591) 184 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 183, 1, 2, 389633) must agree that indentured labour from India cannot be thrust upon the Transvaal in the teeth of the opposition of the majority of its European inhabitants, and we can only hope that the majority will always remain opposed to the introduction of indentured labour from Asia, whether it is India or China.
('3', 183, 1, 3, 389938) On this point, though not for the same reasons as would guide the Europeans, there is complete agreement between European opinion and the Indian.
('3', 183, 1, 4, 390084) In the long run, indentured labour under the conditions mentioned can do absolutely no good to either party.
('3', 183, 1, 5, 390193) To the Europeans it would be in the highest degree demoralising, and to the labourers entirely unprofitable.
('3', 183, 1, 6, 390302) As to the second point, we hope that the Indian Government would never listen to the novel proposal, as Mr. Chamberlain terms it, of repatriation.
('3', 183, 1, 7, 390449) There is no precedent for such a step.
('3', 183, 1, 8, 390488) So far, the Indian Government have turned a deaf ear to any such advance from other Colonies, and although we are aware that the influences that can be set in motion on behalf of the Transvaal are very weighty and great, we think that they cannot be allowed to outweigh the interests of the Indians, which it is the special duty of the Indian Government to safeguard, and if the condition of repatriation is insisted upon, it cannot by any stretch of imagination be said to be for the benefit of the Indians.
('3', 183, 1, 9, 390997) Indeed, Lord Milner does not say it is, he only suggests it “in view of public feeling”.
('3', 183, 1, 10, 391086) And the British Indians in South Africa would be simply selling for a mess of pottage the rights of thousands of their humbler brethren in India if, in a weak moment, they ever accepted the principle of bargaining away the liberties of Indian labourers in exchange for their own.
('3', 183, 1, 11, 391366) It is, however, the third point which is of the greatest importance to the Indian community, especially in the Transvaal, and it is refreshing to find the Indian Government sticking out on behalf of the British Indians who have settled in the Transvaal.
('3', 183, 1, 12, 391620) Of course, it is very difficult to know what is meant by “better class Asiatics” and “speculative acquisition”.
('3', 183, 1, 13, 391732) We very much fear that there would not be the same interpretation put upon these two terms by Lord Curzon and Lord Milner.
('3', 183, 1, 14, 391855) It may be perfectly possible by a process of elimination to refuse to admit any Asiatic as “belonging to the better class”, and there is no knowing that in the term “speculative acquisition” even an ordinary ownership may not be included.
('3', 183, 1, 15, 392094) But we are dealing with these points before they have assumed a concrete form.
('3', 183, 1, 16, 392173) It is yet too early to know how far the Transvaal Government would be prepared
('3', 184, 0, 1, 392252) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 185
('3', 184, 1, 2, 392293) to accept the proposals of the Indian Government.
('3', 184, 1, 3, 392343) We would only, at this stage, beg the authorities in India to remember that anything that is now done should be plain, unequivocal, and definite.
('3', 184, 1, 4, 392489) Loopholes of any kind, as we know to our cost, are very dangerous.
('3', 184, 1, 5, 392556) We, therefore, think that the qualifications ought to be included in any legislation, instead of leaving them to the discretion of an officer.
('3', 184, 1, 6, 392699) As Lord Milner has said, the chief thing is to define the status of British Indians with certainty, so that everyone would be able to know what it is.
('3', 184, 1, 7, 392850) We are deeply indebted to Lord George Hamilton for including in his proposals the legislation of the Orange River Colony also.
('3', 184, 1, 8, 392977) It IS high time that the anti Asiatic activity of the legislators of that Colony was arrested in its progress.
('3', 184, 1, 9, 393088) As our columns would have shown, hardly a month passes without some disabilities in anticipation being imposed on British Indians in that part of the British dominions.
('3', 184, 1, 10, 393257) Indian Opinion, 6 8 1903
('3', 184, 2, 11, 393282) 118. THE LONDON MEETING: III
('3', 184, 3, 12, 393311) SIR CHARLES DILKE AND THE EAST INDIA ASSOCIATION We have already dealt with the proceedings of the East India Association addressed by Sir William Wedderburn on the position of the British Indians in South Africa; but, as we consider that the meeting was of very great importance, and that the speeches made thereat demand very careful attention of the Colonists, we propose to deal with the speech made by Sir Charles Dilke, who presided at the meeting.
('3', 184, 3, 13, 393766) The Honourable baronet has always taken a very sympathetic interest in Indian affairs, and ever since the commencement of the struggle of the British Indians in South Africa, he has followed up his sympathetic attitude and endeavoured to secure justice for us.
('3', 184, 3, 14, 394027) We, therefore, owe him, as well as the other distinguished friends who have been helping us in our troubles, a deep debt of gratitude.
('3', 184, 3, 15, 394162) We wish to remind the Colonists that Sir Charles’ opinions ought to carry a great deal of weight with them in view of the fact that he has made a special study of colonial questions.
('3', 184, 3, 16, 394345) The author of The Problems of Greater Britain knows intimately almost every phase of the Colonial question, and we hope that his opinions will receive the weight that attaches to his ripe experience of the King’s dominions beyond the seas.
('3', 184, 3, 17, 394585) This is what Sir Charles Dilke said at the meeting in his
('3', 185, 0, 1, 394643) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 185, 1, 2, 394685) preliminary remarks:
('3', 185, 2, 3, 394706) The question which brought them together was that of Indians in the Transvaal in particular, but, of course, incidentally, the position of Indian subjects outside India in all parts of the British Empire was one that very naturally produced much feeling in India itself.
('3', 185, 2, 4, 394977) He was present some time ago at a deputation to the Secretary of State which was introduced by the late Mr. Caine, and on that occasion by none of those who advocated the principle, which brought Sir W. Wedderburn there that afternoon, i.e., the principle of the right of British Indian subjects to live freely and carry on their avocations freely in all parts of the British Empire—was that cause pleaded more strongly than by the Secretary of State himself.
('3', 185, 2, 5, 395437) It was impossible for any member to be otherwise than satisfied with the Right Hon.
('3', 185, 2, 6, 395521) Gentleman’s language.
('3', 185, 2, 7, 395543) The above quotation shows the sentiments of Sir Charles Dilke.
('3', 185, 2, 8, 395606) The more one studies the question, the more convinced one becomes of the justice of the claims put forward on behalf of the British Indians in South Africa.
('3', 185, 2, 9, 395763) One reads similar observations on the part of the Indian Government in the correspondence lately published in the Transvaal, and reproduced by us last week.
('3', 185, 2, 10, 395920) We shall, however, deal with it later on.
('3', 185, 2, 11, 395962) That the meeting was held under the auspices of the East India Association is also a matter of considerable importance.
('3', 185, 2, 12, 396082) The Asso ciation is one of the oldest established in the United Kingdom in connection with Indian affairs, and numbers among its members most of the retired Viceroys, Governors, and distinguished Anglo Indians who have devoted years to the study of Indian problems.
('3', 185, 2, 13, 396348) That such a body of men should throw the weight of their great influence in favour of the Indian subjects of His Majesty settled in South Africa cannot but be a matter of very great satisfaction to us.
('3', 185, 2, 14, 396550) It shows unmistakably that not only are our demands just, but that if we have patience enough, we are bound to win in the end.
('3', 185, 2, 15, 396677) We have very great faith in the education of public opinion, and it is because we feel strongly that, the more food the Colonists get for consideration of this particular problem, the quicker will be the solution, that we try to keep the proceedings of the East India Association as prominently as possible before them.
('3', 185, 2, 16, 396997) Indian Opinion, 6 8 1903
('3', 186, 0, 1, 397022) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 187
('3', 186, 1, 2, 397063) 119. IMMIGRATION RESTRICTION BILL
('3', 186, 2, 3, 397097) In spite of the efforts of the Honourable Mr. Jameson to secure a sympathetic hearing for the British Indian petition to the Legislative Council, the Immigration Restriction Bill has passed without an amendment.
('3', 186, 2, 4, 397309) Mr. Dan Taylor’s straightforward remark that the prin ting of the petition was a waste of public money has come true.
('3', 186, 2, 5, 397427) It seems both the Houses had prejudged the issue and made up their minds about the Bill.
('3', 186, 2, 6, 397516) We wonder what Sir John Robinson thinks of this latest instance of the local Parliament practically denying the right of the British Indians to be heard with any effect.
('3', 186, 2, 7, 397686) At the time of introducing the disfranchising Bill.
('3', 186, 2, 8, 397738) he declared that the rights of the disfranchised would be jealously guarded, as every member would consider himself in a measure a guardian of the rights of the disfranchised.
('3', 186, 2, 9, 397914) Well may the Indians say: ‘Save us from our guar dians.’ We hope we have shown conclusively that the prayer of the petitioners was very reasonable.

('3', 189, 3, 8, 404653) 123. STOOPING TO CONQUER
('3', 189, 4, 9, 404678) The visit of Their Majesties the King and Queen to Ireland is one of vast significance not only to the Irish people but to the Empire at large, and it teaches the humblest of His Majesty’s subjects a practical lesson in humility in a manner which the most thrilling sermons from the pulpit would fail to teach.
('3', 189, 4, 10, 404989) The Dublin Corporation, shall we say, in its pettiness, thought fit to decline to present an address to the King and the Queen on their visit to Ireland, as if they were responsible for that country’s distress.
('3', 189, 4, 11, 405200) Now, in the face of such an attitude, what did Their Majesties do?
('3', 189, 4, 12, 405267) They might have refused to visitIreland, seeing that its capital city was not prepared to extend a formal welcome to them; or, having gone there, they might have shown in a significant manner their displeasure at the proceedings of the Corporation.
('3', 189, 4, 13, 405516) But they were pleased to think otherwise; and they have actually by their warm words of sympathy and open hearted manner disarmed all opposition, and by returning good for evil shamed the Corporation of Dublin into an attitude, so we are told, of repentance.
('3', 189, 4, 14, 405775) We read further in the cablegrams that the King walked through the slums of Dublin, visited the homes of the poor, and spoke to them words of sympathy.
('3', 189, 4, 15, 405927) Nor did Their Majesties stop at mere words or sentiments of sympathy; they have translated them into a donation of £ 1,000 Now we are very apt to think that sovereigns can afford to give away money without feeling tile slightest pinch, but it is a well known fact that, probably of all the first class sovereigns in the world, the English King is the poorest, and when one adds to this the fact that there are a thousand and one calls on the
('3', 190, 0, 1, 406369) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 191
('3', 190, 1, 2, 406410) purses of sovereigns, the donation, to our mind, is by no means an insignificant portion of Their Majesties’ acts during their tour in Ireland.
('3', 190, 1, 3, 406554) Her late Majesty the Queen has left behind her a memory that cannot be easily forgotten; but if it were possible to eclipse such a memory, or even to equal it, it seems that our present King Emperor and Queen Empress bid fair to do so.
('3', 190, 1, 4, 406790) The British Constitution has been well settled during the long Victorian era.
('3', 190, 1, 5, 406868) There is, therefore, not the slightest fear of any tampering with it.
('3', 190, 1, 6, 406938) It is then a matter of great satisfaction to all the King’s subjects that he does not spare himself in actively looking after their welfare in his own domain.
('3', 190, 1, 7, 407097) But, apart from what we have said above, the event has a special significance for India.
('3', 190, 1, 8, 407186) Our readers will remember that when he was Prince of Wales, the King Emperor visited India, and by his generous sympathy was able, during his short visit, to win the hearts of the Indian people.
('3', 190, 1, 9, 407381) He has evidently further developed that trait in his character to a very great extent.
('3', 190, 1, 10, 407468) Have we not, then, reason to hope that whenever an opportunity occurs, like his illustrious mother, he will not fail to put in a word on behalf of his millions of subjects in India, even though they are several thousand miles away from him?
('3', 190, 2, 11, 407709) Indian Opinion, 6 8 1903
('3', 190, 3, 12, 407734) 124. MIXED UP
('3', 190, 4, 13, 407748) It grieves us to find Lord Milner appealing to the gallery, and that in State documents.
('3', 190, 4, 14, 407837) His Excellency’s despatches to Mr. Chamberlain on the Indian question show unmistakably that Lord Milner, the statesman, has not left behind Mr. Milner, the editor of the Pall Mall.
('3', 190, 4, 15, 408019) In his two despatches lately published in the papers, His Excellency has made the following three statements which, with due deference to him, we are constrained to say, are without foundation: (1) The Indian traders and hawkers are of no benefit to the Transvaal.
('3', 190, 4, 16, 408284) (2) The Indians are overrunning the country.
('3', 190, 4, 17, 408329) (3) Segregation is necessary on moral and sanitary grounds.
('3', 190, 4, 18, 408389) With the first two, we have dealt already.
('3', 190, 4, 19, 408432) In passing, we may advert to the statement made by the Colonial Secretary that there are only 10,000 Indians in the Transvaal, i.e., hardly half the number of Indians before the war, that only seventy Indian permits are issued weekly as against hundreds of European permits, and that many Indians who had innocently ente red the Colony have been hounded out of it because they entered the
('3', 191, 0, 1, 408821) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 191, 1, 2, 408863) sanitary grounds!
('3', 191, 1, 3, 408881) We seem to be reading the pre war petitions of interested traders presented to the President of the late Orange Free State, which made all kinds of charges of immorality against British Indians.
('3', 191, 1, 4, 409076) The British agents then protected us from them.
('3', 191, 1, 5, 409124) It had remained for Lord Milner to revive them and give the stamp of his high authority.
('3', 191, 1, 6, 409213) His Lordship does not appear to have deigned to give particulars.
('3', 191, 1, 7, 409279) That the staid, sober, industrious, God fearing Indian can do a moral injury to a community with which he may come in contact is a ‘novel’ idea.
('3', 191, 1, 8, 409424) Even the late Transvaal Government never brought such a charge against him.
('3', 191, 1, 9, 409500) We respectfully submit to His Excellency that, in justice to the King’s inoffensive Indian subjects, he should either withdraw it, or substantiate it by producing facts.
('3', 191, 1, 10, 409670) As to the hackneyed charge of insanitation, we refer His Excellency to the voluminous evidence produced by the British Indians in 1896 in refutation.
('3', 191, 1, 11, 409820) That portion of it which is true is not serious, and in any case the fault is largely that of the authorities for the neglect of the community; and the serious portion of it is, in the opinion of unbiased Europeans, not true.
('3', 191, 1, 12, 410046) Dr. Veale, for instance, says:
('3', 191, 2, 13, 410077) I have generally found them (the Indian ) cleanly in their persons, and free from the personal diseases due to dirt or careless habits.
('3', 191, 2, 14, 410213) Their dwellings are generally clean, and sanitation is willingly attended to by them.
('3', 191, 2, 15, 410299) Class considered, I should be of opinion that the lowest class Indian compares more favourably with the lowest class white, i.e., the lowest class Indian lives better, and in better habitation, and with more regard to sanitary measures, than the lowest class white....
('3', 191, 2, 16, 410568) Generally, in my opinion, it is impossible to object to the Indian on sanitary grounds, provided always the inspection by the sanitary authorities is made as strictly and regularly for the Indian as for the white.

('3', 192, 3, 8, 412792) 126. EXPLANATION OF CABLE 1
('3', 192, 4, 9, 412820) JOHANNESBURG, August 10, 1903
('3', 192, 5, 10, 412850) DETAILED EXPLANATION OF THE TELEGRAM DATED AUGUST 4 ANNEXED HERETO
('3', 192, 6, 11, 412917) I beg to enclose herewith copy of the cablegram sent last week; we are anxiously awaiting result.
('3', 192, 6, 12, 413015) The telegram divides itself into seven parts: (1) Non refugee Indians are not allowed to enter the Colony at all, thus causing grave inconvenience to local men.
('3', 192, 7, 13, 413176) 1 This statement was sent by Gandhiji to Dadabhai Naoroji who forwarded it to the Secretary of State for India.
('3', 192, 7, 14, 413288) It was also sent to India which published it, with slight omissions, on 18 9 1903 as from its Johannesburg Correspondent
('3', 193, 0, 1, 413409) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 193, 1, 2, 413451) (2) Even refugee Indians are very sparingly allowed.
('3', 193, 1, 3, 413504) (3) There is a total embargo on Indian arrivals from Natal on the excuse that there is plague there.
('3', 193, 1, 4, 413605) Europeans and Kaffirs are freely allowed.
('3', 193, 1, 5, 413647) Indians in the Transvaal are now permitted to visit Natal and return.
('3', 193, 1, 6, 413717) The embargo is, therefore, hardly a plague prevention.
('3', 193, 1, 7, 413772) (4) Mr. Chamberlain is considering Lord Milner’s dispatch, also the existing anti Indian law, and yet the Government have already laid out 19 Locations.
('3', 193, 1, 8, 413925) Measures, under the existing law, of a temporary nature, may be taken pending replacing legislation, but measures of a permanent character, such as the fixing of Locations, are difficult to understand, if the law is really to be modified.
('3', 193, 1, 9, 414164) (5) Mr. Chamberlain promised that all existing Indian licences to trade outside Locations granted by British Officers would be respected.
('3', 193, 1, 10, 414302) But, apart from such promise, the least that the Indians expect is a recognition of their vested interests under the British Constitution whether they were created before or after the war.
('3', 193, 1, 11, 414491) Under the Bazaar Notice, the licences of those who did not hold such on the outbreak of war are in danger.
('3', 193, 1, 12, 414598) The printed memorial to Lord Milner is still under consideration, but an early assurance regarding the licences is necessary to ease the mind of the community.
('3', 193, 1, 13, 414758) (6) Some licences were granted last year to Indians who did not hold them on the outbreak of war.
('3', 193, 1, 14, 414856) These were not renewed this year by the Officers.
('3', 193, 1, 15, 414906) According to the Bazaar Notice, such licences are renewable up to the end of the year at least.
('3', 193, 1, 16, 415002) Yet on the plea that they have lapsed, the Receiver of Revenue at Johannesburg refuses to renew them, though the fact that they were not renewed at the beginning of the year is no fault of the licensees.
('3', 193, 1, 17, 415206) (7) Lord Milner is reported to have said that compulsory segregation; is necessary on moral and sanitary grounds.
('3', 193, 1, 18, 415320) The charge is so serious that it was thought wise to refute it by cablegram.
('3', 193, 1, 19, 415397) Nothing, more need be said at present about it.

('3', 194, 1, 2, 415963) 127. EVIDENCE AGAINST LORD MILNER’S CHARGE OF INSANITATION
('3', 194, 2, 3, 416022) In view of the cablegram published in the newspapers in the Transvaal to the effect that Lord Milner has dwelt on the insanitary condition of the Indian Location at Johannesburg in his despatch on the proposed change in the existing legislation of the Transvaal, we give below extracts from the evidence given by Dr. F. P. Marais and Dr. Johnston.
('3', 194, 2, 4, 416370) It will be remembered that Dr. Marais is a medical gentleman having bout ten years’ practice in Johannesburg, having large practice among the Indians, and possesses the M.D. degree of Edinburgh.
('3', 194, 2, 5, 416565) Dr. Johnston is a sanitary expert, is a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons, Edinburgh, and holds a diploma of Public Health of Edinburgh and of Glasgow, and possesses very wide South African experience.
('3', 194, 2, 6, 416773) We have not copied the whole of Dr. Johnston’s interesting evidence where he is made, in cross examination, to compare his own statement with that of Dr. Porter, the Medical Officer for Johannesburg.
('3', 194, 2, 7, 416973) Those that have the time to go through the voluminous evidence given before the Johannesburg Insanitary Area Improvement Scheme Commission are referred to the printed evidence published on the 22nd January this year.
('3', 194, 2, 8, 417190) Dr. Porter is a very estimable gentleman, but has next to no experience of life in South Africa.
('3', 194, 2, 9, 417287) To him, anything that fails to come up to the standard observed in London, and is untidy or uncouth, is quite insanitary.
('3', 194, 2, 10, 417409) There is only one word we know that would describe his evidence, namely, hysterical.
('3', 194, 2, 11, 417494) We give one sample.
('3', 194, 2, 12, 417514) This gentleman says of the Indians in the Johannesburg Location:—”They would never think of calling in a doctor and, ostrich like, would consider it the right thing to conceal the existence of the disease.” Dr. Johnston, when asked what he had to say to this evidence, retorted, “You have Dr. Marais’ statement to the contrary.” The reply is conclusive.
('3', 194, 2, 13, 417868) Dr. Marais has had nine years’ practice among the Indians; Dr. Porter, as admitted by himself, has had no ex perience among Indians.
('3', 194, 2, 14, 418001) How did he then know that they “never thought of calling in a doctor,” or that they “consider it the right thing to conceal the existence of the disease”?
('3', 195, 0, 1, 418156) 196 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 195, 1, 2, 418198) However, the extracts we quote from the evidence of the two gentlemen above referred to speak for themselves.
('3', 195, 2, 3, 418308) Dr. F. P. Marais’ Evidence on General Condition (Indians)
('3', 195, 3, 4, 418366) Q.: You have practised among them for a considerable period?
('3', 195, 4, 5, 418427) A.: Yes, for about eight or nine years.

('3', 195, 7, 8, 418550) POSITION
('3', 195, 8, 9, 418559) The position of the Indian Location is good, being on a slope, with a good fall.
('3', 195, 8, 10, 418640) Besides, there is a deep sluit at the lower border, which acts as a drain.
('3', 195, 9, 11, 418715) CONDITION OF SURROUNDINGS
('3', 195, 10, 12, 418741) North side—Perfectly clean.
('3', 195, 11, 13, 418769) South side—Good.
('3', 195, 12, 14, 418786) East side— The big open space was, till lately, used as a depositing site for nearly the whole of Johannesburg, and is in a filthy condition.
('3', 195, 13, 15, 418928) West side—Kelly’s Home, clean.
('3', 195, 14, 16, 418959) Beyond that most disgraceful, due to all sorts of rubbish, manure, etc., being deposited there by the Town Council’s sanitary carts, and others.
('3', 195, 14, 17, 419104) Thus, it will be seen that the Location is fairly well isolated, and the surroundings good, except where they have been rendered insanitary by the Town Council, past and present.

('3', 195, 16, 23, 419651) Not a single case of diptheria, of which I had lately four in Vrededorp, four in Fordsburg, and one in Burghersdorp, at the back of Hoffman’s old bar.

('3', 196, 8, 14, 421246) Yesterday morning I saw two sanitary carts depositing rubbish there.
('3', 196, 9, 15, 421315) HEALTH OF INDIANS
('3', 196, 10, 16, 421333) Now, speaking from your own experience of your patients in the Coolie Location, what have you to say as regards the question of typhoid among the Coolies?—Typhoid is considered to be eminently a filth disease, one of the diseases ascribed particularly to filth and dirt, and the fact that I have not had a single case of typhoid during these nine months speaks well for the Coolie Location.
('3', 196, 11, 17, 421724) Do you think Coolies are not subject to typhoid?—I should think they are as subject as other people.
('3', 196, 12, 18, 421825) Have you had any cases of enteric?—Not a single case.
('3', 196, 13, 19, 421879) SANITARY SERVICE—INDIFFERENT
('3', 196, 14, 20, 421908) Now, with regard to the sanitary service there.
('3', 196, 14, 21, 421956) Is that good, bad, or indifferent, according to your experience?—I should think it pretty indifferent.
('3', 196, 15, 22, 422059) Have you ever had occasion to look at the buckets there?—Yes; in the beginning of September, I attended an old woman, one of the cases of consumption mentioned in my report, and I saw three buckets in a row, all overflowing, which ought to have been carted away by the authorities.
('3', 196, 16, 23, 422341) Have you ever noticed anything in the streets with regard to the sanitary service?—One day I was passing when one of the Coolies called me in and showed me the contents of two buckets being emptied into the road.
('3', 196, 16, 24, 422554) He asked me to give him a
('3', 197, 0, 1, 422580) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 197, 1, 2, 422622) certificate to the effect that I had seen it, as he wanted to go to the Town Council and complain.
('3', 197, 1, 3, 422721) I gave him a certificate that I saw the contents Iying there, but I did not see them being emptied.
('3', 197, 1, 4, 422821) I saw the contents, and there was no doubt that the contents had come out of the buckets.
('3', 197, 2, 5, 422911) A COMPARISON—POOR WHITES AND POOR INDIANS
('3', 197, 3, 6, 422953) With regard to the overcrowding there, do you think the Coolie Location is very much overcrowded?—I do not think it nearly as bad as some parts of Ferreira’s Township and other parts of Johannesburg.
('3', 197, 4, 7, 423153) Have you occasion to go to the Coolie Location at night?—Yes, I have a good practice all over these parts among the Coolies, and I find that they (meaning Europeans) are very much overcrowded in Ferreira’s Township, almost worse, I should say, than in the Coolie Location.
('3', 197, 5, 8, 423426) Now, among poor white areas, have you seen any overcrowding there?— Yes, there is great overcrowding near the Goods Station, at the west end of Kerk Street and Jeppe Street, amongst poorer classes of whites.
('3', 197, 6, 9, 423634) CROSS EXAMINATION—IS THE LOCATION SANITARY?
('3', 197, 7, 10, 423678) The Coolie Location.
('3', 197, 7, 11, 423699) Are you prepared to pledge your professional credit and state that that Location is a sanitary place?—I am prepared to state that it is as sanitary as many parts of Johannesburg.
('3', 197, 8, 12, 423878) Pardon me, we will come to that presently.
('3', 197, 8, 13, 423921) We are dealing with the Coolie Location.
('3', 197, 8, 14, 423962) Are you prepared to state that, in your opinion, that is a sanitary area?
('3', 197, 8, 15, 424036) —I am prepared to state that the soil is as good as any soil in Johannesburg.
('3', 197, 9, 16, 424114) Never mind the soil; I am speaking of the whole area.—Some of the houses are insanitary, but the majority of them are not insanitary.
('3', 197, 10, 17, 424248) My question was whether the area, as a whole, was a sanitary area?—As a whole, I would say the area is sanitary.
('3', 197, 11, 18, 424361) You say that, on the whole, you consider this area sanitary?—Yes.
('3', 197, 12, 19, 424427) The Coolie Location?—Yes.
('3', 197, 12, 20, 424453) I have been amongst these people for the last ten years, and now I know almost every house.
('3', 197, 13, 21, 424545) And from your intimate acquaintance as a medical practitioner in that neighbourhood, you say that the area as a whole is sanitary?—As a whole, it is sanitary.
('3', 197, 14, 22, 424704) You are aware that several medical gentlemen in practice in Johannesburg have given strong evidence to the contrary?—I know doctors differ.
('3', 197, 15, 23, 424844) And you are prepared to differ from them?—I am prepared.

('3', 198, 1, 2, 424942) JOHNSTON’S EVIDENCE
('3', 198, 2, 3, 424962) Dr. Johnston, the Specialist, on the Condition of the Buildings in the Indian Location
('3', 198, 3, 4, 425049) Examined by Mr. Balfour.
('3', 198, 4, 5, 425074) You are a Fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons, Edinburgh?—Yes.
('3', 198, 5, 6, 425141) And you hold a diploma of Public Health of Edinburgh and of Glasgow?— Yes, a Diploma of Glasgow and of Edinburgh.
('3', 198, 6, 7, 425255) How long have you been practising in Johannesburg?—Since August, 1895.
('3', 198, 7, 8, 425326) And how long in the Transvaal?—That is the time I have been practising in the Transvaal.
('3', 198, 8, 9, 425415) Now, then, with regard to the building on the Coolie Location, I understand that on the former occasion you made a house to house visitation?—Yes.
('3', 198, 9, 10, 425562) And you saw a good many houses, a day or two ago?—I did see a certain number.
('3', 198, 10, 11, 425640) Now, speaking generally, what is your general opinion in regard to the buildings on these stands?—There are stands on which there is a certain amount of over crowding, that is where buildings are huddled together.
('3', 198, 10, 12, 425854) Dr. Porter calls them “congeries of narrow courtyards”.
('3', 198, 10, 13, 425910) Well, there are one or two cases that might be described as such, but, taking the area as a whole, it is not overcrowded with buildings.
('3', 198, 10, 14, 426047) On nearly every stand where there are buildings, they have got a regular square courtyard, and in most instances the buildings are ranged round the courtyard.
('3', 198, 10, 15, 426206) I have not come across one instance where there was no courtyard, as, if there was no courtyard on one stand, then they had the courtyard on an adjoining stand.
('3', 198, 10, 16, 426367) I do not know whether it is a feature of the buildings of the Indians or not, but it certainly prevails there.
('3', 198, 11, 17, 426478) Speaking generally, are these courtyards usually wide enough for health purposes?—Yes; and I think it a very wise provision on the part of those Indians that they made these particular courtyards.
('3', 198, 12, 18, 426675) Are they wide enough for purposes of ventilation?—They are exceedingly good for purposes of ventilation.
('3', 198, 12, 19, 426780) In these courtyards, they seem to sit a good deal, instead of in their houses.
('3', 198, 13, 20, 426859) The result of building the rooms round the courtyard is that every room opens directly into the air?—Yes; into the courtyard.
('3', 198, 14, 21, 426985) Now, there were some buildings you found to be very bad?—There are some not in a good state of repair.
('3', 198, 15, 22, 427088) Will you mention the worst place?—The worst one I came across was on Stand No.
('3', 198, 15, 23, 427167) 28, belonging to a man named Bajanath.
('3', 198, 16, 24, 427206) What was the nature of that?—On that stand, fronting the house, there is a
('3', 199, 0, 1, 427281) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 199, 1, 2, 427323) sod built house, what is known as a lean to house.
('3', 199, 1, 3, 427374) I specially wanted to see that, because it struck me as being particularly bad.
('3', 199, 1, 4, 427454) I accordingly told the man, with whom I went, that I wished very much to see that particular stand, and he took me over it.
('3', 199, 1, 5, 427578) I found this low sod house, and in the courtyard a number of what I should describe as scratch work tin shanties.
('3', 199, 1, 6, 427692) The whole of the buildings on that stand one would condemn as being filthy, and although I should say there is plenty of air in these tin shanties, still they are not such as one would like to see in a place like Johannesburg.
('3', 199, 1, 7, 427919) I saw in the centre of this yard a great many bricks, and I asked the meaning of it.
('3', 199, 2, 8, 428004) Mr. Forster: I do not think this is evidence.
('3', 199, 3, 9, 428050) The Witness: I was told the bricks were there for the purpose of erecting a new building.
('3', 199, 3, 10, 428140) That was what the Indian told me.
('3', 199, 4, 11, 428174) Mr. Forster: I do not want to know what anyone told you.

('3', 199, 7, 17, 428746) There may be one or two other stands, not sod buildings, but iron buildings, which might be improved.

('3', 199, 8, 19, 428964) — I have not estimated the total number of buildings I would condemn, but I do not think that there are very many which I would condemn purely for insanitary reasons.
('3', 199, 8, 20, 429131) I have not my notes with me which I took in June last.

('3', 199, 9, 22, 429212) 128. AN EYE OPENER
('3', 199, 10, 23, 429231) MR. MOOR’S REPORT
('3', 199, 11, 24, 429249) Elsewhere we print the report drawn up by Mr. Moor, the Assistant Colonial Secretary of the Transvaal.
('3', 199, 11, 25, 429352) It is a document of abiding interest to the Indian community giving, as it does, a resume of the position of the British Indians as on and up to the 31st December, 1902. The position has considerably changed since then.
('3', 199, 11, 26, 429572) All the same, the report is a very fair indication of the intentions of the Government.
('3', 199, 11, 27, 429660) In one respect, at any rate, the Government have
('3', 200, 0, 1, 429709) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 201
('3', 200, 1, 2, 429750) considerably changed their attitude, to the detriment of the British Indians.
('3', 200, 1, 3, 429828) We refer to the enforcement of the £3 registration.
('3', 200, 1, 4, 429880) Mr. Moor says, in the report under review, that the £3 registration is not to be enforced.
('3', 200, 1, 5, 429971) Now, however, it has been enforced with the utmost rigour.
('3', 200, 1, 6, 430030) Several prosecutions, too, have taken place and, in some cases, fines have been imposed on those who failed to have their names registered.
('3', 200, 1, 7, 430170) We wish to correct one statement made by Mr. Moor, namely, that the Resolution 1101 of the Executive Council of the late Government, notifying its intention to enforce the provisions of Law 3 of 1885, was being carried out before war until the cause for it was removed by the exodus of the British Indians.
('3', 200, 1, 8, 430477) An attempt was undoubtedly made, but owing to the intervention of the then British Agent and the then Vice Consul, no proceedings whatsoever were taken, and when the Boer Government was asked about the notification issued to the different Landrosts, 1 the British Agent was assured that the Law was not to be enforced.
('3', 200, 1, 9, 430796) Not a single British Indian was ever compulsorily removed to Locations or prevented from trading outside Locations.
('3', 200, 1, 10, 430912) Mr. Moor’s summary of the objections on the part of the Europeans to the presence of the Indians shews the same lack of knowledge on their part as has been dwelt upon by the British Indians.
('3', 200, 1, 11, 431103) We, therefore, do not propose to deal with them for the present.
('3', 200, 1, 12, 431168) With due respect to Mr. Moor, we feel constrained to say that he has fallen into the popular error of confusing immigration of Indian labour with the free immigration of people who pay their own passage and wish to enter the Transvaal as independent men.
('3', 200, 1, 13, 431423) He also, evidently mixes up the Indentured Immigration Act of Natal with the free immigration, and proceeds to suggest legislation under the belief that it would be similar to the legislation in other South African Colonies.
('3', 200, 1, 14, 431648) On no other ground would it be possible to understand the proposal that, (first,) permits should be issued to those who may produce indentures from a responsible employer, (second,) that they should pay, by way of registration, £5 per head, (third,) that they should take out passes at 1/ each to control their movement.
('3', 200, 1, 15, 431969) The first provision presupposes that every Asiatic has to enter the Transvaal only as an indentured labourer.
('3', 200, 1, 16, 432079) The payment of £5 has, we suppose, been copied from the Natal Act, which imposes a penalty of £3 annually on those indentured Indians who may wish to settle in the Colony after the
('3', 200, 2, 17, 432260) 1 District Magistrates.
('3', 201, 0, 1, 432284) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 201, 1, 2, 432326) expiry of their indentures.
('3', 201, 1, 3, 432354) The pass proposal, also, we presume, owes its origin to the Natal Laws.
('3', 201, 1, 4, 432426) This shews that Mr. Moor has not been able to distinguish between Natal legislation regulating labour and the legislation regarding immigration.
('3', 201, 1, 5, 432571) Although we are quite willing to think that the confusion on Mr. Moor’s part is an oversight, it does a great deal of injustice to the British Indians.
('3', 201, 1, 6, 432723) Coming as it does so authoritatively, it is likely to produce a wrong impression on the minds of the people in the Tran svaal and abroad.
('3', 201, 1, 7, 432861) We hope, however, that it is unnecessary for us to deal with these proposals at any great length in view of the fact that the policy of the Government has since been considerably changed, and that new legislation is being considered.
('3', 201, 1, 8, 433095) But the report in question shews how imperative it is for our countrymen in the Transvaal to be ever on the look out for danger from unexpected sources.
('3', 201, 1, 9, 433248) The report, moreover, proves most clearly that much of the prejudice against British Indians is based on want of knowledge.
('3', 201, 1, 10, 433372) Every Indian, therefore, should consider it his duty to make a decided effort towards dispelling the existing prejudice by spreading correct information with reference to the habits of the In dian community as well as its aspirations.
('3', 201, 1, 11, 433607) The best way to do it is for each and every one of us to endeavour to live the life of a model Indian.
('3', 201, 1, 12, 433710) What that means is known to everyone who knows anything at all about India, and ought to be known to every Indian child.
('3', 201, 1, 13, 433831) In the last portion of the report in question, Mr. Moor says: “Asiatics would, on the whole, welcome the restriction of Bazaars on plans in conformity with those traditions to which they have been accustomed in the East,” and that “they perceive that the concentration and grouping of their trades in fixed quarters would extend the scope of their business and attract buyers in large numbers”.
('3', 201, 1, 14, 434226) This, to us, is a revelation, and unless we have positive proof, we must refuse to believe that any responsible Indian could ever have made the statement.
('3', 201, 1, 15, 434381) It is simply suicidal, and contrary to the effort of the Indian community, which it has been making in the Transvaal for the last fifteen years, to have the Location legislation removed.
('3', 201, 1, 16, 434568) How is it possible that any well knowing Indian could so suddenly change his mind, and advocate and accept the principle of compulsory segregation, whether it be called Bazaars or Locations?
('3', 201, 1, 17, 434759) Indian Opinion, 13 8 1903

('3', 202, 1, 2, 434826) 129. GREYTOWN LOCAL BOARD
('3', 202, 2, 3, 434852) The Greytown Local Board is much perplexed over the possibility of an Indian buying or leasing land that is to be thrown open.
('3', 202, 2, 4, 434979) The Principal Under Secretary says in reply to its representation that the matter has been placed before His Excellency the Governor, who in his turn has sent the papers to Mr. Chamberlain.
('3', 202, 2, 5, 435169) Mr. Meek, a member of the Board, considers it “inconvenient to prolong the matter for another year, awaiting negotiations”.
('3', 202, 2, 6, 435293) The Board has said the word, and it must come to pass without delay.
('3', 202, 2, 7, 435362) “In the beginning,” we read, “[God said] Let there be light, and there was light.” Now the Greytown Local Board is to give the fiat regarding British Indians, and who shall say nay !
('3', 202, 2, 8, 435545) Seriously, we do not understand why, whenever it is the Indian who is concerned, the proposal is always to adopt any but the legitimate course.
('3', 202, 2, 9, 435689) In the first place, we do not think there is any danger of an Indian buying land in Greytown in residential quarters.
('3', 202, 2, 10, 435807) Secondly, in what way is he going to be an objection, if he puts up a structure in keeping with the bye laws and the surroundings?

('3', 202, 2, 12, 435991) But a little regard for the feelings of the Indian, and the roughness would have gone without the Colonists running the risk of being in any way inconvenienced by the presence of the Indian.

('3', 202, 4, 14, 436208) 130. A SUR REJOINDER
('3', 202, 5, 15, 436229) The East Rand Express has paid us the compliment of quoting and replying to our remarks on the quarrel that is going on between Mr. Moor and the Boksburg Health Board on the latter’s proposal to remove the present Indian Location to One Tree Hill.
('3', 202, 5, 16, 436477) Our contemporary thinks that, in holding that the Government alone has the right to fix Locations, we have indulged in special pleading.
('3', 202, 5, 17, 436614) We may be permitted to say that we have done nothing of the kind.
('3', 202, 5, 18, 436680) We remind our contemporary of the fact that the Government Notice, it is not even a proclamation, is merely an indication of its intention to enforce the anti Asiatic law of the Transvaal, and it lays down rules as to how and to what extent it is to be enforced.
('3', 202, 5, 19, 436943) Our contemporary must know that the Government cannot alter or add to the law itself: that
('3', 203, 0, 1, 437034) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 203, 1, 2, 437076) could only be done by the Legislative Council.
('3', 203, 1, 3, 437123) Now the law says, “the Government shall have the right to appoint special streets, wards, and locations as their residence.” There is, therefore, no power reserved under the law to the Health Boards or Town Councils.
('3', 203, 1, 4, 437340) It is then quite clear that the notice in question merely pays a compliment to such Boards, in re quiring the Colonial Secretary to fix Locations in consultation with Local Boards.
('3', 203, 1, 5, 437521) It also presupposes a reasonable attitude on their part, and, to say the least of it, we venture to think that it is hardly correct for the Boksburg Health Board to convert what is a compliment during pleasure into a right, and to dictate to the Colonial Secretary.
('3', 203, 1, 6, 437787) We have dealt with this matter at length, because we feel that the Board has taken up a position which is clearly not warranted by law.
('3', 203, 1, 7, 437923) We could wish our contemporary had not written the concluding sentences of its rejoinder.
('3', 203, 1, 8, 438013) They seem to convey a threat to the Indians living in the present Location.
('3', 203, 1, 9, 438089) We should be sorry to think that the people of Boksburg would so far forget themselves and the Imperial tie as to take the law in their own hands.
('3', 203, 1, 10, 438236) And if threats are to frighten the residents of the Location, they would deserve to go.
('3', 203, 1, 11, 438324) There is no room for cowards in South Africa.
('3', 203, 1, 12, 438370) We are reminded of the incident that happened in Aliwal North some years ago.
('3', 203, 1, 13, 438448) Then, in spite of the feeling of the focal Europeans, the Magistrate refused to withhold from an Indian merchant the renewal of his licence which he had been in possession of for several years.
('3', 203, 1, 14, 438642) The enraged gentlemen therefore— in hundreds—marched to the store of the offending Indian, and threatened divers penalties if he did not remove bag and baggage from the town.
('3', 203, 1, 15, 438817) The Indian, in face of tremendous odds, stood his ground, and firmly refused to budge.
('3', 203, 1, 16, 438904) The sequel was, protection was ultimately given to him, and he was left unmolested.
('3', 203, 1, 17, 438988) We are living under British, not Russian, rule.

('3', 204, 6, 10, 439404) 1902 1906
('3', 204, 7, 11, 439414) 132. THE USES OF ADVERSITY
('3', 204, 8, 12, 439441) There can be no question that the British Indians in South Africa are hemmed in on all sides by restrictions more or less severe according to the Colonies in which they are imposed, and that they are also very much misunderstood.
('3', 204, 8, 13, 439671) By this time, those of our readers who have followed these columns at all, attentively, would have noticed that there is ample proof for the two statements we have just made.
('3', 204, 8, 14, 439846) The purpose of this article is to draw some lessons from these adverse circumstances.
('3', 204, 8, 15, 439932) We are told “Sweet are the uses of adversity,” which should be “the instructor of the wise.” Let us see, then, whether we have learnt any lessons from adversity.
('3', 204, 8, 16, 440094) There are, in India, sharp divisions between the different races inhabiting it; for instance, the Tamils, the ‘Calcutta men’, as the inhabitants of the upper provinces are called here, the Panjabis, the Gujaratis, etc.
('3', 204, 8, 17, 440313) There are also the Mahomedans, the Hindus, the Parsis, and others, according to religions.
('3', 204, 8, 18, 440404) Then, among the Hindus there are the Brahmans, the Kshatriyas, the Baniyas, and others.
('3', 204, 8, 19, 440492) Now, to our mind, if we have brought from India these divisions and differences as very valuable cargo to be treasured up all this distance, then there is no doubt that it would clog us at every step, and hinder our progress.
('3', 204, 8, 20, 440718) South Africa ought to be to the British Indians a great Puri 1 where all divisions are abolished and levelled up.
('3', 204, 8, 21, 440832) We are not, and ought not to be, Tamils or Calcutta men, Mahomedans or
('3', 204, 9, 22, 440903) 1 A town in Orissa famous for the temple of Jagannath, ‘Lord of the Universe’, where caste distinctions are not observed.
('3', 205, 0, 1, 441025) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 205, 1, 2, 441067) Hindus, Brahmans or Baniyas, but simply and solely British Indians, and as such we must sink or swim together.
('3', 205, 1, 3, 441178) That the interests of all the divisions are absolutely identical cannot be gainsaid.
('3', 205, 1, 4, 441263) That being so, it is plain enough that our duty lies in doing away with any such prejudices.
('3', 205, 1, 5, 441356) That is a preliminary step, and an indispensable one.
('3', 205, 1, 6, 441410) We are quite aware that our people have made a very great advance in that direction, but in drawing general lessons from our difficulties, the statement would be incomplete without a warning.
('3', 205, 1, 7, 441602) It is also incumbent on every Indian not merely to be satisfied with having made sufficient to feed and clothe himself and his family; he must be prepared to put his hands deep into his pocket for the public weal, and here again we know that the community throughout South Africa has not altogether failed in its duty, but we have no hesitation in saying that it might have done much better.
('3', 205, 1, 8, 441994) Courage and patience are qualities which one needs very badly when one is placed in difficult circumstances.
('3', 205, 1, 9, 442103) We had, during the late war, a precious opportunity of watching these two qualities at their best among Englishmen in South Africa.
('3', 205, 1, 10, 442235) The history of the siege of Ladysmith and its relief will always be an example of invulnerable courage and inexhaustible patience.
('3', 205, 1, 11, 442366) Many Indians who took part as stretcher bearers will be able to recollect the scenes that they were witnesses to at the fights of Colenso and Spion Kop.
('3', 205, 1, 12, 442519) In spite of fearful odds and bad reverses, there was no yielding.
('3', 205, 1, 13, 442585) When at one time, even General Buller was inclined to think that relief was impossible, the world knows that there flashed across the wire a message from the hero of Candahar, that as long as General Buller had one man left with him, he was not to give in.
('3', 205, 1, 14, 442842) The great result we all know.
('3', 205, 1, 15, 442872) Ours is not a struggle so difficult, or so heroic to contend against, but it teaches a lesson in courage and patience which we ought to learn.
('3', 205, 1, 16, 443015) If no sum of money, no quantity of blood and no amount of time were considered too great for the honour of the British Empire to relieve what were, after all, a handful of the besieged in Ladysmith, shall we not think similarly when we are engaged in a struggle for our liberties, and come to the conclusion that we must have courage and patience enough to tide over passing misfortunes?
('3', 205, 1, 17, 443403) We should not forget that “Calamity is man’s true touchstone,” and that “none can cure their harms by bewailing them”.
('3', 205, 1, 18, 443522) But we require something more also.
('3', 205, 1, 19, 443558) We are apt as a nation, and the Missionaries have brought it up against us as a charge, to look at things material with philosophical indifference, and make little of
('3', 206, 0, 1, 443725) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 207
('3', 206, 1, 2, 443766) everyday comforts of life.
('3', 206, 1, 3, 443793) Now, that is an attitude for which we haveunbounded admiration; but it would be very much misplaced in South Africa.
('3', 206, 1, 4, 443910) Such an attitude would be a credit to those who do not strive after material gain, but it becomes a misnomer in the case of those who strive their utmost in order to enrich themselves; and we do not know that there are many Indians in South Africa who have migrated with any other desire than that of bettering their material position.
('3', 206, 1, 5, 444246) To such, then, it would be more philosophical to fall in with the natural order of things, and to be prepared to spend in proportion to their earnings.
('3', 206, 1, 6, 444398) The charge, then, against the Indians that they live on nothing a year would be dispelled.
('3', 206, 1, 7, 444489) At the same time, nothing can be further from our thoughts than to suggest that we, as a community, should give ourselves up to pleasure.
('3', 206, 1, 8, 444627) What we do wish to emphasize is the fact that we ought, as far as may be, to “do in Rome as the Romans do”, still retaining the attitude of mental indifference.
('3', 206, 1, 9, 444788) If we can have such comforts, well and good; and if we cannot, well and good, also.
('3', 206, 1, 10, 444872) But, above all else, what is most needed in a community which considers itself to be ill treated at the hands of others is the virtue of love and charity.
('3', 206, 1, 11, 445027) It is well known that, after all, men, being creatures of circumstances, would do things which are unjustifiable quite unconsciously, owing to the control exercised over them by the circumstances in which they are placed.
('3', 206, 1, 12, 445249) Is it not, then, necessary for us to be charitable in our judgments?
('3', 206, 1, 13, 445318) We, as a people, are devoted to religious speculations, and to doctrines of non resistance and of returning good for evil.
('3', 206, 1, 14, 445441) We believe firmly in the fact of even our thought colouring the actions of those of whom we may think.
('3', 206, 1, 15, 445544) We see such instances often in daily life.
('3', 206, 1, 16, 445587) A great crime committed by a man has been known to change his face in such a way as to stamp the crime on it.
('3', 206, 1, 17, 445697) Similarly, a great good act done by a man has produced the opposite effect on his features, and he has been known, as the case may be, either to attract to, or to repulse from, himself people by his very act.
('3', 206, 1, 18, 445906) We then hold it to be our paramount duty not to think evil of those who we may consider are dealing unjustly by us.
('3', 206, 1, 19, 446022) There is hardly any virtue in the ability to do a good turn to those that have done similarly by us.
('3', 206, 1, 20, 446123) That even the criminals do.
('3', 206, 1, 21, 446151) But it would be some credit if a good turn could be done to an opponent.
('3', 206, 1, 22, 446224) If this very simple thing be always borne in mind, we do think that success will come to us far more quickly than we are likely to imagine.
('3', 206, 1, 23, 446364) We hope, as time goes by, to develop more fully each one of the points cursorily
('3', 207, 0, 1, 446445) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 207, 1, 2, 446487) touched upon in this article.
('3', 207, 1, 3, 446517) At present, it is enough for us to ask our countrymen to ponder over what we have said, and to be always on the alert, otherwise, storm tossed as we are, a surging wave may all of a sudden come upon us and engulf us, when any action we may wish to take will be Too Late.
('3', 207, 1, 4, 446788) Indian Opinion, 20 8 1903
('3', 207, 2, 5, 446814) 133. STANDING COUNSEL FOR SOUTH AFRICA
('3', 207, 3, 6, 446853) Truly does Mr. Chamberlain hold a brief for the white Colonists in South Africa.
('3', 207, 3, 7, 446934) Whether good or bad, the cause of South Africa he has made his own.
('3', 207, 3, 8, 447002) He believes, and to a very great extent thinks rightly, that his business is to conserve the interests of the Colonies to the exclusion of every other, be it ever so great or just.
('3', 207, 3, 9, 447183) And if the other ministers do not do justice to their clients, and if, as a consequence, they suffer, it is no fault of the Colonial Secretary.
('3', 207, 3, 10, 447327) It is in that spirit that he has treated the very reasonable proposals of the East India Association suggesting an impartial inquiry into the question of anti Indian legislation in the Transvaal.
('3', 207, 3, 11, 447523) As counsel for his clients, he could not very well accept a proposal which might compromise their position.
('3', 207, 3, 12, 447631) He would, therefore, enter into correspondence with Lord George Hamilton, counsel for the British Indians.
('3', 207, 3, 13, 447738) Such a procedure leaves the position of the Colonists unfettered.
('3', 207, 3, 14, 447804) The charges made by them against British Indians would remain unrefuted; and much less will have to be granted to the Indians labouring under such charges than would have been the case if the inquiry had been undertaken and the finding had exonerated them.
('3', 207, 3, 15, 448061) The generous effort of Sir William Wedderburn and the East India Association has met with little response; still, we do not lose courage or hope.
('3', 207, 3, 16, 448207) Mr. Chamberlain is undoubtedly sympathetic; Lord George Hamilton has promised to do everything he can to secure justice; and we doubt not that the Colonists, for whom Mr. Chamberlain has been doing so much, will not fail to accept his advice to extend to the British Indian settlers “fair and honourable treatment”.

('3', 208, 0, 1, 448549) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 209
('3', 208, 1, 2, 448590) 134. ACCIDENT?
('3', 208, 2, 3, 448605) The catastrophe at Paris 1 must have filled all the portions of the globe where the news reached with gloom.
('3', 208, 2, 4, 448714) We can well imagine the feelings of the victims and the survivors.
('3', 208, 2, 5, 448781) To us, these untoward happenings are not merely accidents but we look upon them as divine visitations from which we, if we chose, may learn rich lessons.
('3', 208, 2, 6, 448935) To us, they show a grim tragedy behind all the tinsel splendour of the modern civilization.
('3', 208, 2, 7, 449027) The ceaseless rush in which we are living does not leave any time for contemplating the full results of events such as have placed Paris in mourning for the time being.
('3', 208, 2, 8, 449196) The dead will be soon forgotten, and in a very short time, Paris will again resume its usual gaiety as if nothing whatsoeverhad happened.
('3', 208, 2, 9, 449334) Those, however, who will give the accident, if so it may be called, more than a passing thought, cannot fail to realize that behind all the splendour and behind all the glittering appearances there is something very real which is missed altogether.
('3', 208, 2, 10, 449583) To us, the meaning is quite dear, namely, that all of us have to live the present life merely as a preparation for a future, far more certain and far more real.
('3', 208, 2, 11, 449744) Nothing that the modern civilization can offer in the way of stability can ever make any more certain that which is inherently uncertain; that, when we come to think of it, the boast about the wonderful discoveries and the marvellous inventions of science, good as they undoubtedly are in themselves, is, after all, an empty boast.
('3', 208, 2, 12, 450076) They offer nothing substantial to the struggling humanity, and the only consolation that one can derive from such visitations has to come from a firm faith not in the theory, but in the fact, of the existence of a future life and real Godhead.
('3', 208, 2, 13, 450320) And that alone is worth having or worth cultivating which would enable us to realise our Maker and to feel that, after all, on this earth we are merely sojourners.

('3', 209, 1, 2, 450680) 135. THE BLEEDING CRY
('3', 209, 2, 3, 450702) Will His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor of the Transvaal, who is now also the Governor of that Colony and High Commissioner for South Africa, amid all his multifarious duties find time to listen to the bleeding cry of the British Indian refugees in Natal who are suffering agony owing to being prevented from returning to their homes?
('3', 209, 2, 4, 451041) The number of cases that are being brought to our notice from day to day is very serious, and if His Excellency would only relax the embargo, it would be nothing more than an act of humanity, pure and simple.
('3', 209, 2, 5, 451250) We have said before that there is no consistency about the plague policy of the Transvaal Government.
('3', 209, 2, 6, 451352) They allow hundreds of Europeans and thousands of Kaffirs to enter the Transvaal from Natal from week to week without any restrictions whatsoever.
('3', 209, 2, 7, 451499) The poor Indian refugees, so anxious they are to return to the Transvaal, have offered to undergo quarantine at Volksrust at their own expense, and still the Transvaal Government have so far turned a deaf ear to their petition.
('3', 209, 2, 8, 451727) 1 Latterly, they have been allowing Indians from the Transvaal to enter this Colony and return.
('3', 209, 2, 9, 451823) Will they not carry with them the plague germs and spread the dread disease in the Colony of the Transvaal?
('3', 209, 2, 10, 451931) The Government evidently seem to think they will not.
('3', 209, 2, 11, 451985) In their opinion, there must be something very special about the British Indian refugees in Natal that renders them more susceptible to plague than any other class of people.
('3', 209, 2, 12, 452160) Really, this is going altogether too far, and unheard of in a British Colony.
('3', 209, 2, 13, 452238) If the embargo is political, it would be simple honest to make the confession, and tell the British Indian refugees in Natal that they need not hope ever to return to the Transvaal.
('3', 209, 2, 14, 452420) Such a reply, if very unjust to the petitioners, would at any rate be honest and remove the extreme sus pense under which the poor refugees are at present labouring.
('3', 209, 2, 15, 452586) I they may not claim to return to their homes, they have a right to be made absolutely certain as to their position, one way or the other, and we sincerely trust that the Transvaal Government would see their way to make a definite and decisive reply so that they would know Where they are.

('3', 209, 3, 17, 452902) 1 This is not available.

('3', 210, 1, 2, 452968) 136. PERMITS AND NON REFUGEES
('3', 210, 2, 3, 452998) Apropos of the plague embargo, we might once more mention the severe restrictions that are imposed about the granting of permits to British Indian refugees throughout South Africa and the total prohibition against non refugee Indians The granting of 70 permits only per week to bona fide refugees is altogether inadequate.
('3', 210, 2, 4, 453321) As the Colonial Secretary informed the Legislative Assembly, there be a iv thousand applications still undisposed of from applicants in South Africa.
('3', 210, 2, 5, 453471) This does not take into account hundreds of Indians who are still in India and have not been able to return to South Africa for some reason or other.
('3', 210, 2, 6, 453621) We Ail to understand the reason for preventing the refugees from returning except in dribblets.
('3', 210, 2, 7, 453717) That they have a right to enter the Colony is not disputed.
('3', 210, 2, 8, 453777) If the only reason, therefore, that all are not allowed to return at once, be that of fear of congestion and too many Indians unable to support themselves entering the Colony, that would be undoubtedly a very fair objection, but there is a remedy, and a very safe one, against any such evil.
('3', 210, 2, 9, 454069) Every refugee can be made to give reliable security that, on his entry into the Transvaal, he will not only be able to find suitable residence but that he has friends ready to support him in case of need.
('3', 210, 2, 10, 454274) Then there need be no fear of overcrowding or starvation.
('3', 210, 2, 11, 454332) The prohibition against non refugees is also, in our opinion, very unjust It means serious inconvenience to the Indian traders and others who may require assistants, salesmen or servants.
('3', 210, 2, 12, 454520) And it is exceedingly unfair to the refugees themselves, who are deprived of earning in the Transvaal a certain livelihood which might be offered to them.
('3', 210, 2, 13, 454675) We do not contend for one moment that all newcomers should be allowed to enter the Transvaal unrestricted, but we do think that those who have actual employment offered to them ought to be allowed to join such employment, without any hindrance.
('3', 210, 2, 14, 454920) We, therefore, hope that the Transvaal Government will be pleased to give this matter also their sympathetic consideration.

('3', 211, 1, 2, 455112) 137. INDIAN TRADE LICENCES IN THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 211, 2, 3, 455156) JOHANNESBURG, August 22, 1903 Lord Milner’s dispatch, dated May 11 and addressed to the Secretary of State for the Colonies, has been received by this week’s mail.
('3', 211, 2, 4, 455320) The Indian community is grateful to His Excellency for the sympathy he has shown for them and regard for their feelings.
('3', 211, 2, 5, 455441) There are, however, statements therein which require correction.
('3', 211, 2, 6, 455506) It appears that they have been made on the persistent assertions of the members of the White League.
('3', 211, 2, 7, 455607) His Excellency says in his despatch:
('3', 211, 3, 8, 455644) Had we had to deal merely with the Asiatic population as it existed before the war, it might have been possible to remain passive until a new law could have been framed to the satisfaction of His Majesty’s Government But, with so many newcomers constantly pouring in and applying for licences to trade, and with the European population protesting with ever increasing vehemence against the indiscriminate granting of such licences and against the neglect of the Government to enforce the law which restricts Asiatics to locations specially set apart for their residence, it became impossible to persist in the policy of complete inaction.
('3', 211, 3, 9, 456283) It is submitted that the Asiatic population even at the present day is smaller than it was before the war.
('3', 211, 3, 10, 456390) The registration law has been enforced, and the result has been to show that there are not more than 10,000 Indians at present in the Colony.
('3', 211, 3, 11, 456532) The official report published by the Government shows that there were at least 15,000 British Indians in the Colony prior to the war.
('3', 211, 3, 12, 456666) Both these statements are official.
('3', 211, 3, 13, 456702) Moreover, stringent “permit” regulations prevent any but British Indian refugees from entering the Transvaal.
('3', 211, 3, 14, 456812) It is, therefore, hardly correct to say that the enforcement of the law became necessary owing to “so many newcomers constantly pouring in and applying for licences to trade”.
('3', 211, 3, 15, 456988) Moreover, the Bazaar Notice deals not merely with applicants for new licences but with all, whether they held licences prior to the war or not, subject to reservations made therein.
('3', 211, 3, 16, 457170) Had the Government declined to issue licences to non refugees, there would be nothing to complain about, but as it is, the whole of the law is at present directed against bona fide refugees.
('3', 211, 3, 17, 457361) His Excellency says:
('3', 211, 4, 18, 457382) The Government are anxious, however, to do so (enforce the law) in the manner most considerate to the Indians already settled in the country, and with
('3', 212, 0, 1, 457533) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 213
('3', 212, 1, 2, 457574) the greatest respect for vested interests, even where these have been allowed to spring up contrary to law.
('3', 212, 1, 3, 457682) As has already been said in a previous letter, as well as in the printed memorial 1 submitted to His Excellency, vested interests are not respected in the sense here understood.
('3', 212, 1, 4, 457860) Hundreds of Indians whotraded before the war contrary to law (that is, without licences) are under notice to remove to Locations at the end of the year, causing complete dislocation of Indian businesses.
('3', 212, 1, 5, 458064) Moreover, all the partners of a single firm are not allowed licences, but only one of them who happens fortunately to be in the country and anticipate his other part ners.
('3', 212, 1, 6, 458236) Nor are they allowed to remove their trade from one place to another in different districts.
('3', 212, 1, 7, 458329) Nor are the licences transferable from one person to another, a prohibition which completely deprives the trader of the value of his goodwill.
('3', 212, 1, 8, 458472) Thus, it will be seen that every Indian trader must ultimately remove his business to the Location.
('3', 212, 1, 9, 458572) His Excellency says (in answer to the complaint that the anti Asiatic laws are being more rigorously enforced under the British regime than under the Boer regime):
('3', 212, 2, 10, 458736) (1) It (Government) is providing in every town special quarters in which Asiatics may reside, and in the selection of these quarters, it is doing its best to choose sites not only healthy but affording reasonable opportunities for trade.
('3', 212, 3, 11, 458974) (2) It has declared its intention not to disturb Asiatics who had established themselves in business before the war,.
('3', 212, 3, 12, 459092) but to renew their licences.
('3', 212, 3, 13, 459121) Under the old Government, all these men were under notice to quit.
('3', 212, 4, 14, 459188) (3) It proposes to exempt Asiatics of a superior class from all special legislation.
('3', 212, 4, 15, 459273) With reference to the first, it is hardly a relief that Locations will be established in every town, for it is against the establishment of these that the Indians very successfully protested under the old regime.
('3', 212, 4, 16, 459486) With the exception, therefore, of a few towns, the late Transvaal Government did not dare lay out any Locations.
('3', 212, 4, 17, 459599) Now the Government have already selected sites for nearly twenty townships.
('3', 212, 4, 18, 459675) As to the choice of healthy sites affording reasonable opportunities for trade, in the absence of any information, it is difficult to say much, but what is already known is not very reassuring.
('3', 212, 4, 19, 459869) In spite of the protests of the British Indians, the existing Location at Barberton is to be removed
('3', 212, 5, 20, 459970) 1Vide “Petition to Transvaal Governor”, June 8, 1903.
('3', 213, 0, 1, 460024) 214 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 213, 1, 2, 460066) away, and though the distance is not very great, it is easy to understand what a great loss the traders of the Location must suffer by reason of the removal.
('3', 213, 1, 3, 460224) As to the second, under the Boer regime, and in spite of any non declaration of intention not to disturb vested rights, the representations of British Agents protected them all up to the outbreak of hostilities.
('3', 213, 1, 4, 460436) The notices to quit were then considered not to be worth the paper on which they were written (for all the Indian traders were under notice for several years, and yet they were never enforced).
('3', 213, 1, 5, 460630) As soon as an attempt was made, a protest was sent to the Home Government and relief was instantaneous.
('3', 213, 1, 6, 460734) As to the third, if the exemption was of the nature contemplated by Lord Milner, namely, “from all special legislation”, it would undoubtedly be of considerable advantage, but the Bazaar Notice is in conflict with any such view.
('3', 213, 1, 7, 460963) It merely grants exemption as to residence.
('3', 213, 1, 8, 461007) The humour of the situation lies in the fact that respectable British Indians, if they would live in towns after the end of the year, would have to get special exemption and prove to the authorities that “they are in the habit of using soap”, and that “they do not sleep on the floor”, and so on.
('3', 213, 1, 9, 461304) But Indians of the servant class are, by law, entitled to reside in towns without any special permission being necessary there under, for the section of the law reads: “The Government shall have the right to appoint special streets, wards and locations as their residence.
('3', 213, 1, 10, 461577) This provision shall not apply to servants living with their masters.” Hundreds of Indian servants, therefore, if not thousands, (for they are very much appreciated as domestic servants), may live in towns without having to make any application for exemption, but a handful of well to do, respectable British Indians may not reside in towns with out having to undergo the indignity of an offensive examination.
('3', 213, 1, 11, 461988) No such exemption was necessary under the old regime because compulsory segregation was never adopted.
('3', 213, 1, 12, 462091) The statement, therefore, made by the British Indians that the anti Asiatic laws are being enforced with a rigour never before known, is literally true.
('3', 213, 1, 13, 462244) As to the charge of insanitation based on an extract from Dr. Porter’s report, the enclosed article from Indian Opinion speaks for itself.
('3', 213, 1, 14, 462383) If prejudiced statements were made against British Indians prior to the war, statements utterly unsupported by facts, the British Indians are still labouring under the same prejudice.
('3', 213, 1, 15, 462567) The evidence of
('3', 214, 0, 1, 462583) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 215
('3', 214, 1, 2, 462624) Dr. Porter falls undoubtedly under the same category.
('3', 214, 1, 3, 462678) To pass to another matter, the British Indian Mahomedans at Pretoria bought a piece of property for the purpose of erecting a mosque in Pretoria some fifteen years ago.
('3', 214, 1, 4, 462847) This property still remains in the name of the seller owing to the Boer law prohibiting the ownership of land by Asiatics outside Locations or streets set apart by Government.
('3', 214, 1, 5, 463023) Several representations were made to the British Agents prior to the war, and on the eve of it, Sir Conyngham Green assured the British Indians that, if war broke out, there would be no difficulty about the transfer after its conclusion.
('3', 214, 1, 6, 463261) In spite of several representations, the Government has refused at present to allow the land to be registered in the names of the trustees.
('3', 214, 1, 7, 463401) A letter has been addressed to the Colonial Secretary by Mr. Hajee Habib on behalf of the Mahomedan congregation.
('3', 214, 1, 8, 463515) 1 The seller is a very old man and, in the event of his unfortunately dying before the transfer is given, complications may arise meaning loss of property which is very valuable to the British Indian Mahomedans in Pretoria.
('3', 214, 1, 9, 463739) The same difficulty has been experienced in Johannesburg with reference to the Johannesburg Mosque, but here the need is not so great, as the seller is not in the same position as the seller at Pretoria.
('3', 214, 1, 10, 463943) It is, therefore, hoped that Mr. Chamberlain will be pleased to induce the Government to grant the transfer.
