('3', 249, 1, 2, 547419) 162. THE DEALERS’ LICENSES ACT REDIVIVUS: III
('3', 249, 2, 3, 547465) AN APPEAL TO THE LEGISLATORS
('3', 249, 3, 4, 547494) It is with great regret that your petitioners have to record that the fears expressed in the memorial 1. have been more than realised, and that the judicial interpretation has been against the British Indians in the Colony in a case herein below referred to.
('3', 249, 3, 5, 547753) Their Lordships of the Privy Council have decided that from the decision of the Town Councils or the Town Boards, there is no appeal to the Supreme Court of the Colony under the above Act.
('3', 249, 3, 6, 547942) This decision has paralysed the Indian traders.
('3', 249, 3, 7, 547990) Consternation has seized hold of them, and there prevails amongst them a feeling of insecurity and a nervous fear as to what may happen during the ensuing year.
('3', 249, 3, 8, 548151) How the next year will open for the Indian traders, your petitioners do not know.
('3', 249, 3, 9, 548233) Every storekeeper is, therefore, in a state of feverish anxiety.
('3', 249, 3, 10, 548298) The suspense is dreadful.
('3', 249, 3, 11, 548324) The large houses, fearing that their customers, small storekeepers, might be refused their licences and, having the only hope they had of securing some check on the licensing authorities taken away from them by Their Lordships of the Privy Council, have become despondent and hesitate to clear their goods.
('3', 249, 3, 12, 548631) This was written by the British Indian traders in 1898 and addressed to Mr. Chamberlain in connection with the Dealers’ Licenses Act.
('3', 249, 3, 13, 548765) History has repeated itself this year, and the above prayer may well be addressed, in view of what has passed during the last three weeks, to the legislators of the Colony.
('3', 249, 3, 14, 548938) Let us clear the way by at once making an admission for the sake of agreement, conciliation and yielding to the wishes of the Colonists, namely, that some restriction should be placed on traders’ licences.
('3', 249, 3, 15, 549144) Mr. Ellis Browne, in his now famous Bazaar Notice, dealt with the question of insanitation, and undue competition on the part of those who did not live as lavishly as the European traders.
('3', 249, 3, 16, 549333) We will, for the sake of argument, assume that there exists undue competition, and that there is a great deal of insanitation amongst the British Indians, and that these two evils ought to be remedied by some legislation.
('3', 249, 3, 17, 549555) That agreement being arrived at between the Europeans and the Indians residing in the Colony, the question is: How should the end be achieved?
('3', 249, 3, 18, 549698) The Europeans responded in 1897 by passing the Dealers’
('3', 249, 4, 19, 549754) 1 “Petition to Chamberlain”, December 31, 1898.
('3', 250, 0, 1, 549802) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 251
('3', 250, 1, 2, 549843) Licenses Act.
('3', 250, 1, 3, 549857) Then followed an interval.
('3', 250, 1, 4, 549884) It was recognised that the Act was too drastic, and its operation was tempered with a large amount of discretion, reason and justice.
('3', 250, 1, 5, 550018) Now, however, there seems to be a reaction, and the Act is to be enforced, if the decisions lately given by the Newcastle Town Council and the Durban Town Council are a fair index, to the fullest extent without regard to right or wrong.
('3', 250, 1, 6, 550255) As against this, the position taken up by the British Indians is, in our humble opinion, unanswerable.
('3', 250, 1, 7, 550358) The Act is, in its present form, manifestly unjust.
('3', 250, 1, 8, 550410) In taking away the jurisdiction of the ordinary Law Courts of the Colony, it strikes at the very foundation of the principles of the British Constitution.
('3', 250, 1, 9, 550565) It gives extraordinary powers to men whose interests are in conflict with those of the applicants for licences who may appear before them, and it enables them to appoint an officer (the Licensing Officer) who holds practically the livelihood of poor men in the palms of his hands, one who cannot give an unbiased, disinterested, and fearless judgment.
('3', 250, 1, 10, 550917) The British Indians then say: ‘Take away all this from the Licensing Act.
('3', 250, 1, 11, 550991) Define, as nearly as possible, the powers of the Town Councils and Local Boards.
('3', 250, 1, 12, 551072) Deal with insanitation ruthlessly, and insist on suitable buildings— dwellingrooms separate from stores, proper book keeping, etc.
('3', 250, 1, 13, 551203) But after you have your requirements fulfilled, let the applicant feel certain that he will receive his licence, whether it is a new licence or whether it is merely a renewal.
('3', 250, 1, 14, 551379) Let the Licensing Officer be not merely a creature of the Town Council, but an independent officer, who will be able to give his decision on the merits of each application, and, with certain well defined reservations, let there be an appeal from the decisions, either of the Licensing Officer or of the Town Councils, to the Supreme Court.’ There will then be no opposition from the Indians.
('3', 250, 1, 15, 551771) Not that any opposition from the Indians is worthy of consideration by the legislators, still we state it as a fact for what it may be worth.
('3', 250, 1, 16, 551913) Anyhow, there will be no injustice.
('3', 250, 1, 17, 551949) The law will be capable of being understood by outsiders, and those who may be affected by it will know exactly what their position is.
('3', 250, 1, 18, 552085) This is what Sir Walter Wragg said in connection with the appointment of Licensing Officers:
('3', 250, 2, 19, 552178) It has been suggested to the Court that an officer so appointed must have a certain amount of bias in his mind because he was an officer permanently under the Town Council and must be in the Council’s confidence.
('3', 250, 2, 20, 552391) His Lordship was not going to decide the matter on that point, but he could quite see that the
('3', 251, 0, 1, 552486) 252 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 251, 1, 2, 552528) Licensing Officer should be some person who was not in the Town Council’s service and who was not in the confidence of the Council.
('3', 251, 1, 3, 552660) How the powers vested in the Town Councils have been abused in the past will be clear from the following remarks made by Mr. Justice Mason, who then adorned the Natal Bench.
('3', 251, 1, 4, 552834) In the course of proceedings in appeal filed on behalf of the British Indians:
('3', 251, 2, 5, 552913) He ‘considered the proceedings under appeal were a disgrace to the Town Council, and he did not hesitate to use this strong language.
('3', 251, 2, 6, 553047) He considered, under the circumstances, that it was an abuse of words to say there had been an appeal to the Town Council.’ The present Attorney General, when he was a member of the Town Council, gave vent to the following sentiments:
('3', 251, 3, 7, 553282) He ‘had purposely refrained from attending the meeting owing to the anomalous policy pursued in appeals of that kind.
('3', 251, 3, 8, 553400) He disagreed with the dirty work they (the Councillors) were called upon to do.
('3', 251, 3, 9, 553480) If the burgesses wished all such licences stopped, there was a clean way of going about the matter, namely, getting the Legislative Assembly to enact a measure against the granting of licences to the Indian community; but sitting as a Court of Appeal, unless there were good grounds to the contrary, the licences should be granted.’ Dealing with the question of deprivation of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, and the decision of the Privy Council on the Act in question, our contemporary, The Natal Advertiser, expressed its opinion as follows:
('3', 251, 4, 10, 554032) We can only say that we deeply regret the decision (of the Privy Council) .
('3', 251, 4, 11, 554108) It is an Act which might have been expected from the Transvaal Raad.
('3', 251, 4, 12, 554177) That body in the Aliens Expulsion Law has outstepped the jurisdiction of the High Court, and our readers will remember the outcry raised about it in the Colonies.
('3', 251, 4, 13, 554340) But it is not one whit worse than this Act; indeed, if there is any difference, ours is worse, because it is likely to be much more frequently enforced.
('3', 251, 4, 14, 554493) It is absurd to say that the.
('3', 251, 4, 15, 554523) Act would not have been effective if right of appeal to the Supreme Court had been allowed.
('3', 251, 4, 16, 554615) Surely, that body could be trusted to exercise common sense....
('3', 251, 4, 17, 554679) Far better, indeed, that in one or two eases, the latter (the desire of the Municipalities) should have been overruled than that the principle should be laid down in a self governing community under representative institutions, that, inany case affecting the rights of the citizens, recourse to the highest judicial body in the State should be deliberately debarred.
('3', 251, 4, 18, 555046) We hope we have thus shown from the mouths of the
('3', 252, 0, 1, 555096) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 253
('3', 252, 1, 2, 555137) responsible Colonists how far the objection recited above has been held just by them.
('3', 252, 1, 3, 555223) We, therefore, appeal to the legislators, and the Colonists in general, to set themselves right without any pressure from Downing Street in a matter of such vital importance, especially because what they want to do can be done in a far less offensive manner, unless the intention is really to root out every Indian trader from the Colony, whom, Sir James Hulett only last week, in giving his evidence before the Labour Commission of the Transvaal, has described as a benefit to the Colony.
('3', 252, 1, 4, 555713) Mr. Ellis Browne, also, was pleased to say that the intention was not to offend the feelings of the Indians nor yet to root them out, but to do justice and to recognise vested rights.
('3', 252, 1, 5, 555897) We hope that, in uttering these sentiments, he has voiced the general Colonial feeling.
('3', 252, 1, 6, 555985) If so, our appeal is, in our humble opinion, fair, and it ought to receive the consideration it deserves.
('3', 252, 2, 7, 556091) Indian Opinion, 24 9 1903
('3', 252, 3, 8, 556117) 163. THE LABOUR QUESTION IN THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 252, 4, 9, 556159) The Labour Commission, which has been sitting at Johann esburg in order to inquire whether there is a sufficient supply of labour in Africa for the development of the Transvaal, is now drawing to a close.
('3', 252, 4, 10, 556364) The Commissioners, who went out to the East to find out whether Chinese labour is available, are due to return some time this week.
('3', 252, 4, 11, 556496) That the Commission will find that the labour supply available in Africa is inadequate for the demand, is a foregone conclusion.
('3', 252, 4, 12, 556625) That importation of Asiatic labour, and most likely Chinese labour, would be then decided upon, may also be taken for granted.
('3', 252, 4, 13, 556752) The question, therefore, affects the British Indians residing in the Transvaal to some extent.
('3', 252, 4, 14, 556847) The British Indians already know, to their cost, how the status of independent Indian settlers has been very much mixed up with the question of importation of indentured Indians.
('3', 252, 4, 15, 557026) The Transvaal Government, as it were by prophetic vision, have prepared us for further confusion.
('3', 252, 4, 16, 557124) In the Transvaal, the most specific term “British Indians” has given place to the more general term “Asiatics” It is “The Department of Asiatic Affairs”, “Asiatic Supervisors”, and “Asiatic Bazaars”.
('3', 252, 4, 17, 557324) The importation, therefore, of the Chinese will, if only indirectly, prejudice the Indian cause.
('3', 252, 4, 18, 557421) Be that, however, as it may; for the present, we propose to examine the
('3', 253, 0, 1, 557493) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 253, 1, 2, 557535) question from the Chinese standpoint, and on broad general principles.
('3', 253, 1, 3, 557606) We have already said that, in thinking of the importation of the Chinese, the millionaires and their supporters in the Transvaal forget the native of the soil entirely, and forget also the interests of the future generation of white settlers.
('3', 253, 1, 4, 557849) Bad enough, however, as the positionis from these two standpoints, it is infinitely worse from that of the poor people, who would be imported into the country under most galling terms.
('3', 253, 1, 5, 558034) The millionaires, in their eagerness to add to their millions, and others in their rush to become suddenly rich, do not even consider it necessary to give a passing thought to the fact that the Chinese, much abused as they are, have some claim as their fellow human beings on their attention.
('3', 253, 1, 6, 558327) And we make bold to say that the mere fact of their agreeing to conditions that may be imposed on their arrival would not, in any degree, lessen the awful responsibility of those who would make them.
('3', 253, 1, 7, 558527) According to the British laws, there are some contracts which are void or voidable even though the contracting party may have given the necessary consent.
('3', 253, 1, 8, 558682) For instance, those entered into by minors, or married women.
('3', 253, 1, 9, 558744) If a ruffian were to present a loaded revolver at a man and say, “Your life or your signature”, and if the latter gave the signature, the law steps in and says it is of no effect whatsoever.
('3', 253, 1, 10, 558935) If any undue influence is used in obtaining the ratification of a contract, it is also void.
('3', 253, 1, 11, 559028) A starving man giving away all his possessions and all his liberties would be allowed to recall them as soon as he wished to, and we have no hesitation in saying that, in spite of all the elaborate preparations that might be made to explain the nature of the indentures that might be offered to the Chinese, and in spite of their assent thereto in the presence of big officials, it would be morally, at any rate, if not legally, undue influence, for we cannot conceive the possibility of a free human being willingly agreeing to the terms such as those proposed at the various meetings that have recently been held in the Transvaal.
('3', 253, 1, 12, 559661) The labourers will be expected to enter into a contract of service for a term of years, Sat the end of which they would be forced back to the place where they came from.
('3', 253, 1, 13, 559831) In the Transvaal, they are to be confined to Compounds, and they will not be allowed to use their brains, or their pens, or the brush, or the chisel.
('3', 253, 1, 14, 559981) All they may use would be the shovel and the spade.
('3', 253, 1, 15, 560033) We have hitherto been accustomed to think that the natural abilities of a man would be
('3', 254, 0, 1, 560120) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 255
('3', 254, 1, 2, 560161) allowed to have full play when coming in contact with a type of men other than himself, but the poor Chinese will not be able to do anything of the kind, and it is no earthly use whatever for him to find out after his arrival that he would be able to earn, for instance, in cabinet making, as much in one hour as he would as a mining labourer in eight hours.
('3', 254, 1, 3, 560520) He must allow his intelligence to be dwarfed, and be content to remain an unskilled labourer, pure and simple.
('3', 254, 1, 4, 560631) This we consider to be totally indefensible and unjust.
('3', 254, 1, 5, 560687) The pity of it all is that, after creating such an artificial situation, the Colonists would grumble if the “Heathen Chinese”, as he is called, turns out to be a moral leper, resorts to all kinds of make shifts in order to throw off his yoke, and by hook or by crook endeavours to make use of his abilities which he may have inherited from his ancestors.
('3', 254, 1, 6, 561042) The mining industry is undoubtedly the mainstay of the Transvaal, but the Colonists may be buying its development too dearly.
('3', 254, 1, 7, 561168) Nor is it at all contended that it will come to a standstill without the supply of labour from outside sources.
('3', 254, 1, 8, 561280) Sir George Farrar, at the great meeting held some months ago at Boksburg, (which, in spite of his eloquence and persuasive powers, by an overwhelming majority very rightly rejected his proposal to introduce forced Asiatic labour) compared the mines to “treasure chests”.
('3', 254, 1, 9, 561551) The gold locked up in those chests is not going to rust away for want of labour.
('3', 254, 1, 10, 561632) Why not, then, keep some of these chests locked up for the use of the future generations?
('3', 254, 1, 11, 561722) Why should they be forced open for the benefit of the few at the sacrifice of everything else?
('3', 254, 1, 12, 561817) Ours, we know, is a very insignificant voice in the wilderness.
('3', 254, 1, 13, 561881) All the resources of the White Leagues seem to be proving absolutely ineffectual against those of the magnates who are determined upon bringing 200,000 Chinese.
('3', 254, 1, 14, 562042) So far, however, these gentlemen have taken up, if we may venture to say so, a low standpoint of selfishness.
('3', 254, 1, 15, 562152) May we not appeal to them to add to their mode of propaganda, and strengthen their position by defending the defenceless and the voiceless also?
('3', 254, 1, 16, 562297) Let us make it perfectly clear that, in making our appeal to them, we do not wish to be understood as advocating the free immigration of Asiatics.
('3', 254, 1, 17, 562444) We have said before, and repeat here, that restrictions on immigration will be perfectly justified within reasonable bounds.
('3', 254, 1, 18, 562569) We believe as much in the purity of race as we think they do, only we believe that they would best serve the interest, which is as dear to us as it is to them, by advocating the purity of all the races and not one alone.
('3', 254, 1, 19, 562790) We believe also that the white race in
('3', 255, 0, 1, 562829) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 255, 1, 2, 562871) South Africa should be the predominating race, and the gentlemen of the White Leagues will be simply furthering their object by standing on the rock of morality, and saying: “Even if we believe that all those restrictions which are so much talked of can be enforced, and that the Chinese who may be brought here would without difficulty be sent back, we reject them as inhuman and as unworthy of a race that leads other races in civilisation.” We would remind them of Lord Ma caulay’s remark in one of his essays, wherein he says: “We are free, we are civilised to little purpose if we grudge to any portion of the human race an equal measure of freedom and civilisation.” Indian Opinion, 24 9 1903
('3', 255, 2, 3, 563570) 164. MR. STUART THE MAGISTRATE
('3', 255, 3, 4, 563601) On reading Mr. Stuart’s minute on an Indian murder case, referred to elsewhere, 1 it gave us pain to remark upon his making political capital out of it.
('3', 255, 3, 5, 563754) It now gives us pleasure to congratulate our worthy Magistrate on putting his foot firmly down on the serpent of immorality, as he did in the case of a wretched Indian the other day.
('3', 255, 3, 6, 563937) That is the kind of proceeding which would appeal forcibly to the delinquents against the morality law.
('3', 255, 3, 7, 564041) We hope that the Indians would endorse the action of the Magistrate by visiting the man with such ostracism as the Indians alone know how to do.

('3', 257, 2, 9, 568133) To the British Indians, the uncertainty of their position becomes still more uncertain.

('3', 257, 2, 12, 568392) His despatch to the Federal Ministers in Australia on the employment of Lascars as seamen has placed the question on the Imperial platform, but now we are face to face with, perhaps, a revision by the Colonial Office of the situation.
('3', 257, 2, 13, 568627) Lord George’s resignation, also, and the fact that Mr. Brodrick (who has made himself so thoroughly unpopular in India by his proposal to tax her for the sake of keeping up a large garrison in South Africa) is to succeed him, are ominous signs.
('3', 257, 2, 14, 568872) Let us, however, hope that Mr. Brodrick, on taking up his new portfolio, will think more of India than he has been hitherto known to do.

('3', 258, 1, 3, 569944) Speaking of the traders, Sir James said, in reply to Mr. Quinn:
('3', 258, 2, 4, 570008) The Arabs were limited, and were traders almost entirely.
('3', 258, 2, 5, 570066) The ordinary small trader could not compete with the Arab.
('3', 258, 2, 6, 570125) The retail Kaffir trade of the Colony was practically in the hands of the Arabs.
('3', 258, 2, 7, 570206) In the country districts, witness had no objection to this, because he thought the ordinary young white man or woman could do something better than looking after country Kaffir stores.

('3', 258, 2, 9, 570456) They sold at a smaller profit and, to a certain extent, they dealt fairer with the natives than the European traders, who, at the country stores, desired to make such large profits.

('3', 258, 3, 11, 570675) he did not think that the importation of Indians had been harmful to Natal.

('3', 258, 3, 14, 570911) Indian Opinion, 24 9 1903
('3', 258, 4, 15, 570937) 169. THE MILLIONAIRE AND THE INDIAN GOVERNMENT
('3', 258, 5, 16, 570984) Sir George Farrar’s wrath has descended upon the Indian Government and the Colonial Secretary for daring to insist upon less than half of the rights of the British Indians, as such, in the Colony of the Transvaal before they would think of lending Indian labour to the Colony for the development of its resources; and, with the weight of millions that Sir George can bring to bear on any problem he may handle, we do not know what effect it would have upon the objects of his indignation.
('3', 258, 5, 17, 571473) Intimately connected with, and being dependent for his millions upon, the mining industry, Sir George’s position is quite capable of being understood.
('3', 258, 5, 18, 571624) With a money making man, the end very often justifies the means.
('3', 258, 5, 19, 571689) Following up that doctrine, it matters little to Sir George, and the other mining magnates, how the source of their wealth is to be fed, and to them, from such a point of view, if anyone offers any opposition, just or otherwise, he is a man to be silenced somehow or other.
('3', 258, 5, 20, 571963) Sir George must have been in some such
('3', 259, 0, 1, 572002) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 259, 1, 2, 572044) mood when he uttered the following words before the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Mines held in Johannesburg on the 17th instant:
('3', 259, 2, 3, 572178) It was with a view to relieving this tension that it was suggested by your Chamber that the Government should import indentured coolies from India for the purpose of new Railway construction.
('3', 259, 2, 4, 572370) After some time, the reply of the Secretary of State for the Colonies was laid on the table of the Legislative Council.
('3', 259, 2, 5, 572490) I feel it my duty to refer in strong terms to the attitude taken up by the Indian Government, endorsed by the Secretary of State for the Colonies.
('3', 259, 2, 6, 572637) Whilst feeling strongly our position as a fellow unit with India in the British Empire, yet we are forced to consider the welfare of the white population in this Colony.
('3', 259, 2, 7, 572807) We have already offered a labour market to the people of overpopulated India, who could but benefit by the wages taken home by these labourers at the end of their contracts, but we consider that it is the right of the people of this country to decide whether they will allow this country to be overrun by Indian traders, free to compete and settle in a country which we hope some day will be wholly a white man’s country.
('3', 259, 2, 8, 573229) We give to our fellow subjects in India the right to trade in bazaars, and in this way we consider that the Government have made a generous concession, and in return we certainly do not expect, when we have pledged ourselves to a contribution of 30 millions towards the cost of the South African war, the interest of which we are only able to pay out of the results of our industrial prosperity, that the Indian Government should be so short sighted as to refuse to help us to meet our obligations incurred in the interests of the Empire of which India is a portion.
('3', 259, 3, 9, 573796) Indian Opinion, 24 9 1903

('3', 260, 8, 11, 574792) 1902 1906
('3', 260, 9, 12, 574802) 171. THE DEALERS’ LICENSES ACT REDIVIVUS: IV
('3', 260, 10, 13, 574847) PROMISE AND PERFORMANCE
('3', 260, 11, 14, 574871) Mr. Cressler has let the cat out of the bag and shown the real reason why the mining magnates wish to insist upon Asiatic labour.
('3', 260, 11, 15, 575001) We now know it is not a question of the impossibility of getting white labour at a paying rate, but it is that of the white labourer becoming, in course of time, master of the situation and dictating terms to his employers as to wages, period of working and numerous other things, and becoming a strong political factor in the Transvaal.
('3', 260, 11, 16, 575339) It is, therefore, the old story of the strong and the powerful wishing to retain all the
('3', 261, 0, 1, 575428) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 261, 1, 2, 575470) power to themselves, and shutting out competitors.
('3', 261, 1, 3, 575521) The fear that actuates the mining magnates is the fear which actuated our legislators in Natal when responsible government was granted.
('3', 261, 1, 4, 575657) And when the first step they took was to silence the British Indian by depriving him of the right to vote, Sir John Robinson, meaning every word of what he said in reply to the British Indian petition, 1 insisted that their position would be far better without the votes as the House would be taking over a serious responsibilityon its shoulders, and would have to see that their liberties were not, in any other respect, curtailed.
('3', 261, 1, 5, 576090) Unfortunately, that was a promise which had not the force of law.
('3', 261, 1, 6, 576156) Although, therefore, such a speaker as the then Prime Minister expressed the above authoritative and representative opinion, and, therefore, morally binding on our legislators, the performance has been quite contrary to the promise which Sir John so generously made.
('3', 261, 1, 7, 576423) The Immigration Act and the Dealers’ Licenses Act followed closely on the heels of the disfranchising Act.
('3', 261, 1, 8, 576530) It is, however, the latter on which we wish to lay the utmost stress, as it is a law which affects the well being of those who have already settled in the Colony, and to whom it is an everpresent danger.
('3', 261, 1, 9, 576734) We have already dealt with the different ways in which that Act has injured British Indian interests.
('3', 261, 1, 10, 576836) We reproduce elsewhere the petition 2 to which we referred last week.
('3', 261, 1, 11, 576906) It deals exhaustively with the working of the Act, and is very seasonable in view of the activity shown by the Durban and Newcastle Town Councils.
('3', 261, 1, 12, 577053) What we fail to understand is the tenacity with which the Town Councils cling to the most objectionable portion of the Act, namely, the deprivation of the jurisdiction of the Supreme Court over their decisions in regard to the granting of dealers’ licences; for, as we have already shown, the object they had in view can be easily and equally well served without recourse to what has been proved to be an unconstitutional procedure.
('3', 261, 1, 13, 577486) We cannot do better than quote from the Times of Natal, as it admirably expresses the Indian opinion:
('3', 261, 2, 14, 577588) By all means make them (Indian traders) adhere to the strictest sanitary regulations, keep their books in English, and otherwise do as English traders do, but when they have met these demands, give them justice.
('3', 261, 2, 15, 577800) No honest thinking man can say that the new Bill (referring to the Dealers’ Licenses Act) gives these people justice, or the community justice, because it puts into the hands of interested parties the power to push out competition which is
('3', 261, 3, 16, 578040) 1Vide “Guide to London”, 1893 94 2 “Petition to Chamberlain”, December 31, 1898.
('3', 262, 0, 1, 578121) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 263
('3', 262, 1, 2, 578162) beneficial to the multitude, and enables these interested parties to fill their own pockets.
('3', 262, 1, 3, 578255) This was written in 1898, and what was true then is doubly true today after the experience the British Indians have had of the working of the Dealers’ Licenses Act now for the last seven years.
('3', 262, 1, 4, 578449) Unless prejudice has entirely blinded the sense of justice of the Colonists, it is simple enough to recognise that the utmost uncertainty which hedges round every Indian licence owing to this Act should be removed, and that after the requirements, no matter how severe they may be, are fulfilled, the applicant ought to be allowed to feel certain as to his position.
('3', 262, 1, 5, 578816) And until this elementary measure of fairness is meted out to the British Indians, there can be no rest, and it is the clear duty of our countrymen to persistently agitate, so that the desired amendment may be made in the Act.
('3', 262, 2, 6, 579043) Indian Opinion, 1 10 1903
('3', 262, 3, 7, 579069) 172. THE JOHANNESBURG INDIAN LOCATION
('3', 262, 4, 8, 579107) About two years ago, it was that Major O’Meara, the then dictator of Johannesburg, with his fine Irish humour, perpetrated on the Johannesburg public a practical joke by drawing up a most sensational report on the alleged insanitary condition of the Indian Location in Johannesburg.
('3', 262, 4, 9, 579390) He warned the public, in the plainest terms possible, of the grave and immediate danger to health owing to the existence of the Indian Location.
('3', 262, 4, 10, 579535) The cry was later taken up by Mr. Lionel Curtis and Dr. Porter, two enthusiasts fresh from London.
('3', 262, 4, 11, 579634) Thinking that they should render the Johannesburg community some signal service and earn their wages as also the gratitude of a certain class of people, they improved upon the worthy Major and condemned some other sites also near the Indian Location, the cry still being that the whole of what was dubbed “Insanitary Area” constituted an ever present and immediate danger to the lives of the inhabitants of Johannesburg.
('3', 262, 4, 12, 580055) The Town Councillors, consisting of business men, naturally scented a cheap bargain for the Municipality, and drew up a thundering report for submission to Lord Milner, asking His Lordship to give the Town Council extraordinary powers for the expropriation of what they described as an insanitary area.
('3', 262, 4, 13, 580358) Lord Milner hesitated a little and effected a compromise by appointing a Commission to inquire into, and to report upon, the
('3', 263, 0, 1, 580483) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 263, 1, 2, 580525) proposition made by the Town Council.
('3', 263, 1, 3, 580563) The farce was gone through.
('3', 263, 1, 4, 580591) The Commissioners decided in favour of the Town Council, condemning the area, and advised Lord Milner to give the Town Council the power of expropriation.
('3', 263, 1, 5, 580746) Thus, Major O’Meara’s leisurely report has resulted in the deprivation of the just rights of thousands of inhabitants within the area.
('3', 263, 1, 6, 580881) If there is any doubt about our statement, we refer the sceptic to the burning words of the late Sir William Marriott, who condemned the policy of the Town Council in no measured terms.
('3', 263, 1, 7, 581067) Many eminent medical men, also, gave evidence to the effect that the area, which it pleased the Town Council to describe as insanitary, was not more so than many another part of Johannesburg, and that the defects pointed out as existing in that area were common more or less to the whole of Johannesburg.
('3', 263, 1, 8, 581372) All that, however, was of no avail.
('3', 263, 1, 9, 581408) The Town Council was determined upon having all that portion of Johannesburg, and Mr. Curtis and Dr. Porter proved valuable agents in accomplishing the object.
('3', 263, 1, 10, 581568) Nero’s fun, however, has only just commenced.
('3', 263, 1, 11, 581614) The Town Council has entered upon the whole of that area, and holds the inhabitants at its mercy.
('3', 263, 1, 12, 581712) We read in the Johannesburg newspapers how the claims for compensation are being starved out.
('3', 263, 1, 13, 581806) We also understand that, danger or no danger, the Town Council proposes at present not to disturb the occupation of tenants and that it would graciously allow the tenants to occupy its premises at the same rental they used to pay to their respective landlords before the 26th of September.
('3', 263, 1, 14, 582096) If, therefore, there were rack renters, the Town Council would now have the honour of taking up that role.
('3', 263, 1, 15, 582203) f there was overcrowding before, and we have it on the authority of Dr. Porter that overcrowding in some parts of the insanitary area was beyond description, then such overcrowding also is to remain, with this difference that whereas, prior to the 26th September, the poor individual landlords were subject to the Town Council regulations as to overcrowding, etc., the Council itself is practically free from any such restrictions.
('3', 263, 1, 16, 582635) And now that the Council is in possession, the danger to the health of the community has, of course, vanished altogether.
('3', 263, 1, 17, 582757) Such, also, is the difference between strength and weakness, power and subjection.
('3', 263, 1, 18, 582840) Two years have elapsed and no epidemic has visited Johannesburg, nor have the inoffensive inhabitants of the so called insanitary area proved a source of danger in any way whatsoever.
('3', 263, 1, 19, 583024) That fact is an irrefutable demonstration of the hollowness of the hysterical arguments advanced by Dr. Porter.
('3', 263, 1, 20, 583136) But the pinch of all this will be most felt by the weakest among the weak,
('3', 264, 0, 1, 583211) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 265
('3', 264, 1, 2, 583252) namely, the British Indians in Johannesburg.
('3', 264, 1, 3, 583297) It is they whose position is the worst possible.
('3', 264, 1, 4, 583346) Others will be able to invest what they may receive in respect of their claims in landed property elsewhere in the Transvaal.
('3', 264, 1, 5, 583472) They will be able to reside where they please.
('3', 264, 1, 6, 583519) But the Indians are now without either of these rights.
('3', 264, 1, 7, 583575) The only place in the Transvaal where the Indians held ninety nine years’ leases in their own names was Johannesburg and it was in connection with the ninety six stands in the Location in question.
('3', 264, 1, 8, 583773) But now they do not know whether they will be allowed to hold land elsewhere in Johannesburg under an equivalent title.
('3', 264, 1, 9, 583893) And although provision is made in the Insanitary Area Expropriation Ordinance for the residence of the people dispossessed on a site very near to the expropriated area, there is entire uncertainty as to where they are to be located.
('3', 264, 1, 10, 584126) It should also be remembered that most of the Indian population is concentrated in Johannesburg.
('3', 264, 1, 11, 584223) Our countrymen there have our sympathy, and if the powers that be do not help them, we have an abiding faith in the mercy of the all wise Providence, who will not forsake them.
('3', 264, 2, 12, 584400) Indian Opinion, 1 10 1903
('3', 264, 3, 13, 584426) 173. POLITICAL MORALITY
('3', 264, 4, 14, 584450) We dealt last week with Mr. Stuart’s report on the enquiry made by Mr. Chamberlain regarding certain cases in Natal.
('3', 264, 4, 15, 584567) We propose now to deal with the cases of two licences in the Transvaal about which Lord Milner sent a report to Mr. Chamberlain.
('3', 264, 4, 16, 584696) In dealing with the report, however, we are aware that, if it is at variance with the facts of the case, His Excellency could hardly be held responsible, seeing that he would have to depend upon the statements placed before him by those in charge of the matter in question.
('3', 264, 4, 17, 584970) We print below the official version and the true facts as we know them.
('3', 264, 5, 18, 585042) OFFICIAL VERSION
('3', 264, 6, 19, 585059) (1) The Indian in question (Hoosen Amod) was trading in Wakkerstroom in 1899 in premises occupied under lease not in his own name, which lease expired on the 15th July, 1899.
('3', 264, 8, 20, 585234) (1) The report omits to state that the lease was in the partner’s name, and that although it expired on the 15th July, 1899, it was renewed, both of which facts were
('3', 265, 0, 1, 585400) 266 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 265, 1, 2, 585442) within the knowledge of the Magistrate.
('3', 265, 2, 3, 585482) OFFICIAL VERSION
('3', 265, 3, 4, 585499) (2) By the First Volksraad resolution, article No.1072 of the 5th August, 1892, he was prohibited from trading after that date except in the Coolie Location, and on the 15th July, 1899, the Landrost of the district closed the store.
('3', 265, 5, 5, 585732) (2) The report omits to mention that the resolution was never acted upon in a single instance, that the licence holder denied that the Landrost ever closed the store, and produced evidence of responsible European residents of Wakkerstroom, one of whom was a bank manager, and the other an officer in the employ of the late Government, showing that the store remained open, at least, up to the end of August, and that he (Hoosen Amod) voluntarily locked it when the exodus from the Transvaal commenced owing to the impending war.
('3', 265, 6, 6, 586261) OFFICIAL VERSION
('3', 265, 7, 7, 586278) (3) In June, 1902, Hoosen Amod applied to the Resident Magistrate of Wakkerstroom, stating that his lease had not expired.
('3', 265, 7, 8, 586401) The Resident Magistrate, without making enquiries, granted a licence to trade until the 31st of December, 1902. In November, the Magistrate discovered that the lease had really expired, and that the licence granted had, consequently, been obtained under false pretences.
('3', 265, 9, 9, 586672) (3) It has been already stated above that the lease had not expired because it was renewed.
('3', 265, 9, 10, 586764) Therefore, if the charge of false pretences had been brought by an ordinary man, it would have been considered a libel.
('3', 265, 9, 11, 586884) At the time the Magistrate granted the licence, he had seen the lease in question.
('3', 265, 10, 12, 586967) OFFICIAL VERSION
('3', 265, 11, 13, 586984) (4) The case of Hoosen Amod did not come within the scope of the principle by which this office had been guided in dealing with the applications of Asiatics for licences to trade, which was to the effect that those who had held licences to trade before the war, and whose trade was stopped by the war either by its outbreak or in anticipation of it, were entitled to a renewal of their licences.
('3', 265, 11, 14, 587380) Hoosen Amod was not trading at the outbreak of war, and his trade was not stopped by any reason connected with the war.
('3', 265, 13, 15, 587500) (4) The practice, at the time the question of this licence was engaging the attention of the Government, was that all who traded before the war, whether they closed their business on the outbreak or in anticipation of war, were able to get their licences.
('3', 265, 13, 16, 587756) Indians who traded in the Transvaal in 1898, or even earlier, were then being granted licences.
('3', 265, 13, 17, 587852) Instances by the dozen could be produced to prove this.
('3', 266, 0, 1, 587908) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 267
('3', 266, 1, 2, 587949) applicant urged the contention and brought the fact to the notice of the Government, without avail.
('3', 266, 1, 3, 588049) Further, if anybody could be said to have closed his store in anticipation of the war, it was Hoosen Amod.
('3', 266, 2, 4, 588156) OFFICIAL VERSION
('3', 266, 3, 5, 588173) (5) Nevertheless, it having been ascertained that the trader has laid in a large stock of goods, and in spite of the fact that this had been done, on the face of a licence acquired by him under false pretences, it was decided to extend every leniency that was possible in the case, and to renew Hoosen Amod’s licence, instructions to which effect were issued to the Resident Magistrate at Wakkerstroom in April last.
('3', 266, 5, 6, 588590) (5) The report omits to mention that the Government took four months to find out that Hoosen Amod had a large stock of goods, and that he was practically starved out, his store having been forcibly and illegally closed, there being no statutory Authority for forcible closing of stores, the only remedy open to the Government against persons trading without licence being to prosecute them for a breach of the law, and to fine them.
('3', 266, 5, 7, 589023) A few remarks, however, may well be added to complete the story of downright oppression.
('3', 266, 5, 8, 589112) (The term is not strong enough, in our opinion, to characterise the proceedings to which Mr. Hoosen Amod was deliberately subjected.) He was a resident of the Transvaal for over ten years, and was one of the select few who were favoured by the old Government with licences to trade in their own names.
('3', 266, 5, 9, 589414) Our readers may be aware that most of the British Indians traded under the Republic either without any licences whatsoever, under the protection guaranteed to them by the British Agents, or under licences taken out by their white friends.
('3', 266, 5, 10, 589653) The report, naturally, does not mention the fact that even white inhabitants of Wakkerstroom were so disgusted at the treatment that was meted out to Mr. Hoosen Amod that they signed a certificate expressing their opinion that he was fully entitled to a licence.
('3', 266, 5, 11, 589916) We look in vain, in the report, for a statement to the effect that Mr. Hoosen Amod’s was the only Indian store in Wakkerstroom, and that he was largely supported by the European houses there.
('3', 266, 5, 12, 590108) We now deal with the other licence, namely, that of Mr. Suliman Ismail in Rustenburg.
('3', 266, 6, 13, 590194) OFFICIAL VERSION
('3', 266, 7, 14, 590211) (1) Suliman Ismail held no licence to trade in Rustenburg at the time of the out.
('3', 266, 7, 15, 590293) break of war, but during the British military occupation, he established this branch of his house.
('3', 267, 0, 1, 590392) 268 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 267, 2, 2, 590434) (1) The report does not give the material fact that the military authorities granted him the licence, enabling him to establish a business in Rustenburg.
('3', 267, 3, 3, 590588) OFFICIAL VERSION
('3', 267, 4, 4, 590605) (2) In October, 1902, the Resident Magistrate of Rustenburg served on the representative of Suliman Ismail a notice to the effect that he was not entitled to trade in town.
('3', 267, 6, 5, 590778) (2) The report might have added that the Resident Magistrate, being the successor in office of his predecessor who granted the licence, could not question the latter’s decision and recall the licence granted to the applicant under the full knowledge that he did not possess licence to trade in that district previous to the war.
('3', 267, 6, 6, 591107) The report, moreover, omits other material facts that were brought out before this licence was granted, namely, that in many other districts, licences under similar circumstances were granted to British Indians although they never traded in the respective districts, and that these licences were not disturbed.
('3', 267, 6, 7, 591418) It was merely, in the case in question, an eccentricity on the part of the Magistrate.
('3', 267, 6, 8, 591505) The report might also have added that it was by an accident that justice was done to Mr. Suliman Ismail, for the reason for refusing a renewal of his licence, given officially, was that he should remove to the Location.
('3', 267, 6, 9, 591725) Fortunately, he was able to point out that there was no Location whatsoever in Rustenburg at the time.
('3', 267, 6, 10, 591828) The Government, being thus cornered, had no option but to grant a renewal.
('3', 267, 6, 11, 591903) His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor realised the injustice done to the man, so much that the fine, imposed on him by the Magistrate for trading after the expiry of his licence without obtaining a renewal, was graciously refunded to him.
('3', 267, 6, 12, 592143) We had no desire to dwell on these two distressing cases, but the report having been published in the Mercury, we could not, consistently with what we consider to be our duty, remain silent and allow it to pass unchallenged.
('3', 267, 6, 13, 592368) The only relieving feature in the whole of this miserable business and official zulum is, the painstaking manner in which His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor, Sir Arthur Lawley, personally investigated the two cases, and in spite of the deliberation with which the officers at the respective places attempted to prevent justice being done, meted it out to the aggrieved parties, although tardily enough.
('3', 268, 0, 1, 592775) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 269
('3', 268, 1, 2, 592816) These two cases are an index of the official feeling in the Transvaal, and they shew most clearly how difficult it is.
('3', 268, 1, 3, 592935) under a separate Asiatic administration for British Indians to get the barest possible justice.
('3', 268, 1, 4, 593031) The injustice becomes enhanced when we remember that the fear of such things happening was mentioned by the deputation at Pretoria to Mr. Chamberlain, 1 who assured them that licences granted after British occupation could never be withdrawn.
('3', 268, 1, 5, 593274) To him, coming from the English atmosphere, the word of a British officer was “as good as a banknote”, much more so his signature given by him in his official capacity.
('3', 268, 1, 6, 593443) Before closing this painful chapter, we wish to add that all the statements we have made in this article are based on documentary evidence which is in our possession, and if we appear to have used strong language, we have done so because we feel strongly.
('3', 268, 1, 7, 593699) Indian Opinion, 1 10 1903.
('3', 268, 2, 8, 593726) 174. THE VALUE OF A VOTE
('3', 268, 3, 9, 593751) Dr. Jameson, the leader of the Progressive Party at the Cape, has returned the following characteristic reply to a coloured voter who tackled the gentleman on the policy of the Progressive Party on the colour question:
('3', 268, 4, 10, 593970) (1) Education, compulsory where possible, and free where necessary.
('3', 268, 4, 11, 594038) This applies absolutely to everybody, white or coloured, and of whatever race.
('3', 268, 4, 12, 594117) (2) Equal rights to all civilised men absolutely again, to both white and coloured.
('3', 268, 4, 13, 594201) It is only the aboriginal natives whom we consider uncivilised.
('3', 268, 4, 14, 594265) Reading and writing is not the test.
('3', 268, 4, 15, 594302) (3) The Malays in this country are British subjects, and as such there is no prejudice against them, and they shall have equal rights with the whites.
('3', 268, 4, 16, 594453) The coloured community at the Cape commands enough votes to turn the scales in hotly contested elections where each candidate is trying his best to keep his opponent out.
('3', 268, 4, 17, 594624) Mr. Merriman has been severely chastising General Botha for having spoken out his mind on the Native labour question, because his party wants the Native vote.
('3', 268, 4, 18, 594783) He, therefore, waxes eloquent on the unrighteousness of compelling the Native to work and depriving him of his laws, and even compares the position of General Botha’s countrymen to that of the Natives,
('3', 268, 5, 19, 594985) 1Vide “Address to Chamberlain”, January 7, 1903.
('3', 269, 0, 1, 595034) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 269, 1, 2, 595076) conveniently forgetting for the while that the Republics gave precious little to the Natives and care less for their sentiments or rights.
('3', 269, 1, 3, 595215) We, therefore, hope that the coloured gentlemen at the Cape will, by wisely using their power, continue to enjoy the privilege of the franchise which, under the British Constitution, is such a powerful instrument for securing justice.
('3', 269, 1, 4, 595450) Here in Natal, the late Mr. Escombe thought fit to deprive us of it, and we know to our cost what harm has been wrought to us.
('3', 269, 1, 5, 595577) A community without the vote under popular government is an anomaly and without a valuable faculty.
('3', 269, 2, 6, 595677) Indian Opinion, 1 10 1903
('3', 269, 3, 7, 595703) 175. A CAUSE FOR THANKFULNESS
('3', 269, 4, 8, 595733) It is seldom that we get an opportunity for congratulating the Transvaal Government.
('3', 269, 4, 9, 595818) We have a very good reason, however, to do so this week, for we read in the Government Gazette that the work of granting Indian permits has been re transferred to the Chief Secretary for Permits.
('3', 269, 4, 10, 596014) This ought to have been done long ago.
('3', 269, 4, 11, 596053) The Indians have been protesting against the separate Asiatic administra tion ever since its establishment; and we sincerely trust that the reform in the matter of issuing permits is the beginning of the end of the Asiatic Department, which is absolutely unnecessary and a waste of good money.
('3', 269, 4, 12, 596347) The Government, we read, are carrying on retrenchmenton a large scale.
('3', 269, 4, 13, 596418) The Legislative Council has voted a large sum for the Asiatic Department.

('3', 270, 1, 2, 597271) 176. AN OPPORTUNITY FOR THE INDIANS
('3', 270, 2, 3, 597307) We congratulated Mr. Stuart last week on the stand he took up against the social evil 1. But our congratulations are not unmixed with pain.
('3', 270, 2, 4, 597447) For he seems to have been unable to resist the temptation of overdoing it.
('3', 270, 2, 5, 597522) We notice a slight tendency on his part to bring in the whole Indian community.
('3', 270, 2, 6, 597602) And we venture to think that his remarks about Mr. Khan were hardly justified.
('3', 270, 2, 7, 597681) So great an authority as Lord Brougham used to say that an advocate who, although he knew the guilt of his client, declined to take up his case, was unworthy of his profession; and on the principle that every man in the eye of the law is innocent until he is found guilty by a duly constituted court, the doctrine is sound enough.
('3', 270, 2, 8, 598012) The case of a well known member of the Cape Legislative Assembly is still fresh.
('3', 270, 2, 9, 598093) The M.L.A. was found guilty of the crime for which the Indian was tried.
('3', 270, 2, 10, 598166) Will Mr. Stuart say that the learned counsel who defended him was not justified in taking up the brief?
('3', 270, 2, 11, 598270) We all have our private opinion about that case.
('3', 270, 2, 12, 598319) But shall we say that the leading barrister who argued the appeal for the M.L.A. or the Chief Justice, who upheld the appeal because there was an element of doubt as to the legal guilt, was to blame—the one for championing the apparently guilty man and the other for discharging him?
('3', 270, 2, 13, 598603) What, again, is the duty of an advocate who finds out in the middle of a case that his client is really guilty?
('3', 270, 2, 14, 598715) Is he to throw up the brief?
('3', 270, 2, 15, 598744) If we dare do anything of the kind, we fancy that his conduct would be regarded as highly unprofessional.
('3', 270, 2, 16, 598850) The matter bristles with difficulty.
('3', 270, 2, 17, 598887) And we think that it is one for every advocate to determine for himself, and not for the Magistrate to read a homily to the defending counsel whenever he thinks that the case is bad.
('3', 270, 2, 18, 599070) So much for the “tiff” between Mr. Stuart and Mr. Khan; while it takes away fromthe good work done by Mr. Stuart, the residue is sufficient to entitle him to praise.
('3', 270, 2, 19, 599236) The Indian community has got a unique opportunity of showing the best that is in it.
('3', 270, 2, 20, 599321) By an effort in the right direction, it can clear the Augean stables, by running the powerful stream of public opinion through them.
('3', 270, 2, 21, 599454) It can put the finishing touch to the work done by the police and the Magistrate, without whose assistance the moral pressure exerted by it would not have produced any impression on the rhinoceros hide of the hardened delinquents.
('3', 270, 2, 22, 599685) But if it strikes now
('3', 270, 3, 23, 599707) 1Vide “Mr. Stuart the Magistrate”, 24 9 1903.
('3', 271, 0, 1, 599753) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 271, 1, 2, 599795) while the iron is hot, the blow will be fully effective.
('3', 271, 1, 3, 599852) We do not want to see a single Indian among us living on the disgusting and demoralising traffic.
('3', 271, 1, 4, 599950) We are glad that the Indian community thorou ghly approves of the action of the police and the Magistrate, and is determined to visit the parties concerned with such social penalties as may be considered advisable.

('3', 271, 3, 6, 600191) 177. THE IMMIGRATION RESTRICTION ACT, NATAL
('3', 271, 4, 7, 600235) The erstwhile Immigration Bill 1, having received the Royal ass ent, has been gazetted as an Act, and is now of full force and effecting the Colony.
('3', 271, 4, 8, 600384) It was never doubted that it would receive sanction from Downing Street.
('3', 271, 4, 9, 600457) The Colonies have become very powerful, and are becoming more and more so day by day.
('3', 271, 4, 10, 600543) The Indian subjects of the King Emperor, therefore, have to patiently and quietly submit to the restrictions that the Colonists may choose to impose upon them, hop ing with Lord Milner 2 that “times and discussion” would enable the Colonists to see the error of their ways and recognise the obligations that they should discharge as component parts of the mighty Empire.
('3', 271, 4, 11, 600914) It may be well to set forth the material difference between the old Act and the new.
('3', 271, 6, 12, 600999) (1) The language test consisted in the ability of the applicant to write out, in the characters of some European language, an application in accordance with the simple form that was attached to the Act.
('3', 271, 8, 13, 601202) (1) The applicant has to write out any application that may be dictated by the Immigration Officer.
('3', 271, 10, 14, 601302) (2) The minor children of eligible immigrants were entitled to enter the Colony, whether they could satisfy the language test or not, the age of majority being 21 years.
('3', 271, 11, 15, 601472) 1Vide “The Immigration Restriction Bill”, 9 7 1903,“Immigration Restriction Bill” 6 8 1903 & “Potchefstroom Indians”, 6 8 1903 2 Sir Alfred Milner, High Commissioner and Governor of Cape Colony (1897 1901) and of the Transvaal and Orange River Colony (1901 5).
('3', 272, 0, 1, 601733) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 273
('3', 272, 2, 2, 601774) (2) The age of majority has now been arbitrarily fixed at sixteen years.
('3', 272, 4, 3, 601847) (3) Any person who could prove two years’ residence in the Colony was entitled to a domicile certificate, and, therefore, was not a prohibited immigrant.
('3', 272, 6, 4, 602001) (3) The period has now been increased to three years.
('3', 272, 8, 5, 602055) (4) Temporary passes were granted to applicants making applications through friends or agents.
('3', 272, 10, 6, 602150) (4) Personal application is now to be insisted upon.
('3', 272, 12, 7, 602203) (5) The law was silent as to whether an indentured Indian, by having served the Colony for five years, could be considered to have been domiciled.
('3', 272, 14, 8, 602350) (5) It now lays down that such five years’ residence would not constitute domicile within the meaning of the Act.
('3', 272, 14, 9, 602464) Thus, in five essential particulars, the restrictions have been made harsher by the law of the Colony in spite of reasonable objec tions raised by the British Indians against the Bill, and there is no guarantee that we have seen the last of them.
('3', 272, 14, 10, 602711) Indian Opinion, 8 10 1903
('3', 272, 15, 11, 602737) 178. MR. WYBERG AND ASIATIC LABOUR
('3', 272, 16, 12, 602772) Mr. Wyberg, the Commissioner of Mines for the Transvaal, in gving his evidence before the Labour Commission, has placed it on a platform higher than that hitherto adopted by any of the witnesses, and a member though he is of the Legislative Council, he has not he sitated to utter some home truths.We give below the most telling points made by him in reply to Mr. Quinn, the indefatigable opponent of the introduction of Asiatic Labour.
('3', 272, 16, 13, 603209) Mr. Wyberg said:
('3', 272, 17, 14, 603226) He knew nothing personally of the experiments which had been made in the use of white unskilled labour on the mines, but he had followed the
('3', 273, 0, 1, 603367) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 273, 1, 2, 603409) controversy with great interest.
('3', 273, 1, 3, 603442) His opinion with regard to the use of white labour was expressed in the adage, ‘Where there’s a will, there’s a way’.
('3', 273, 1, 4, 603560) If there was a great desire to extend the employment of white labour, he could not help thinking it would be done.
('3', 273, 1, 5, 603675) He looked upon it primarily as a political question of great importance.
('3', 273, 1, 6, 603748) It all depended upon the policy to be pursued.
('3', 273, 2, 7, 603795) The question as to whether white labour would be employed, or Coloured, obtained locally or elsewhere, depended entirely upon the wishes of the mine owners.
('3', 273, 2, 8, 603952) If they said to their engineers.
('3', 273, 2, 9, 603985) ‘We wish you to make a great effort to have white labour, and the man who can show us how best to use it will be freely rewarded,’ then he thought very great efforts would be made to use white labour, and also that it might be successful.
('3', 273, 2, 10, 604224) On the other hand, if the mine owners said, '‘We would rather not have white labour,’ then, I don’t think the engineer [would]he should not, as an engineerhave an adequate
('3', 273, 3, 11, 604398) incentive to put himself out to try and make it a success.
('3', 273, 3, 12, 604457) In reply to Mr. Whiteside, Mr. Wyberg proceeded:
('3', 273, 4, 13, 604506) He took a keen interest in public affairs in pre war days and was at one time President of the South African League, whose policy was to get all the Englishmen into Transvaal that they possibly could.
('3', 273, 4, 14, 604707) That was his policy and the policy of every Englishman, he supposed.
('3', 273, 4, 15, 604776) There could be no two opinions as to the encouragement of Englishmen settling in this country being of the very greatest importance, and it should be the object of every loyal man in the country.
('3', 273, 4, 16, 604972) He would go further and say that, apart from all questions of loyalty or disloyalty, from the point of view of making this a valuable portion of the British Empire, such as Canada and Australia, which were white man’s countries, and not allowing it to sink into the position of Jamaica or British Guiana, or other sub tropical countries, where the white man was the task master and the bulk of the population little better than slaves,  from that
('3', 273, 5, 17, 605420) point of view–it was of the highest importance that they should make the bulk of the population here white men, and white men who would do the work of the country.
('3', 273, 5, 18, 605584) It was a most demoralising thing to take up the attitude that, if they could not get enough Coloured labour in South Africa, they must supplement it from some other source.
('3', 273, 5, 19, 605757) Mr. Wyberg in these telling sentences has made it clear that, in his opinion, the position of indentured labourers from Asia would be little better that that of slaves, and that it is one of the grounds on which he bases his objections to the introduction of assisted Asiatic labour.
('3', 273, 5, 20, 606041) There is nothing in an attitude of this kind against which any reasonable man can take exception, and we can but hope that his evi dence will be considered weighty enough to turn the scales agianst
('3', 274, 0, 1, 606239) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 275
('3', 274, 1, 2, 606280) those gentlemen who are so eager, irrespective of considerations of right and wrong, to exploit the Asiatic labour in order to benefit them selves.
('3', 274, 1, 3, 606428) Mr. Wyberg is evidently a man with principles, and strong enough to resist interested pressure at the risk of losing money, for Mr. Quinn elicited from him the fact that he had to leave the Consoli dated Gold Fields because, Mr. Wyberg said, “they wished me to alter or suppress my political opinions”.
('3', 274, 1, 4, 606731) It is interesting also to note that, in Mr. Wyberg’s opinion, he does not consider that there is any real paucity of Native labour.
('3', 274, 1, 5, 606863) When told by Mr. Quinn that his statement did not agree with a good deal of the evidence that preceded his, Mr. Wyberg said:
('3', 274, 2, 6, 606988) I have had exceptional facilities for finding out what is going on, and I think there is no likelihood of a great immediate demand for labour in the outside districts.

('3', 274, 3, 8, 607181) MOCKERY OF GOD IN THE ORANGE RIVER COLONY
('3', 274, 4, 9, 607223) His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor, Sir Hamilton John Goold Adams, signed a proclamation appointing last Sunday a day of humiliation and prayer or of thanksgiving, as the case may be, “in order that.” the proclamation proceeds.
('3', 274, 4, 10, 607455) “we may humble oursleves before Almighty God and beseech Him that the country may be freed from the scourge of the drought and blessed with plenteous and refreshing rain”.
('3', 274, 4, 11, 607627) “In case,” the proclamation adds, “it may please Almighty God to send the blessing of rain before the above mention ed date, I hereby, proclaim that the day shall be observed as a Day of Thanksgiving”.
('3', 274, 4, 12, 607829) As fate would have it, this proclamation is imme diately followed by one making it compulsory for Coloured people to be vaccinated on pain of being fined five pounds, or in default, being imprisoned with hard labour for 14 days.
('3', 274, 4, 13, 608058) The juxtaposition of the two is no doubt purely an accident.
('3', 274, 4, 14, 608119) The safeguard against smallpox, we believe to be necessary; and, by itself, there can be no serious complaint against the Coloured people being specially subjected to compulsory vaccination.
('3', 274, 4, 15, 608310) But coming as it does from the OrangeRiver Colony, the second proclamation is typical of the most hostile policy against Coloured people, which has been handed down to it by the old Government.
('3', 274, 4, 16, 608504) What, then does the first proclamation mean?
('3', 274, 4, 17, 608549) In days of yore, when men humbled themselves, they sacrificed something.
('3', 274, 4, 18, 608622) They insti 
('3', 275, 0, 1, 608634) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 275, 1, 2, 608676) tuted a searching self examination, repented of their sins and turned over, as it were, a new leaf.
('3', 275, 1, 3, 608776) Did it ever occur to Mr. H. F. Wilson, the Colonial Secretary, who drew up the proclamation, or the Lieutenant Governor who signed it, that there was no repentance intended, that, in the opinion of the Government whom they represent, there could be no turning away from its policy, whether sinful or otherwise?
('3', 275, 1, 4, 609087) We venture to think that the Colony’s blind and unreasonable prejudice against colour and its deliberate closing of the Colony’s gates against the people of British India, of whose assistance it gladly availed in its hour of need, is a national sin before God, and that so long as that policy is continued, so long will it be impossible for it to practise real humiliation that would be acceptable in the sight of God Almighty, Who will judge, not according to a man’s colour, but according to his merits.
('3', 275, 1, 5, 609593) We have the authority of the Asiatic Prophet, Jesus Christa Coloured man by the wayfor saying that a mere lip prayer does not ensure entrance into heaven: “Not every man that sayeth unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter the Kingdom of Heaven, but he that doth the will of my Father”.
('3', 275, 1, 6, 609874) The prayer unaccompanied by deed is a vain repetition.
('3', 275, 1, 7, 609929) “The Earth is the Lord’s”, says the Bible.
('3', 275, 1, 8, 609972) The Colonists have revised the text and say, “The Earth is ours”.
('3', 275, 1, 9, 610038) The appointment, therefore, of a day of humiliation is a mere hollow pretension, so long as God’s commands are trampled under foot.
('3', 275, 1, 10, 610170) And yet, we are free to confess that the proclamation is not a deliberate mockery of the Godhead.
('3', 275, 1, 11, 610268) It is the yearning of the heart after our Maker in the hour of need and trial.
('3', 275, 1, 12, 610347) But it is also a fine illustration of the weakness of our natures.
('3', 275, 1, 13, 610414) We measure God by our measure, forgetting that our ways are not His ways.
('3', 275, 1, 14, 610488) Were it otherwise, we would very soon be without many things in spite of what we may, in our vanity, mis term humiliation and prayer.
('3', 275, 1, 15, 610622) The All wise God makes His sun shine alike on the good and the wicked.
('3', 275, 1, 16, 610693) May we not, however, ask His Excellency and his Government to pause and think?
('3', 275, 1, 17, 610772) The proclamation is a sign of a godly heart.
('3', 275, 1, 18, 610817) Is it consistent with godliness to condemn a whole race of men, related to one by ties of allegiance to a common sovereign, because they happen to wear a skin different from one’s own?
('3', 275, 1, 19, 611002) Have the British Indians committed any wrong to merit the degradation that they are subjected to in the Colony?
('3', 275, 1, 20, 611114) But if the crusade against men of colour must be presisted in, why offend God and humanity by appointment of days of humiliation falsely so called?

('3', 277, 3, 14, 615132) 182. PERMITS FOR THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 277, 4, 15, 615163) We draw the attention of our Indian readers to the advertisements regarding Permit Regulations, which appeared in our last issue.
('3', 277, 4, 16, 615293) We have to congratulate Captain Hamilton Fowle, the Chief Secretary for Permits, on having drawn up regulations which are so simple and yet effective.
('3', 277, 4, 17, 615444) Our readers will note that they will not now have any longer to go through half a dozen channels before receiving their permits.
('3', 277, 4, 18, 615573) The idea of doing away with the necessity of applicants having to go to the Permit Offices at the different towns is, in our opinion, very sound and original.
('3', 277, 4, 19, 615732) All that a refugee has now to do is to obtain a form of application for permit, fill it in, sign it before a J. P., and forward it to the Chief Secretary for Permits.
('3', 277, 4, 20, 615899) The applicant then would receive by return of post, an acknowledgment, and as soon as his turn comes, would receive his authority to enter the Transvaal.
('3', 278, 0, 1, 616053) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 279
('3', 278, 1, 2, 616094) He has then to report himself at Johannesburg and take out the perma nent document entitling him to reside in the Colony.
('3', 278, 1, 3, 616216) It would at first appear somewhat hard that people wishing to go to other parts of the Transvaal must necessarily pass through Johannesburg: but, seeing that the choice was between having different offices for issuing of permits and for all to proceed to Johannesburg, we consider that the latter course was the lesser evil of the two, when it is borne in mind that a very large percentage gravitate to Johannesburg.
('3', 278, 1, 4, 616633) The applicants should bear in mind that, after the receipt of authority to proceed to the Transvaal, they would have only a certain time within which to proceed.
('3', 278, 1, 5, 616795) It would, therefore, be well for them to be very careful about not exceeding the time limit.
('3', 278, 1, 6, 616888) In these permit regulations, we see an altogether new era before the poor refugees who have hitherto been simply robbed of honest money in endeavouring to get what they ought to have got without the slightest trouble or expense.
('3', 278, 1, 7, 617117) Captain Fowle reminds the applicants that “there is no charge whatsoever either for application forms or permits”, and adds, “Should an applicant have any complaint against any member of the permit staff at any time, he is requested to communicate direct with the Chief Secretary for Permits”.
('3', 278, 1, 8, 617411) Refugees should note that their applicatoions have to be sent directly to the Chief Secretary for Permits, and not through an agent.
('3', 278, 1, 9, 617544) It will be their own fault if they spend any money over agents or solicitors.
('3', 278, 1, 10, 617622) Indian Opinion, 8 10 1903
