('3', 280, 0, 1, 620923) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 281
('3', 280, 1, 2, 620964) problem touching the mining industry.
('3', 280, 1, 3, 621002) How to secure the labour for that industry under terms the most favourable to it, and the least favourable to the labourers themselves, is the question Mr. Skinner has set himself to answer throughout the five and a half columns which it occupies in the Johannesburg Star.
('3', 280, 1, 4, 621275) These are the restrictions which Mr. Skinner would impose on the labourers: (1) Indenture for a term of years.
('3', 280, 1, 5, 621386) (2) The restriction to certain classes of labour and places of abode.
('3', 280, 1, 6, 621456) (3) Prohibition of trade and inability to lease and own property for such period.
('3', 280, 1, 7, 621538) (4) Compulsory return on termination of indenture, unless indenture renewed.
('3', 280, 1, 8, 621615) (5) The necessity of complying with English laws and health regulations; both foreign to Chinese traditions.
('3', 280, 1, 9, 621724) Thus, with the exception of the first and the fifth, all the res trictions are to be imposed so as to prevent the Chinaman from mak ing use of his brains or his limbs more profitably than his masters will allow him to.
('3', 280, 1, 10, 621943) Mr. Skinner adds to these restrictions the Compound System, and would, therefore, make the labourer a prisoner, pure and simple.
('3', 280, 1, 11, 622072) The next step now as the Leader gravely puts it, is for the Legislature to sanction the introduction under the disabilities mentio ned above, and the labour problem of the Transvaal is solved.
('3', 280, 1, 12, 622265) We would, however, in spite of Mr. Skinner’s conclusion, venture to hope that, although the legislation may be sanctioned,as to which we have serious doubtsthe people affected will turn a deaf ear to the persu asion of the labour agents and simply decline to accept the inhuman terms.
('3', 280, 1, 13, 622552) Then the question of the mining industry will be solved gradu ally, and with benefit both to the white settlers and the native of the soil, without having the distrubing elements in the shape of Chinese or any other assisted Asiatic immigration.
('3', 280, 1, 14, 622798) Indeed, Mr. Skinner himself fears the possibility of guilds or combinations working against the interests of his masters.
('3', 280, 1, 15, 622920) We give that portion of the report in his own words:
('3', 280, 2, 16, 622973) A very potent force amongst the Chinese is a system of co peration somewhat akin to freemasonry.
('3', 280, 2, 17, 623070) They understand well the power and advantage to be derived from combination.
('3', 280, 2, 18, 623147) In San Francisco, there are six Chinese Companies or Guilds, and to one or other of these the great majority of Chinese
('3', 281, 0, 1, 623267) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 281, 1, 2, 623309) immigrants used to contribute and become members.
('3', 281, 1, 3, 623359) The system is far reaching, but in the general application exercises a wholesome influence.
('3', 281, 1, 4, 623451) These guilds transact business for their members, they supervise labour contracts, receive and deposit money, or remit same to China, and generally look after and take a lively interest in the welfare of the Chinese community.
('3', 281, 1, 5, 623678) Another function of theirs is to make all the necessary arrangements, when so desired, to have the bones of deceased members sent to their relatives in China.
('3', 281, 1, 6, 623837) Such societies, comprehensive as they are, if established on the Rand, would have a very powerful bearing on the Chinese immigrants.
('3', 281, 1, 7, 623970) In many ways, as in those mentioned above, they might be useful and beneficial, but their power might also become a danger, especially if they could suppose that the mines were entirely dependent on the Chinese for their unskilled labour.
('3', 281, 1, 8, 624209) To avoid such an emergency, it is plainly desirable that all the present effort to increase the supply of Kaffir labour should be vigorously continued with a view to balancing, as far as possible, the supply of Kaffir, Chinese and other unskilled labourers on the mines.
('3', 281, 1, 9, 624480) This principle might also be adopted in the cases of Chinese from different districts.
('3', 281, 1, 10, 624567) For instance, experience points to the fact that it is unlikely that northern men would co operate with the southern Chinese.
('3', 281, 1, 11, 624693) Thus, Mr. Skinner would evidently follow the policy of “divide and rule”.
('3', 281, 1, 12, 624767) We, however, think that, in basing his hope on legislative enactments to break down combinations, he is counting without his host.
('3', 281, 1, 13, 624898) However much the northern Chinese and the southern Chinese may quarrel among themselves in their own land, he will find that a common grievance would make them good companions, and that it would not prevent them from combining together in order to resist the practical working of Compounds and the deprivation of their personal liberties.
('3', 281, 1, 14, 625237) Mr. Skinner’s suggestion as to the details of the scheme is very interesting, though, in our opinion, utterly impracticable.
('3', 281, 1, 15, 625362) As soon as he imports Chinese doctors and Chinese headmen, he will find that they will want their personal liberty, and they will want to use their brains in an unrestricted manner.
('3', 281, 1, 16, 625544) It would be a most interesting experiment to watch one set of intelligent people trying to dwarf the intelligence of another set of people equally intelligent.
('3', 281, 1, 17, 625704) We give the details as under, and leave the reader to judge for himself whether any legislation that can be devised by Sir Richard Solomon would be sufficient to carry out the paper policy so light heartedly drawn up by Mr. Skinner.
('3', 281, 2, 18, 625937) The composition of the complement of Chinese labourers for one mine would broadly be:
('3', 282, 0, 1, 626023) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 283
('3', 282, 1, 2, 626064) (1) One headman who would act as interpreter to, and work along with, the Compound manager.
('3', 282, 2, 3, 626156) (2) Four under headmen, two for underground and two for surface work, capable of talking or sufficiently intelligent to acquire soon, a little English.
('3', 282, 3, 4, 626308) (3) Overman or boss coolies: one for every thirty men, to act in the same capacity as the boss boys in gangs of Kaffirs.
('3', 282, 4, 5, 626429) (4) One cook for every 50 men, with a young coolie as assistant.
('3', 282, 5, 6, 626494) (5) One Chinese doctor.
('3', 282, 5, 7, 626518) He can act as headman in charge of the hospital under the local mine doctor.
('3', 282, 5, 8, 626595) Many of the Chinese, especially at the outset, would insist on the option of being treated by a countryman of their own.
('3', 282, 5, 9, 626716) To meet this, a supply of Chinese medicines will require to be kept.
('3', 282, 6, 10, 626785) Individual mines will have to be manned by white skilled and Kaffir unskilled, or by white skilled and Chinese unskilled.
('3', 282, 6, 11, 626907) No mixing of Kaffir and Chinese on any one mine should be permitted.
('3', 282, 6, 12, 626976) Indeed, it would be advisable to prevent mixing in districts, if it could be arranged.
('3', 282, 6, 13, 627063) Along with the first few thousands of coolies, who would probably precede the main flow, men accustomed to Chinese ought to be brought to see that the coolies are pro perly handled, and also to assist those mines likely to employ Chinese labour in the study of it, so that they will not have a new condition of things sud denly sprung upon them without some preparation.
('3', 282, 6, 14, 627434) Indian Opinion, 15 10 1903
('3', 282, 7, 15, 627461) 185. THAT INSANITARY AREA IN JOHANNESBURG
('3', 282, 8, 16, 627503) The speakers at the mass meeting held on the 7th instant at Johannesburg, Main Road, did not mince matters in giving expression to their views on the position taken up by the Johannesburg Town Council regarding the payment of expropriation claims, and the char ging of rents against the quondam owners of the Stands within that Area.
('3', 282, 8, 17, 627837) Some very strong language was used.
('3', 282, 8, 18, 627873) The action of the Town Council was considered to be an outrage.
('3', 282, 8, 19, 627937) Mr. Mark Gibbons, the Chairman, considered “the action of the Town Council was really disgraceful, and it imposed a burden which they ought not to bear”.
('3', 282, 8, 20, 628091) Another speaker described expropriation to be “confiscation”, and motives were freely attributed to the Town Councillors.
('3', 282, 8, 21, 628213) We do not consider that these epithets are justified.
('3', 282, 8, 22, 628267) Unless we have positive proof to the contrary, we would decline to believe that Mr. Quinn and his coadjutors are actuated by any but the purest motives; but when we have said so much, we have said all that can possibly be said in favour
('3', 283, 0, 1, 628504) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 283, 1, 2, 628546) of the Insanitary Area Committee.
('3', 283, 1, 3, 628580) That its action is very niggardly we have not the slightest doubt, and as it has to deal with a very large number of Indian claims, it might be as well to examine the two charges laid at its door by the speakers, who would have done far greater good to themselves if they had confined themselves to a bald statement of facts, which are staggering enough.
('3', 283, 1, 4, 628935) And the best proof to be adduced against the Town Council is in its own admission, namely, that out of 1,200 claims, only164 claimants have thought fit to accept the ridiculous offers made by it.
('3', 283, 1, 5, 629131) It might be said that claimants knew their business far better than outsiders, and that their having accepted a settlement shows that the offer must have been very fair.
('3', 283, 1, 6, 629301) Those, however, who will argue thus, forget the main fact that the Council and the claimants are not equally matched.
('3', 283, 1, 7, 629419) People who are deprived of their land, which is perhaps their only support in life, and are hard pressed by creditors, would have to, whether they would or not, come to terms with their adversary, who may control an inexhaustible purse, as the Town Council undoubtedly does, so far as the poor residents of the Insanitary Area are concerned.
('3', 283, 1, 8, 629761) We, therefore, think that even the settlement of the few claims cannot be put forward to the credit of the Town Council.
('3', 283, 1, 9, 629882) But it stands self condemned when we consider that the largest number of claims is still undisposed of.
('3', 283, 1, 10, 629986) Coming to the nature of the claims, we have been supplied with information which goes to show that the work of valuation has been taken up without any methods.
('3', 283, 1, 11, 630146) There are Stands, on which very decent buildings have been erected, which have been valued at the same price as those on which there are rickety structures only.
('3', 283, 1, 12, 630308) It should be borne in mind that the Stands in question are, apart from the structures, of the same value, being in the same locality and almost adjacent.
('3', 283, 1, 13, 630462) And these are not merely isolated instances.
('3', 283, 1, 14, 630507) In many more cases, Stands, which, when last changing hands, brought a fair value, have been undervalued by the Council Valuators.
('3', 283, 1, 15, 630638) It is all very well to say that the owners have put in exorbitant claims.
('3', 283, 1, 16, 630712) They may or may not have done so, but we do think that, in adopting the cheese paring policy, the Council is doing but an ill service to the general body of ratepayers.
('3', 283, 1, 17, 630881) In doing so, the Councillors have perhaps formed an exaggerated opinion of their duty, and in trying to save money to the ratepayers in general, they are inflicting an injustice on those ratepayers who are most in need of fairness, if not generous treatment.
('3', 283, 1, 18, 631140) The law has deprived them, the owners, of the benefit of the rise that will take place in the value of rent within the Insanitary Area after the improvements have been
('3', 284, 0, 1, 631308) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 285
('3', 284, 1, 2, 631349) made thereon.
('3', 284, 1, 3, 631363) No complaint can be made against the proposition that the whole of such increment would belong to the ratepayers.
('3', 284, 1, 4, 631477) But that being so, it was only to be expected of the Town Council that it would treat the owners of the Insanitary Area in a fair and handsome man ner.
('3', 284, 1, 5, 631629) As to the proposal of the Town Council to charge rents from the owners, it is very difficult to withhold one’s sympathy from those who are opposing it.
('3', 284, 1, 6, 631781) The speakers at the mass meeting uttered nothing but the truth when they said that many of them were dependent on the income from their properties.
('3', 284, 1, 7, 631929) The Town Council may be legally justified in insisting on its pound of flesh, but in a matter of this kind the legal justification becomes nothing short of cruelty if it is not tempered with humane considerations.
('3', 284, 1, 8, 632143) The question of finding residential sites for those who have been dispossessed is more or less indefinietly postponed.
('3', 284, 1, 9, 632262) If, therefore, until full arrangements for their housing are made, the owners are not allowed to make use of their properties temporarily and receive the income therefrom, what are they to do, especially in these times of stress and trouble?
('3', 284, 1, 10, 632504) Rains are very much belated, and we do not know when the heavens will smile on South Africa.
('3', 284, 1, 11, 632597) The industries are stagnant, the money market is dull, and we read in the newspapers that there are thousands of men in Johannesburg absolutely without work.
('3', 284, 1, 12, 632755) To deprive innocent men, under such circumstances, of their only means of living is an action for which there cannot be the slightest justification.
('3', 284, 1, 13, 632904) The Council is still nominated and can perhaps afford to disregard popular feeling but we believe that, owing to its irresponsible position, it is doubly its duty to deal with the inhabitants of the Insanitary Area with justice and fairness, and if it cannot, or will not, do so, then it can easily suspend action until the elective Council is established in Johannesburg, which will be within a very short time.
('3', 284, 1, 14, 633317) Indian Opinion,15 10 1903
('3', 284, 2, 15, 633343) 186. JOHANNESBURG LOCATION
('3', 284, 3, 16, 633370) We have no hesitation in supporting the petition said to be in circulation, as will appear from the extract we print today from The Transvaal Leader of the 7th instant, on the part of the “Residents and Ratepayers of Johannesburg”, addressed to the Town Council, asking for the removal of the present Indian Location to a more suitable position.
('3', 284, 3, 17, 633716) The petition has reference to the proposal of the Health Committee of the Johannesburg Town Council, namely, that the
('3', 285, 0, 1, 633834) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 285, 1, 2, 633876) present Indian Location, of which the residents have been dispossessed under the Insanitary Area Expropriation Ordinance, should be removed to the Kaffir Location, and that the Kaffir Location should be placed further up.
('3', 285, 1, 3, 634098) We confess that the reasons that induce the ratepayers to make their protest against the suggestion are not the same that guide us.
('3', 285, 1, 4, 634230) The petitioners evidently consider that the Indians ought to be removed further away from even the present Kaffir Location.
('3', 285, 1, 5, 634354) In our opinion, the Kaffir Location itself is too far away from the Expropriated Area to be of any use to the British Indians, [more so] in view of the fact that the law provides that the residents within the Insanitary Area should not be removed from their occupation until a site near the Insanitary Area has been pointed out to them for their residence.
('3', 285, 1, 6, 634711) Now we are aware that the Kaffir Location is over a mile form the Location expropriated by the town Coucil, and we hardly think that removing the men fully one mile away from their present place will be considered to be in accordance with the require ments of the Expropriation Law.
('3', 285, 1, 7, 634994) Either, therefore, the men have to be allowed to remain within the Expropriated area, or another less obje ctionable site pointed out to them.
('3', 285, 1, 8, 635137) The example of Cape Town is cited in connection with the proposal of the petitioners and justification sought for the removal of the British Indians to a place far away from Johannesburg on the strength of the Kaffirs in Cape Town being brought all the way from Maitland.
('3', 285, 1, 9, 635409) There is, however, absolutely no analogy between the two.
('3', 285, 1, 10, 635467) If the Indians residing in the Location were all of them workmen pure and simple, there might be something to be said in favour of the Cape Town system being repro duced in Johannesburg, but seeing that most of them are independent men engaged in trade and some of them depending for their living on the trade in the Location itself, it will be seen at once that the site has to be so near the town as to afford, at any rate, reasonable facilities for attracting the town custom alike from the white people as the Natives.
('3', 285, 1, 11, 635990) Indian opinion,15 10 1903

('3', 285, 3, 13, 636043) The die is cast, and Mr. St. John Brodrick has been inflicted upon India.
('3', 285, 3, 14, 636117) The universal judgment about Mr. Brodrick’s career has been that he has succeeded in utterly mismanaging the War Office, and that he has shown himself incapable of holding a ministerial position.
('3', 285, 3, 15, 636313) Mr. Balfour found, however, that he could not very well give
('3', 286, 0, 1, 636374) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 287
('3', 286, 1, 2, 636415) him the go by, and has, therefore, given him a position against which there cannot be an effective outcry.
('3', 286, 1, 3, 636522) He is not likely to forfeit a single vote by Mr. Brodrick being installed at the India Office.
('3', 286, 1, 4, 636617) India may unanimously cry out against the appointment, but then India has no votes and no say whatsoever in the election of members of the House of Commons.
('3', 286, 1, 5, 636774) It did not matter a bit that Mr. Brodrick brought out, in order to save himself, the preposterous proposal to saddle India with an annual cost of nearly £ 500,000 towards the upkeep of the South African garrison.
('3', 286, 1, 6, 636987) It did not matter at all that the scheme was so universally condemned that it had to be abandoned.
('3', 286, 1, 7, 637086) The injustice and the heartlessness of the appointment have appealed even to the people in South Africa.
('3', 286, 1, 8, 637191) We could not have written more strongly against it than the leader writer in The Transvaal Leader.
('3', 286, 1, 9, 637290) This is what he has to say on the appointment:
('3', 286, 2, 10, 637337) That Mr. Brodrick should have left Pall Mall is unquestionably a gain, but we doubt whether people in India will be pleased to see him at the head of their affairs.
('3', 286, 2, 11, 637502) It is difficult to resist the unanimous verdict that he is a thor ughly incompetent man, and, that being the case, he should be quietly dismissed into unofficial life.
('3', 286, 2, 12, 637670) Of course, it is impossible to ascertain all the facts of the case.
('3', 286, 2, 13, 637738) In Lord Curzon, he has the strongest, most competent Viceroy since the time of Lord Dalhousie, and he may have received secret instructions to defer to Lord Curzon in all things, and to be a figure head simply.
('3', 286, 2, 14, 637949) It can only be hoped that this is the case, for really the experiments he has initiated, so far, have been such disastrous failures that no one wants any tinkerings with the delicate affairs of the East from his hand.
('3', 286, 2, 15, 638167) Indian Opinion, 15 10 1903
('3', 286, 3, 16, 638194) 188. INDIA’S SERVICE TO THE EMPIRE
('3', 286, 4, 17, 638229) One of the recent numbers of India to hand gives some startling figures regarding the contribution made by India to the Empire, and these services are very widely distributed and have been rendered ever since 1860. We read then that in 1860 and 1861 India sent two regi ments and one regiment respectively to New Zealand.
('3', 286, 4, 18, 638551) In 1867, for the Abyssinian Expedition, India lent sixteen infantry regiments, five cavalry regiments, seven companies of engineers, five batteries of artil lery, commander and staff.
('3', 286, 4, 19, 638735) In 1875, the whole of the Perak Expe dition was fitted out by India.
('3', 286, 4, 20, 638804) The Afghan War of 1878 and 1879 claimed from 60,000 to 70,000 men.
('3', 286, 4, 21, 638871) In 1882, the Egyptian Expe dition drew on India for five infantry regiments, three cavalry regi 
('3', 287, 0, 1, 638968) 288 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 287, 1, 2, 639010) ments, two companies of engineers, and two batteries of artillery.
('3', 287, 1, 3, 639077) The expeditions for the Soudan and Suakin in 1885 and 1896 respectively were formed entirely in India.
('3', 287, 1, 4, 639180) In all but one instance, India paid all the ordinary expenses.
('3', 287, 1, 5, 639243) During the Afghan War, India paid £18,000,000 as against £5,000,000 paid by Great Britain, and for the Egyptian Expedition, India not only paid the ordinary expenses, but £800,000 besides for extraordinary expenses.
('3', 287, 1, 6, 639459) We may add to this India’s contribution to the Afghan War before 1860 when thousands were buried in snow, and when General Sai was enabled to make his name famous through his Indian brigades.
('3', 287, 1, 7, 639651) We might also add to this wonderful record the recent Chinese Expedition, the most timely aid rendered to South Africa by Sir George White and his 10,000 from India, and the war at present going on in Somaliland.
('3', 287, 1, 8, 639864) We have, in a previous issue, described India as “the Cinderella of the Empire”, 1
('3', 287, 2, 9, 639947) and we ask our readers whether our description is at all far fetched.
('3', 287, 2, 10, 640017) We venture to think that, in the history of the Empire, especially in the history of the Colonial expansion, there is nothing to compare with the record we have been able to produce.
('3', 287, 2, 11, 640200) The colonies have never given, or been called upon to give, to the same extent as India, and while it is undo ubtedly a matter of satisfaction and pride to every member of the Empire that the colonial response during the late war was very liberal, we think that it dwindles into insignificance before that which India has undergone and given, for the fact should not be lost sight of that, after all, the Colonists have been paid for every bit of service they have rendered, and, if we be permitted to mention an incident, we may state that the Australian ministers even went so far as to charge comm ission and interest for moneys disbursed by them on account of Great Britain, as if the relation between the Mother Country and Australia was merely that of Agent and Principal.
('3', 287, 2, 12, 640979) Indian Opinion, 15 10 1903

('3', 289, 1, 2, 642884) 191. TRANSVAAL PERMITS
('3', 289, 2, 3, 642907) The Return of Permits issued by the Chief Secretary during the past months, published in the Johannesburg papers, is a document of very great importance and interest to the British Indians.
('3', 289, 2, 4, 643097) The total number of permits granted during that period is 32,351, of which 7,827 only were granted to old residents, and 24,524 to new comers.
('3', 289, 2, 5, 643240) These figures are for the Transvaal only.
('3', 289, 2, 6, 643282) There were 11,865 permits granted between January and March, 11,844 between April and June, and 8,642 between July and September.
('3', 289, 2, 7, 643412) The figures do not take into account any of the ex burghers who surrendered during the war, or ex burghers who were allowed to return.
('3', 289, 2, 8, 643547) They, therefore, apply solely to the non Boer Europeans, for it should be remembered that they do not include Asiatic permits.
('3', 289, 2, 9, 643674) These are a complete answer to the charge often brought against the immigration of British Indians into the Transvaal, namely, that it would, if it was allowed to be unrestricted, flood the Colony.
('3', 289, 2, 10, 643872) According to official returns, there are at present scarcely 10,000 Indians in the colony of the Transvaal as against, acc ording to one Johannesburg newspaper, nearly 500,000 Europeans, including burghers.
('3', 289, 2, 11, 644079) It does not, therefore, seem as if there was any imminent danger of the British Indians overrunning the Transvaal.
('3', 289, 2, 12, 644194) But the figures also tell another painful tale, namely, that, while three times the number of European refugees have been allowed permits to enter the Transvaal, very few, if any, permits have hitherto been granted to the non refugee British Indians, no matter what their claims may be to special consderation.
('3', 289, 2, 13, 644505) We are aware of scores of instances of men, who were promised employment to the Transvaal being unable to accept same owing to permits having been refused to them on account of their not being refugees.
('3', 289, 2, 14, 644708) Only seventy permits per week are issued to Asiatics, including, we presume, Chinese, and the reply to applications from non refugeeBritish Indians has been that, unless the whole list of applications from refugee British Indians is exhausted, no such applications could be considered.
('3', 289, 2, 15, 644994) The Permit Department has now been entirely transferred over to the Chief Secretary for Permits, and may we hope that he will, in dealing with Indian applications, show the same generous spirit to British Indian applications as the has evidently shown to Europeans, whether British subjects or not.
('3', 289, 2, 16, 645293) We do not suggest for one moment that he should allow thousands of non refugee British Indians to enter the Colony; in the first place, there are not thousands waiting to enter the Transvaal, and in the second place, even if there were thousands of Indians wishing to immigrate to the Transvaal, we quite understand that the applications could not be
('3', 290, 0, 1, 645644) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 291
('3', 290, 1, 2, 645685) considered.
('3', 290, 1, 3, 645697) But when men are required for the assistance of those who have already settled in the Colony, or when men are well educated, or have independent means and probably connections in the Transvaal, they ought to be treated in a liberal manner.
('3', 290, 1, 4, 645937) Lord Milner has assured Mr. Chamberlain, 1 that the Transvaal Government is not enforcing the old Law as strictly as before.
('3', 290, 1, 5, 646062) We have entered our respectful protest against the statement, because it is not borne out by facts.
('3', 290, 1, 6, 646162) And the question of Indian immigration is very much in point in this con nection, for, whereas during the old regime the Indian immigration to the Transvaal was quite unrestricted, now even the refugees are not being allowed to return except in dribblets, and the gates of the Trans vaal are entirely closed against non refugee Indians.
('3', 290, 1, 7, 646499) The Transvaal Government, therefore, not only goes beyond the old anti Asiatic Law, but it goes much further than either the Natal or the Cape Law.
('3', 290, 1, 8, 646647) Indians domiciled either in the Cape or Natal are free to leave their respective Colonies and re enter them at any time they like, and those who have a knowledge of one of the European languages are allowed to enter and settle in either of the Colonies, whether they have been previously domiciled or not.
('3', 290, 1, 9, 646953) Lord Milner has suggested the Natal Act as a model to replace the Law 3 of 1885 of the Transvaal.
('3', 290, 1, 10, 647051) May we then suggest that, at any rate for the time being, the applicants who would not be considered prohibited immigrants either under the Natal Act or the Cape Act should be allowed to enter the Transvaal without hindrance, and that the refugees should be granted permits as fast as they apply?
('3', 290, 1, 11, 647348) Both the Natal Act and the Cape Act contain also a provision for special permission for those who are neither domiciled nor educated in any of the European languages, but are nevertheless eligible as immigrants.
('3', 290, 1, 12, 647560) Such people as, for instance, domestic servants required by the settlers in the Transvaal, or store men should also have free access.
('3', 290, 1, 13, 647694) These we venture to consider to be very reasonable demands.
('3', 290, 1, 14, 647754) They would go far to propitiate Indian sentiment, and, as under the suggestion we have made, there can be no question whatso ever of unrestricted influx, nor of a very large number of non refugee applicants, we hope that the Government will see [it] fit to give a sympathetic consideration thereto.
('3', 290, 1, 15, 648053) Indian Opinion, 22 10 1903
('3', 290, 2, 16, 648080) 1 Joseph Chamberlain (1836 1914), Secretary of State for the Colonies, 1895 1903.

('3', 291, 1, 2, 648204) 192. BRITISH AND INDIAN EMPIRE LEAGUE OF AUSTRALIA
('3', 291, 2, 3, 648255) We have received the manifesto of this important Association formed in Australia.
('3', 291, 2, 4, 648337) It is a healthy sign that the British Indians, who have settled in different parts of the world, are banding themselves in order to resist any attempt to curtail their rights as subjects of the King Emperor.
('3', 291, 2, 5, 648545) A perusal of the list of office bearers of the Associa tion would show that our countrymen in Australia have been able to secure the active co operation of some influential Europeans also.
('3', 291, 2, 6, 648734) We read the names of Messrs.
('3', 291, 2, 7, 648763) Tepoo Hall, G. Thorburn, Pascall, Quinn and others.
('3', 291, 2, 8, 648815) And if the list of members of the Committee be any indi cation of the general members, the Association evidently represents all classes of Indians.
('3', 291, 2, 9, 648963) We understand that Mr. Charles Francis Seivwright is one of the founders of the Association.
('3', 291, 2, 10, 649056) The gentleman, according to the Indian Daily News, is a native of Melbourne, and the second son of Mr. Marcus Seivwright, a barrister in practice in Melbourne.
('3', 291, 2, 11, 649216) Mr. Sevwright has been deputed by the Association to represent it at the forthcoming session of the National Congress, as well as the Mahomedan Education Conference.
('3', 291, 2, 12, 649382) He is the bearer to them of petitions urging them to look after the interests of their brethren beyond the seas.
('3', 291, 2, 13, 649495) This is a right step, and we shall follow Mr. Seivwright’s efforts with a great deal of interest.
('3', 291, 2, 14, 649593) For, although the Indian question in South Africa has its own local bearings and, therefore, may not be much affected by Mr. Seivwright’s mission, in so far as it is an Imperial question, what the authorities in Downing Street may do in Australia will very largely apply to South Africa.
('3', 291, 2, 15, 649881) The objects of the Association are such as to command general approval.
('3', 291, 2, 16, 649953) Its aim is “to assist the Commonwealth Government to carry out its laws as they relate to undesirable immigrants, such as those of ignorant, pauper, and immoral classes”.
('3', 291, 2, 17, 650124) Having done so, it aims also “at removing certain hurtful restrictions which now operate detri mentally against natives of British India, who belong to the more enlightened commercial classes”.
('3', 291, 2, 18, 650318) The league also seeks “to improve the social status of Indian citizens of Australia, and in doing this, will serve the dual purpose of benefiting the Indians themselves as well as those with whom they are thrown in contact in their daily life”.
('3', 291, 2, 19, 650563) The manifesto proceeds:
('3', 292, 0, 1, 650587) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 293
('3', 292, 1, 2, 650628) We shall work together and without regard to personal aggrandisement of any individual member, bearing in mind that the interests of the whole of the members must take precedence over all other considerations.
('3', 292, 1, 3, 650838) We shall have to be whole hearted and unselfish, and work for no class or clique in making our appointments to the various high places of the League, and our aim as an organisation must be ‘justice throughout the Commonwealth for all British subjects’.
('3', 292, 1, 4, 651091) The objects are laudable, and such as no one can take exception to.
('3', 292, 1, 5, 651159) The spirit with which the members are to work in admirable.
('3', 292, 1, 6, 651219) And if they continue to work along the lines laid down in their manifesto, success must be certain.
('3', 292, 1, 7, 651319) We welcome the formation of the League, and wish it a long and useful career.
('3', 292, 1, 8, 651397) Indian Opinion, 22 10 1903

('3', 293, 1, 2, 652653) 194. IN TRUE COLOURS
('3', 293, 2, 3, 652674) The following is taken from a report in The Natal Mercury of the meeting of the Dundee Town Council recently held in Dundee:
('3', 293, 3, 4, 652799) Councillor Willson protested against the action of the Licensing Officer in granting a licence to an Indian store keeper who had erected a building for trading purposes.
('3', 293, 3, 5, 652969) He considerd this most unfair, as similar licences had been refused to proposed Indian tenants of substantial stores built by Europeans, and with which the former building could only be classed as a hovel.
('3', 293, 4, 6, 653175) Councillor Jones spoke very strongly on the subject, and stamped the action as disgraceful, in view of the express wish of the Council that no further Indian licences be granted.
('3', 293, 4, 7, 653354) Councillor Jones has come out boldly, and called the action of the Licensing Officer, in using his judgment, as “disgraceful”.
('3', 293, 4, 8, 653481) Coun cillor Willson thought it was “unfair”.
('3', 293, 4, 9, 653526) Truly good judges of the ap pellate court!
('3', 293, 4, 10, 653569) For it should be remembered that the Dundee Council is the appellate court to hear appeals against the decisions of the Licen sing Officer.
('3', 293, 4, 11, 653709) The Licensing Officer in Dundee, therefore, is hence forth not to give his own decisions on applications for licences, but he is merely to become the mouthpiece of the Council, and carry out its behests.
('3', 293, 4, 12, 653913) And yet, in a British Colony, we are told that the Dealers’ Licenses Actreserves to the applicants the right of appeal!
('3', 293, 4, 13, 654033) We take the liberty to say that rather than the action of the Licensing Officer being “disgraceful”, it is the remarks made by the above named councillors ( both store keepers in Dundee) which are disgraceful.

('3', 293, 5, 15, 654270) 195. ASIATIC BAZAARS

('3', 293, 7, 18, 654574) The third question, that of Asiatic Bazaars, is a subject that needs a deal of discussion.

('3', 293, 7, 20, 654765) We are simply informed that the subject will be discussed at the meeting.

('3', 294, 0, 1, 654867) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 295
('3', 294, 1, 2, 654908) discussion will be that Government will be asked to take immediate steps to have the Ordinance enforced.
('3', 294, 1, 3, 655013) We are perfectly in the dark as to why the Chamber is in such feverish haste to do something to have the Asiatic traders shifted out of the town, and think that a discussion on the present dusty state of the streets would be more in place.
('3', 294, 1, 4, 655253) It is refreshing to find our contemporary taking such a sensible view of the question, and we join the Advertiser in the remark that the Chamber is in feverish haste in trying to summarily remove the Asiatic traders settled in Zeerust.
('3', 294, 1, 5, 655489) We understand that at Zeerust there is already a Location established under the old regime, and that now the government has re surveyed it and wishes to rename it a Bazaar, and then force all the Indian traders who did not hold licences prior to war to the Location.
('3', 294, 1, 6, 655756) We consider that such action on the part of the Gov ernment would hardly be in accordance with its own notice, 1 for it has said deliberately that Bazaars shall be so far within the towns as to enable the British Indians to have a portion of the white trade also.
('3', 294, 1, 7, 656020) Now, if the old location at Zeerust, which is on the outskirts of the town and therefore not within it, is a sample of how the Bazaars are to be established in other towns, then we think that it would be a most serious matter.
('3', 294, 1, 8, 656247) In any case, it would be serious enough for established traders to have to remove their businesses, and we still hope that no such procedure will be adopted as to touch vested interests.
('3', 294, 1, 9, 656434) But it would be utterly impossible even for new applicants for licences to do any business in places situated in out of the way localities and, as the end of the year is drawing near, the matter is becoming more and more pressing every day.

('3', 294, 3, 11, 656702) 196. INDENTURED LABOUR FROM INDIA
('3', 294, 4, 12, 656736) We dealt last week with a portion of the interesting report of the Acting Protector of Immigrants for the year 1902. During that year, sixteen vesselseleven from Madras and five from Calcuttalanded 4,373 Indians, 2,940 being men, and 1,069 being women.
('3', 294, 4, 13, 656991) There were, during that time, 18,000 applications, and 1,902 applications undealt with for the year 1901. At the end of the year 1902, therefore, accor ding to the report, there was an unsupplied balance of 17,500 men.
('3', 294, 5, 14, 657210) Unless, therefore, the report proceeds, recruiting in India can be expedited,
('3', 294, 6, 15, 657288) 1Vide “British Indians in South Africa” 12 4 1903
('3', 295, 0, 1, 657338) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 295, 1, 2, 657380) and the despatch of Indians increased, it is hardly possible that the Indians required can be supplied much under two and a half years at the earliest.
('3', 295, 1, 3, 657532) The greatly increased demand arises from the utterly unreliable character of the Native labour of the Colony, especially for agricultural purposes.
('3', 295, 1, 4, 657680) The other reasons given for the extraordinary demand are that
('3', 295, 2, 5, 657742) the Natives have been used to higher wages during the war; that, as riksha pullers, they can make as much as £ 1 per day, and that the increase in the white population of 9,000 must have absorbed a very large number of Natives.
('3', 295, 2, 6, 657970) In consequence of this great scaricity of labour, Natives and free Indians are continuing to receive very high wages for the seventh year as
('3', 295, 3, 7, 658112) high as 60s per month.
('3', 295, 3, 8, 658135) Thus the report shows most clearly how indispensable the Indian is for the prosperity of the Colony.
('3', 295, 3, 9, 658236) He is needed everywhere, and yet we see writers in the newspapers complaining of the influx of Indians in the Colony.
('3', 295, 3, 10, 658354) Our contemporary, The Natal Advertiser, even goes so far as to confuse the Immigration Restriction Act with the Indentured Immigration Law of the Colony, stating that the former has utterly failed to be of any use whatsoever in restricting immigra tion.
('3', 295, 3, 11, 658608) We may remind our contemporary that indentured labour is taken out of the scope of the Immigration Act, and that, therefore, there is no connection between indentured labour and restrictions on free immigration.
('3', 295, 3, 12, 658820) During the year under review, 329 men and 105 women returned to India, and, under the Act amending the Indentured Immigration Law of 1891, 643 men and 296 women re indentured themselves after the expiry of the five years; 1,655 men and 451 women paid the £ 3 poll tax, giving to the Colony and annual revenue of £ 6,318. The fact that so many men and women have paid the annual tax further shows the extraordinary demand that there is for even free Indian labour.
('3', 295, 4, 13, 659284) The demand for special servants, such as cooks, waiters, dhobies, etc,.
('3', 295, 4, 14, 659356) continues to be as great as ever.
('3', 295, 4, 15, 659390) Many free Indians have gone to the Transvaal at high wages, and an ordinary cook will not now proceed to the inland colonies under £ 6 per month, and a man with special qualifications can command even £ 16 per month.
('3', 295, 4, 16, 659607) These high rates of wages have made it next to impossible for ordinary people in private life to employ free Indian servants of this class, and it is only by employing indentured Indians that they can afford to hire such servants at all.
('3', 295, 4, 17, 659845) The last sentence proves also that it is only by a form of slavery that the people in need of servants can obtain them at less than half
('3', 296, 0, 1, 659982) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 297
('3', 296, 1, 2, 660023) the market price, and yet these very people who give their services at such ridiculously low rates for a term of five years or longer have to pay the penalty of £ 3 per year for the sake of their freedom.
('3', 296, 1, 3, 660228) The Indian Marriage Law of the Colony continues to remain in a most unsatisfactory state.
('3', 296, 2, 4, 660318) 1,053 marriages of Indian immigrants were registered as against 403 in the pervious year.
('3', 296, 2, 5, 660408) Of these, 527 were registered before the allotment of Indians after arrival, the remainder being marriages contracted in Natal.
('3', 296, 2, 6, 660536) The question has been again raised as to the validity of religious marriages when one of the contracting parties refuses to register the marriage under Section 71, Law 25 of 1891. Many abuses are no doubt practised by unscrupulous persons who give their children in marriage at a tender age, and then when the child becomes of age, place impediments in the way, and even, for a consideration, induce her to take up with some other man; and as the religious ceremony is not necessary under the section, it has no value so far as registration is concerned.
('3', 296, 2, 7, 661091) The difficulty will continue until the Law is brought into harm ony with the laws of the Colony, and recognition given to marriages solemnised according to the religion of the parties.
('3', 296, 2, 8, 661276) Indians have an inveterate prejudice against registering their marriages.
('3', 296, 2, 9, 661350) With them, marriage is not merely a question of civil contract, but it is a religious ceremony endowed with peculiar sanctity.
('3', 296, 2, 10, 661477) With many sects, the tie once bound is inviolable, and divorce is not recognised at all.
('3', 296, 2, 11, 661566) Registr ation, to such people, is practically a farce, and, as the Protector has shown:
('3', 296, 3, 12, 661654) With the better class of Indians, naturally, scarcely any troubles arise, troubles which are almost wholly confined to the class of people who look upon their daughters as so much value in coin.
('3', 296, 3, 13, 661849) Several women who have presented themselves for registration were unable to declare, on oath, that their husbands were dead, consequently, they could not be registered as married.
('3', 296, 3, 14, 662029) There are two ways of mitigating the evil; the one is to take an accurate record of married and unmarried men and women before they leave India, and the second is to recognise all marriages contrac ted in accordance with the religions of the parties, so long as they are not repugnant to the genreral law of the Colony as to polygamy and marriageable age.
('3', 296, 3, 15, 662385) Indian marriage officers of undoubted integrity might be appointed to compile a record of all marriages, and recogn ised Indians priests might be given the authority to frame such rec 
('3', 297, 0, 1, 662570) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 297, 1, 2, 662612) And although under some such regulations, the difficulty will not altogether disappear, we doubt not that it will very greatly be min imised.
('3', 297, 1, 3, 662754) 1,412 Indians who returned to India are said to have taken with them, in cash £ 16,522, and in jewellery £ 4,809, giving a little over £ 15 per head, representing the savings during five years’ stay in Natalthat is to say, a saving of £ 3 per year.
('3', 297, 1, 4, 663004) If these figures are at all an indication of the savings of the general body of immigrants, they show that the proposal to terminate the indentures in India would leave such people without tangible resources; for £ 15 after five year hard toil will not carry the people, even in a poverty stricken place like India, very far, and would hardly serve as sufficient capital on which to engage in any occupation, trade, or pursuit there.
('3', 297, 1, 5, 663438) It is worthy of note that the Madras Indians have once more proved their thrifty habits by taking £ 12,600 with them as against £ 8,700 by their Calcutta brethren.
('3', 297, 1, 6, 663602) The total population of Indian im migrants on the 31st of December was 87,000, of whom 15,000 were born in the Colony.
('3', 297, 1, 7, 663721) We notice, also, that the Indians continue to be employed for the gold mines, though the experiment does not seem to have become entirely a success, the chief reason being that they have been employed during the cold weather, which naturally puts them at a disadvantage.

('3', 297, 1, 9, 664064) higher, being 15s.
('3', 297, 1, 10, 664083) per month instead of 10s.

('3', 297, 2, 12, 664202) from 233 Indians, and the amount remitted through the Post Office was £ 105,889. The amount standing to the credit of Indian immigrants in the Natal Savings Bank on the 31st of December was £ 46,309, and the number of depositors 1,787 as against £ 34,108 by, 1,310 deposi tiors in the previous year.

('3', 298, 1, 2, 664769) 197. INDIANS IN LADYSMITH
('3', 298, 2, 3, 664795) Our contemporary, The Natal Witness, gives a fair report of an interesting meeting of the Chamber of Commerce at Ladysmith.
('3', 298, 2, 4, 664919) Mr. D. Sparks, the Mayor, expressed the following sentiments regar ding Indian licences:
('3', 298, 3, 5, 665008) He pointed out that the Arabs paid their best men £4 per month, whereas the white store keeper had to pay £ 20 or more.
('3', 298, 3, 6, 665128) The Indians had licences to trade, but they ignored the usage of the European store keepers, and kept their premises open at all hours.
('3', 298, 3, 7, 665264) He wished those present to say whether they wished their employees to work from five in the morning until nine at night.
('3', 298, 3, 8, 665385) The question was coming home to them, and the sooner they moved in the matter, the better it would be for Ladysmith, for the district, and for their children after them.
('3', 298, 3, 9, 665555) If they went on in the slipshod way they were doing, that historic town of Ladysmith would become an Asiatic town.
('3', 298, 3, 10, 665670) It would be difficult to compress in half a dozen sentences and equal number of mis statements as the worthy Mayor of Ladysmith has evidently managed to do in the remarks noted above.
('3', 298, 3, 11, 665854) We chal lenge Mr. Sparks to prove his first statement, namely, that the Indian merchants pay their best men £ 4 per month.
('3', 298, 3, 12, 665977) We claim to have some little knowledge of the wages paid to clerks and storemen in Indian businesses, and we have much pleasure in presenting Mr. Sparks with the information that the best men are paid even as much a £ 25 per month, or an equivalent, that is to say, they draw a salary of about £ 12 to £ 15 besides being provided with food and lodgings.
('3', 298, 3, 13, 666331) We may add also that the best men receive, at the end of their term of employment, handsome rewards.
('3', 298, 3, 14, 666432) We could mention half a dozen instances, and if Mr. Sparks would be good enough to bring out the names of the best men employed by Indian merchants receiving £ 4 a month, we would be pleased to give the names of those who have been in receipt of the wages mentioned by us.
('3', 298, 3, 15, 666705) It is perfectly true that some Indian clerks and employees receive £4 a month, and when they do so, as a rule, they deserve probably no more.
('3', 298, 3, 16, 666847) Men totally new to the work, who have to be trained, and who are very much at a disadvantage so far as knowledge of the English language is concerned, can not expect very handsome wages.
('3', 298, 3, 17, 667034) And even when £ 4 per month are paid, it should not be forgotten that, as a rule, board and lodging are added.
('3', 298, 3, 18, 667145) It is not our contention that the Indians do not accept a lower salary: as a
('3', 299, 0, 1, 667222) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 299, 1, 2, 667264) matter of fact, they very often do, but we do protest against extrava gant statements which are calculated to unnecessarily add to the preju dice that is already existent.
('3', 299, 1, 3, 667436) Their simple mode of life and frugal habits enable the Indians to be satisfied with a lower salary, and we do not know that in a place where competition is keen and open to all, there should be any grumbling as to the salaries.
('3', 299, 1, 4, 667664) While we are pre pared to admit that Indian shops are kept open longer than many, though by no means all, European shops, it is far from true to say that they are opened at five in the morning and closed at nine o’clock at night.
('3', 299, 1, 5, 667894) As to the historic town of Ladysmith becoming an Asiatic town, may we remind His Worship that, if Sir George White’s testimony is correct, it was saved from passing into the Boers’ hands, even tem porarily, to some extent be it ever so small, owing to the work of a single Indian, namely, Parbhu Singh?
('3', 299, 1, 6, 668197) 1 It was he who, at the peril of his life, sat perched upon a tree and gave the warning by ringing a gong, each time that the Boer gun from the Umbulwana Hill was fired.
('3', 299, 1, 7, 668367) The work done by Parbhu Singh was considered sufficiently important to merit special mention by Sir George, and a special recognition on the part of Lady Curzon who sent a choga 2 to be presented publicly in Durban.
('3', 299, 1, 8, 668583) The taunt, therefore, from Mr. Sparks comes with ill grace.
('3', 299, 1, 9, 668643) While, therefore, we consider that the remarks made by the Mayor, and the other gentlemen of the Chamber of Commerce at Ladysmith, were hardly justified, we wish to sound a note of warning to the British Indian merchants and store keepers in Ladysmith.
('3', 299, 1, 10, 668896) We cannot but sympathise with the objection raised by Mr. Sparks, in the first instance, and urged so well and so moderately by Mr. G.W. Lines, the Lincensing Officer, as to the unfairness of the Indian stores being kept open for longer hours than the general European stores.
('3', 299, 1, 11, 669173) Mr. Omar, one of the merchants, pertinently remarked that the Indian trade was not the same as the European, and that the former’s customers requ ired the keeping open of the shops for a longer time, but we have no doubt that a middle way must be possible, and the demand of the European store keepers ought to be treated in a reasonable manner.
('3', 299, 1, 12, 669519) In these, and matters affecting the well being of the community as a whole, we ought to be able without any pressure to respond to all sen sible suggestions and advice.
('3', 299, 1, 13, 669688) It is quite possible that the law may step
('3', 299, 2, 14, 669731) 1 Gandhiji describes the incident in his Satyagraha in South Africa, Chapter IX pp.
('3', 299, 2, 15, 669815) 78 9. 2 A robe
('3', 300, 0, 1, 669830) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 301
('3', 300, 1, 2, 669871) in and regulate hours of business, but it would be far more graceful and far more profitable if the Indian merchants took the initiative and brought about the necessary reform.
('3', 300, 1, 3, 670048) We would then be able to show that, whenever a just cause for complaint is brought to our notice, we are ever ready to rectify the error and co operate with the Europeans.
('3', 300, 1, 4, 670220) We, therefore, trust that the promise that the Indians who met Mr. Lines have made, as to considering his moderate proposal would bear good fruit.

('3', 300, 2, 6, 670394) WHAT CONSTITUTES RESPECT TO THE COURT
('3', 300, 3, 7, 670432) Sir Henry Bale, the learned Chief Justice of Natal, is reviving the question of what is proper respect on the part of British Indians, when they enter the Law Courts.
('3', 300, 3, 8, 670599) One “Manorath”, a British Indiain, who was a witness in a case pending before His Lordship, appeared without his head dress.
('3', 300, 3, 9, 670724) His lordship required of the Interpreter (Mr. Mat thews) as to what the custom was in India regarding witnesses and, on the Interpreter saying that it was an insult to the Judge if the witness wore boots, His Lordship intimated that he should write to the Chief Justice of Calcutta to ascertain the exact practice.
('3', 300, 3, 10, 671039) His Lordship added that he noticed Indians in court wearing both head dress and boots, humorously adding also that, if they removed their boots, they were likely to disappear.
('3', 300, 3, 11, 671215) We respectfully venture to think that Sir Henry has made “much ado about nothing”.
('3', 300, 3, 12, 671298) The practice, so far as Natal is concerned, has been settled more than once.
('3', 300, 3, 13, 671375) Sir Walter Wragg 1 met an Indian deputation years ago, and decided that salaam should be accepted as an equivalent to the removal of the head dress.
('3', 300, 3, 14, 671524) When the delegates on behalf of the Natal Government went to India in 1894, they also brought out full particulars as to the Indian custom, and dwelt upon it in their report submitted to the Government.
('3', 300, 3, 15, 671727) They made it clear that the custom in India is not to remove the head dress or the boots when the parties are dressed either wholly or partly in the Indian costume; that is to say, if the head dress is Oriental, then it is not to be taken off, but the shoes or boots have to be taken off in accordance with the Oriental practice if they are of Indian make.
('3', 300, 3, 16, 672084) Sir Walter, who knew this, ordered that the boots or shoes need not be taken off because of the impracticability in Natal, and because, as rule, it was only the European boots or shoes that were used by the Indians in
('3', 300, 4, 17, 672302) 1 Puisne Judge, later Acting Chief Justice, Natal.
('3', 301, 0, 1, 672353) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 301, 1, 2, 672395) South Africa.
('3', 301, 1, 3, 672409) We may also remind His Lordship that, when he was in practice and ornamented the Natal Bar, he was Senior Counsel in the case of Cassim Abdulla & Bennett, wherein Mr. Cassim Abdulla sued Mr. Bennett, the Magistrate, for damages on account of the Magistrate having ordered forcible removal of the head dress of a witness in a case before him.
('3', 301, 1, 4, 672751) He was then able to secure a dictum from the judges that the British Indians were not to be forced either to remove their head dress or their boots, but that they were to salaam on entering the court.
('3', 301, 1, 5, 672952) This practice has been followed ever since, and it would be a pity to re open the question.
('3', 301, 1, 6, 673044) Indian Opinion, 29 10 1903
('3', 301, 2, 7, 673071) 199. THE BAZAARS IN THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 301, 3, 8, 673105) The notices to the British Indian store keepers and merchants in the Transvaal about removal to the Location (miscalled Bazaars) expire on the 31st December next.
('3', 301, 3, 9, 673268) There seems to be somewhere in the Asiatic Department of the Government an evil genius working through it.
('3', 301, 3, 10, 673375) We have seen notices issued by the Magistrates in different townships offering Stands to applicants, and the offers are hedged in by so many restrictions, that we cannot help saying that there appears to be a deliberate attempt to deprive the Indian of even what little he had under the existing law.
('3', 301, 3, 11, 673676) Why there should be on the part of, or, at any rate, in the name of, the Government of the Colony, such petty jealousy of the Indian ever arising in business, we cannot understand.
('3', 301, 3, 12, 673857) The following is what one of the notices states:
('3', 301, 4, 13, 673906) If you require particular Stands, you should state in your application your reason for requiring them, and any claims you may have to the lease of these Stands.
('3', 301, 4, 14, 674067) You must bear in mind that I cannot give Stands to any person who is not actually residing or trading within the town and does not require Stands for the purpose of his residence or trade, nor more than he actually requires for his residence or trade.
('3', 301, 4, 15, 674319) We cannot recall any such dog in the manger policy even by the late Republican Government.
('3', 301, 4, 16, 674410) We are hoping that, no matter how tempting the offers may be for Stands in the so called Bazaars, the Indians in the Transvaal will refuse to have anything to do with them until the Legislation promised by Lord Milner has been settled.
('3', 301, 4, 17, 674646) But, in any case, why should an applicant give his reason for requiring Sta nds?
('3', 301, 4, 18, 674727) Under the law, it is open to Indians to hold land without restri ction in places set apart for the purpose.
('3', 301, 4, 19, 674835) Why should not, then, any
('3', 302, 0, 1, 674861) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 303
('3', 302, 1, 2, 674902) applicant receive a Stand if he wants one in those Bazaars?
('3', 302, 1, 3, 674962) Why, again, should an applicant be restricted to a Stand or Stands only in so far as the same may be required for his residence or trade?
('3', 302, 1, 4, 675100) Are we to understand that the lessors of such Stands will not be allowed to sub let their Stands and must always remain thereon themselves on pain of being deprived of their leases?
('3', 302, 1, 5, 675282) Why again, should the giving of leases of Stands be confined to those only who are now residing or trading within the towns?
('3', 302, 1, 6, 675407) Every Indian Location established during the old regime had owners or lessors who were not residing on their Stands, but who were allowed to deal with them freely, to sub let them, as also to hold any number of Stands.
('3', 302, 1, 7, 675626) Why should they, under the British Government, be deprived of such freedom of action?
('3', 302, 1, 8, 675712) The assurance given by Lord Milner that the Government has no prejudice against the British Indians, and that it wants to deal with them justly, fairly, and even liberally is utterly at variance with the practice as we see it illustrated in the notices that have been sprung upon the community regarding the precious Bazaars.
('3', 302, 1, 9, 676038) If the Government intends to drive the Indian out by harassing regulations, it would be mercy to send them out bag and baggage at once.
('3', 302, 1, 10, 676174) They will then know their position, and there would be no hypocritical justification for any action that the Government may take.
('3', 302, 1, 11, 676304) Like the late Government of the Orange River Colony, it could take a firm stand and absolutely declare: “Though you are British subjects, we will have none of you because you wear the brown skin”.
('3', 302, 1, 12, 676501) The course would be drastic, perhaps un British, but it would be an honest course.
('3', 302, 1, 13, 676584) And if the Government really means well by the Indians, and if the assurance above referred to is to be carried out, then the sooner there is a change in the policy hitherto pursued, the better it will be for all concerned.
('3', 302, 1, 14, 676808) Indian Opinion, 29 10 1903
('3', 302, 2, 15, 676835) 200. BRITISH INDIANS IN THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 302, 3, 16, 676873) We offer no apology for reverting to the question of the so called Indian Bazaars in the Transvaal.
('3', 302, 3, 17, 676973) The position of the British Indians there is very critical, and we consider it our duty to concen trate much of our attention on it, seeing that it is, at present, the wea kest part of the question.
('3', 302, 3, 18, 677172) We reproduce in another column a notice signed by the Magistrate at Standerton addressed to the Asiatic com munity, which shews clearly the spirit which seems to guide the policy of the Asiatic Department in dealing with the British Indians.
('3', 303, 0, 1, 677414) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 303, 1, 2, 677456) ording to the notice, applications were invited for lease of Stands in the Bazaar, the list closing on the 30th ultimo.
('3', 303, 1, 3, 677576) Applicants are to “state in their applications their reasons for requiring particular Stands and the claims they may have, if any, to the lease of these Stands”.
('3', 303, 1, 4, 677738) then “on the date mentioned, the Magistrate will consider the applications and apportion the Stands between the applicants subject to the provisions that
('3', 303, 2, 5, 677892) (a) no person is to be given any Stand who has not actually resided or traded in the town and does not require Stands for the purposes of his residence or trade;
('3', 303, 3, 6, 678054) (b) no person is to be given more Stands than he actually requires for his residence or trade;
('3', 303, 4, 7, 678149) (c) if there is more than one applicant for any particular Stand, the appointtment shall, in the absence of the possession by any claimant of a good claim to preferential treatment, be decided by law or in some other way as the Magistrate may decide.
('3', 303, 4, 8, 678400) Now, as we have pointed out more often than once in these columns, the Law 3 of 1885 gives unrestricted right to Indians to hold landed property in wards, streets, or Locations that may be set apart for them, but this right is to be hedged in by most vexing conditions with reference to Locations far away from towns where it would be utterly impossible to trade and very dangerous to live.
('3', 303, 4, 9, 678791) In order to un derstand the extreme harshness of the terms imposed, one has to bear in mind the fact that the Stands are mere vacant pieces of ground; the lessees have not only to pay survey fees and rental, but they have to erect their own buildings, and then they can get the Stands only for their residence or trade, and enough only for such purposes and no more.
('3', 303, 4, 10, 679158) How does the Government expect every Indians to take out a lease and build on the Stand and live there, presumably without being able to sub let?
('3', 303, 4, 11, 679304) The thing is very difficult to understand.
('3', 303, 4, 12, 679347) In order to be able to comply with the ridiculous conditions laid down in the notice, every Indian will have to be a man of considerable means, which, unfortunately, he is not.
('3', 303, 4, 13, 679524) And then, if he fails to erect handsome structures, or erects only tin shanties, the blame will be placed on his shoulders, and he will be held up to scorn and contempt because he lives in mere shanties, although the situation will have been not at all of his creation, but of the Government’s.
('3', 303, 4, 14, 679819) Notices, more or less simi larly worded, haver been sent to British Indians in many places in the Transvaal.
('3', 303, 4, 15, 679928) We very much question whether His Excellency the Gover 
('3', 304, 0, 1, 679984) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 305
('3', 304, 1, 2, 680025) nor has any part whatsoever in imposing the conditions therein related.
('3', 304, 1, 3, 680097) Indeed, the fact is quite plain, seeing that each notice is wor ded differently form the rest.
('3', 304, 1, 4, 680192) It would, therefore, appear that the Mag istrates have been acting on their own initiative, probably on very gen eral instructions from headquarters.
('3', 304, 1, 5, 680342) If so, it illustrates once more the position taken up by usnamely, that there is no connected, settled policy regarding the Indians, and that they are more or less at the mercy of the Magistrates or other officers who deal with them lenie ntly or severely in proportion to their prejudices for or against Indi ans.
('3', 304, 1, 6, 680658) Such a state of things cannot last long, and it is to be hoped that Sir Arthur Lawley, who has a large heart, will spare some time from his multifarious duties and take a personal interest in the matter.
('3', 304, 1, 7, 680862) The Indians, who have been obliged to remain in a state of uncertainty and suspense for the last two years, have a right to expect a clear definition of their status.
('3', 304, 1, 8, 681029) In the meanwhile, as we have said already in our last issue, we trust that the British Indians in the Transvaal would patiently await developments and decline to have anything to do with the Bazaars.

('3', 304, 2, 10, 681255) 201. EAST LONDON AND ITS INDIAN RESIDENTS
('3', 304, 3, 11, 681297) We reproduce in another column a temperate leading article from the East London Despatch on the question of the right of British Indians to hold landed property within that borough.
('3', 304, 3, 12, 681479) Our contempo rary has based it on the incident of an Indian having lately bought a piece of land in a principal street there for which he has paid a handsome price.

('3', 304, 3, 16, 682209) And we doubt not that there is an effective remedy against undue or unfair competition, and the defects that are usually and often unfairly ascribed to Indians.

('3', 305, 1, 2, 682438) 202. THE PLAGUE AND THE RED TAPE
('3', 305, 2, 3, 682471) Complaints have been received by us from several corres pondents to the effect that, although the plague restrictions of Indian departures from Natal to the Transvaal have been removed, authorised British Indians are required to take out medical certificates costing them 10s.
('3', 305, 2, 4, 682748) each, and are still subjected to medical inspection at Volksrust.
('3', 305, 2, 5, 682814) The medical officer gives them letters addressed to the Magistrate, saying that they are to be under medical surveillance for ten days.
('3', 305, 2, 6, 682950) This appears to us to be red tape with a vengeance.
('3', 305, 2, 7, 683002) If the harassment is to continue in spite of the removal of the regulations, we do not know the meaning of the cancellation of the Plague Notice of the Transvaal Government.
('3', 305, 2, 8, 683176) The taking out of the medical certificate and payment of half a guinea therefor are a totally unnecessary tax on the poor refugees, and the sooner the Government in the Transvaal issue the necessary instructions to their officials, the better it will be for the Indian refugees.
('3', 305, 2, 9, 683455) As it is, these poor people have been put to no end of trouble and inconvenience for the last nine months in the name of sanitary and health precautions, when thousands of other people form Natal have been freely allowed to enter the Transvaal without the slightest medical inspection or supervision.

('3', 306, 2, 11, 685890) TRAVELLING IN THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 306, 3, 12, 685918) Our contemporary, the Transvaal Leader, has given prominence to an anonymous writer regarding the Native railway travellers, and waxes very wrathful over the audacity of the railway administration in having accommodated Native travellers in a first class carriage on a local train.
('3', 306, 3, 13, 686200) The facts appear to be, according to the corespondent in question, that these four Native travellers were found by him in a first class railway compartment in a train from George Goch, all the other compartments being occupied by European passengers.
('3', 306, 3, 14, 686451) The corres pondent held a first class ticket, and wanted to travel by that train.
('3', 306, 3, 15, 686533) Not finding room in any of the other compartments, he seems to have passed by the one occupied by the Native passengers.
('3', 306, 3, 16, 686654) This was altoge ther too much for him; he could not understand why they should be allowed to travel first class at all.
('3', 306, 3, 17, 686774) That they had paid their fares was no question for him to consider.
('3', 306, 3, 18, 686842) He approached the guard, and the guard seems to have said that, seeing that the Native passengers had paid first class fares, they were as much entitled as the correspondent himself to travel by that train in a first class carriage.
('3', 306, 3, 19, 687075) But the guard’s reply is the reason why he has rushed to the Press.
('3', 306, 3, 20, 687143) In his letter, he has mixed up the Natives with the Indians, and so has our contemporary 
('3', 307, 0, 1, 687233) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 307, 1, 2, 687275) by no means an unusual thing in this sub continent.
('3', 307, 1, 3, 687327) It just shows the danger that faces our contrymen in South Africa generally, and particularly in the Transvaal.
('3', 307, 1, 4, 687439) There is often a tendency to use the terms “Natives, Coolies and Indians” as if they were all one and the same.
('3', 307, 1, 5, 687551) The Leader calls upon the railway authorities promptly to prohibit first class travelling by Natives and coolies, as it is pleased to call British Indiansforgetting that the railway regulations at present do not prohibit first class travelling by either the Indians or the Natives; [that] only with reference to the latter it is provided that they have to make their applicaions at least half an hour before the advertised time of departure of trains, and that their application would be specially considered if they are in companies of four or more.
('3', 307, 1, 6, 688104) We may remind our contemporary that, even during the old regime, first class travelling by Indians was not prohibited, and we may further remind it of the fact (though in newspaper history, we are told, precedents count for nothing) that the Transvaal Leader before the war was the champion of the rights of Colourd people who had not a more sympathetic friend than Mr. Pakeman, who adorned the editorial chair.

('3', 307, 2, 8, 688541) 205. INDIAN STORE KEEPERS IN LADYSMITH
('3', 307, 3, 9, 688580) We have much pleasure in making room for notes from the Natal Witness and The Times of Natal regarding the action of Mr. Lines towards the Indian store keepers in Ladysmith, and his threat that their licences will not be renewed unless they consent to close their stores at the same time as the Europeans.
('3', 307, 3, 10, 688886) After denouncing, in its usual fashion, the British Indians, The Times of Natal proceeds:
('3', 307, 4, 11, 688976) But for all that, it is a question how far Mr. Lines, the Town Clerk of Ladysmith, was justified in his action in calling the Arab traders together and practically ordering them to close their places of business at the same hours as their European fellows, and to observe the same holidays, under threat of having their licences withdrawn.
('3', 307, 4, 12, 689316) This strikes one as being a very arbitrary exercise of the powers of a licensing officer.
('3', 307, 4, 13, 689406) Once a man has obtained a licence and observes the laws of the country generally, and by laws of his municipality particularly, it should be beyond the powers of any local official to so utterly ruin him, as proposed by Mr. Lines, for, if this latest instance of officialdom be carried to a just conclusion, then the autocrat of Ldysmith and others similarly placed throughout the Colony, can order any European to
('3', 308, 0, 1, 689821) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 309
('3', 308, 1, 2, 689862) close his store at any hour he may please.
('3', 308, 1, 3, 689905) It is a ticklish subject if you like, but the old nostrum that ‘an Englishman’s house is his castle’ will have to be knocked on the head before it can be solved by Ladysmith.
('3', 308, 1, 4, 690080) These remarks are undoubtedly just, and from a purely legal and British point of view, the proposals made by Mr. Lines are arbitrary and high handed.
('3', 308, 1, 5, 690230) All the same, we adhere to the opinion we have already expressed, namely, that it would be very graceful on the part of the British Indians in Ladysmith, notwithstanding the arbitrary procedure adopted by Mr. Lines, to fall in with Mr. Lines suggestion, provided, of course, that it is at all workable.
('3', 308, 1, 6, 690533) If they could do so, they would have in their hands an exceedingly good weapon of defence, and it would disarm much of the opposition in Ladysmith.
('3', 308, 1, 7, 690681) So long as the Dealers’ Licenses Act remains on the Statute book of the Colony in its present form, so long will it be necessary for the Indian com munity to be on its guard, and to be yielding whenever yielding is fea sible, even at the risk of some pecuniary loss, because, as has been re peatedly pointed out, they are (we mean the traders) totally at the mer cy of the licensing officers and Town Councils or Local Boards; and while it may be possible in isolated instances to secure relief from the Home authorities, it should be recognised that it is a very slow machi nery to move.
('3', 308, 1, 8, 691270) The safest thing, therefore, is to recognise the position as it is, to make all the efforts in order to have the law removed, and in the meanwhile to act in such a manner as to show by our action how utterly underserved are the disabilities that are imposed on us.
