('3', 310, 3, 5, 693108) NOTES ON THE INDIAN QUESTION IN THE TRANSVAAL, ENDING NOVEMBER 9, 1903 The question of paramount importance is, at present, the working of Notice 356 of this year, known as the Bazaar Notice.
('3', 310, 3, 6, 693300) In view of the approaching end of the year, a British Indian deputation waited on His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor 2 with a view to induce him to respect the licences of all British Indians who are at present trading in the Colony under licences duly issued to them.
('3', 310, 3, 7, 693573) It will be remembered that, according to the Notice, strictly speaking, only those who held licences at the commencement of hosti lites are entitled to trade outside Locations after the end of this year.
('3', 310, 3, 8, 693777) Two classes of licences remain, therefore, to be considered.
('3', 310, 3, 9, 693838) First, those who traded before the war, but not with licences.
('3', 310, 3, 10, 693901) Second, those who had licences granted to them, after British occupation, by British officers on the strength of their being refugees.
('3', 310, 3, 11, 694036) From the correspondence with His Excellencey on the Bazaar Notice, it was hoped that there would be no difficulty regarding lice nces belonging to the first class, because a very large majority of Bri tish Indians traded in the Transvaal before the war without any licen ces whatsoever (because none were granted) on the strength of tenders of licence money or in the names of their white friends, with the knowledge of the then Government.
('3', 310, 3, 12, 694477) But, His Excellency, unfortunately for the British Indians, took a different view and said that he never meant to convey to the Asso ciation that any but those who actually held licences to trade outside Locations before the war should be allowed to continue to do so after the 30th December next.
('3', 310, 3, 13, 694775) However, His Excellency, on learning that, as a matter of fact, there were hundreds of British Indians who traded before the war
('3', 310, 4, 14, 694904) 1 Gandhiji as usual forwarded this statement to Dadabhai Naoroji who sent a copy to the Secretary of State for India.
('3', 310, 4, 15, 695022) India published it as a despatch in its issue of 4 12 1903. 2 On October 30.
('3', 311, 0, 1, 695099) 312 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 311, 1, 2, 695141) without licences, owing to the protection granted to them by the British Government, said that he would consider the question at a mee ting of the Executive Council.
('3', 311, 1, 3, 695307) There is, therefore, reason for hoping that the licences belon ging to the first class will get relief.
('3', 311, 1, 4, 695411) We are, however, used, nowadays, to so many disappointments that it may not be amiss to state the position clearly and to contem plate the consequences of sending such men to Bazaars or Locations.
('3', 311, 1, 5, 695608) Although it is difficult to give authentic figures, it may be safely assumed that more than 50 per cent of the licence holders would fall under the first class.
('3', 311, 1, 6, 695769) They have been, many of them, in business for the last ten or more years; they hold long leases of premises equipped by them, and are large importers, doing white as well as Kaffir trade.
('3', 311, 1, 7, 695957) Are they to remove to Locations at the end of the year?
('3', 311, 1, 8, 696013) Although it was for these very men that Mr. Chamberlain fought strenuously and successfully during the Republican regime!
('3', 311, 1, 9, 696135) They were allowed to trade outside Locations without licences, because the British Governemnt proved too strong for Mr. Kruger; 1
('3', 311, 2, 10, 696265) and why should the favoured few Indians who were able to obtain licences from the Boer Government receive exceptional treatment?
('3', 311, 2, 11, 696394) In deed, their case is in no way stronger than that of the unfortunate men of the first class who are now under notice to remove to Locations.
('3', 311, 2, 12, 696537) The reason why some of them were able to get licences before the war is as follows: After voluminous correspondence with the British Government, and after the Boer Government had realised that it could not relegate British Indians to Locations, it was decided in 1899 to grant licences to British Indians who had been trading before that year outside Locations.
('3', 311, 2, 13, 696899) Those who were able, therefore, got out their licences, but others who had left the Transvaal for a time in 1898 were unable to do so; nor were all granted their licences at once.
('3', 311, 2, 14, 697079) The Boer Government machinery was very slow; the Licensing Officers hardly ever acted promptly, or in accordance with instruc tions.
('3', 311, 2, 15, 697212) The result was [that,] in outlying districts, in spite of applica tions, many Indians were unable to get their licences, but at the same
('3', 311, 3, 16, 697349) 1 S. J. Paul Kruger (1825 1904), President of the Transvaal, 1883 1900. Vide “Late President Kruger”, 23 7 1904.
('3', 312, 0, 1, 697462) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 313
('3', 312, 1, 2, 697503) time they were not disturbed in their businesses.
('3', 312, 1, 3, 697553) Are they now, then to be deprived of the right of trading in towns outside Locations for no fault of their own?
('3', 312, 1, 4, 697665) There still remain to be considered the licences belonging to the second class.
('3', 312, 1, 5, 697745) Now, these men received their licences upon British occupation without any conditions whatsoever.
('3', 312, 1, 6, 697843) The question of enforcing the law 3 of 1885, as stated in Lord Milner’s despatch, was only evolved this year.
('3', 312, 1, 7, 697953) Last year nobody ever thought of enforcing the anti Asiatic, un British laws of the late Government.
('3', 312, 1, 8, 698054) Those men were refugees.
('3', 312, 1, 9, 698079) Many of them engaged before the war in trade in some district or another, and the British officers who were not trained in the local prejudices could not naturally understand why they should refuse to grant trading licences to British subjects when they were being granted to foreigners.
('3', 312, 1, 10, 698367) It was reserved for the Asiatic Office to unearth the anti Asiatic laws, and make suggestions for enforcing them.
('3', 312, 1, 11, 698481) Its hands were strengthened by the interested agitation set up against British Indians, and the result was that we have the Bazaar Notice.
('3', 312, 1, 12, 698620) When the British Indian deputation waited on Mr. Chamberlain in January last, 1 he could not understand how licences once granted could ever be taken away.
('3', 312, 1, 13, 698776) Moreover, men of the second class are very few; they, too, have large stocks on hand, in some cases having leases, and it would mean entire ruin to them to be compelled to remove to Bazaars.
('3', 312, 1, 14, 698967) The British Indian Association has been trying to get authentic reports from professional men in the various districts in which the Government have seen fit to select sites for Bazaars, and, according to reports received, not in any case are the sites selected such as to attract any trade whether white or Kaffir, although both Lord Milner and Sir Arthur Lawley assure us that they will be selected within towns and in such places as to give the British Indians reasonable facilities for getting both white and Kaffir trade.
('3', 312, 1, 15, 699493) In every one of the cases, the Bazaars have been fixed in out of the way places and, though legally within the town boundary, cer tainly away from the inhabited protion thereof.
('3', 312, 1, 16, 699671) In one case, an atte mpt was made to remove the existing Location to a site much further

('3', 313, 5, 12, 700906) 208. THE ORANGE RIVER COLONY AND COLOUR LEGISLATION
('3', 313, 6, 13, 700958) A recent number of the Government Gazette shows quite plai nly that the Government of the Orange River Colony is not to be dete rred by any considerations whatsoever from following up the legisla tion restrictive of the liberties of Coloured people.
('3', 313, 6, 14, 701208) In the Gazette dated 23rd October is published a draft Ordinance to amend the Law relating to Municipalities, and we read the following provision regar ding the qualification of voters for the municipal elections: Any one
('3', 313, 7, 15, 701430) who is a Coloured person in terms of Article 8 of Law 8 of 1893, and who is not the offspring of a lawful marriage of a white father with a Colourd mother, or a coloured father with a white mother, or who, being such an offspring, has not obtained the right to the ownership or occupation of immovable property in this colony under provision of Chapter 34 of the Law, is disqualifed from being a voter.
('3', 313, 7, 16, 701833) Now by Article 8 of Law 8 of 1893,
('3', 313, 8, 17, 701868) the expression ‘Coloured person’ appearing in this Law shall be interpreted and taken, unless the context clearly forbids it, to apply to and include a man,
('3', 314, 0, 1, 702025) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 315
('3', 314, 1, 2, 702066) or men, as well as woman, or women, above the age or estimated age of sixteen years, of any Native tribe in South Africa, and also all Coloured persons, and all who, in accordance with law or custom, are called Coloured persons, or are treated as such, of whatever race or nationality they may be.
('3', 314, 1, 3, 702364) The definition, therefore, is as wide as could be imagined, and includes British Indians also.
('3', 314, 1, 4, 702459) Taken by itself, the provision is hardly of much consequence, for we are aware that the Transvaal Govern ment has only lately disfranchised all Coloured people from participa tion at municipal election, and such a disqualification is by no means the most important disability of the British Indians, but taken as an in dication of the deliberately hostile policy of the Government against the British Indians, it is a matter of no small importance.
('3', 314, 1, 5, 702908) There is, for the Government of that Colony, absolutely no turning back from the inheritance of the past.
('3', 314, 1, 6, 703014) When there is any change at all in the past legislation, it is for the worse.
('3', 314, 1, 7, 703092) Mr. Chamberlain, in his despatch to Lord Milner in reply to his demand for Asiatic indentured labour, dwelt upon the anti Indian legislation in both Colonies, and expressedthe hope that they would grant relief in the direction pointed out by him.
('3', 314, 1, 8, 703339) The clause we have referred to above and the clause we are about to refer to are the answers returned to the despatch by the Government of the Orange River Colony.
('3', 314, 1, 9, 703503) It is inconceivable how the Government of that Colony, which is, after all, subordinate to, and under the direct control of, the Colonial Office, can defy the head of that office and continue not only to refuse to undo the past but to tighten the cord that binds the British Indians.
('3', 314, 1, 10, 703787) Later, in the same draft Ordinance, we notice certain clauses referring to Locations.
('3', 314, 1, 11, 703873) The marginal note merely mentions “Native Locations”, but the clause itself clearly applies to “all Coloured persons”.
('3', 314, 1, 12, 703992) It reads:
('3', 314, 2, 13, 704002) The council is empowered to establish Locations in such part or parts of the Municipal land as they may think fit, within which all coloured persons, other than domestic servants residing on their employees’ premises, shall be compelled to reside, and they may from time to time close such Locations and establish other or others.
('3', 314, 2, 14, 704333) The council is further empowered to frame regulations for the proper control of all such persons.
('3', 314, 2, 15, 704431) No Coloured persons, male or female, above the estimated age of sixteen years, or under the estimated age of sixty years, shall reside for more than forty eight hours within any such Locations, unless
('3', 314, 3, 16, 704632) (a) he is actually in the employment of a white employer residing within the Municipality, or within a radius of five miles from the limit of the Municipal
('3', 315, 0, 1, 704788) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 315, 1, 2, 704830) area and is in possession of a permit from the Town Council to that effect, Or unless
('3', 315, 2, 3, 704916) (b) he has obtained a certificate of permission to work on his own account in terms of Article 3 of Law 8 of 1893, and is actually engaged in such work, Or unless
('3', 315, 3, 4, 705079) (c) he is a person who has obtained a letter of exemption under the provisions of the Coloured Persons Relief Ordinance, 1903, Or unless
('3', 315, 4, 5, 705216) (d) she is the lawful wife of a person residing within such Location under the aforesaid provisons.
('3', 315, 4, 6, 705316) Boiled down, these sub clauses mean that, even to be able to live within the confines of a Location, which like a stable, or a pound may be removed at the sweet will of the Concil, a Coloured persons must have obtained previous permission and must be a menial servant, that is to say, he cannot reside in any part of the colony except as a labo urer pure and simple.
('3', 315, 4, 7, 705683) Lest our readers might imagine that there are very great privileges reserved, by the laws referred to, to the wearers of a coloured skin, we may mention that Article 3 of Law 8 of 1893 contemplates special permission to be given by the Local Board on payment of a fee of 5s.
('3', 315, 4, 8, 705958) per month to a Coloured man to sell his services to anybody he likes, provided that he obtains the necessary certificate for so doing.
('3', 315, 4, 9, 706093) The Coloured Persons Relief Ordinance defi nes the qualifications, which are high enough, entitling a Coloured person to obtain exemption from liability to carry a personal pass ren ewable from time to time and bearing a certain fee.
('3', 315, 4, 10, 706327) The precious exe mption is granted after very irksome formalities having been gone through, and really consists in the carrying of the exemption certifi cate in exchange for the ordinary pass.
('3', 315, 4, 11, 706520) Beyond this, the Ordinance gives no relief, and leaves such exempted persons under all the other disabilities, namely, those as to trading, farming, holding immovable property, residence outside Locations, etc.
('3', 315, 4, 12, 706731) Such, then, is the attitude of the Government of the Orange River Colony towards Coloured persons, and unless the Colonial Office chooses to exercise its prerogative for the protection of non white subjects of the Empire, it will go hard with the hundreds of British Indians who are waiting to emigrate to the Orange River Colony and settle there for purpose of earning a livelihood.
('3', 315, 4, 13, 707115) We trust that the friends of British Indians in England will see these remarks of ours, study them, and come to the rescue and insist on the Colonial Office doing its duty towards the loyal Indian subjects of the King Emperor.
('3', 315, 4, 14, 707342) During his fiscal
('3', 316, 0, 1, 707360) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 317
('3', 316, 1, 2, 707401) campaign, Mr. Chamberlain has not been slow to lay stress upon the fact that India contains an inexhaustible reserve of fighting material upon which the Empire could draw without the slightest hesitation in case of need.
('3', 316, 1, 3, 707622) Yes, India is ever ready to do her part for the service of the Empire at large.
('3', 316, 1, 4, 707702) Will the Right Honourable Gentleman also use his influence in inducing the Colonies to do theirs?
('3', 316, 2, 5, 707800) 209. THE LATE SIR JOHN ROBINSON
('3', 316, 3, 6, 707832) Death has removed from our midst one of the Makers of Natal in the person of the late Sir John Robinson.
('3', 316, 3, 7, 707937) The first Prime Minister under responsible Government, Sir John has left behind him a record of useful service to the Colony which it will not be easy for anyone to equal, much less to surpass.

('3', 316, 3, 9, 708401) Had it not been for the great start that they gave, it is not difficult to see what would have been the position of Natal under responsible government.
('3', 316, 3, 10, 708553) From Editor to Prime Minsiter is a long leap, and that fact alone shows the sterling worth of the man who is now no longer among us.
('3', 316, 3, 11, 708686) By his ability zeal, and honesty of purpose, he succeeded in making The Natal Mercury the power that it is in Natal.
('3', 316, 3, 12, 708803) He brought all those qualities to bear on the government of the Colony only in a higher degree, and his merit was recognised by the Sovereign also in that he received the Order of K.C.M.G. By the British Indians, the honourable gentleman will be best remembered as the author of the Disfranchising Bill 1. ('3', 316, 3, 14, 709383) We can only wish that the words he uttered at the time of introducing the measure were also a part of the legislation, for he distinctly said that, in disfranchising British Indians, every member of the Legislative Assembly took upon himself a very serious responsibility and became a trustee for them.
('3', 316, 3, 15, 709686) Had that spirit guided our legislators in framing the legislation that has followed, there would have been very little to com

('3', 317, 3, 8, 710659) 210. THE PROPOSED SITE FOR THE ASIATIC BAZAAR IN KLERKSDORP
('3', 317, 4, 9, 710719) We understand that the British Indians in the several towns, for which the Transvaal Government has selected sites for Asiatic Bazaars, have had reports drawn up as to the suitability or otherwise of these places.

('3', 317, 4, 11, 711088) Confirmation of that report appears from very strange quarters, According to the Klerksdorp Mining Record of the 3rd instant, the District Surgeon for the place has also reported unfavourably about it, and it would be quite laughable, if it were not painful, how the Health Board for that district has professed helpless ness in the matter as the site has been selected by the Government.
('3', 317, 4, 12, 711477) They would, therefore, if they could, wash their hands clean of any complicity whatsoever in the selection.
('3', 317, 4, 13, 711585) Unfortunately for the Health Board, however, according to the Government Notice regarding Baza ars, the Government could not possibly have fixed upon the particular spot without consultation with the Health Board, and while there may be some excuse for the Government, having their seat in Pretoria, not knowing about the unfitness of the site from a medical standpoint, there can be none for the Health Board, as the members are local men and they must have recommended the site with their eyes wide open.

('3', 318, 3, 8, 713097) 211. THE WHITE LEAGUE AND BRITISH INDIANS
('3', 318, 4, 9, 713139) A meeting was held on the 5th instant, under the auspices of the White League at Fordsburg, in Johannesburg, where a number of que stions were discussed.
('3', 318, 4, 10, 713293) The proceedings, according to the newspaper reports, appear to have been: “extremely lively” and “at times noisy”.
('3', 318, 4, 11, 713408) Mr. A. Macfarlane presided, and there seems to have been an attendance of about eighty persons.
('3', 318, 4, 12, 713504) The chairman, in his opening speech, dwelt at some length on the question of Asiatic immigration.
('3', 318, 5, 13, 713602) The League, he said, was formed about a year ago, because of the feeling that Johannesburg was being flooded by large numbers of an undersi rable class of aliens who were filling up the small shops and trading areas, forestalling in many cases people of our own nationality who had been detained at the coast and had in many ways borne the full brunt of the war.
('3', 318, 5, 14, 713965) He referred to the ease with which Asiatics got permits to return after the war, the difficulty which the British people experienced in getting permits.
('3', 318, 5, 15, 714118) By the Transvaal Law, Chinamen and Indians were precluded from holding licences, but this law had been supended by the present Government for Chinamen and Indians who were engaged in business illegally previous to the war.
('3', 318, 5, 16, 714341) .The question might be asked whether, in view of the Indian Government having refused permission to allow labourers to be recruited there for the relief of the railway labour demands, we should not ask for repatriation of the whole of these people now here, who, as traders, simply acted as a Drag on the real advancement of this country.
('3', 318, 5, 17, 714680) This is what Mr. Macfarlane has to say on the British Indians.
('3', 319, 0, 1, 714743) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 319, 1, 2, 714785) The facts are, according to official records, that whereas nearly 28,000 permits have been issued to Europeans between January and October, less than a 10,000 permits have been issued from the declaration of peace up to now to the British Indians.
('3', 319, 1, 3, 715033) Moreover, from the figures already published by us, it would appear that the whole of the 28,000 Europeans were non refugees.
('3', 319, 1, 4, 715159) With the exception of perhaps a few dozen British Indians, all who have received permits have been refuge es.
('3', 319, 1, 5, 715269) As to the alleged unscrupulous methods of the Asiatics in obtain ing permits, we refer the worthy chairman to the prosecutions insti tuted lately by Captain Hamilton Fowle against several Europeans for being in the Transvaal without permits, or for having trafficked in the permit trade.
('3', 319, 1, 6, 715557) The Greek Assistant Vice Consul, who only lately was heavily fined for such traffic, we presume, was instrumental in obtain ing permits for Europeans only.
('3', 319, 1, 7, 715713) The suggestion that the Indians, who have been domiciled in the Transvaal for several years, who have vested interests in it and have entered the Colony as free men, should be repatriated, because the Indian Government declines to sell Indian labour to the Transvaal on terms bordering on slavery, is quite in keeping with the whole tenor of the speech.
('3', 319, 1, 8, 716067) And it is the opposition of these gentlemen that counts with the present Government that has inspired the Bazaar Notice, and that fairly promises, by the end of the year, to make beggars of hundreds of British Indian store keepers.

('3', 319, 2, 11, 716483) 212. INDIANS AND “THE EAST RAND EXPRESS”
('3', 319, 3, 12, 716524) Our contemporary is still busy over the Indian question.
('3', 319, 3, 13, 716581) In one of the latest issues, over half a column is devoted to the purchase by an Indian of a piece of land in the East Rand district.
('3', 319, 3, 14, 716715) The facts as set forth are fairly accurate; we are in full possession thereof.
('3', 319, 3, 15, 716794) We may, however, remind our contemporary of one very material fact, namely, that the land in question was bought in a perfectly bona fide manner.
('3', 319, 3, 16, 716940) When the Transvaal was occupied by the British, the people  inclu ding officers, the general public, and the Indians themselvescame to the conclusion that the old discriminating laws had lapsed.
('3', 319, 3, 17, 717137) The dispa tches of Lord Milner and the speeches of Her late Majesty’s ministers were still fresh in their memory, and bearing them in mind, they came
('3', 320, 0, 1, 717287) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 321
('3', 320, 1, 2, 717328) to the natural conclusion that the evil, to remove which the late war was fought, must certainly have disappeared.
('3', 320, 1, 3, 717443) In no other part of the British Dominions do such discriminating laws against British subjects exist.
('3', 320, 1, 4, 717545) The Indian, therefore, bought the property, and the white man sold it, under the full belief that the transfer would be registered.
('3', 320, 1, 5, 717677) Indeed, it was even submitted to the Registrar for registration.
('3', 320, 1, 6, 717742) The only thing, therefore, that could be done when it was found that the hopes of the Indians were not to be fulfilled, and that the lot could not be transferred to an Indian name, was to have it in the name of a white man.
('3', 320, 1, 7, 717966) The poor man applied to a white friend to help him by taking up the property in his own name, so that when it could be sold, he would sell it and save himself from loss.
('3', 320, 1, 8, 718136) The friend, be it said to his credit, consented to do so.
('3', 320, 1, 9, 718194) There the matter ends.
('3', 320, 1, 10, 718217) To us it is painful, but if our contemporary can derive any satisfaction from such a state of things, we wish it all joy of it.
('3', 320, 1, 11, 718345) We can only say that it is exrem ely un British, but we are not surprised at the attitude taken up over this paltry case, for, in the same article, we read later of that the programme of the East Rand people is to be: (1) No Asiatic trading save in Bazaars outside the towns as provided by the law; (2) the support of the existing law prohibiting Asiatic ownership of land and fixed property; (3) the placing of all Asiatics on the same basis as Kaffirs.
('3', 320, 1, 12, 718800) We have always admired the frankness of our contemporary, and in this instance we find the same trait; there is no hesitation to call a spade a spade.
('3', 320, 1, 13, 718951) The Government is to be asked to set apart Bazaars outside the towns.
('3', 320, 1, 14, 719021) Really speaking, this request is unnecessary, beca use the Government has already done so in almost every case in which sites have been selected.
('3', 320, 1, 15, 719167) We hardly think that the most rabid East Randite could have made better selections from his own standpoint.
('3', 320, 1, 16, 719275) They are so situated that trade is practically imposssible, and living dangerous.
('3', 320, 1, 17, 719357) The second request also is hardly necessary, because the Government has not shown the slightest willingness to depart from the existing law, and its activity has been all towards making the restric tions as severe as possible.
('3', 320, 1, 18, 719584) The third is undoubtedly the frankest of all, and would certainly solve the question once for all, if only the ques tion of the status of British subjects can be indefinitely shelved.
('3', 320, 1, 19, 719768) The placing of all Asiatics on the same basis as Kaffirs is a very simple solution, but the inconvenient fact is that no matter how willing and ready the Government of the Transvaal may be to trample under foot all the past declarations, we fancy that even they would hestitate to adopt the course suggested by our contemporary.
('3', 320, 1, 20, 720097) It would mean the
('3', 321, 0, 1, 720115) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 321, 1, 2, 720157) abrogation of Law 3 of 1885 in favour of legislation which they never allowed the old Government to pass.
('3', 321, 1, 3, 720263) The attempt was often made by Ex President Kruger to secure the consent of Her late Majesty’s Government to the amendment of the 14th article of the London Convention so as to include all Asiatics in the term “Natives of South Africa”.
('3', 321, 1, 4, 720499) Lord Derby, however, was quite firm and would not think of any such proposal.
('3', 321, 1, 5, 720577) The plan, therefore, suggested by our contempo rary, simple though it is, is not free from some difficulty so long as there is the slightest vestige of fair dealing with the Indians as yet left in the Transvaal.
('3', 321, 1, 6, 720789) Indian Opinion, 12 11 1903
('3', 321, 2, 7, 720816) 213. LETTER TO LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR’S SECRETARY
('3', 321, 3, 8, 720863) BRITISH INDIAN ASSOCIATION 25 & 26, COURT CHAMBERS, P.O. BOX 6522, JOHANNESBURG, November 14, 1903 TO THE PRIVATE SECRETARY TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR PRETORIA
('3', 321, 4, 9, 721038) SIR, The question of the removal for present holders of trading licences is to them so important and serious that I venture again to trespass upon His Excellency’s attention.
('3', 321, 4, 10, 721213) It was submitted to His Excellency by the deputation that Lord Milner’s despatch dated 11th May and addressed to Mr. Chamberlain strengthened the view held by the British Indians that existing licences would not be affected by the Notice 356 of this year.
('3', 321, 4, 11, 721469) In support, I beg to quote as follows from the despatch.
('3', 321, 5, 12, 721526) They (the Govenment) are anxious, however, to do so in the manner most considerate to the Indians already settled in the country, and with the greatest respect for vested interests, even where these have been allowed to spring up contrary to law.
('3', 321, 5, 13, 721773) Had we had to deal merely with the Asiatic population as it existed before war, it might have been possible to remain passive until a new law could have been framed to the satisfaction of His Majesty’s Government, But with so many new comers constantly pouring in and
('3', 322, 0, 1, 722041) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 323
('3', 322, 1, 2, 722082) applying for licences to trade, it became impossible to persist in the policy of complete inaction.
('3', 322, 1, 3, 722182) As I have already stated, the government is prepared to recognise the vested interests of Asiatics resident here before the war.
('3', 322, 1, 4, 722311) On the other hand, it feels that it would not be justified in allowing new vested interests to spring up contrary to the law.
('3', 322, 1, 5, 722437) During the war and since the declaration of peace, a large number of temporary trading licences were issued to new comers.
('3', 322, 1, 6, 722560) These licences have been renewed until December 31st, 1903, but the holders have been warned that, on that date, they will be required to remove to streets or Bazaars selected for this purpose.
('3', 322, 1, 7, 722754) From the above, it is clear that Lord Milner has been under the impression that trading licences have been granted to new comers and therefore they alone should be removed to streets or Bazaars.
('3', 322, 1, 8, 722949) But as the deputation has submitted, there are very few new comers, if any, that have been granted licences to trade outside Bazaars.
('3', 322, 1, 9, 723083) Again Lord Milner states:
('3', 322, 2, 10, 723109) We have no wish to subject respectable British Indians or civilised Asiatics generally to any disabilities.
('3', 322, 2, 11, 723217) It (the Government) is in there most impor tant respects showing a consideration for these Asiatics which the late Government did not show.
('3', 322, 2, 12, 723357) One of these respects is exemption of Asiatics of a superior class from all special legislation.
('3', 322, 2, 13, 723454) So far, it is meant to be granted in respect of residnets only.
('3', 322, 2, 14, 723518) I venture to submit that, pending new ligis lation, those who conform to the sanitary and other regulations should, according to the above, be left undisturbed in their trade.
('3', 322, 3, 15, 723694) I have the honour to remain, Sir, Your most obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI
('3', 322, 4, 16, 723769) Pretoria Archives: L.G. 2132, Asiatics 1902 1906.
('3', 323, 0, 1, 723819) 324 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 323, 1, 2, 723861) 214. NOTES
('3', 323, 3, 3, 723872) [JOHANNESBURG,
('3', 323, 4, 4, 723887) November 16,1903]
('3', 323, 5, 5, 723905) WEEKLY STATEMENT ENDING NOVEMBER 16,1903
('3', 323, 6, 6, 723946) The situation remains still the same.
('3', 323, 6, 7, 723984) The summary given last
('3', 323, 7, 8, 724007) week2 may be very greatly elaborated on the strength of Lord Milner’s dispatch dated 2nd May, 1903 and addressed to Mr. Chamberlain,
('3', 323, 8, 9, 724140) It was shewn last week how very little regard has been paid to the
('3', 323, 9, 10, 724207) Indians, although Lord Milner states that the Government are anxious to enforce the Law in a way most considerate to the Indians already settled in the Colony.
('3', 323, 10, 11, 724367) In view of the great interests which are at stake, it is necessary to
('3', 323, 11, 12, 724437) pick out other passages from Lord Milner’s dispatch to shew how truly at variance it is with the practice that is being followed at present.
('3', 323, 11, 13, 724578) Lord Milner says:
('3', 323, 12, 14, 724596) Had we had to deal with merely the Asiatic population as it existed before the war, it might have been possible to remain passive until a new law had been formed to the satisfaction of His Majesty’s Government; but with so many new comers constantly pouring in, etc.
('3', 323, 12, 15, 724863) it became impossible to persist in the policy of complete inaction.
('3', 323, 12, 16, 724931) His Lordship continues:
('3', 323, 13, 17, 724955) As I have already stated, the Government is prepared to recognise the vested interests of Asiatics resident here before the war.
('3', 323, 13, 18, 725084) On the other hand, it feels that it would not be justified in allowing new vested interests to spring up contrary to the law.
('3', 323, 13, 19, 725210) During the war and since the declaration of peace, a large number of temporary trading licences were issued to new comers.
('3', 323, 13, 20, 725333) These licences have been renewed until December 31st, 1903, but holders have been warned that on that date they will be required to remove to streets or Bazaars selected for this purpose.
('3', 323, 13, 21, 725521) Now, according to the above, there should be no difficulty inthe
('3', 323, 14, 22, 725586) way of those who were trading before the war either with or without licences, also, with those who were settled in the country before war, whether they traded in the country before war or not.
('3', 323, 14, 23, 725779) The Bazaar
('3', 323, 15, 24, 725790) 1 This statement was sent by Gandhiji to Dadabhai Naoroji, who forwarded a
('3', 323, 16, 25, 725865) copy to the Secretary of State for India.
('3', 323, 16, 26, 725907) It was published in India of 11 12 1903.
('3', 323, 17, 27, 725948) 2 Vide “Notes”, November 9, 1903.
('3', 324, 0, 1, 725982) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 325
('3', 324, 1, 2, 726023) Notice should, according to the dispatch, affect only those new comers who are said to have poured in.
('3', 324, 1, 3, 726126) As a matter of fact, as has been pointed out in previous statements, there are very few new comers, because only refugees have been allowed to enter the country.
('3', 324, 1, 4, 726288) It would not, therefore, do to rely upon the dispatch in question and sit still.
('3', 324, 1, 5, 726369) Time is quickly passing by, and it is very necessary that, in accordance with the dispatch, there should be a guarantee given to the poor British Indians that their licences would be respected.
('3', 324, 1, 6, 726563) Further on, Lord Milner states:
('3', 324, 2, 7, 726595) We have no wish to subject respectable British Indians, or civilised Asiatics generally, to any disabilities, and therefore, His Excellency proceeds:
('3', 324, 3, 8, 726745) It is, in three most important respects, shewing a consideration for the Asiatics which the late Government did not shew.
('3', 324, 3, 9, 726867) One of those respects is exemption of Asiatics of a superior class from all special legislation; this consideration has not yet been shewn, except with regard to residence, which is the least important thing; the most important part being to leave undisturbed the trade of the men who conform to the laws of the country.
('3', 324, 3, 10, 727188) Much stress is undoubtedly laid on the right of residence outside Locations, but comparatively speaking, the right of residence is a matter of sentiment, the right of trade one of bread and butter.
('3', 324, 3, 11, 727386) As to the selection of the Bazaar sites, there is only one opinion among the Indians, namely, that they could not have been worse chosen by their inveterate opponents; for trade they are perfectly use less; in most cases they are vacant pieces of ground away from the business centres.
('3', 324, 3, 12, 727672) Disinterested professional men have testified to their being valueless for trade.
('3', 324, 3, 13, 727754) With reference to the Rustenberg Bazaar, even a member of the Health Board has not hesitated to say that trade cannot be carried on there, and yet this is what Lord Milner has said to Mr. Chamberlain:
('3', 324, 4, 14, 727955) As you are aware, the sites selected by the Government of that late South African Republic for the purpose of Asiatic Bazaars were in many cases most unsuitable for such a purpose, being remote from the business centres of the town.
('3', 324, 4, 15, 728188) In many towns, no site at all was selected.
('3', 324, 4, 16, 728232) It is the intention of the Government to lose no time in selecting suitable sites for Asiatic Bazaars accessible to all classes of the community, and I am confident that, once the Bazaars are established and arranged in conformity with the customs and requirements of the occupants, the latter will be enabled to carry on their busi 
('3', 325, 0, 1, 728566) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 325, 1, 2, 728608) ness with as great, if not greater, advantage than under exisiting conditions.
('3', 325, 1, 3, 728687) The quotation shews not that Lord Milner’s intentions are not good, but that they are not being carried out by those in whom is vested the administration of the Law 3 of 1885. Indeed, they are enforcing it in a manner most hostile to the Indians, because the law does not tie the Government down to selection of Bazaars in out of the way corners only, but it gives them the power to point out streets, wards, and Locations for residence of the Asiatics.
('3', 325, 1, 4, 729141) Lord Milner him self contemplated the setting apart of streets, when he said in the same dispatch that “they will be required to remove to streets or Bazaars selected for this purpose”.
('3', 325, 1, 5, 729327) It will, therefore, be seen that Lord Milner’s statement is as definite as it possibly can be; the least that is, therefore, expected of the Government is that they should give full effect to Lord Milner’s declaration, and save the British Indian traders from ruin by conti nuing the renewal of their licences.
('3', 325, 1, 6, 729638) New applicants may be treated, if they so choose, in a different manner.
('3', 325, 1, 7, 729711) As shewing the apathy or hostility of the administration towards the Indian interests, the action of the Health Board at Barberton may be cited as an instance in point.
('3', 325, 1, 8, 729880) There, as stated last week, the attempt was made to shift the present Location to a place further away from town.
('3', 325, 1, 9, 729994) The Government have since written saying that the equipment of the present Location will not be disturbed, as the Health Board is not able to pay them compensation for removal, or to bear the cost thereof; but what has been given with one hand has been taken away with the other, because a Notice has just been issued signed by the Resident Magistrate, imposing on the tenancy of the present occupants new and extraordinary conditions, unheard of even between private parties; that is to say, if they do not want to remove to the new Locations, they will not be permitted to sub let their premises, or even to have any visitors “on pain of eviction”, [and] “in default of the payment of the rent due, on the prescribed date, the tenancy will be terminated”.
('3', 325, 1, 10, 730752) The licences are never transferable in respect of place, or renewable, except for the present holders.
('3', 325, 1, 11, 730855) Thus, the Board, if their decision is upheld, would have the satisfaction of removing the Indi ans from the present Location without having to pay a single penny.
('3', 325, 1, 12, 731018) All this is clearly contrary to Law 3 of 1885, for, at any rate, within the Location, the British Indians may have the same rights as any ordinary Individual.
('3', 325, 1, 13, 731177) The matter has been placed before the Government.
('3', 325, 2, 14, 731227) India Office: Judicial and Public Records, 402

('3', 326, 1, 2, 731315) 215. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('3', 326, 2, 3, 731348) JOHANNESBURG,
('3', 326, 3, 4, 731362) November 18, 1903
('3', 326, 4, 5, 731380) CHHAGANLAL,
('3', 326, 5, 6, 731392) I have your letter.
('3', 326, 5, 7, 731412) I have written in detail about myself to
('3', 326, 6, 8, 731453) Revashankarbhai1. You will know everything from it.
('3', 326, 6, 9, 731505) I cannot make any sort of promise to your aunt2. I think I shall take another four years.
('3', 326, 6, 10, 731595) I do not like the idea of her staying there for the sake of the jewellery or any such temptation.
('3', 326, 6, 11, 731693) If she wishes to stay there, she should live contented and without being a burden to others.
('3', 326, 6, 12, 731786) But if she cannot do that she has my permission to come over.
('3', 326, 6, 13, 731848) Read this to her.
('3', 326, 7, 14, 731866) Pass on the letters I am writing to Chi.
('3', 326, 7, 15, 731907) Harilal and Gokaldas3.
('3', 326, 8, 16, 731930) Send the books I have asked for and also the unframed as well as the other photographs.
('3', 326, 8, 17, 732018) Of the framed photographs, keep those you think worth while.
('3', 326, 8, 18, 732079) I am sorry that you have not yet regained your health.
('3', 326, 8, 19, 732134) Let me repeat that you must not strain yourself because you feel ashamed.
('3', 326, 8, 20, 732208) There is no warrant for making distinctions.
('3', 326, 8, 21, 732253) And where there is no sense of distinction, there is no question of embarrassment.
('3', 326, 8, 22, 732336) If your aunt or anyone else feels hurt by anything, do not think about it when it comes to looking after your health or performing other duties.
('3', 326, 8, 23, 732481) Then alone shall I feel happy.
('3', 326, 8, 24, 732512) Bring your aunt here if she wants to come, even if she does not wish to stay here long.
('3', 326, 8, 25, 732600) I think it will be good.
('3', 326, 8, 26, 732625) But if you think that you will not feel comfortable on a steamer, I shall not insist that you come braving hardships.
('3', 326, 9, 27, 732743) In such a case you can make alternative arrangements.
('3', 326, 9, 28, 732797) I see no
('3', 326, 10, 29, 732806) harm in [your aunt] coming alone by the s.s.
('3', 326, 10, 30, 732851) Send the booksand the photographs early.
('3', 326, 10, 31, 732892) Give to Mulibehn4 the amount she has not received from Bhai5. From now on make the remitance to her every month.
('3', 326, 10, 32, 733005) It would be good if the accounts of Shivlalbhai and Narbheram were settled soon.
('3', 326, 11, 33, 733086) Blessings from MOHANDAS
('3', 326, 12, 34, 733110) From the Gujarati original: C.W. 11294 Courtesy: Chhaganlal Gandhi
('3', 326, 13, 35, 733177) 1 Revashankar Jagjivan Jhaveri 2 Kasturba Gandhi 3 A nephew of Gandhiji 4 Gandhiji’s sister 5 Lakshmidas Gandhi
('3', 327, 0, 1, 733289) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 327, 1, 2, 733331) 216. THE TRANSVAAL BAZAARS
('3', 327, 2, 3, 733358) The friends of British Indians, in London, will do well to
('3', 327, 3, 4, 733417) compare Lord Milner’s dispatch to Mr. Chamberlain dated the 11th May with the attitude of the authorities in the Transvaal regarding the trading licences of British Indians.
('3', 327, 3, 5, 733591) Lord Milner in his dispatch states regar ding the store keepers that
('3', 327, 4, 6, 733660) they (the Government) are anxious, however, to do so (that is, to enforce the existing law), in the manner most considerate to the Indians already settled in the country, and with the greatest respect for vested interests, even where these have been allowed to spring up contrary to law.
('3', 327, 4, 7, 733948) Now, according to this statement, it would lead one to suppose
('3', 327, 5, 8, 734011) that all those Indians, who are at present trading in the Colony under licences issued to them, will not be disturbed and will not be comp elled to remove to Locations.
('3', 327, 5, 9, 734180) The fact, however, is that, with the exce ption of the very few who were able to obtain licences to trade before the war, all the others, even though they were engaged in trade before the war but without licences, will have to remove to Locations as if such people did not have any vested interest.
('3', 327, 5, 10, 734479) People in England, the refore, not knowing the correct situation in the Transvaal, are likely to be lulled into a sense of security under the mistaken belief that the tra ders holding their licences will not be touched at the end of the year.
('3', 327, 5, 11, 734722) We, therefore, warn them against holding any such belief, and have very good reasons for assuring them that, unless Herculean efforts are made to protect these innocent men, in spite of the above quotation from Lord Milner’s dispatch, hundreds of Indian traders are likely to be ruined at the end of the year.
('3', 327, 5, 12, 735032) The more we consider Lord Milner’s dispatch, the more we feel that it is misleading.
('3', 327, 5, 13, 735117) His Lordship says:
('3', 327, 6, 14, 735136) As I have already stated, the Government is prepared to recognise the vested interests of Asiatics resident here before the war.
('3', 327, 6, 15, 735265) On the other hand, it feels that it would not be justified in allowing new vested interests to spring up contrary to law.
('3', 327, 6, 16, 735387) During the war and since the declaration of peace, a large number of temporary trading licences were issued to new comers.
('3', 327, 6, 17, 735510) These licences have been renewed until December 31st 1903, but the holders have been warned that on that date they will be required to remove to Streets or Bazaars selected for this purpose.
('3', 327, 6, 18, 735701) Here there is not a word to show that either those Indians who
('3', 327, 7, 19, 735764) traded before the war without licences, or those Indian refugees who,
('3', 328, 0, 1, 735834) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 329
('3', 328, 1, 2, 735875) although they did not trade in the respective districts before the war, had their licences granted since, would be disturbed.
('3', 328, 1, 3, 736001) The only ques tion, according to Lord Milner, is that of new comers.
('3', 328, 1, 4, 736070) If then the Bazaar Notice were to apply merely to new comers in possession of temporary trading licences, perhaps not much could be said, but every one of the present licence holders, almost without exception, could be proved to be a refugee “resident here before the war”.
('3', 328, 1, 5, 736344) And yet these men will be required to remove to “streets or Bazaars selected for this purpose”.
('3', 328, 1, 6, 736440) And mark again the word “streets”, and read what follows:
('3', 328, 2, 7, 736498) As you are aware, His Lordship proceeds, the sites selected by the Government of the late African Republic for the purposed of Asiatic Bazaars, were in any cases most unsuitable for such a purpose, being remote from the business centres of the town.
('3', 328, 2, 8, 736748) In many towns no site at all was selected.
('3', 328, 2, 9, 736791) It is the intention of the Government to lose no time in choosing suitable sites for Asiatic Bazaars accessible to all classes of the community, and I am confident that, once the Bazaars are established and arranged in conformity with the customs and requirements of the occupants, the latter will be enabled to carry on their business with as great, if not greater, advantage than under existing conditions.
('3', 328, 2, 10, 737200) A reading of the above would naturally lead one to suppose that Bazaars would be very fine places, and very unlike those selected by the late Republican Government, and that, after all, it may mean me erely a change of streets; but we again hasten to assure those who have no means of knowing the conditions in the Transvaal that the Bazaars have not been selected in the spirit above mentioned, that in no case have streets been set apart for Indian trade or residence.
('3', 328, 2, 11, 737671) They are, in almost all the cases, as far away from business centres of the towns as they could possibly be.
('3', 328, 2, 12, 737780) We reproduce the reports handed to us for publication and prepared, at the instance of the British Indian Associ ation in the Transvaal, by professional gentlemen of standing in the colony, and they would show that the unanimous opinion is that the sites selected are unfit for trade.
('3', 328, 2, 13, 738065) Lord Milner acknowledges that the Bazaars selected by the late Government were most unsuitable for trade.
('3', 328, 2, 14, 738171) We say then with the utmost confidence that the sites selected by the present Government, in most cases, are doubly so.
('3', 328, 2, 15, 738291) An attempt has been made to remove the existing sites selected by the old Gover nment further away, and with the exception of one or two cases where there were old sites, they have been retained.
('3', 328, 2, 16, 738487) In almost all cases, at present they are veritable deserts, without sanitary conveniences, with out any water laid on, without any buildings.
('3', 328, 2, 17, 738629) It may be unbelievable
('3', 329, 0, 1, 738652) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 329, 1, 2, 738694) 5,000 miles away from the Transvaal, but it is literlly true that the people who are to inhabit these Bazaars have really to establish pra ctically new townships.
('3', 329, 1, 3, 738857) They are to get leases of Stands, build on them themselves at their own expense, and attract, if they can, a new trade.
('3', 329, 1, 4, 738977) We lay some stress on the pharse “at their own expense”, because it is only those who want to use the Stands for their trade and residence who are to compete for them.
('3', 329, 1, 5, 739145) It will, therefore, be easily understood that petty traders cannot command from £ 300 to £ 400 in order to build a decent structure.
('3', 329, 1, 6, 739278) The Bazaars have just been selected, and they are to be expected to commence building, finish before the 1st of January, and transport themselves to their new abode on that date.
('3', 329, 1, 7, 739457) “The Bazaars,” His Lordship says, “would be accessible to all classes of the community”.
('3', 329, 1, 8, 739546) If by that is meant that they will not be fenced in with barbed wire, with a yellow flag flying over them, the expression is true; but if it is meant to convey an idea that all classes of the com munity will go there to make their purchases, we again say that they will do nothing of the kind.
('3', 329, 1, 9, 739840) They will decline to walk one mile from business centres and go out of their way to make purchases in Indian Bazaars, And yet His Lordship expects that “the latter (that is, the Indians) will be enabled to carry on their business with as great, if not greater, advantage then under existing conditions”.
('3', 329, 1, 10, 740144) The heartlessness of the situation is beyond description.
('3', 329, 1, 11, 740202) It is only the hope that, before the year is out, some relief will be granted and that the present licence holders will not be disturbed which buoys them up.
('3', 329, 1, 12, 740360) We have not yet done with the dispatch.
('3', 329, 1, 13, 740400) We have noticed, both in the papers received from England and from India, that the impression created by the dispatch is that respectable British Indians or civilised Asiatics will not be affected by the Bazaar Notice, for, says Lord Milner,
('3', 329, 2, 14, 740642) we have no wish to subject respectable British Indians, or civilised Asiatics generally, to any disabilities.
('3', 329, 2, 15, 740752) While the present Government is, for the time being, maintaining the law on the subject passed by the late Govern ment, it is in three most important respects showing a consideration for the Asiatics which the late Governement did not show.
('3', 329, 2, 16, 740993) The present tense used by His Lordship is worthy of notice.
('3', 329, 2, 17, 741053) One of the three important respects is exemption of Asiatics of a supe rior class from all special legislation.
('3', 329, 2, 18, 741165) We once more assure our readers in England and in India that the principle of exemption is not yet recognised, is no part of the law except as to residence, and that if it is to come at all, it will come at some future unknown date.
('3', 329, 2, 19, 741398) In the meanwhile, respectable British Indians and others sail in the same boat,
('3', 330, 0, 1, 741478) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 331
('3', 330, 1, 2, 741519) and will be unceremoniously compelled to remove to Locations and trade there and there alone.
('3', 330, 1, 3, 741613) Such is the wide difference between the picture drawn by Lord Milner of the position of the Asiatics and the picture that we have drawn from existing conditions.
('3', 330, 1, 4, 741775) The one is likely to blind the people to the real state of things; the other is true to life without, we say with deliberation, the slightest exaggeration.
('3', 330, 1, 5, 741931) We have endeavoured to keep strictly to facts and reports.
('3', 330, 1, 6, 741990) We can only hope that the position being so accute and un British, even at the eleventh hour, there will be a turning away from it, and the New Year will dawn upon the British Indian traders not so gloomily as it at present pro mises to do.
('3', 330, 2, 7, 742231) Indian Opinion,19 11 1903
('3', 330, 3, 8, 742257) 217. THE GRAND OLD MAN OF INDIA
('3', 330, 4, 9, 742289) The mail papers to hand from India contain very long notices of the birthday anniversary of Mr. Dadabhai Naoroji, who is undou btedly to India what Mr. Gladstone was to Great Britain.
('3', 330, 4, 10, 742473) He has entered upon his 79th year, and the whole of India has celebrated the anniversary in a manner befitting the occasion.
('3', 330, 4, 11, 742598) Millions of voices have gone up to Heaven praying for the blessings of the Almighty to be showered upon the grand old man and for many years of life on this earth.
('3', 330, 4, 12, 742762) We join the millions in their prayer.
('3', 330, 4, 13, 742800) Mr. Dadabhai is loved form the Hindukush to Cape Comorin and from Karachi to Calcutta as no other living man in India is loved.
('3', 330, 4, 14, 742928) He has given a lifetime to the service of the country of his birth, and though a Parsi, Hindus, Mahomedans, Christians and all revere him just as strongly as the followers of Zoroaster.
('3', 330, 4, 15, 743114) He has sacrificed for the cause of India ease and luxury, and has imposed upon himself a long exile.
('3', 330, 4, 16, 743215) He has devoted his wealth also to the cause.
('3', 330, 4, 17, 743260) His is the purest type of patrio tism and comes from a sense of duty to the motherland.
('3', 330, 4, 18, 743348) Nor is this all.
('3', 330, 4, 19, 743365) Mr. Dadabhai’s private character has been also a perfect pattern to be copied by the rising generation in every respect, and if we are not much mistaken, there is behind all his political work a strong religious pious fervour which nothing can quench.
('3', 330, 4, 20, 743617) The land which is capable of producing a Dadabhai has every reason to hope for the best in the long run.
('3', 330, 4, 21, 743722) Soon after he was elected member of the House of Com mons, an honour conferred by a British constituency for the first time on an Indian, he paid a visit to India, and those who were privileged to witness his triumphal progress from Bombay to Lahore have
('3', 331, 0, 1, 743977) 332 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 331, 1, 2, 744019) testified that the enthusiasm with which he was received was only equalled, if at all, by that which accompanied the progress of the ever to be remembered Lord Ripon when he retired from his Viceroyalty.
('3', 331, 1, 3, 744223) The nation certainly honoured itself by honouring such a man.

('3', 333, 3, 11, 750169) 220. THE HISTORY OF A PERSECUTION
('3', 333, 4, 12, 750203) For several years and long before the war, the British Indians
('3', 333, 5, 13, 750266) have been in occuption of a Location established for them by the late Government at Barberton.
('3', 333, 5, 14, 750361) Emboldened by the Bazaar Notice, the Health Board of that place decided to remove the inhabitatnts of the Location to a place further away from the town on various excuses.
('3', 333, 5, 15, 750534) The Health Board had necessarily to obtain the sanction of the Gove rnment, which was at once given on condition that the buildings on the present Location should be removed to the new one at the expense of the Health Board, or that due compensation in respect of the buil dings only should be paid to the owners.
('3', 333, 5, 16, 750848) Notices were therefore given to the occupants, who, grasping the situation, set about working in right earnest and approached the Government, protesting against the contemplated removal.
('3', 333, 5, 17, 751035) They sent several petitions, and an enquiry was made.
('3', 333, 5, 18, 751089) The grounds taken up by the petitioners were: 1st that they had been established for a long time in the Location where they were at present and had formed good wills in connection with their trade; 2nd.
('3', 333, 5, 19, 751292) that to such people it would mean a very serious loss to have to remove to the new Location; 3rd.
('3', 333, 5, 20, 751390) that it was not such as would enable
('3', 334, 0, 1, 751427) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 335
('3', 334, 1, 2, 751468) them to do any trade at all; that it was much further away from town than the present location, and that it was not a healthy site.
('3', 334, 1, 3, 751600) They had a special report prepared in connection with the matter and Mr. Bertier, a well known surveyor of the town, reported that the new site was one mile 930 yards from the Market Square by the shortest route, that the soil
('3', 334, 2, 4, 751827) of the new site is of the same granitic nature as that of the adjacent Hospital kopje, a portion of the site being actually on the slope of the kopje.
('3', 334, 2, 5, 751978) In view of this, the ravages caused by white ants to the hospital buildings on the said kopje are worthy of serious consideration.
('3', 334, 2, 6, 752109) Mr. Bertier also goes exhaustively into the question whether the removal of the present Location is at all called for, and shews clearly that it is not, and says as follows:
('3', 334, 3, 7, 752283) While the present position of the Indian Location, close to the Main Road from Barberton to the Kaap Valley, allows trade to a certain extent at the Location, and while its distance from the town proper does not preclude business transactions in town, the new site would only in one corner abut on the Main Road, and the increase of distance from the town would entail increased difficulties in the transaction of business, the more so as public passenger transport is unprovided for in the township and suburbs.
('3', 334, 3, 8, 752796) Whatever road east of the Hospital kopje is made to penetrate in the proposed Location will pass within one hundred yards of the Health Board site, where mules are stabled, night soil and rubbish waggons out spanned, and buckets tarred and stacked.
('3', 334, 3, 9, 753045) The Government, however, has returned a reply saying that it does not consider the site to be unhealthy.
('3', 334, 3, 10, 753150) It ignores the fact that the removal is totally unnecessary, but says that, as the Local Board is not prepared to pay compensation or bear the cost of removal, the present occupants will be left undisturbed.
('3', 334, 3, 11, 753358) Were it not for the most exasper ating conditions now imposed on them, the above might have been considered a fair compromise as thing go with the British Indians in the Transvaal, but the terms under which the occupants are to be allo wed to remain undisturbed are such as to render the compromise ut terly useless.
('3', 334, 3, 12, 753675) What has been given with one hand has been taken away with the other, for we read in a notice sent to these poor people as follows:
('3', 334, 4, 13, 753807) Only existing licensees, their wives and children will have the option of remaining in the present Location.
('3', 334, 4, 14, 753916) That in default of payment of the rent due on the prescribed date, the tenancy will be determined.
('3', 334, 4, 15, 754015) That no licensee shall
('3', 335, 0, 1, 754038) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 335, 1, 2, 754080) sub let or permit others to occupy his Stand on pain of eviction.
('3', 335, 1, 3, 754146) That no new licences will be issued in respect of the present Location, nor any right to transfer licences granted.
('3', 335, 1, 4, 754262) Now these terms appear to us to be most exasperating.
('3', 335, 1, 5, 754316) We have the misfortune of being tenants, but we must confess that our landlord has not imposed any such conditions whatsoever, nor are we aware of any lease containing such novel conditions.
('3', 335, 1, 6, 754507) It would have been far more decent of the Board if they had said:‘We do not want to pay you any compensation and you shall have to remove to the new Location,’ but to drive the people away from their position by underhand in direct policy hardly reflects any credit on its authors.
('3', 335, 1, 7, 754789) In Barberton, the Health Board evidently wishes to override the Law of the Colony, such as it is, affecting British Indians.
('3', 335, 1, 8, 754914) Either the site at present occu pied by the British Indians is a Location in terms of Law 3 of 1885, or it is not.
('3', 335, 1, 9, 755029) If it is, then unless we have misread the law, any Indian has not only the right to live there but to have sub tenants and certainly to have guests, also to trade in any part of the Location he likes on payment of the licence fee.
('3', 335, 1, 10, 755260) But as will have been seen according to the new conditions, the Board would prevent the residents from having any guests “on pain of eviction”.
('3', 335, 1, 11, 755404) We understand that the matter has been placed before the Government.
('3', 335, 1, 12, 755473) We shall await its decision with anxiety.
('3', 335, 1, 13, 755515) We wonder what His Excellency Lord Milner would have to say in defence of what the Health Board of Barberton proposes to do.

('3', 339, 1, 3, 760698) According to the lecturer,
('3', 339, 2, 4, 760725) the Tsar of all the Russians has several millions of Buddhist and Pagan subjects, and 207,000,000 Hindus acknowledge the sway of the Emperor of India; but Islam alone presents identical problems to their servants in the East.
('3', 339, 2, 5, 760951) British India includes no fewer than 53,804,000 followers of the Prophet.
('3', 339, 2, 6, 761025) According to the census of 1897, those who owe allegiance to the Great White Tsar numbered 18,707,000. .
('3', 339, 2, 7, 761130) By way of contrast I may state that the Commander of the Faithful at Constantinople has less than 18,500,000 subjects who acknowledge his creed.
('3', 339, 2, 8, 761275) It is thus apparent that Mr. Skrine has set well defined limits to his comparison, and while it therefore does not admit of any bold generalisations, it is a paper well worth reading.
('3', 339, 2, 9, 761459) The Government of India has been somewhere called “benevolent despotism”, and pro bably, although the expression involves a contradiction in terms, it very nearly explains the condition of British rule in India.
('3', 339, 2, 10, 761671) So long as there is no interference with the paramountcy of English rule, the institutions which the people of India have inherited from ancient times are respected and left intact.
('3', 339, 2, 11, 761853) They have, in domestic affairs, self government of a more or less crude nature.
('3', 339, 2, 12, 761933) The historc Proclamation of 1857 1 and the later declarations of the succeeding Viceroys show that the intention is to do away with all distinctions of caste, colour and creed, and to ensure equal rights for all the subjects of the Em pire.
('3', 339, 2, 13, 762174) If, therefore, in India itself, these declarations are not carried out to their fullest extent, it is not because the authorities did not intend to fulfil them, but because in practice they are limited either by undue fear as to the supremacy of British rule or by vague suspicion about the governed.
('3', 339, 2, 14, 762475) In spite, however, of temporary aberrations, there are grounds for hoping that such suspicion or fear will gradually give way to confidence as opportunities occur to test the inborn loyal spirit of the people.
('3', 339, 2, 15, 762685) The recent war in South Africa, as well as the expedition to China, has created a striking impression on the minds of the rulers of India, and indirectly has done a lot of good from the Indian stand point.
('3', 339, 2, 16, 762891) The chief point, however, on which Mr. Skrine has laid stress is religious rather than political, and he contends that there is not that
