('3', 423, 2, 12, 964558) 277. LORD HARRIS ON LABOUR
('3', 423, 3, 13, 964585) We publish in another column a report from the Daily Mail of an interview which its representative has had with Lord Harris, the ex Governor of Bombay, who is at present in Johannesburg and who is the Chairman of the Consolidated Gold Fields.
('3', 423, 3, 14, 964828) His Lordship has given to the interviewer his views on labour importation and he thinks that the opposition against it at home is very unreasonabloe and quotes, in support of his contention, the fact that the West Indies and other countries have before now imported Coloured indentured labour.
('3', 423, 3, 15, 965122) One would have expected far better argument than this from His Lordship, for we are sure he could not be unaware that there is very great difference between the West Indies and the Transvaal as also between the labour ordinances elsewhere and the Labour Ordinance which the Transvaal Government would have the Home Government sanction without any demur.
('3', 423, 3, 16, 965476) The West Indies it is well known, is hardly suited for white labour, the climate of that country being very trying, whereas the climate of the Transvaal is ideally good and the white workmen would have no difficulty in doing the same kind of work
('3', 424, 0, 1, 965723) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 425
('3', 424, 1, 2, 965764) that they are used to in England.
('3', 424, 1, 3, 965798) Nobody has ever contended that the climate is not suitable for such labour: the only objection is that white labour is too expensive.
('3', 424, 1, 4, 965932) Mr. Morley has disposed of the economic argument by pointing out that the mines ought to be satisfied with less profits and those that could not be worked at all by white labour need not be in a hurry to give up their gold.
('3', 424, 1, 5, 966156) As to the difference between the indenture laws elsewhere and in the Transvaal, there is that difference between the the two which exists between the contract of slavery and a free contract.
('3', 424, 1, 6, 966347) So far as we are aware, in the histroy of British colonization, it would be difficult to find an indenture law so drastic, so sweeping, and so unjust to the labourer as the Labour Importation Ordinance of the Transvaal.
('3', 424, 1, 7, 966567) The indentured labourers who go to the West Indies and elsewhere do not go there as slaves, but as soon as their contract is finished, they are free to settle in the country and enjoy the ordinary civic rights.
('3', 424, 1, 8, 966778) It is, therefore, we respectfully submit, hardly fair that Lord Harris should cite the West Indies and other countries as an example.
('3', 424, 1, 9, 966912) His Lordship’s remarks on the attitude of the Indian Govern ment are even more interesting and instructive.
('3', 424, 2, 10, 967020) From the Indian point of view, says His Lordship, I think the Govern ment of India made a mistake orginally, whatever their attitude be now.
('3', 424, 2, 11, 967161) The trader and the coolie are entirely different persons.
('3', 424, 2, 12, 967219) It would have been a splendid thing for India if there had been an out and in flow from India to the Transvaal.
('3', 424, 2, 13, 967331) Considerable trade would be certain to spring up between the two countries, and the coolie, having given the Transvaal the benefit of his labour, would go back to his village with his rupees, the capital that India precisely wants.
('3', 424, 2, 14, 967563) We may be pardoned for saying that although the coolie and the trader may be different persons, it does not follow that the coolie must always remain a coolie and be treated as chattel.
('3', 424, 2, 15, 967749) Why should he be de nied the right, if he is brought to the country at all, of settling and ear ning an honest livelihood?
('3', 424, 2, 16, 967872) And why should the Indian Government go out of its way to accommodate a Government which is callous to all ideas of justice in treating the resident Indian population with fair ness?
('3', 424, 2, 17, 968055) It is all very well to talk of the trade between India being consi derably increased owing to the importation of indentured labour.
('3', 424, 2, 18, 968187) A few thousand Indians going to the Transvaal as slaves would hardly solve the problem of Indian poverty, and we think that the Indian Government has come to a proper decision in not allowing indentured
('3', 425, 0, 1, 968390) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 425, 1, 2, 968432) emigration from India to the Transvaal on the terms suggested and without amelioration of the condition of the British Indians who have already settled in the colony.

('3', 425, 2, 4, 968625) 278. LADYSMITH LICENCES
('3', 425, 3, 5, 968649) Mr. Lines, the Town Clerk and Licensing Officer at Ladysmith, has now issued license to British Indian store keepers with the follo wing note endorsed thereon:
('3', 425, 4, 6, 968809) This license is issued strictly in accordance with the undertaking entered into by the holder hereof that the licensed premises shall not be open for business after the hour of 5 p.m.
('3', 425, 4, 7, 968993) except on Saturdays and that the licensed premises shall be closed on holidays.
('3', 425, 4, 8, 969073) Having accepted the principle that the Indian store keepers should agree to the stipulations laid down by Mr. Lines as to early closing, we cannot say much against the above endorsement.
('3', 425, 4, 9, 969260) Subject, however, to such reservation, we are bound to protest against the remarks being made on the licenses because they are illegal and out of place.
('3', 425, 4, 10, 969413) It is one thing to hold certain powers and another thing to dangle them before the public in an offensive manner.
('3', 425, 4, 11, 969527) If Mr. Lines had remained content with his victory and not paraded it on the licenses, it would have been no less effective and would have appeared graceful.
('3', 425, 4, 12, 969685) He could have taken severe notice of any breach of the undertaking the following year.
('3', 425, 4, 13, 969772) As it is, we venture to think that the whole of the grace has been taken away by the note made as above.
('3', 425, 4, 14, 969877) Mr. Lines may also know that, in spite of the endorsement on the licenses, supposing any of the holders chooses to ignore same and continues to open his business after five in the evening, he (Mr. Lines) could not cancel the license once granted.
('3', 425, 4, 15, 970124) There is no process of law available for enforcing the prohibition.
('3', 425, 4, 16, 970192) It is merely a matter of compromise and compact beween himelf and the Indian store keepers.
('3', 425, 4, 17, 970284) We, therefore, regret that Mr. Lines has endorsed the note on the licenses.
('3', 425, 4, 18, 970360) At the same time.
('3', 425, 4, 19, 970378) there is no use crying over spilt milk, and we think it is clearly the duty of the British Indian store keepers in Ladysmith to strictly abide by the undertaking.

('3', 426, 1, 2, 970608) 279. LETTER TO DR.
('3', 426, 2, 3, 970627) 21 TO 24, COURT CHAMBERS February 11, 1904 DR.
('3', 426, 2, 4, 970674) C. PORTER MEDICAL OFFICER OF HEALTH P. O. BOX 1049 JOHANNESBURG
('3', 426, 3, 5, 970738) DEAR DR.
('3', 426, 3, 6, 970747) PORTER, I venture to write you regarding the shocking state of the Indian Location.
('3', 426, 3, 7, 970831) The rooms appear to be overcrowded beyond description.
('3', 426, 3, 8, 970886) The sanitary service is very irregular, and many of the residents of the Location have been to my office to complain that the sanitary condition is far worse than before.
('3', 426, 3, 9, 971057) There is, too, a very large Kaffir population in the Location for which really there is no warrant.
('3', 426, 3, 10, 971157) From what I hear, I believe the mortality in the Location has increased considerably and it seems to me that, if the present state of things is continued, outbreak of some epidemic disease is merely a question of time.
('3', 426, 3, 11, 971376) I know you are very great on sanitary reform.
('3', 426, 3, 12, 971422) May I, therefore, ask you to be good enough to pay a personal visit and deal effectively as well with the overcrowding as with the sanitation.
('3', 426, 3, 13, 971565) If I can be of any service, I shall be pleased to accompany you, should you approve of my suggestion.
('3', 426, 3, 14, 971667) I would add that for the present state of things the occupants of the Location are in no way responsible.
('3', 426, 4, 15, 971773) I remain, Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion.

('3', 427, 1, 2, 971876) 280. LETTER TO DR.
('3', 427, 2, 3, 971895) 21 TO 24 COURT CHAMBERS, February 15, 1904 DR.
('3', 427, 2, 4, 971942) C. PROTER MEDICAL OFFICER OF HEALTH JOHANNESBURG
('3', 427, 3, 5, 971991) DEAR DR, PORTER, I am extremely obliged to you for having paid a visit last Saturady to the Indian Location and for the interest you are taking in the proper sanitation of the site.
('3', 427, 3, 6, 972173) The more I think of it, the uglier the situation appears to me, and I think that, if the Town Council takes up a position of non possumus, it will be an abdication of its function, and I do respectfully say that nothing can justify the Public Health Committee in saying that neither overcrowding nor insanitation could be helped.
('3', 427, 3, 7, 972503) I feel convinced that every minute wasted over the matter merely hastens a calamity for Johannesburg and that through absol utely no fault of the British Indians.
('3', 427, 3, 8, 972666) Why, of all places in Johannes burg, the Indian Location should be chosen for dumping down all the kaffirs of the town passes my comprehension.
('3', 427, 3, 9, 972810) While the great projects for sanitary reform of the Public Health Committee are undoubtedly very laudable and probably necessary, the obvious duty of dealing with the present danger of insanitation and overcrowding in the Indian Location, in my humble opinion, is not to be neglected.
('3', 427, 3, 10, 973095) I feel that a few hundred pounds now spent will probably cause a saving of thousands of pounds; for, if, unfortunately, an epidemic breaks out in the Location, panic will ensue and money will then be spent like water in order to cure an evil which is now absolutely preventible.
('3', 427, 3, 11, 973374) I do not wonder that your staff, hard worked as it is, is unable to cope with sanitation in the Location, for what you do want, and what you cannot get, is a topaz for each Stand.
('3', 427, 3, 12, 973554) What is everybody’s business is also nobody’s.
('3', 427, 3, 13, 973601) You cannot expect every resident to look after the sanitation.
('3', 427, 3, 14, 973664) Before expropriation, every Stand holder was held responsible, and very naturally, for the proper sanitatiion of his Stand.
('3', 427, 3, 15, 973788) The result, as I know personally, was that evry Stand, had a topaz attached to it who continually looked after the Stand, and I have no hesitation in saying that compared to what the Stands are now, they were kept in an ideally good condition.
('3', 428, 0, 1, 974032) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 429
('3', 428, 1, 2, 974073) You ask me to suggest remedies.
('3', 428, 1, 3, 974105) I have slept over the matter and, if only the Town Council would take up a reasonable atitude, I have no doubt that an immediate improvement, without any cost to the Town Council, and probably to the saving of a few pounds, is possi ble.
('3', 428, 1, 4, 974343) Let short leasessix monthly or quarterlybe given to the Stand holders.
('3', 428, 1, 5, 974416) The leases may state exactly how many people are to be kept on each Stand, or in each room.
('3', 428, 1, 6, 974508) The lessees could pay, say, 8 per cent on the valuation of the valuators and should be made strictly responsible for the sanitation of the Stand leased by them.
('3', 428, 1, 7, 974669) The sanitary regulations could then be strictly enforced; one or two inspectors could visit the Stands daily and come down upon defaulters with a heavy hand.
('3', 428, 1, 8, 974827) If this humble suggestion is accepted, you will see a vast improvement in two or three days, and you, by a stroke of the pen, could deal effectively with insanitation and overcrowding.
('3', 428, 1, 9, 975012) The Town Council would also be saved the necessity of having to make individual collections of rents.
('3', 428, 1, 10, 975114) Of course, under my suggestion, the Town Council must with draw the Kaffirs from the Location.
('3', 428, 1, 11, 975209) About this mixing of the Kaffirs with the Indians, I must confess I feel most strongly.
('3', 428, 1, 12, 975297) I think it is very unfair to the Indian population and it is an undue tax on even the proverbial patience of my countrymen.
('3', 428, 1, 13, 975421) Although I have not personally visited other portions included within the Insanitary Area, I very much fear that the same condition of things exists there and the suggestion I have made above would apply to the other parts also.
('3', 428, 1, 14, 975650) I trust you will receive this letter in the spirit in which it is written, and I hope that I have not expressed myself more stongly than the urgency of the occasion requires.
('3', 428, 1, 15, 975825) I need hardly add that my services in this connection are entirely at the disposal of yourself and the Public Health Committee and I have no doubt that, if the Town Council would but give the Indian community a fair chance of proving what it is capable of doing in the way of sanitation, I do not think it would be much mistaken.
('3', 428, 1, 16, 976155) You may make what use you like of this communication.
('3', 428, 1, 17, 976209) In conclusion, I hope that an immediate remedy will be found for the danger that threatens the community.
('3', 428, 2, 18, 976315) I remain, Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI Indian Opinion, 9 4 1904

('3', 430, 2, 4, 979008) 282. PIETERSBURG AGAIN
('3', 430, 3, 5, 979031) Pietersburg, which last year led the way in harassing British Indian store keepers, 1 continues its policy with unabated vigour.
('3', 430, 3, 6, 979160) The newly formed Town Council, in its anxiety to keep up the persecution, has now passed a resolution that even hawkers are not to be allowed to carry on their trade without molestation.
('3', 430, 3, 7, 979347) Mr. Krause, one of the members of the Town Council, has proposed that
('3', 430, 4, 8, 979417) a bye law be drafted stating that no licenses would be issued to Asiatics or coloured persons except for trading in such places as are set aside for them specially.
('3', 430, 4, 9, 979582) Mr. Chittenden seconded the resolution and, continues the Zoutpans burg Review, “It was agreed that infringement of the bye law, if confirmed by the Lieutenant Governor, should be punishable by a fine of £20 or six months imprisonment.” How a hawker can be made to confine hawking merely to a Location, it is difficult to understand.
('3', 430, 4, 10, 979916) Mr. Kruger’s Government, although it did many unkind things, never went so far as the Pietersburg Town Council would go.
('3', 430, 4, 11, 980037) There are many lawyers on the Pietersburg Town Council, and it seems strange that it never occurred to any of them that the Town Council was making itself ridiculous in trying to arrogate to itself powers which by statute it does not possess.
('3', 430, 4, 12, 980280) Pushed to its logical conclusion, the resolution would involve the compounding of British Indians without the elaborate necessity of a special Ordinance, for if an Indian can hawk his goods only within the confines of his Location, it could not be at all unfair to say that he could move about also only within his Bazaar, and should never go beyond the Bazaar line.
('3', 430, 4, 13, 980647) We have no doubt that such an interpretation of the powers of the Town Council would be an ideal thing in the estimation of the Town Council of Pietersburg.
('3', 430, 4, 14, 980804) We, however, hope that Sir Arthur Lawley will save the Council from ridicule and an impossible position by telling it plainly that the bye law proposed to be framed could not be sanctioned.

('3', 431, 5, 13, 981894) 284. THE MUNICIPAL CONFERENCE AND INDIAN TRADERS
('3', 431, 6, 14, 981943) At the meeting of the Municipal Conference of the Transvaal which sat at johannesburg last week.
('3', 431, 6, 15, 982040) Mr. George Constable, represen ting the Boksburg Council, moved the following resolution:
('3', 431, 7, 16, 982130) That in view of the fact that a new Asiatic law is to be brought before the Legislative Council for its consideration, and that the question is of such vital importance to local governing bodies, this Conference of Transvaal Municipalities places on record its opinion that the most satisfactory policy to the inhabitants will be to place all Asiatics in Bazaars, fair compensation to be paid to any who may be trading outside under licenses first granted by the late Government; further, that all local authories be permitted to make what by laws may be necessary to regulate matters concernig coloured people and in regard to the fixing of sites for bazaars, places of residence, etc.
('3', 432, 0, 1, 982817) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 433
('3', 432, 1, 2, 982858) The resolution was carried, Mr. Goch alone dissenting.
('3', 432, 1, 3, 982913) The resolution modestly asks that all Asiatics be placed in Bazaars for trade and residence; that those who traded before the war under licenses be compensated, and that powers be given to the Municipalities to regulate these matters.
('3', 432, 1, 4, 983148) In naked terms, the propo sition means that the British Indians should be starved into leaving the country.
('3', 432, 1, 5, 983256) In Mr. Goch’s words “the idea of placing Asiatics in bazaars is not so much to put them there as to get rid of them altogether.” The British Indians have shown conclusively that the so called Bazaars are totally unfit for habitation or trade.
('3', 432, 1, 6, 983499) It were a mercy to put the British Indians out of the country altogether rather than subject them to vivisection and kill them by inches.
('3', 432, 1, 7, 983637) Mr. Constable’s ideal of the powers he would have for the Municipalities is Brandfort in the Orange River Colony.
('3', 432, 1, 8, 983751) We had occasion some time ago to deal with the municipal bye laws for that township, and we think we shewed how the Coloured people thereunder become mere chattels.
('3', 432, 1, 9, 983916) It is, we fear, useless to appeal to Mr. Constable’s sense of fari ness.
('3', 432, 1, 10, 983989) He worships the fetish of the law of self preservation.
('3', 432, 1, 11, 984045) And he has no difficulty in getting round his conscience, as so many of us do when blinded by prejudice or bigotry, and satisfying himself that the great law demands that the British Indians should be ruined.
('3', 432, 1, 12, 984254) We have had other interpretations of the law by Englishmen who were perhaps more equi minded and, therefore, better able to judge.
('3', 432, 1, 13, 984385) They thought that the law was limited by another and higher, namely, that we should so preserve ourselves as not to encroach upon other people’s rights.
('3', 432, 1, 14, 984538) The simple corollary that Mr. Constable’s countrymen have also laid down as flowing from the above limitation is that when we have to deal with people who do not do as we do, and if we are satisfied that we are in the right, we should act by them so as to raise them to our level and not to crush them.
('3', 432, 1, 15, 984841) May we ask him and his friends to con sider this view?
('3', 432, 1, 16, 984896) What is, however, the secret of the increasing intensity of the opposition to the Indian trader?
('3', 432, 1, 17, 984993) Not that the number hostile to the Indian interests is increasing, but the gentlemen who first instigated the oposition are becoming more and more exacting in their dema nds for repression of the Asiatic.
('3', 432, 1, 18, 985198) Have the Indians given any cause?
('3', 432, 1, 19, 985232) The answer is undoubtedly in the negative.
('3', 432, 1, 20, 985275) What is it, then, that has fed the flame of prejudice?
('3', 432, 1, 21, 985330) The speakers at the meeting have supplied the answer.
('3', 432, 1, 22, 985384) They supported the
('3', 433, 0, 1, 985403) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 433, 1, 2, 985445) resolution to aid the Government.
('3', 433, 1, 3, 985479) Why aid the Government?
('3', 433, 1, 4, 985503) Is it anti Asiatic?
('3', 433, 1, 5, 985523) Does it, therfore, need the support of the populace in the policy?
('3', 433, 1, 6, 985590) We would not go so far as to say that the Government is deliberately anti Asiatic.
('3', 433, 1, 7, 985673) But the gentlemen of the White Leagues, hav ing found by experience that, if they cry loud enough and persis tenty against the Asiatics, they can practically get what they want, have naturally grown bolder in their demands.
('3', 433, 1, 8, 985897) They asked for the enforcement of the Law of 1885 and the Bazaar Notice was the reply.
('3', 433, 1, 9, 985984) they wanted the Asiatics sent to Locations, and Bazaars have been established in several places.
('3', 433, 1, 10, 986081) We might quote further instances of yielding to the white opposition on the part of the powers that be.
('3', 433, 1, 11, 986185) Such accommodation on the part of the Government has been rightly interpreted as an invitation to continue the agitation.
('3', 433, 1, 12, 986307) Mr Constable’s motion is the response.
('3', 433, 1, 13, 986346) Lord Milner having tinkered with the rights of the Asiatics, our friends at Boksburg, like the baby in the tub, “won’t be happy till they’ve got it”.
('3', 433, 1, 14, 986496) Lord Milner has promised to alter the anti Asiatic laws so as to bring them in harmony with the British Constitution.
('3', 433, 1, 15, 986614) The Muncipal Conference has declared in what way it wants them altered.
('3', 433, 1, 16, 986686) It would out Kruger Mr. Kruger.
('3', 433, 1, 17, 986718) The erstwhile Uitlanders complained that they had no voice in the affairs of State during the old regime.
('3', 433, 1, 18, 986824) Now that they cried themselves hoarse, they would make the British Indians, whose co operation they were glad to have in fighting the old rergine, Uitlanders under the common flag.
('3', 433, 1, 19, 987005) And this is their view of honour and faith!
('3', 433, 1, 20, 987049) In the midst of the whole of the wretchedly painful proceedings of the Conference, Mr. Goch’s speech was an oasis in the deseert.
('3', 433, 1, 21, 987179) He spoke plainly and firmly.
('3', 433, 1, 22, 987208) He protested against the resolution and adduced arguments in support of his protest which would convince anyone not steeped in bias.
('3', 433, 1, 23, 987341) The Indian community is beholden to Mr. Goch for his outspokenness and the stand he took up for Justice.
('3', 433, 1, 24, 987446) And so long as we have men like him, we shall continue to believe in the ultimate triumph of a cause which is inherently just.
('3', 433, 1, 25, 987573) Indian Opinion, 25 2 1904
('3', 433, 2, 26, 987599) 285. LABOUR FOR THE TRANSVAAL FROM INDIA
('3', 433, 3, 27, 987640) In his excellent review of the year’s work for the mines, sub mitted last week to the annual meeting of the Chamber of Mines, Sir George Farrar naturally dwelt on the labour question at length.
('3', 433, 3, 28, 987834) From the remarks made by him it would appear that an attempt is still being
('3', 434, 0, 1, 987910) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 435
('3', 434, 1, 2, 987951) made to obtain indentured labour for the mines from India.
('3', 434, 1, 3, 988010) He said:
('3', 434, 2, 4, 988019) It may be that we may extend our operations to India, but so far, the attitude of the Indian Government has been one of opposition, They are willing to send us labourers, but they object to our terms of repatriation.
('3', 434, 2, 5, 988236) When however, it is seen to what extent the return of labourers, after their term of contract in these mines, brings prosperity to their own country, then the objections which the Indian Government holds to day may be waived in the sole interests of the Indian Empire.
('3', 434, 2, 6, 988505) It is wonderful how people would find arguments in support of their preconceived ideas.
('3', 434, 2, 7, 988593) That the Indian Government would waive objections in the sole interests of the Indian Empire is not a novel idea.
('3', 434, 2, 8, 988707) Lord Harris, who might be expected to know better, has said as much and more already.
('3', 434, 2, 9, 988793) We are not, therefore, surprised that Sir Geo rge Farrar should adopt a similar view.
('3', 434, 2, 10, 988879) If, however, he would only look a little beneath the surface, he will find at once that there is not hing whatever in his arguments.
('3', 434, 2, 11, 989012) We assume, for instance, the 20,000 Indians went to the Transvaal under the proposed conditions at, say, a monthly wage of £ 3 or even £ 3 10 0; that they saved £ 30 per year.
('3', 434, 2, 12, 989188) That would mean a saving of £ 90 at the end of three years, that is to say, £ 1,800,000. among 20,000 labourers.
('3', 434, 2, 13, 989301) India has a population of 300,000,000. How many years’ continuous working would be neces sary before there would be £ 1 per head distributed in India out of the indentured labour in the Transvaal?
('3', 434, 2, 14, 989498) Will any man in his senses con tend that, for the sake of such a visionary gain, the Indian Govern ment would sell Indians into virtual slavery?
('3', 434, 2, 15, 989643) The figures we have quo ted are, of course, based on the supposition that every Indian would save almost the whole of his wages.
('3', 434, 2, 16, 989772) Moreover, year after year, if the principle of compulsory repatriation were accepted, India would have to support an Indian population used to a comparatively more expen sive style of living, and the result would be that, instead of identured immigration under the conditions proposed being a blessing, it would be a veritable curse even to the labourers themselves.

('3', 435, 2, 12, 991903) 287. THE DEALERS’ LICENSES ACT
('3', 435, 3, 13, 991934) The Durban Town Council has once more proved what a terrible engine of oppression the Dealers’ Licenses Act is to the traders.
('3', 435, 3, 14, 992061) One Mr. J. M. Woolfson has been in trade for the last three years, as appe ars from the proceedings.
('3', 435, 3, 15, 992162) This year, however, the Licensing Officer took it into his head to refuse to renew his license.
('3', 435, 3, 16, 992258) No reasons were given for it, and the aggrieved trader, therefore, procured Mr. Ask ew’s services and has gone through the farce of an appeal which is provided for in the Act.
('3', 435, 3, 17, 992434) Mr. Askew was, however, groping in the dark as he did not know on what grounds his client’s bread had been taken away from him.
('3', 435, 3, 18, 992562) He had only guessed that his client’s books were not properly kept, and now wanted to know definitely whether that was the cause for refusal.
('3', 435, 3, 19, 992704) The Mayor, therefore, called for the report of the Licensing Officer, but Mr. Askew was not to see it as it was “pri vileged”.
('3', 435, 3, 20, 992831) In vain did Mr. Askew protest until he found in Mr. Burne a Councillor who was not prepared to sit still and be a party to the cruel
('3', 436, 0, 1, 992964) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 437
('3', 436, 1, 2, 993005) injustice of condemning a man unheard.
('3', 436, 1, 3, 993044) On the Mayor protesting that the document in question could not be divulged, Mr. Burne threa tened that he would not in the future sit in appeal if the Mayor persis ted in his objection.
('3', 436, 1, 4, 993231) This was a threat which His Worship could not disregard and, therefore [he] effected a compromise by saying that the matter would be considered in committee.
('3', 436, 1, 5, 993389) Mr Askew, therefore, rightly intervened and said that they were going back to the Middle Ages.
('3', 436, 1, 6, 993484) For our part, we do not know that even in the Middle Ages such a shocking state of affairs was allowed in the teeth of well laid down legal procedure: surely, if a man has a right to appeal, he ought to have a right to see the documents which are on record.
('3', 436, 1, 7, 993742) Mr. Justice Mason, in deciding the case of Somnath 1 quoted by Mr. Askew, pas sed some trenchant remarks on the high handed action of the Town Council, some years ago, in refusing to allow the appellant to have access to the record or in considering anything in committee, that is behind the back of the appellant.
('3', 436, 1, 8, 994057) However, in [to] committee the Town Council did go on this occasion, and, after having been in labour for some time.
('3', 436, 1, 9, 994174) They brought forth the proposal that Mr. Askew might look at the record.
('3', 436, 1, 10, 994247) It was laconic enough!
('3', 436, 1, 11, 994270) “Books unsatis factory; license refused.” Mr. Askew then produced evidence to shew that the books were kept by a competent book keeper and that, therefore, the Town Council should exercise its jurisdiction and order the Licensing Officer to issue a license.
('3', 436, 1, 12, 994528) The Town Council, however, was not to be so easily induced to do justice.
('3', 436, 1, 13, 994602) It, therefore, dismissed the appeal but suggested to Mr. Askew that he should renew his application to the Licensing Officer.
('3', 436, 1, 14, 994728) That the Town Council of the premier and model borough in South Afirica should thus disgrace itself and make a confession of its incapacity to take an unbiassed view of cases that may come before it sitting as a Court of Appeal, is, in the face of it, a sad reflection; but it is not at all suprising.
('3', 436, 1, 15, 995030) The fault lies with the Legislature.
('3', 436, 1, 16, 995067) It has chosen to give most arbitrary powers to the Town Councils, and even the Town Council of a well regulated place like Durban could not resist the temptation to use such powers when there are no salutary checks against its abuse.
('3', 436, 1, 17, 995301) The members who sit in appeal are not trained in law.
('3', 436, 1, 18, 995355) Some of them are rival traders, and it is not fair to expect them to give an impartial decision when their own interests are involved.
('3', 436, 2, 19, 995490) 1Vide “The Grievances of the British Indians in South Africa: An appeal to the Indian Public”, 14 8 1896
('3', 437, 0, 1, 995595) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('3', 439, 2, 11, 1001293) 290. IMMIGRATION RESTRICTION REPORT
('3', 439, 3, 12, 1001329) We give in another column the main points of the interesting, exhaustive, and able report drawn by Mr. Smith 1 and presented to the Honourable the Colonial Secretary.
('3', 439, 3, 13, 1001496) Before proceeding to examine the different points, we venture to draw Mr. Smith’s attention to what appears to us to be the one fault of his otherwise unexceptionable summary of the year’s work in restricting immigration into the Colony.
('3', 439, 3, 14, 1001734) Mr. Smith has a vigorous style of writing, but, with all deference, it is hardly becoming in an Official report to adopt a theatrical or newspaper style.
('3', 439, 3, 15, 1001888) Speaking of the complaints of delay on the part of passengers at the time of examination, he says:
('3', 439, 4, 16, 1001987) Facts are of little account to the man with a grievance associated with the landing basket and a sixty minutes’s wait in a tug at the anchorage in fresh weather.
('3', 439, 4, 17, 1002149) The circumstance that the officer in question may have finished his work and be himself anxiously waiting to get ashore is unknown to him.
('3', 439, 4, 18, 1002288) He has heard someone (probably a returned Colonist) speak dispargingly of the Department, and he takes the tune with facility.
('3', 439, 4, 19, 1002415) Full of uncharitable feelings, he hurries to his hotel to write and dispatch to the Press a commentary on the shortcomings of the Department, and to exercise his altruistic instincts in the framing of impracticable suggestions for the amelioration of the lot of future passengers.
('3', 439, 4, 20, 1002696) Take, again, the following:
('3', 439, 5, 21, 1002724) I have already shown the futility of expecting any relief from passengers who
('3', 439, 6, 22, 1002802) 1 Harry Smith, Immigration Restriction Officer.
('3', 440, 0, 1, 1002850) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 441
('3', 440, 1, 2, 1002891) ‘know the ropes.’ The report is ínterspersed with such racy paragraphs which no doubt make interesting reading, but, in our opinion, are out of place in a matter of fact document, such as official reports should be.
('3', 440, 1, 3, 1003107) Mor eover, the style adopted betrays irritation on the part of Mr. Smith, who is othrwise not easily upset and who is universally courteous to those who have any dealings with his office.
('3', 440, 1, 4, 1003295) We think that the public have a perfect right to make complaints.
('3', 440, 1, 5, 1003361) Some times the complaints are unreasonable, often expressed in forcible language, and occasion ally exaggerated.
('3', 440, 1, 6, 1003474) Unfortunately, that is a state of things that cannot be corrected and on the principle that “what cannot be cured should be endured”, officers who have to perform unpleasant duties are expec ted to tolerate such things from the public and not ridicule them.
('3', 440, 1, 7, 1003732) We do not at all mean to convey that Mr. Smith should not have attem pted a reply to the complaint.
('3', 440, 1, 8, 1003832) Our objection is to the manner in which it is done.
('3', 440, 1, 9, 1003884) Coming to the report itself, Mr. Smith, in his opening paragr aph, takes pardonable pride in the fact that the original Immigration Restriction Act 1897 “has been repealed and been substituted by the new and more comprehensive measure on the lines which I (he) had the honour of suggesting”.
('3', 440, 1, 10, 1004176) To us, it is not easy to see why there should be any ocasion for glory in the fact.
('3', 440, 1, 11, 1004260) To refuse entrance to men who may come to the Colony for the purpose of earing a livelihood, and whose only fault is probably their poverty or their skin, could at no time be a pleasant duty, and it must be particularly painful to a man of Mr. Smiths’s generous temperament.
('3', 440, 1, 12, 1004535) We find in his report that he succeeded in shutting out 6,763 would be immigrants, of whom 3,244 were British Indians, including 24 females and 37 children, Of course, the Immigration Act being the law of the Colony, and Mr. Smith being the officer entrusted with the work of enforcing it, he could not but turn away the men who did not fulfil the test applied under the Act, but it shews how harsh the law itself is and with what terrible effect it is telling on the British Indians, for it should be remembered that these men had undergone a long voyage, and had probably invested all they had in taking out a passage for Natal, thinking that they would not be prohibited from landing in a British Colony.
('3', 440, 1, 13, 1005243) In spite of the Act, which has hardly reached the ears of the millions of India, the people there cannot assimilate the doctrine that there could be differences in the nature of their rights as citizens of the Empire under the same flag in different parts of it.
('3', 441, 0, 1, 1005506) 442 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 441, 1, 2, 1005548) The immigrants admitted after examination were 1,869 Indians, including 195 females and 499 children, 21 Chinese, I Egyptian, 38 Greeks, 8 Singalese, 1 Syrian and 8 Turks, Of the Indians admitted, 158 passed the educational test.
('3', 441, 1, 3, 1005778) This is less than one tenth of the total admitted.
('3', 441, 1, 4, 1005829) It may be here remarked that the new Act has only just come into operation, and the next report from Mr. Smith will, we very much fear, shew us considerable decrease in the number of those who would have passed the educational test.
('3', 441, 1, 5, 1006062) Mr. Smith gives the interesting information that
('3', 441, 2, 6, 1006111) during the twelve months, some 269 certificates (of domicile) were conficated and the men who produced them sent about their business.
('3', 441, 2, 7, 1006246) Seeing that thousands of such certificates are now in vogue, the number of certificates improperly used is remarkably small.
('3', 441, 2, 8, 1006371) All the same, it shews that the Legislature in its wisdom has put a temptation in the way of the public to evade the law.
('3', 441, 2, 9, 1006493) That is the history of all restrictive legislation throughout the world, and it is especially so when it is restriction of personal freedom and pesonal movements.
('3', 441, 2, 10, 1006656) The report would have been more complete if Mr. Smith had included in his summary the grounds on which intending immigrants have been debarred from entering the Colony.
('3', 441, 2, 11, 1006825) Another thing also seems to have been omitted from the report, namely, that British Ind ians who entered the Colony after 1897 after having passed the exa mination under the Department are being turned out of the Colony although they may have settled.
('3', 441, 2, 12, 1007077) While we may not say much against a ruthless carrying out of the law so far as new immigrants are con cerned, we do feel that the Department will be going a little too far in attempting to drive away men who are already established in the Colony.
('3', 441, 2, 13, 1007324) It is hardly fair to hound decent people out of the Colony as if they were criminals, especially when it is known that the very Department which allowed them to enter the Colony is driving them away.
('3', 441, 2, 14, 1007524) We would not go into the question of how and why they suc ceeded in establishing themselves after 1897. Although they did not fully satisfy the requirements of the law, the fact stands the they have not stolen into the country, but that they entered after having been properly examined by the officers engaged to do the work under Mr. Smith.
('3', 441, 2, 15, 1007866) We, therefore trust that Mr. Smith would be pleased to stay his hand so far as the British Indian residents of the Colony are concer ned, no matter whether they were in the Colony before 1897 or not.

('3', 442, 1, 2, 1008133) 291. THE ASIATIC TRADERS COMMISSION
('3', 442, 2, 3, 1008169) The British Indian traders have before them a very difficult task about submitting their claims rearding vested interests created before the war, and in view of the fact that the Commission is to hold its preliminary meeting on the 14th instant, it may not be amiss to study the reference to the Commission.
('3', 442, 2, 4, 1008477) It is wide enough in its scope, but in this instance the fact that the terms are so general gives rise to many intricacies and to the question: what are to be treated as vested interests?
('3', 442, 2, 5, 1008665) In the first place, the Commissioners are to
('3', 442, 3, 6, 1008710) consider the cases of certain Asiatics and to enquire and report as to the number of such traders, and the nature and value of the vested interests claimed by them in respect of their having been allowed to trade outside locations.
('3', 442, 3, 7, 1008942) Thus, the Commissioners have no power to deal with the trading question at all, but merely to submit a report to His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor.
('3', 442, 3, 8, 1009095) The strict interpretation of the reference would appear to be that they are not even to value the vested interests or to determine their nature, but merely to report what the Asiatics may have to say on these points.
('3', 442, 3, 9, 1009312) If so, the question is very simple.
('3', 442, 3, 10, 1009348) All that the British Indians have to do is to state in what manner, where, and how long they have been trading, whether they had partners or not, and what value they place upon their good will and business because vested interests would include not only the actual price of the goods in which they dealt on the outbreak of war, but also the price of good will.
('3', 442, 3, 11, 1009709) It is, however, in putting a valuation on it that the greatest difficulty will arise.
('3', 442, 3, 12, 1009795) Then comes the most thorny question as to who are the Asitics that would be allowed to file their claims.
('3', 442, 3, 13, 1009901) We know that, according to the terms of reference, they are defined as
('3', 442, 4, 14, 1009972) those who were trading in the Transvaal in towns outside locations without license at and immediately before the outbreak of hostilities.
('3', 442, 4, 15, 1010110) A British Indian, therefore, before he can file his claim, has to prove 1 that he was trading in the Transvaal; 2 that he was trading outside Locations; 3 that he held no license; 4 that he was trading at the outbreak of hostilities; 5 that he was trading also immediately before the outbreak of hostilities.
('3', 443, 0, 1, 1010419) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 443, 1, 2, 1010461) If we are not mistaken, “and” occurring after “at” should read ör” in the above quotation, because the whole of the debate in the Legislative Council went to shew that the intention was to respect the rights of those who either traded actually at the outbreak of hostilities or immediately before.
('3', 443, 1, 3, 1010759) And yet we find that the claimants, in accor dance with the reference, have to shew that they were not only trading at but also immediately before the outbreak of hostilities.
('3', 443, 1, 4, 1010935) To put the difficulty in a concrete form, it means that, according to the reference, it is not enough that an Indian was trading, say, in the month of June 1899 and left the Transvaal owing to the prospect of war, but he should also prove that he was actually engaged in trade on the 11th of October, 1899. And if the terms are strictly adhered to, hundreds of claimants would be simply brushed aside.
('3', 443, 1, 5, 1011337) We have mentioned these difficulties in order to shew the expensive nature of the work before the British Indians.
('3', 443, 1, 6, 1011452) The test case is to be heard before the Supreme Court very shortly.
('3', 443, 1, 7, 1011520) If the result is favourable to the Indian community, the Indian traders need not go to the expense of filing their claims at all.
('3', 443, 1, 8, 1011650) But they are on the horns of a dilemma.
('3', 443, 1, 9, 1011690) It is not certain when the case will be heard.
('3', 443, 1, 10, 1011737) The Commissioners have fixed the 15th of this month as the irrevocable date before which the claims are to be filed.
('3', 443, 1, 11, 1011854) The British Indian Association, we understand, have approached the Commissio ners for an adjournment.
('3', 443, 1, 12, 1011956) The request seems to us to be extremely rea sonable.
('3', 443, 1, 13, 1012009) On the other hand, the Commissioners have a duty to per form; they must report to the Lieutenant Governor with all dispatch.
('3', 443, 1, 14, 1012134) The appointment of the Commission was made before the test case was brought, and unless His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor authorises the Government to postpone their deliberations until the case is decided, we can quite understand that the Commisioners would find themselves in an awkward predicament in deciding upon the req uest for an adjournment.
('3', 443, 1, 15, 1012490) Yet it would be simply cruel to expect the Indian traders to file their claims when they have every hope of avoiding the inconvenience and the expense attendant thereupon in view of the test case.
('3', 443, 1, 16, 1012687) It is, therefore, to be trusted that the Commi sioners will be able to cut the Gordian knot and do justice to the Ind ians consistently with the duty imposed upon them by His Excellency the Lieutentant Governor.
('3', 443, 1, 17, 1012899) Indian Opnion, 10 3 1904
('3', 444, 0, 1, 1012924) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 445
('3', 444, 1, 2, 1012965) 292. LOGICAL
('3', 444, 2, 3, 1012978) We have already dealt with the action of the Municipal Confer ence 1 at Johannesburg with reference to Mr. Constable’s proposal that all Asiatic traders should be removed to Locations, subject to compen sation being paid only to those who held licenses to trade outside bazaars or Locations before war.
('3', 444, 2, 4, 1013281) Our contemporary, the South African Guardian has a very reasonable article on it the logic of which is irresistible.
('3', 444, 2, 5, 1013398) The Guardian rightly states that, if there is to be an invasion from China in the shape of slaves, there could be no ground for harassing a handful of British Indian traders, and the argument receives very great force from the fact that Boksburg, on behalf of which Mr. Constable spoke, has decided in favour of the Chinese invasion.
('3', 444, 2, 6, 1013732) We give the argument in our contemporary’s own words:
('3', 444, 3, 7, 1013786) The lack of principle inspiring this movement is shown by the fact that it was pressed forward by Boksburg traders, who have been most active in advocating the introduction of hordes of Chinese into the Transvaal under restrictions which preclude them from trading.
('3', 444, 3, 8, 1014052) These men are not concerned with the moral well being of the community, all they wish is that trade shall be diverted into their establishments which at present goes to the Indians.
('3', 444, 3, 9, 1014234) While advocating the introduction of 100,000 or more Mongolians, who will corrrupt and debase the national life they urge that a few Indian traders shall be compelled to forgo opposition to their trade, and that the people of the Transvaal shall provide opposition compensation.
('3', 444, 3, 10, 1014513) The people of the Trans vaal might well do this to separate Asiatics from Europeans, and to prevent, as far as possible, race contamination.
('3', 444, 3, 11, 1014654) If, however, the Chinese are to come in their tens of thousands, all hope of maintaining a high standard of civili zation in the Transvaal must be abandoned, and the presence of Indian traders will be a minor evil compared with that which has been so enthusiastically endorsed by the traders of Boksburg.
('3', 444, 3, 12, 1014959) If these gentlemen think that, having abandoned principle, they can obtain something which can only be urged with success on the grounds of that high expediency which demands the prevention of race contamination, they are, we fancy, doomed to disappoint ment.
('3', 444, 3, 13, 1015219) It would be an injustice to the taxpayer to call upon him to provide compensation for Indian traders denied the right to trade in a Mongolian community.
('3', 444, 3, 14, 1015372) It has been proclaimed that it is the will of the people of the Transvaal that Asiatic labour should be made the basis of its prosperity.
('3', 444, 3, 15, 1015510) If this should come about, the loss sustained by white traders in competition with coloured will not be a matter of any particular importance.

('3', 447, 3, 13, 1022761) 294. FOOT PATHS AGAIN
('3', 447, 4, 14, 1022783) Ever since the British occupation of the Transvaal, represen tations have been persistently made to the Government regarding the anti Asiatic laws of the country among which is the old Town Regul ation preventing Coloured persons from using the side walks.
('3', 447, 4, 15, 1023040) Last year, the British Indian Association drew the Lieutenant Governors attention to this Regulation, and His Excellency said that he did not want to deal with the anti Asiatic legislation haphazard, but that the whole question would be dealt with together.
('3', 447, 4, 16, 1023298) In the meanwhile, he assured the deputation that waited on him that British Indians would
('3', 448, 0, 1, 1023388) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 449
('3', 448, 1, 2, 1023429) not be molested by the police.
('3', 448, 1, 3, 1023460) News has, however, arrived from the Transvaal that the Commissioner of Police has issued instructions for the enforcement of the Foot path Bye law, the reason for the sudden departure is this.
('3', 448, 1, 4, 1023653) A Kaffir is alleged to have misbehaved himself.
('3', 448, 1, 5, 1023701) The case came before Mr. Van Der Berg, and he (the Kaffir) was dis charged.
('3', 448, 1, 6, 1023777) Some interested parties thought that it was a miscarriage of justice.
('3', 448, 1, 7, 1023847) Letters, most passionately worded, were sent to the Press.
('3', 448, 1, 8, 1023906) The Leader encourged the agitation by opening its columns and advo cating a stringent anti Native policy.
('3', 448, 1, 9, 1024012) The result is what we see, and if any regulations are to be enforced against the Natives, other Coloured people including Indians are covered by them as a matter of course.
('3', 448, 1, 10, 1024185) Lord Milner has declined to draw the distinction, and the Indians have to suffer.
('3', 448, 1, 11, 1024267) Indeed, the Commissioner of Police has been pleased to add to the instructions that Coloured persons of the better class and Natives exempted under Ordinacce 28 of 1902 are not to be inter fered with.
('3', 448, 1, 12, 1024468) The police, therefore, will have a very invidious duty to perform.
('3', 448, 1, 13, 1024535) They will have to become experts in knowing Coloured people of the better class from others.
('3', 448, 1, 14, 1024628) Evidently, there is no test laid down as to what is to constitute a Coloured person of the better class.
('3', 448, 1, 15, 1024733) The matter will, therefore, be left to the absolute discretion of the police.
('3', 448, 1, 16, 1024811) It does not seem to have struck the Commissioner of Police that such instructions are bound to create a great deal of irritation and inconvenience.
('3', 448, 1, 17, 1024959) Rather than having regulations which are so very indefinite in their scope, it would be infinitely better for all concerned to enforce the regulations as they are and prevent any Coloured per son from using the foot paths.
('3', 448, 1, 18, 1025182) It may be a drastic remedy, but if the anti Coloured Policy is to be followed up by the Transvaal Govern ment, we see no other solution.
('3', 448, 1, 19, 1025319) The latest regulations are one more illustration of how the complaint of the British Indian Association that the old laws of the Transvaal against the Asiatics are far more severely enforced now than before is being justified, for it should be noted that the foot path regulations were totally a dead letter during the Boer regime so far as the British Indians were concerrned.

('3', 450, 3, 6, 1027832) 296. INTERVIEW TO “THE STAR” 1
('3', 450, 4, 7, 1027863) JOHANNESBURG, March 21, 1904 Mr. M. K. Gandhi, the well known Indian advocate, who has acted on two Plague Committees, and was a volunteer nurse of plague patients for two years, interviewed by a representative of The Star this morning, said that the Indian community warned the proper autho rities of what were very suspicious indications about two months ago.
('3', 450, 4, 8, 1028225) Subsequently, another communication was sent to Dr. Porter, stating that plague symptoms had developed.
('3', 450, 4, 9, 1028329) Four days later, Mr. Gandhi stated that he received a letter from Dr. Porter to the effect that the health officer had failed to find any indication in substantiation of the statement.
('3', 450, 4, 10, 1028514) On Friday, however, Mr. Gandhi was informed that number of Indians “dead or dying” were being “dumped” down in the Lo cation by rickshaws.
('3', 450, 4, 11, 1028653) After informing the authorities, Mr. Gandhi, accompanied by Dr. Godfrey, Dr. Pereira and a health inspector, visted the suspected area, and on entering a house which the Indian community had themselves isolated, they discovered 14 patients.
('3', 450, 4, 12, 1028894) Voluntary subscriptions had been taken up amongst the Indians, and the patients had been made comparatively comfortable under the supervision of a number of volunteer male nurses.
('3', 450, 4, 13, 1029074) Dr. Godfrey at once took control of the improvised hospital, and arranged that there should be a medical attendant present through the night.
('3', 450, 4, 14, 1029216) On Saturday morning, Mr. Gandhi states that the Town Clerk visited him, and said that, while he could not undertake any financial responsibility on behalf of the Town Council, he would as requested, grant the use of the Government Entrepot, Station Road, as a temporary hospital, and that Dr. MacKenzie, the District Surgeon, would supervise the arrange ments, leaving the details to Dr. Godfrey.

('3', 450, 5, 16, 1029642) 1 This was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 24 3 1904.

('3', 451, 1, 2, 1029736) premises offered were cleaned, disinfected, 25 beds brought in, and by 3.30 o’clock the patients had been admitted.
('3', 451, 1, 3, 1029852) Dr. MacKenzie had arranged that Sister West should be sent over from the nurses quarters to superintend the work of the male nurses.
('3', 451, 1, 4, 1029985) Medical opinion was not at that time made up as to what the symptoms indicated, but, by reason of the virulence of the disease, Dr. MacKenzie subsequently came to the conclusion that the patients were suffering from pneumonic plague.

('3', 451, 1, 6, 1030340) Continuing, Mr. Gandhi said that the Indian community had done everything it possibly could to prevent the spread of the outbreak, and up to the present every case had been reported by it.
('3', 451, 1, 7, 1030529) Speaking as a layman, Mr. Gandhi considered that, if proper precautions were taken, there should be no spread of the disease.
('3', 451, 1, 8, 1030655) He had been nursing in quarters where there had been extraordinary mortality from plague, owing to the great care exercised by those who came in contact with the patients, the disease had been confined to the isolated spot.

('3', 451, 2, 15, 1031678) 297. BRITISH INDIAN ENTERPRISE
('3', 451, 3, 16, 1031709) Our contemporary, The Natal Advertiser, has published from its special correspondent a communication dealing with the question of British Indian landowners in the County of Victoria.
('3', 451, 3, 17, 1031892) The correspondent is very wroth that Indians should hold any land whatsoever in Natal.
('3', 451, 3, 18, 1031979) Unfortunately for him, the arguments and the facts adduced by him all go to shew that the settlement of Indians in that County and the holding by them of land have been a great
('3', 452, 0, 1, 1032156) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 453
('3', 452, 1, 2, 1032197) boon to the County itself.
('3', 452, 1, 3, 1032224) Before we deal with the facts stated in the communication, we would take the liberty of correcting an error.
('3', 452, 1, 4, 1032333) The writer of the article thinks that a very large quantity of land has passed into the hands of the Indians.
('3', 452, 1, 5, 1032443) We may, however, state that up to now the bulk of the land is still owned by the Europeans.
('3', 452, 1, 6, 1032535) The vast plantations are theirs and so are the magnificent mansions which have become possible owing to Indian labour.
('3', 452, 1, 7, 1032654) And, surely, a path of land here and there in the hands of Indians would not justify the alarm that the writer evidently intends to raise.
('3', 452, 1, 8, 1032793) In any case, however, what has the writer got to say in disparagement of the Indians?
('3', 452, 1, 9, 1032879) He says:
('3', 452, 2, 10, 1032888) Anyone who travels over the district.
('3', 452, 2, 11, 1032926) will find no difficulty in admitting that.
('3', 452, 2, 12, 1032969) this is at least the most diligently cultivated district in the Colony.
('3', 452, 2, 13, 1033041) A few years ago, the North Coast belt had not this prosperous appea rance.
('3', 452, 2, 14, 1033116) Before so much land came under cultivation, at this time of the year about all that could be seen between the Umgeni and the Tugela was great stre tches of veldt browned with summer sun.
('3', 452, 2, 15, 1033303) Today the area of natural grass is becoming insignificant and that, with the abundant rains, is as green as spring verdure, while the crops approaching maturity are said never to have been so prolific.
('3', 452, 2, 16, 1033505) One would have considered that such a state of things woul be a cause for congratulation, but the writer considers that it is depl orable because the prosperity of the County is due to Indian enter prise.
('3', 452, 2, 17, 1033710) He would rather see the County barren and devoid of any population than see it green and yielding any splendid revenue to the Colony, making it possible for hundreds of princely European farmers to enjoy themselves.
('3', 452, 2, 18, 1033926) The writer, moreover, admits that much of the land is leased out to the Indians by the Europeans, that is to say, the European farmers are unable themselves to make the land pay unless they are to employ Indian agriculturalists to till it.
('3', 452, 2, 19, 1034166) Again, it should be remembered that, after all, if it has been possible for the Indian to own any land at all, it is due to the sale by the original Euro pean owners, and in spite of the correspondent of our contemporary calling them unpatriotic on that score, unbiased people would consider that it was not only a benefit to the sellers but also to the community in general that they, by giving the Indian an opportunity of working on the soil, have added to the prosperity of the Colony.
('3', 452, 2, 20, 1034656) The arguments and facts advanced by the correspondent, in our humble opinion, shew deplorable weakness of mind and a lack of appreciation of economic policy.
('3', 452, 2, 21, 1034814) Well behaved, sober, industrious
('3', 453, 0, 1, 1034847) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 453, 1, 2, 1034889) people would be considered a valuable asset in any community.
('3', 453, 1, 3, 1034951) It is only in the Colonies where a dog in the manger policy is the ruling passion that we hear an outcry against such people.
('3', 453, 1, 4, 1035077) After all, we imagine that a community bereft of simple living and industrious people would not be able for long to hold its own and turn the resources of the land upon which it lives to good account.

('3', 453, 2, 6, 1035304) 298. PLAGUE IN JOHANNESBURG 1
('3', 453, 3, 7, 1035334) THE GREAT WORK OF THE INDIAN COMMUNITY The Plague had been discovered (it would not be correct to say it had broken out) in Johannesburg nearly two months ago.
('3', 453, 3, 8, 1035494) The Indians gave the warning to the authorities2 that they must expect an epidemic unless they remedied the condition that the so called Insan itary Area had assumed after the Town Council took possession, for, after the 26th September, tenants were accepted by the Town Council within that area irrespective of the size of the buildings let.
('3', 453, 3, 9, 1035837) There has, therefore, taken place overcrowding that defies description.
('3', 453, 3, 10, 1035909) Add to this the increase in insanitation owing to inability of the Council to keep the premises clean.
('3', 453, 3, 11, 1036012) The responsibility having been taken out of the hands of the Stand owners, they were powerless to control fifty or more people living on each Stand.
('3', 453, 3, 12, 1036161) Before the 26th September last year, the owners of 96 Stands in the Indian Location, for instance, were liable for proper sanitation; when the Town Council assumed control, it therefore meant the employing of at least 96 topazes.
('3', 453, 3, 13, 1036391) This the Council could not or would not do; anyhow, the area that never was so insanitary as to call for expropriation has been made so by the Council.
('3', 453, 3, 14, 1036543) Hence the necessity for the warning above referred to.
('3', 453, 3, 15, 1036598) On top of this, came the recent phenomenal wet weather which gave rise to acute pneumonia, which can easily become infectious: and this disease, finding suitable soil in the Insanitary Area, assumed a very deadly form and became the pneumonic plague.
('3', 453, 3, 16, 1036849) As soon as such cases occurred, the authorities were again informed.
('3', 453, 3, 17, 1036918) But after 4 days’ investigation they came to the conclusion that they were brought to the Location in a dying condition.
('3', 453, 3, 18, 1037039) The matter was again reported to the authorities.
('3', 453, 3, 19, 1037089) But the community now took the matter in its own hands also.
('3', 453, 3, 20, 1037150) It realised that red tape might prevent prompt action.
('3', 453, 4, 21, 1037205) 1 This appeared as “From our own Correspondent”.
('3', 453, 4, 22, 1037254) 2 Vide “Letter to Dr. Porter”, February 11, 1904.
('3', 454, 0, 1, 1037304) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 455
('3', 454, 1, 2, 1037345) Medical assistance was promptly rendered to the patients.
('3', 454, 1, 3, 1037403) Dr. God frey, who had just come from Glasgow, placed his services freely at the disposal of the community.
('3', 454, 1, 4, 1037510) Later the same day (Friday), the Health Inspector came on the scene and gave a helping hand, still being unable to take up official responsibility.
('3', 454, 1, 5, 1037658) Some buildings were commandeered and temporarily turned into a hospital.
('3', 454, 1, 6, 1037731) Those who witnessed the scenes at this hospital, patients who should never have been ill suffering agony, Dr. Godfrey, Mr. Madanjit, and young educated Indians becoming at much risk nurses and carefully atten ding to the 14 patients who were crowded into the small rooms, and the patients dying one after another, would never forget the sight at once ghastly and inspiring—ghastly, because of the grim tragedy, and inspiring, because the event showed the ability of the community to rise to the occasion and to organise.
('3', 454, 1, 7, 1038252) While the patients were being looked after on one Stand, a very largely attended mass meeting was going on on another Stand.
('3', 454, 1, 8, 1038377) Nearly £ 1,000 were subscribed by the rich and the poor in order that a permanent hospital may be erected for the use of the community.
('3', 454, 1, 9, 1038513) The manner in which the poor men came forward with subscriptions reflects the greatest credit on them.
('3', 454, 1, 10, 1038616) On Saturday morning, the authortities seemed to grasp the situ ation.
('3', 454, 1, 11, 1038686) They provided a large warehouse, the old Customs House, as a temporary hospital, the Town Clerk still declining to undertake any financial responsibility for the time being and leaving it to the comm unity to find beds, mattresses, etc.
('3', 454, 1, 12, 1038923) The Indians, however, could not afford to calculate the £.s.d.
('3', 454, 1, 13, 1038986) and took [over] the managership.
('3', 454, 1, 14, 1039019) The District Surgeon very kindly provided a very good trained nurse, and at last five out of twenty five patients have been removed to the lazaretto and the outbreak of the plague has been officially declared.
('3', 454, 1, 15, 1039229) Thus, it has required an ocular demostration of poor men dying like flies to enable the Town Council to come up to the scratch.
('3', 454, 1, 16, 1039357) And yet no one indvidual is to blame; for every one as such has been anxious to do good.
('3', 454, 1, 17, 1039446) It is the soulless bulky corporation wound up in red tape and nurtured on theory that must be held blameable for the ghastly tragedy.
('3', 454, 1, 18, 1039580) A cordon is now drawn round the Location, though there are cases of plague in other districts also.
('3', 454, 1, 19, 1039680) But the Indian community is bearing its troubles with a heroic patience worthy of its traditions.

('3', 457, 2, 4, 1043910) 300. THE PLAGUE
('3', 457, 3, 5, 1043926) The plague has after all broken out in Johannesburg.
('3', 457, 3, 6, 1043979) It has claimed already about 60 victims, of whom 46 are Asiatics, six whites and four Natives.
('3', 457, 3, 7, 1044074) The mortality has been practically cent per cent.
('3', 457, 3, 8, 1044124) This is an appalling fact.
('3', 457, 3, 9, 1044151) It is not so in India, and has not been so in South Africa before.
('3', 457, 3, 10, 1044218) The type in Johannesburg, therefore, is the deadliest yet known.
('3', 457, 3, 11, 1044283) The victims, again have been carried away in an incredibly short time.
('3', 457, 3, 12, 1044354) What at first appear to be a slight fever and a little coughing, in a few hours, or the second day, develop into high fever, spitting of blood, and violent paroxysms.
('3', 457, 3, 13, 1044521) The suffering of the patient is terrible.
('3', 457, 3, 14, 1044563) Delirium and death follow the third day.
('3', 457, 3, 15, 1044604) During the last stages, the patient gets so exhausted that, even though one notices intense agony on his face, the poor sufferer is not able to give it speech.
('3', 457, 3, 16, 1044764) Our correspondent has stated the cause for it.
('3', 457, 3, 17, 1044811) The Public Health Committee of Johannesburg has now risen to the occasion; but this fact does not  [it] cannotabsolve it from blame for the past neglect.
('3', 457, 3, 18, 1044967) The timely warning given to it through the letter addressed to Dr. Porter, which, we understand, was passed on to the Chairman, was unheeded.
('3', 457, 3, 19, 1045109) Valuable time was wasted in wrangling about a site.
('3', 457, 3, 20, 1045161) The Town Council collectors, in the meanwhile, continued to pack the Insanitary Area with tenants irrespective of the rules relating to overcrowding.
('3', 457, 3, 21, 1045311) Sanitation was totally neglected, individual tenants being unable to do anything in the matter.
('3', 457, 3, 22, 1045407) The people of the Transvaal are now paying dearly for it.
('3', 457, 3, 23, 1045465) We would, however, much rather bury the dead past.
('3', 457, 3, 24, 1045516) Pakes and MacKenzie, 1 Special Plague Officers, are grappling with the scourge with great courage and devotion.
('3', 457, 3, 25, 1045628) The Committee having realised the danger is unsparing in its efforts and has wisely given unlimited powers to the worthy doctors who are assisted by a good staff of inspectors.
('3', 457, 3, 26, 1045805) They have got it well under control, and by this time the plague has lost its terrors.
('3', 457, 3, 27, 1045892) The Public Health Committee has thus expiated for its laches.
('3', 457, 3, 28, 1045954) It is however sad to have to confess that the Indian community cannot be held free from blame.
('3', 457, 3, 29, 1046049) The Nemesis that has overtaken it more than any other community is, we fear, more

('3', 458, 1, 2, 1046243) or less deserved.
('3', 458, 1, 3, 1046261) They ought to have protested against neglected sanitation and overcrowding.
('3', 458, 1, 4, 1046337) That the Town Council allowed such a state of things is no excuse.
('3', 458, 1, 5, 1046404) While we are the first to defend our countrymen from violent attacks and exaggerated charges often brought in order to make political capital, we would not be true to our profession if we failed to apportion the blame without flinching.

('3', 458, 2, 17, 1047948) 301. THE ASIATIC TRADERS’ COMMISSION IN THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 458, 3, 18, 1048002) We reproduce in another column from the Johannesburg Lea der a report of the proceedings of the Asiatic Traders’ Commission at its first regular meeting held on the 16th March.
('3', 458, 3, 19, 1048179) The Commissioners have ruled that they have no authority to examine the claims of those British Indian traders who are not in a position to prove that they were trading outside Locations with licenses on the eve of the war and that they were obliged to leave their business owing to the outbreak of war; that is to say, men who were
('3', 459, 0, 1, 1048512) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 459, 1, 2, 1048554) engaged in trade for fifteen years in the Transvaal but who disposed of their businesses in, say, August of 1899 would have no status before the Commissioners; and, if the report of the Commissioners under the restricted Reference is to be the end of the matter, then hundreds of Indians who are now trading under licenses will be deprived of their right to trade, and will consequently be totally ruined.
('3', 459, 1, 3, 1048960) Hard, however, as the ruling appears to be, the Commissioners had absolutely no choice.
('3', 459, 1, 4, 1049048) In fact, we had already prepared our readers for it when we dealt with the question some time ago.
('3', 459, 1, 5, 1049147) 1 The wording of the Reference leaves no loop hole; it merely states that the Com missioners are to consider the cases of those who were trading without licenses outside Locations at, and immediately before, the outbreak of hostilities.
('3', 459, 1, 6, 1049384) We hope that the Government, when it drafted the Ref erence, never contemplated any such result, for the Colonial Secretary, as also Lord Milner, has repeatedly said that it is not the intention of the Government to disturb the trade of those Indians who were carrying it on prior to the war, whether with or without licenses.
('3', 459, 1, 7, 1049711) There can be absolutely no distinction between those few Indians who managed to get licenses to trade in 1899 and those who did not but were yet trading.
('3', 459, 1, 8, 1049865) In the estimation of the Boer Government, they were doing so illegally, but the illegality was created and fostered by the British Government to which the Law 3 of 1885 was absolutely hate ful.
('3', 459, 1, 9, 1050059) Indians, therefore, were allowed, during the fifteen years prece ding the war, to have confidence in the British protection; so much so, that they left the Transvaal and re entered at will, established busi nesses, desposed of them and re established them, also at will.
('3', 459, 1, 10, 1050330) A vested interest, therefore, was created in the right to trade outside Locations in defiance of the law, and although it is undoubtedly an extraordi nary state of things, it is nevertheless a fact.
('3', 459, 1, 11, 1050529) While such a situation was in vogue, the war broke out, and “one of the causes of the war was the law 3 of 1885”.
('3', 459, 1, 12, 1050643) Indians, therefore, very naturally thought that the successful issue of the war would see the end of the law, and it follows that, if the British Indians could trade in defiance of the Law at any time before 1899, they have now a stronger claim, for it does not in the slightest degree matter whether they were trading im mediately before the war or not.
('3', 459, 1, 13, 1050998) The test is whether they ever traded in the Transvaal before the war; and if they did, they at least have the right to do so now in accordance with the policy that the British
('3', 459, 2, 14, 1051174) 1Vide “The Asiatic Traders’ Commission”, 10 3 1904
('3', 460, 0, 1, 1051225) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 461
('3', 460, 1, 2, 1051266) Government followed during the Boer regime, for any Indian who entered the Transvaal and established himself in trade before the war knew that he could set up in trade any time he liked and break it up and renew it.
('3', 460, 1, 3, 1051482) We therefore, feel that if any justice is to be done to the British Indians, the Reference to the Commission will have to be considerably widened.
('3', 460, 1, 4, 1051629) Mr. Burgess, Supervisor of Asiatics, gave evidence before the Commission, and he clearly stated that very few Indians (3) we granted licenses after the war, unless they could prove to his satisfaction that they were doing business in the Transvaal outside Location before the war.
('3', 460, 1, 5, 1051910) All those Indians, therefore, (as has always been contended by the British Indian Association,) who are now licensed to trade outside Locations, have already proved their right to do so, in accordance with Mr. Burgess’ statement.
('3', 460, 1, 6, 1052140) At the risk of repeating, we may add that no conditions were attached to the issue of these licenses, and according to our view of right and wrong, it will be a miscarriage of justice if a single British Indian trader who is now doing business in the Transvaal outside Locations is interfered with.
('3', 460, 1, 7, 1052439) Indian Opinion, 2 4 1904
('3', 460, 2, 8, 1052464) 302. NATAL DEALERS’ LICENSES ACT
('3', 460, 3, 9, 1052497) At Weenen the other day, seven Indian traders appealed to the Local Board against the decision of the Licensing Officer who had refused all the seven applications for dealers’ licenses.
('3', 460, 3, 10, 1052683) From the evidence given it would appear that one of them is a store keeper of eight year’s standing; the others are also old store keepers having held liceness to trade for several years.
('3', 460, 3, 11, 1052871) The Licensing Officer declined to renew these licenses, hence the appeal to the Local Board.
('3', 460, 3, 12, 1052964) One of the applicants gave evidence to the effect that he had held a license for eight years and that his books were kept by his English book keeper from time to time out of rough memoranda kept by him.
('3', 460, 3, 13, 1053167) The others too, had the same system of book keeping.
('3', 460, 3, 14, 1053220) After hearing these cases for two days, the Board decided that it was not satisfied with the system of book keeping and, therefore, upheld the decision of the Licensing Officer.
('3', 460, 3, 15, 1053398) If things continue to be managed in this fashion, we are very much afraid that almost every Indian store keeper will be swept away.
('3', 460, 3, 16, 1053530) It is a matter of common knowledge that petty store keepers are not in a position even to keep books.
('3', 460, 3, 17, 1053632) Their transactions are all in cash.
('3', 460, 3, 18, 1053668) They buy and sell largely for cash and it is exceed ingly hard to expect these people to keep any books at all.
('3', 461, 0, 1, 1053780) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 461, 1, 2, 1053822) present instance, the men have made an attempt to keep books in the English language.
('3', 461, 1, 3, 1053908) Evidently, the Board expects them to keep their books through competent book keepers from day to day which would mean £ 6 or £ 7 per month or more.
('3', 461, 1, 4, 1054056) Petty traders who hardly save from £ 10 to £ 15 per month out of their businesses cannot possibly indulge in a luxury of that kind.
('3', 461, 1, 5, 1054188) The result would be that, if the Local Boards insist upon such a manifestly absurd rule as the keeping of books by competent book keepers in the English language from day to day, it would be a short cut to the extermination of, at any rate the petty Indian trader in the Colony.
('3', 461, 1, 6, 1054467) Was the Dealers’ Licenses Act passed with such a view?
('3', 461, 1, 7, 1054522) The decision of the Board raised once more the question of amendment of the law.
('3', 461, 1, 8, 1054603) Just when the Dealers Licenses Act was passed, there was a tendency to abuse the powers given to the Municipalities.
('3', 461, 1, 9, 1054720) Then followed a remonstrance from Mr. Chamberlain which had the desired effect, but it was only momentary.
('3', 461, 1, 10, 1054827) Unless therefore, some definite powers are included in the Dealers’ Licenses Act enabling the aggrieved party to go to the Supreme Court or defining the reasons for which licenses may be refused, cases of the kind we have alluded to above are bound to occur from time to time.
('3', 461, 1, 11, 1055104) The matter is worthy of serious consideration by the Government if the vested interests of people are to be respected.

('3', 462, 1, 2, 1056159) passionately, I venture to enclose herewith copy of correspondence between Dr. Porter and myself, with Mr. Roy’s concurrence, for pub lication.
('3', 462, 1, 3, 1056303) It will be seen that sufficient warning was given of what was imp ending on the 11th February last, i.e,.
('3', 462, 1, 4, 1056409) exactly a month and nine days before the official discovery of the existence of the plague in our midst.
('3', 462, 1, 5, 1056514) It was repeated in strong terms (entirely justified, I think, by the events that have since happened) on the 15th February last.
('3', 462, 1, 6, 1056643) On the 1st of March, a letter was written to Dr. Porter definitely informing him that, in my humble opinion, plague had actually broken out.
('3', 462, 1, 7, 1056784) Could there be anything more precise?
('3', 462, 1, 8, 1056822) The only answer to this perhaps is that the information given was unofficial and came from a layman.
('3', 462, 1, 9, 1056923) But was there not a terrible confirmation there of in the mortuary record, which showed, as we are officially told, a pronoun cedly abnormal mortality in the Insanitary Area?
('3', 462, 1, 10, 1057098) No, sir, it required an ocular demonstration of the ghastly tragedy that took place on the 18th, 19th and 20th of last month before energetic measures could be officially taken.
('3', 462, 1, 11, 1057276) What was a clear public duty was left to be perfore med by volunteers who, the disease having got a fatal grip of the patients, had to wade through what was a chamber of horrors.
('3', 462, 1, 12, 1057455) I need not recall the graphic though fanciful description of the Insanitary Area by Major O’Meara in the middle of 1902 and the repetition thereof by Dr. Porter in 1903. The danger to public health was even then considered to be so immediate that the Town Council was advised not to wait for expropriating until an elected Council was given to Johannesburg.
('3', 462, 1, 13, 1057813) The Council received on the 30th day of April, 1903 authority to expropriate.
('3', 462, 1, 14, 1057891) It had then the right, as it was its clear duty, to fix upon a spot for the habitation of the people who had to be dispossessed.
('3', 462, 1, 15, 1058020) It failed in its duty; it gave notice of its intention to expropriate on the 6th June, 1903 but it still failed to provide a site for the housing of the residents of the Insanitary Area, It entered upon possession on the 26th September 1903. If, on that day, instead of becoming landlord to every individual tenant and leaving it to its collectors, who received a commission, to let the premises to as many tenants as chose to apply, it had dealt with the area as it is doing now under stress, would the ratepayers have been mulated of £ 20,000?
('3', 462, 1, 16, 1058566) Would precious lives, though Indian, have been lost?
('3', 462, 1, 17, 1058619) Would a whole family, save one member left as a reminder, have been wiped out?

('3', 463, 1, 2, 1058740) And yet the Indian is being made to feel the heat of the burden 1
('3', 463, 2, 3, 1058806) especially in outside districts.
('3', 463, 2, 4, 1058839) He is debarred from the markets.
('3', 463, 2, 5, 1058872) He is prevented from earning his livelihood.
('3', 463, 2, 6, 1058917) Though there may be no plague there, he is quarantined or at least removed to isolation camps far away from towns.
('3', 463, 2, 7, 1059032) I do not seek to justify him.
('3', 463, 2, 8, 1059062) On the contrary, I admit that the poorer of my countrymen do not observe the laws of sanitation, except under supervision.
('3', 463, 2, 9, 1059185) But I do submit that they are not the keepers of public health, They are defaulters as individuals, and they have suffered as such.
('3', 463, 2, 10, 1059317) It is the Public Health Committee which has to enforce obedience to such laws, and not flagrantly break them, as it has done since the 26th of September last.
('3', 463, 2, 11, 1059476) A trinity of interests (viz.
('3', 463, 2, 12, 1059505) of truth, public weal and my country men) is my excuse for trespassing upon your courtesy.
