('3', 465, 1, 6, 1064173) Naturally, the poor people resented such high handed action, but seeing that the Indians are labouring under very great prejudice [of the whites] accentuated by the outbreak of plague at first among them, it was considered advisable for the time being that the people should fall in with the wish of the authorities.
('3', 465, 1, 7, 1064490) Mr. Ritch therefore, paid a visit to Krugersdorp, explained the position to the people and they have now, with the exception of a few store keepers, removed to a temporary camp far away from town.
('3', 465, 1, 8, 1064687) Nor is this all.
('3', 465, 1, 9, 1064704) The majority of the inhabitants of the Location who have been thus removed are hawkers and they are simply ruined owing to the prejudice and are at present living on the charity of friends, for the Municipality has not undertaken the feeding of the people.

('3', 465, 1, 12, 1065190) The position in Pietersburg is much the same.
('3', 465, 1, 13, 1065236) But Potchefstroom heads the list in the war against the Indian.

('3', 465, 1, 15, 1065438) Then their presence in the midst of the people in the Location was made an excuse for quarantining the whole of the Location, thus dislocating Indian trade entirely.
('3', 465, 1, 16, 1065604) It should be remembered that the Kaffirs, because they are wanted for the European householders, are left untouched.

('3', 467, 1, 7, 1068669) All these troubles the community is bearing with philosophic calmness, and it is only to be hoped that when the plague has been entirely wiped out, their patience would stand them in good stead.

('3', 467, 1, 12, 1069319) It was after the Municipality became, in Johannesburg, the immediate landlord to every individual tenant that the mischief of excessive overcrowding and insanitation arose, bringing in their train the awful scourge.

('3', 469, 1, 2, 1072349) did give information as to the outbreak on March 1. An attempt has been made in the report in question to contro vert my statement that there was a terrible confirmation of my opinion given on March 1 in the mortuary record.
('3', 469, 1, 3, 1072574) Figures have been produ ced for the period commencing from July, 1903 to February this year, which show that the highest mortality from pneumonia in any single month was seven, and the average mortality from the same cause 4.75 per month.
('3', 469, 1, 4, 1072813) During the first seventeen days of the month of March last, there were fourteen deaths from the same cause, that is to say, at the rate of 25.35 per month.
('3', 469, 1, 5, 1072969) In other words, the mortality during the first fort night after the date of my letter was three and a half times as much as the highest mortality during the preceding eight months, and six times as much as the average mortality per month during the same period.
('3', 469, 1, 6, 1073231) I venture, therefore, to ask again whether there is not herein a terrible confirmation of the opinion expressed on March 1 last.
('3', 469, 1, 7, 1073360) It is a gratuitous assumption that my reference to the mortality has any connection with the period prior to March 1. The letters addressed to Dr. Porter in February merely gave warning of the calamity that was impending but never once stated that the plague had actually broken out.
('3', 469, 1, 8, 1073644) Mr. McCann, 1 in speaking of my inability to furnish particulars of suspicious deaths, refers to the single interview.
('3', 469, 1, 9, 1073763) 2 What happened was this.
('3', 469, 1, 10, 1073789) I had not the names or the numbers of the Stands before me.
('3', 469, 1, 11, 1073849) I rang for the clerk who knews something about this matter, and it was there and then Mr. McCann was supplied with the names of at least three men who, in my opinion, had died from the plague, and the numbers of the Stands.
('3', 469, 1, 12, 1074073) I have nowhere stated that the Kaffirs were first introduced into the Indian Locations after the Council entered on possession, and I freely admit that some of my countrymen and Kaffirs are their tenants.
('3', 469, 1, 13, 1074278) But I have stated, and I venture to repeat, that they were dumped down in the Location after September 26th last, and I am in a position to show that several Stands which were never occupied by Kaffirs before that date were crowded by them after it.
('3', 469, 1, 14, 1074528) Even if the Council could not remove the overcrowding that existed on that date, any increase thereto was, in my opinion, unpardonable.

('3', 470, 3, 6, 1075569) 308. THE PLAGUE
('3', 470, 4, 7, 1075585) Although the plague has practically left Johannesburg, the res triction against the Indians continue in all their rigour.
('3', 470, 4, 8, 1075707) Potchefstroom seems to take the lead, as will appear from the following: 1. That Asiatics and Coloured persons arriving in Potchefst room from plague infected areas be given their choice of quarantine for 10 days or returning to their point of departure.
('3', 470, 4, 9, 1075962) 2. To remove Asiatics and Indians from the town proper.
('3', 470, 4, 10, 1076018) 3. That the Police authorities be requested to stop Asiatics and Natives from entering the town by trunk roads.
('3', 470, 4, 11, 1076130) 4 To stop the importation of fruit of all descriptions from stations between Potchefstroom and Johannesburg, and stations north of Johannesburg.
('3', 470, 4, 12, 1076275) 5. That Section 7 of the Public Health Bye Laws be in force for six months.
('3', 470, 4, 13, 1076351) 6. That Natives, accompanying their masters or in charge of cattle, be allowed to pass to and fro, provided they are in possession of their usual Monthly Passes, proving them to be resident in this District.
('3', 470, 4, 14, 1076559) Thus, the movements of the Indians are far more severely controlled than those of the Natives.
('3', 470, 4, 15, 1076654) And yet plague in the districts outside Johannesburg has by no means been more prominent among the Indians than among the other races.
('3', 470, 4, 16, 1076789) In fact, the Indians seem to have been more immune.
('3', 470, 4, 17, 1076841) With reference to Johannesburg itself, the correspondence we published last week shews quite clearly that the
('3', 471, 0, 1, 1076951) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 471, 1, 2, 1076993) blame for the outbreak lies entirely at the door of the Town Council.
('3', 471, 1, 3, 1077063) Had the excessive overcrowding which took pace after the 26th of Septemberthat is, the date of entry as owners by the Town Coun cilbeen prevented, there would probably have been no plague whatsoever throughout the Colony.
('3', 471, 1, 4, 1077287) The Indians residing in the Location protested against the disgraceful state of affairs.
('3', 471, 1, 5, 1077376) They had to remain in the Location merely by force of circumstances.
('3', 471, 1, 6, 1077445) They did not want to become tenants of the Town council, and repeatedy asked for a site in lieu of the Location in terms of the law.
('3', 471, 1, 7, 1077578) It is, therefore, quite clear the terrible outbreak in Johannesburg was under circums tances quite beyond the control of the Indians.
('3', 471, 1, 8, 1077712) The natural inference from this chain of facts is that the special restriction imposed on the Indians are quite unwarranted and uncalled for.
('3', 471, 1, 9, 1077854) The Central Govern ment may take up a position of helplessness, saying that they cannot interfere with the action of the local authorities, so long as it is not in contravention of the plague regulations.
('3', 471, 1, 10, 1078059) Our complaint, however, is against the regulations themselves, especially when the powers imp osed thereunder are abused by the Local Boards and Councils and are made to subserve trade jealousy.
('3', 471, 1, 11, 1078254) We have more than once admitted that during the plague scare some hardships are inevitable, that sufi cient powers should be given to the local authorities, in order to stamp out the scourge, but when, as in Potchefstroom, the local authorities go beyond all bounds and subject British Indians to unnecessary res trictions, it is time to cry “halt”.
('3', 471, 1, 12, 1078604) The position of the British Indians, undefined as it is, has become far more difficult owing to the outbreak of the plague, and we venture to think that it is the clear duty of Lord Milner who, to use his own simile, “sitting on the watch tower” has an opportunity of taking a larger view of everything pas sing under his notice, to protect the inoffensive British Indians from further molestation under the excuse of plague precautions.
('3', 471, 1, 13, 1079042) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1904
('3', 471, 2, 14, 1079068) 309. THE VALUE OF A FICTION
('3', 471, 3, 15, 1079096) Dr. Turner, Medical Officer of Health for the Colony of Transvaal, in his letter to the press on the plague, said that apart from simple, ordinary restriction nothing more was necessary to be done in order to prevent or stamp out the disease, and gave it as his opinion that the extraordinary measures that were being taken were merely an appeal to sentiment.
('3', 471, 3, 16, 1079456) This dictum is more than verified in the confla 
('3', 472, 0, 1, 1079505) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 473
('3', 472, 1, 2, 1079546) gration that took place in Johannesburg last week in connection with the Indian Location.
('3', 472, 1, 3, 1079636) It was essentially a theatrical display calculated to fire the imagination of the people.
('3', 472, 1, 4, 1079726) While the buildings should certainly have been gutted out, to think that, because they have been burned down, the only source of infection is gone quite contrary to facts, and, as our correspondent has pointed out, the cordon round the Location and the control over movements of the inmates were merely a fiction kept up to satisfynot the requirements of sanitationbut public sentiment.
('3', 472, 1, 5, 1080115) The rookeries outside the Location are infinitely worse than were the worst parts of that much−abused site.
('3', 472, 1, 6, 1080223) The most deadly cases of plague came from Station Road in Burghersdorp, Johannesburg.
('3', 472, 1, 7, 1080309) Other cases also have happened within the Insanitary Area of Johannesburg but outside the Location.
('3', 472, 1, 8, 1080409) Nothing has been done and nothing probably was necessary beyond disinfecting those places.
('3', 472, 1, 9, 1080500) The movement of the people residing there was not interfered with.
('3', 472, 1, 10, 1080567) And yet no amount of argument and cold reasoning by Dr. Pakes would have eased the public mind as has this burning down of the Location and the isolation of the people residing in it.
('3', 472, 1, 11, 1080751) Now, however, that these two measures have been carried out, let us trust that, so far at any rate, as Johannesburg is concerned, the British Indian population would be left fairly free.
('3', 472, 1, 12, 1080938) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1904
('3', 472, 2, 13, 1080964) 310. ORANGE RIVER COLONY AND THE PLAGUE
('3', 472, 3, 14, 1081004) This Colony is nothing if it is not thorough in its hatred of the Asiatics.
('3', 472, 3, 15, 1081080) The Government Gazette dated 25th March has the following two regulations:
('3', 472, 4, 16, 1081155) (1) From and after the date of these regulations, it shall not be lawful for any Asiatic to enter this Colony from the Transvaal so long as the said regulations shall remain in force.
('3', 472, 4, 17, 1081339) Any Asiatic contravening these regulations shall, on conviction, be liable to a fine not exceeding £5 or in default of payment, to imprisonment not exceeding one month, and such convicted person shall on payment of the said fine or completion of his imprisonment be forthwith deported beyond the limits of the Colony.
('3', 472, 5, 18, 1081657) (2) Every coloured person entering this Colony by rail or otherwise shall be subject to examination and if, in the opinion of a duly qualified Medical Practitioner, he or she shall display any actual or suspicious sympto ms of plague, or have been in contact with actual or suspicious cases of plague, such person shall be detained and segregated in a camp until such time
('3', 473, 0, 1, 1082030) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 473, 1, 2, 1082072) as the Medical Officer in charge shall be of opinion that it is safe for him or her to be allowed to travel.
('3', 473, 1, 3, 1082181) Thus, a Coloured person other than an Asiatic may enter the Colony under restrictions, but an Asiatic, no matter who he may be, is not to place his foot on the sacred soil of the Orange River Colony so long as the plague scare lasts, under penalty of a fine.
('3', 473, 1, 4, 1082440) And even after he has paid the fine or completed the term of imprisonment, he is to be “forthwith deported beyond the limits of the Colony”!
('3', 473, 1, 5, 1082581) We well remember and cannot but recall the occassion of the war.
('3', 473, 1, 6, 1082646) At that time in Queenstown, among the followers of the army that had come from India, a plague case had actually occured.
('3', 473, 1, 7, 1082768) The populace was a little uneasy, but we do know that neither the Orange River Colony nor, for that matter, any other part of South Africa was prepared to put an embargo on the entry of the British Indian syces, bhistis, and dooly bearers.
('3', 473, 1, 8, 1083008) In fact, in spite of the plague outbreak, these followers were sent to all parts of South Africa as fast as transport could be provided.
('3', 473, 1, 9, 1083145) Times, however, have now changed.
('3', 473, 1, 10, 1083179) The Indian is no longer required for the wants of the Colonials, and, therefore, he may be kept out indefinitely.
('3', 473, 1, 11, 1083293) Whether he wishes to enter O.R.C. or not is a very small matter and no business of the powers that be.
('3', 473, 1, 12, 1083396) Indian Opinion, 16 4 1904
('3', 473, 2, 13, 1083422) 311. WAR AGAINST COLOUR
('3', 473, 3, 14, 1083446) In the Orange River Colony Gazette dated 31st March appears the following in the Additional Board of Health Regulations for Registered Vehicles:
('3', 473, 4, 15, 1083591) Any cab proprietor desirous of employing his cab for the purpose of conveying coloured passengers (“kleurlingen”) only may obtain from the Town Clerk a board with the words “For Coloured Passengers” legibly printed thereon, which board shall be affixed outside in a conspicious manner on the back or the left side of the vehicle.
('3', 473, 5, 16, 1083921) No coloured person shall be allowed to travel in any registered cab, save and except those set apart for the purpose and distinguished by the painted board herinbefore mentioned.
('3', 473, 5, 17, 1084100) We have so often dealt with the uncompromisingly hostile attitude of the Orange River Colony Government against Coloured people, that we merely draw the attention of our readers to the above extracts to emphasise our remarks.

('3', 474, 1, 2, 1084426) 312. CAMP LIFE 1
('3', 474, 2, 3, 1084443) April 20, [1904] The plague Bill to date is as follows: Proved plague cases15 whites; 4 Coloured (including Malays); 54 Asiatics; 35 Natives.
('3', 474, 2, 4, 1084586) Of these, deaths7 whites; 51 Asiatics; 14 Natives.
('3', 474, 2, 5, 1084638) There are 3 white suspects, 1 Asiatic and 25 Native suspects.
('3', 474, 2, 6, 1084700) These are the figures for Johannesburg.
('3', 474, 2, 7, 1084740) In Germiston, there have been 5 proved plague cases of Natives, 1 Asiatic, no Asiatic suspects, and 13 Native suspects.
('3', 474, 2, 8, 1084860) Of these, the single Asiatic case has proved fatal.
('3', 474, 2, 9, 1084912) In Benoni there has been only one Native case proved plague, which has turn out to be fatal.
('3', 474, 2, 10, 1085005) In Krugersdorp, one Native plague case and five suspects, also Natives, of which three have proved not be the plague.
('3', 474, 2, 11, 1085123) Thus it will be noticed that the Asiatic cases are practically those that happened in the first stage.
('3', 474, 2, 12, 1085226) The increase has been mostly in the Native cases and a little in the white cases.
('3', 474, 2, 13, 1085308) In the districts outside Johan nesburg, in Krugersdorp and Benoni no Asiatic cases at all.
('3', 474, 2, 14, 1085399) In Germi nston one.
('3', 474, 2, 15, 1085419) Thus, then, upto the time of writing the statement made before that the disease is not personal to the Asiatic still hold good.
('3', 474, 2, 16, 1085547) At the Klipspruit, however, the regulations continue to be extremely irritating.
('3', 474, 2, 17, 1085628) The camp has been declared open since the 11th instant.
('3', 474, 2, 18, 1085684) There had been no plague cases whatsoever since inauguration of the camp.
('3', 474, 2, 19, 1085758) Nor has there been any sickness worth mentioning.
('3', 474, 2, 20, 1085808) And yet the movements of inmates are very uncomfortably controlled.
('3', 474, 2, 21, 1085876) They can not leave except on permits, which have to be renewed from day to day, and these permits are issued only if the inmates are in a position to produce the registration certificates which are merely receipts to show that they have paid £ 3. There is a train service between the camp and Johannesburg, the morning train leaving 6 a.m., and the evening train leaving Johannesburg for the camp at 6.15 p.m.
('3', 474, 2, 22, 1086286) For this, a sum of 3s.
('3', 474, 2, 23, 1086309) is charged per week, excepting Sundays.
('3', 474, 2, 24, 1086349) Only third class compartments are provided, and no lights for the evening train.
('3', 474, 2, 25, 1086430) Those who want to leave the camp for any town in the Transvaal except Johannesburg, must notify same to the Superintendent of the Camp, giving the description of the dwelling to be occupied by the applicant.
('3', 474, 2, 26, 1086638) The Medical Officer of Health then enters into correspondence with
('3', 474, 3, 27, 1086705) 1 This appeared as “From our Johannesburg Correspondent”
('3', 475, 0, 1, 1086762) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 475, 1, 2, 1086804) the officer of the town that may be named by the applicant, and if the dwelling is certified as habitable and sanitary, permission is given to leave the camp entirely.
('3', 475, 1, 3, 1086972) Those who wish to reside in Johannesburg have to follow the same routine, and if the dwelling pointed out is approved by the Medical Officer of Health, a leaving pass is granted.
('3', 475, 1, 4, 1087151) Unless a man is in possession of a leaving pass he must report him self at the camp before 8.30 p.m.
('3', 475, 1, 5, 1087252) and failure to do so makes him liable to penalty not exceeding £ 15, or, in default of payment, imprisonment for three months for the first offence.
('3', 475, 1, 6, 1087401) A repetition of the offence subjects the offender to a penalty not exceeding £ 50, or to imprisonment with hard labour for a period not exceeding six months.
('3', 475, 1, 7, 1087559) Rations have been stopped since Monday last except for women and children and employment is offered for excavation or quarry work at 2s.
('3', 475, 1, 8, 1087696) per day rising to 3s.
('3', 475, 1, 9, 1087718) per day, if the labourer proves to be first class.
('3', 475, 1, 10, 1087769) On their return, the inmates are examined and also searched.
('3', 475, 1, 11, 1087830) This is more or less a prison life hardly deserved by the men who have, as admitted by authorities, behaved splendidly.
('3', 475, 1, 12, 1087950) If the camp is really open, there seems to be no reason why there should be such a sharp distinction between the Asiatics living in the camp and the Asiatics living in Johannesburg.
('3', 475, 1, 13, 1088132) The only purpose that the camp should really serve now is to afford shelter to those who cannot find residence elsewhere.
('3', 475, 1, 14, 1088254) Why they should be obliged to point out such residences, and make application, and go through the whole of the tedious routine above described, it is difficult to understand.
('3', 475, 1, 15, 1088429) Surely if the authorities wish to examine the dwellings, they can do so without subjecting the people to the above restraints.
('3', 475, 1, 16, 1088556) It isand if it is not, it should bean offence for anybody to occupy any dwellings which do not fulfill the requirements of the sanitary regulations and the Rand Plague Committee which is constantly of the qui vive for insan itation should certainly been in a position to hound out any Indians who may occupy insanitory dwellings.
('3', 475, 1, 17, 1088888) But it is hardly justified in putting what are, after all, unlawful restraints on the liberty of the subject.
('3', 475, 1, 18, 1088998) Outside the camp, the condition of the British Indians is also very diffcult.
('3', 475, 1, 19, 1089076) No Asiatic can travel outside the district of Witwa tersrand unless he is in possession of a health certificate.
('3', 475, 1, 20, 1089189) In many places, they are debarred from the use of the market.
('3', 475, 1, 21, 1089251) Potchefstroom refuses to receive any Indian from the Transvaal at all.
('3', 475, 1, 22, 1089322) The result is that the railway authorities decline to issue any tickets.
('3', 475, 1, 23, 1089395) The Indian merchants and store keepers are suffering heavily owing to the ousting of the 1,600 men from the Location, many of whom are

('3', 476, 1, 2, 1089571) indebted to these merchants and store keepers and who are now unable to meet their liabilities.
('3', 476, 1, 3, 1089667) The Johannesburg Town Council has met today to consider advisability of asking for further powers to the Indian Locations as it has over Kaffir Locations.
('3', 476, 1, 4, 1089822) This is evidently meant to get out of its liability, under the Insanitary Area Expro priation Ordinance, to find suitable accomodation within the Insa nitary Area or in the immediate vicinity thereof.
('3', 476, 1, 5, 1090023) What the upshot of all this anti Indian activity will be no one can foretell.
('3', 476, 1, 6, 1090101) Time alone will show whether justice will in the end be triumphant.

('3', 476, 2, 8, 1090195) 313. THE PLAGUE
('3', 476, 3, 9, 1090211) Although the plague in the Transvaal is dying out, the cases found on a mine in Krugersdorp shew that there is still necessity for very strict vigilance.
('3', 476, 3, 10, 1090365) And if it is permissible to derive any satisfaction from such painful occurrences as plague cases, the Krugersdorp incident, happily for the British Indians, shews that, after all, the plague is no respecter of persons and that the extra special restrictions to which British Indians in the Transvaal have been subjected are unnecessary, for the majority of cases outside Johannesburg proper have been Native cases, including Europeans.
('3', 476, 3, 11, 1090802) The disease, therefore, can in no case be described as personal to the Indians.
('3', 476, 3, 12, 1090882) In fact, the plague seems to have arisen in and been brought from the mines, for these Indian cases that happened in the Location were, in the first instance, confined to those who were working on the mines, and the fact that at first it was merely the pneumonic variety goes probably to establish some connection between the mine working and the plague.
('3', 476, 3, 13, 1091237) Be that however as it may, the central fact to which we have drawn attention and which is never to be lost sight of is that the Indian is being blamed for the outbreak without any valid cause.
('3', 476, 3, 14, 1091430) It is necessary to bear this prominently in mind, as we are very much afraid that attempts may be made to impose further permanent legal disabilities on the British Indians in the Transvaal, and to colour the negotiations that are now going on between the Indian Government and the Transvaal Government in the matter.
('3', 476, 3, 15, 1091748) The cause of the outbreak has been now clearly shown in the correspondence 1 that was published by us the other week and the correspondence we publish in this issue.
('3', 476, 4, 16, 1091914) 1Vide letters to Dr. C. Porter dated February 11, 15 and 20, 1904.
('3', 477, 0, 1, 1091981) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 477, 1, 2, 1092023) The utter incapacity of the Johannesburg Town Council to attend to details is the real and chief cause for the outbreak of plague in Johannesburg.
('3', 477, 1, 3, 1092170) From the figures published by the Town Council, it is clear that the mortality in March from pneumonia was so abnormally high that the inertia of the Town Council in the face of this tremen dous fact is totally unaccountable unless it be that the Council as a body believed that Johannesburg was proof against an outbreak of plague.
('3', 477, 1, 4, 1092503) It is not often that authorities receive gratuitous, definite, and urgent warnings, as has happened in Johannesburg.
('3', 477, 1, 5, 1092620) It was always possible for the Town Council to prevent the outbreak by attending to the elementary principles of sanitation, and yet, for nearly eighteen months, the Council never went beyond framing big schemes on pa per.
('3', 477, 1, 6, 1092843) It is, therefore, nothing but a hollow mockery now for the Health Committee to state that they did everything they could, and that it was not possible for them to fix a new site in place of the Insanitary Area by reason of public opposition, as if any such opposition could warrant the Council endangering, as it undoubtedly did, the health and lives of the community at large.
('3', 477, 1, 7, 1093221) It should be borne in mind that the plague broke out five months after the Council took possession of the Insanitary Area.
('3', 477, 1, 8, 1093344) The questions then arise: Why did not the Council, before expropriating, sound the public sentiment as to the choice of a site?
('3', 477, 1, 9, 1093472) Having failed to do that, why did not the Council remain satisfied with a mere constructive possession?
('3', 477, 1, 10, 1093576) Why did it not allow the people, who were prepared to continue to perform the work of landlords, to do so?
('3', 477, 1, 11, 1093683) Having rejected that proposal, why did the Council not cease deriving rents from property which was condemned by itself as unfit for human habitation and which was allowed to be inhabited either, as we would say owing to its gross neglect, or, as the Council would say, owing to public opposition to the adoption of the site selected by it in place of the Insanitary Area?
('3', 477, 1, 12, 1094056) Having, however, under taken the land lordship of each individual tenant in the Area, and having decided to derive an income from the tenants, why did the Council introduce overcrowding and horrible insanitation?
('3', 477, 1, 13, 1094269) Why was the rubbish allowed to remain on the Stands?
('3', 477, 1, 14, 1094322) Why, while there was time, did not the Council accept the very reasonable suggestion made in Mr. Gandhi’s letter to Dr. Porter in February?
('3', 477, 1, 15, 1094462) In our opinion, these very pertinent questions require decisive answers.
('3', 477, 1, 16, 1094535) We cannot recall any instance of a public body, having stumbled upon mistakes after mistakes, declining to profit by past experience, and declining to see even the natural conclusions and proposition laid down by itself.
('3', 477, 1, 17, 1094756) Was it merely a
('3', 478, 0, 1, 1094772) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 479
('3', 478, 1, 2, 1094813) subterfuge that the Town Council went to Lord Milner for authority to expropriate the Area on the ground of its insanitation, which was described to be so great that nothing but the complete taking over of private property could cure the evil?
('3', 478, 1, 3, 1095057) And if it was not a subterfuge, then it was certainly its clear duty to see that the first thing to do, after [obtaining the] authority to expropriate, was to remove the people within the Area to healthier quarters.
('3', 478, 1, 4, 1095273) Unfortu nately, beyond the removal of the inhabitants of the Indian Location to a temporary camp at Klipspruit, we see even now no sign of a movement towards selection of a permanent site.
('3', 478, 1, 5, 1095462) From the foregoing, it must be clear that the outbreak of plague amongst the Indians in the first instance at Johannesburg, was due to exceptional circums tances, for which the Council, and it alone, is responsible.
('3', 478, 1, 6, 1095678) The power for observing sanitation, as the poorer class of Indians know it, was taken away from them on the 26th September.
('3', 478, 1, 7, 1095802) It was so bad that they cried out against it, and the overcrowding that took place in the Location after the 26th September under the direct control and supervision of the Town Council was such as they were not used to and though they themselves wanted to escape from it, there was no provision made by the Council for them and so they were helpless.
('3', 478, 1, 8, 1096153) That the Council rose to the ocassion after the actual discovery of the outbreak is beside the point when we are considering the first cause.
('3', 478, 1, 9, 1096295) Indian Opinion, 23 4 1904
('3', 478, 2, 10, 1096321) 314. KRUGERSDORP AND BRITISH INDIANS
('3', 478, 3, 11, 1096358) Krugersdorp Town Council has approved of the recommen dation of the General Purposes Committee that no Coloured person should be allowed to be out of doors between the hours of 9 and 4 o’clock during night time, and that no such person should be allowed to walk, be on, or remain on any pavement or foot path.
('3', 478, 3, 12, 1096668) In using the phrase “Coloured person”, the Municipality of Krugersdorp could only mean British Indians, for, besides the Natives, the only Coloured people in Krugersdorp are probably a handful of British Indians.
('3', 478, 3, 13, 1096881) We suppose that the recommendation is one of the results of the outbreak of plague in the Tansvaal.
('3', 478, 3, 14, 1096981) From the report of the proceedings of the Municipality, which we reproduce elsewhere, it appears that that body holds that the outbreak of plague was due to the neglect of the Johan nesburg Town Council, and yet the Councillors would punish not the guilty party, which, of course, is too powerful for them, but they
('3', 479, 0, 1, 1097297) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 479, 1, 2, 1097339) would punish the innocent, who are quite powerless.
('3', 479, 1, 3, 1097391) We would anxi ously watch how His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor views the recommendation, and, in the meanwhile, may we hope that such manifestly unjust regulation would not meet with His Excellency’s sanction?
('3', 479, 1, 4, 1097607) Indian Opinion, 23 4 1904
('3', 479, 2, 5, 1097633) 315. THE PRETORIA TOWN COUNCIL AND BRITISH INDIANS
('3', 479, 3, 6, 1097684) The Town Council of Pretoria wants the entire control of Native Locations.
('3', 479, 3, 7, 1097759) The proposal seems on the face of it, to be quite innocent, and we do not know that, under the Town Council, the Indians will be much worse off.
('3', 479, 3, 8, 1097904) At the same time, at present there is central authority and, even in the harshness, there is possibility of uniformity of pro cedure.
('3', 479, 3, 9, 1098038) But the proposal of the Pretoria Town Council will, if carried out, not only leave the Indians entirely to its tender mercy, but would subject them to all the regulations to which the Natives are exposed.
('3', 479, 3, 10, 1098243) While it may be that the regulations that have been framed regarding the control of the Native Locations are necessary in that the Natives are all, or almost all, of the labouring class, they would be dangerously irksome for the British Indians.
('3', 479, 3, 11, 1098489) The following is the reply sent by the Colonial Secretary to the proposal:
('3', 479, 4, 12, 1098564) I have the honour to inform you that, as both the locations are situated within the jursdiction of the Town Council, the Council has the same control over them as it has over every other portion of the Municipal area.
('3', 479, 4, 13, 1098782) The Govern ment exercises no extraordinary control except that, in so far as the Asiatic Location is concerned, it is the landlord who apportions the Stands between the various applicants.
('3', 479, 4, 14, 1098971) These leases are, as I believe you are aware, granted subject to the condition that all Municipal by laws are complied with and Municipal taxes paid by the lessees.
('3', 479, 4, 15, 1099136) So far as the Cape Location is concerned, I am not aware on what principle the stands are leased out, and I would suggest that you would place yourself in communication with the Department of Native Affairs on the subject.
('3', 479, 4, 16, 1099359) The application that the income derived form the Asiatic and Cape Locations may be transferred to the Municipality I have referred to the Secretary to the Treasury, whom I have asked to address you direct on the subject.
('3', 479, 4, 17, 1099580) The Town Council has rejoined saying that it desires to obtain control of the Indian and Cape Locations on the same terms as the Native Location.
('3', 479, 4, 18, 1099726) It should be borne in mind that the Town Council has got
('3', 480, 0, 1, 1099783) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 481
('3', 480, 1, 2, 1099824) special powers for framing regulations regarding Native Locations, and this is exactly what the Council evidently wants regarding Indians.
('3', 480, 1, 3, 1099963) When the Municipal Corporations Ordinance was passed, the point was raised, but the Government decided not to yield.
('3', 480, 1, 4, 1100080) And so long as the Law 3 of 1885 is on the Statute book, it is difficult to see how the Town Council can have the power asked for without special legislation.
('3', 480, 1, 5, 1100239) On the one hand, the Law 3 of 1885 is objected to very strenuously, and we think rightly, by the British Indians.
('3', 480, 1, 6, 1100353) On the other, even its full enforcement does not satisfy the Pretoria Town Council, as indeed the other Town Councils also in the Transvaal.
('3', 480, 1, 7, 1100494) Well may Lord Milner say he is between two fires!
('3', 480, 1, 8, 1100544) We can only hope that he will not succumb to the fire from the Town Councils and other anti Indian gentlemen, who would, if they could, blot out all the British traditions from the Transvaal, and allow the Union Jack to wave in Pretoria merely as an empty show, and, if anything, as a shelter for all the anti British measures, under cover of the rights of a self governing people.
('3', 480, 1, 9, 1100926) Indian Opinion, 23 4 1904
('3', 480, 2, 10, 1100952) 316. A LESSON FROM THE PLAGUE
('3', 480, 3, 11, 1100982) The plague has taught the British Indians lessons which we trust will not be forgotten, and which, it is hoped, the community will profit by.
('3', 480, 3, 12, 1101124) We have a homely saying in India that it were better for a man to lose millions then that he should lose a good name.
('3', 480, 3, 13, 1101242) It follows as a corollary from the saying that, once a man has acquired a bad name, it is difficult for him to undo the effect and to rehabilitate himself in the popular regard.
('3', 480, 3, 14, 1101420) What is true of individuals is equally true of com munities.
('3', 480, 3, 15, 1101481) The French have a name for the artistic, the English for per sonal bravery, the Germans for hard headedness, the Russians for frug ality, the Colonies in South Africa for gold hunger; similarly, the Ind ians in South Africa have, rightly or wrongly, got the evil reputa tion of being insanitary and ignorant of the first principles of hy giene.
('3', 480, 3, 16, 1101826) The result is that the individaul members against whom such a charge could not be proved to the slightest extent are often obliged to undergo hardships merely because they belong to the Indian commu nity.
('3', 480, 3, 17, 1102031) Nor could it be otherwise.
('3', 480, 3, 18, 1102058) This has been very forcibly exemplifi ed owing the the outbreak of plague in the Transvaal.
('3', 480, 3, 19, 1102150) Restrictions, for which there would not be any warrant if they were examined calmly and fairly, have been imposed on the liberty of the Indians throug hout South Africa.
('3', 480, 3, 20, 1102320) In the Transvaal, the inhabitants of the late Indian
('3', 481, 0, 1, 1102373) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 481, 1, 2, 1102415) Location are being treated practically as prisoner.
('3', 481, 1, 3, 1102467) Even dogs, cats, and other animals that were found in the Location have been killed—lest their contact with the Indians may have conveyed to them the plague germs!
('3', 481, 1, 4, 1102631) The Local Boards of the different towns there have erected barbed wire fence regulations against the Indians.
('3', 481, 1, 5, 1102741) The Orange River Colony has entirely closed its gates against the Indians from the Transvaal.
('3', 481, 1, 6, 1102835) The Cape and Natal admit him under severe restrictions which have no scientific meaning.
('3', 481, 1, 7, 1102924) For instance, an Indian may be sharing the same compartment with a Kaffir.
('3', 481, 1, 8, 1102999) As soon, however, as the train bringing the passengers reaches the Natal border, the Indian is obliged to undergo 5 days’ quarantine before entering the Colony, whereas the Kaffir is permitted to do so without let or hindrance.
('3', 481, 1, 9, 1103227) Such regulations, harsh as they undoubtedly are, ought not to make us angry.
('3', 481, 1, 10, 1103304) But we should so order our conduct as to prevent a repetition of them.
('3', 481, 1, 11, 1103375) And with that end in view, we should set about put ting our houses in order as well literally as figuratively.
('3', 481, 1, 12, 1103486) The meanest of us should know the value of sanitation and hygiene.
('3', 481, 1, 13, 1103553) Overcrowding should be stamped out from our midst.
('3', 481, 1, 14, 1103604) We should freely let in sun shine and air.
('3', 481, 1, 15, 1103647) In short, we should ingrain into our hearts the English saying that cleanliness is next to godliness.
('3', 481, 1, 16, 1103749) And what then?
('3', 481, 1, 17, 1103764) We do not promise that we shall at once be freed from the yoke of prejudice.
('3', 481, 1, 18, 1103841) A name once lost is not to be so easily regained.
('3', 481, 1, 19, 1103891) The loss of a name is like a disease, it overtakes us in no time, but it costs us much to remove.
('3', 481, 1, 20, 1103989) But why need we think of reward in the shape of subsidence of prejudice?
('3', 481, 1, 21, 1104062) Is not cleanliness its own reward?
('3', 481, 1, 22, 1104097) Would it not be an inestimable boon to ward off another attack of the plague?
('3', 481, 1, 23, 1104175) Would we not cease to be harassed by sanitary inspectors and their regulations in that they will have lost their use?
('3', 481, 1, 24, 1104293) By and by, when we have asserted our position as a people regarding sanitation and hygiene as part of our being, and not merely of lip profession, the prejudice, in so far as it is based on that charge, will go.
('3', 481, 1, 25, 1104505) And we shall gain for ourselves a name for the practice of the laws of health which would always stand us in good stead.
('3', 481, 1, 26, 1104626) This is the lesson we would have our countrymen learn from the recent trial they have undergone.
('3', 481, 1, 27, 1104723) It is well for us to protest against exaggerated charges.
('3', 481, 1, 28, 1104781) It is our duty to strain every nerve to prevent legislative measures based on them.
('3', 481, 1, 29, 1104865) But we hold it to be equally our duty to examine those charges critically, admit the partial truth in them, and strive to correct the evil that may be in us.
('3', 481, 1, 30, 1105023) It is thus, and only thus, that we can rise in the estimation of our neighbours.
('3', 481, 1, 31, 1105104) Indian Opinion, 30 4 1904
('3', 482, 0, 1, 1105130) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 483
('3', 482, 1, 2, 1105171) 317. KLIPSPRUIT FARM
('3', 482, 2, 3, 1105192) In order to control the plague, the Johannesburg Municipality have spent large sums of money, and opened the Klipspruit camp about a month ago for the Indians [moved] from the Locations.
('3', 482, 2, 4, 1105379) In the beginning, the people had to suffer a variety of discomforts, but these related only to food and lodging.
('3', 482, 2, 5, 1105492) Provisions are given free to the poor, while all are free to enter the city, but that does not appear to have afforded relief to the people to any extent, since only those who can afford to pay heavy rents can benefit from this concession.
('3', 482, 2, 6, 1105732) Also, in the ciy, it will be impossible for every man to get a place to live in.
('3', 482, 2, 7, 1105813) Taking advantage of the condition of Indians, landlords demand exorbitant rents, which the poor cannot pay.
('3', 482, 2, 8, 1105921) Despite the expense and the [consequent] shortage of money, some of them have rented a few houses.
('3', 482, 2, 9, 1106020) But they can go to stay in the city only after the Municipality have inspected the houses and passed them as fit.
('3', 482, 2, 10, 1106134) Till then it would appear that the “prison” at Klipspruit must be suffered.
('3', 482, 2, 11, 1106210) The procedure for getting a house approved is by no means easy.
('3', 482, 2, 12, 1106274) When a man has gone through this mill, he looks squeezed dry.
('3', 482, 2, 13, 1106336) He looks like one who has been slapped in the face, but acquiesces helplessly in the situation.
('3', 482, 2, 14, 1106432) He is dazed, looks troubled, but cannot speak out his mind.
('3', 482, 2, 15, 1106492) Since he brought these troubles on himself [by not observing sanitary regulations,] how can he talk of his woes to others?
('3', 482, 2, 16, 1106615) After the house has been approved, he goes post haste to Klipspruit.
('3', 482, 2, 17, 1106684) On inquiry there, he learns that his application has not been received back by the Camp Superintendent.
('3', 482, 2, 18, 1106788) He then returns to Johannesburg only to find out that the Superintendent is not at fault.
('3', 482, 2, 19, 1106878) When a man is worried, all manner of fearfull fancies arise in the mind.
('3', 482, 2, 20, 1106951) Though the forebodings are sometimes baseless, it cannot be claimed that all of them will prove untrue.
('3', 482, 2, 21, 1107055) On the one hand, money is hard to come by; on the other, there is the desire to get away from the Camp.
('3', 482, 2, 22, 1107159) Again, the landlord has pocketed the rent well in advance and the [paid up] rent goes on accumulating.
('3', 482, 2, 23, 1107262) But then as the municipal authorities have already checked the plague, they are content, like a man who has had his fill, to do their duty leisurely and urge patience on the poor ones, [eager to move into their city houses] reminding them that haste only makes for despair.
('3', 482, 2, 24, 1107536) But one cannot advise a poor man who has lost patience to pass through the inevitable ordeal.
('3', 482, 2, 25, 1107630) This is how things are, and we do not know who is to blame.
('3', 482, 2, 26, 1107690) But this much
('3', 483, 0, 1, 1107704) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 483, 1, 2, 1107746) is certain: one should not be dispirited by adversity, and throw away milk, as if it were water; nor, like the potter who, having thrown out the milk, vented his anger upon his donkey, should one find fault with the Municipality.
('3', 483, 1, 3, 1107976) No one will sympathise with a person who follows the wrong path, because he would not take the right one, trips and then blames it on his luck.
('3', 483, 1, 4, 1108120) We know it is difficult to get a house in the city.
('3', 483, 1, 5, 1108172) Therefore, we should petition the Municipality to set apart special places for us.
('3', 483, 1, 6, 1108255) If the Municipality is unheeding, we should apply to the Government for employment in the Railways asking for reasonable wages.
('3', 483, 1, 7, 1108383) If the Government is willing to pay five or six shillings a day, we do not see why we should not accept work in the Railways.
('3', 483, 1, 8, 1108509) Those who have the money have not to worry in this situation, but then as they have become used to paying lower rents in Location, they may pay high rents for a month or two, but they cannot afford it much longer.

('3', 483, 1, 16, 1109417) Menacing clouds [which portend suffering] will always loom over Indians in this land of the white man.
('3', 483, 1, 17, 1109520) And when we are at fault, we can expect that the sky will darken further.
('3', 483, 1, 18, 1109594) It will take us time to live down the blame for the outbreak of plague.

('3', 483, 2, 21, 1109924) For instance, some people are smug gling bottles of liquor into the Camp, from the city.

('3', 486, 3, 7, 1115974) 319. THE CAPE IMMIGRATION ACT
('3', 486, 4, 8, 1116004) Dr. Gregory’s report on the working of the Cape Immigration Act, a condensation of which we give in another column as it appears in The Star is interesting reading.
('3', 486, 4, 9, 1116169) Acording to it, during the months of May and June last year the number of alien immigrants was 2,032 and during the three months October to December, it was 4,715. The pro portion of alien immigration to that of British passengers was 20.2 per cent during May and June, 22.7 during July to September, and 25.2 during October to December, and Dr. Gregory thinks that even this high proportion 1 is not high enough when it is considered that the British immigration is of a totally different type.
('3', 486, 4, 10, 1116665) According to the report, of the 46,933 British passengers, 3,947 were domiciled in the Colony, 11,093 were women, 7,203 were minor children, and 6,969 travelled first class.
('3', 486, 4, 11, 1116839) The proportion, therefore, if only real British immigrants were taken into consideration, will be much higher.
('3', 486, 4, 12, 1116950) A very considerable portion of these aliens are Russians and Jews, being, the report proceeds, “unsatisfactory in most important respects, being ill provided, indifferently educated, unable to speak or understand any language but Yiddish, of inferior physique, often dirty in their habits, persons and clothing, and most unreliable in their statements”.
('3', 486, 4, 13, 1117304) Dr. Gregory also raised the question as to whether Yiddish is to be considered a European language, if a language at all, and he suggests that the onus of proving that it is a European language should be thrown on the immigrants themselves.
('3', 486, 4, 14, 1117545) So, as we have all along expec ted, as soon as the European Colonists in South Africa have done with the Indians, they would commence operations against immigrants from Europe, and when the aliens have been dealt with, as happened in the case of the English hatters 2 in Australia, opposition will be

('3', 487, 2, 6, 1118393) 320. KRUGERSDORP INDIAN LOCATION
('3', 487, 3, 7, 1118426) As will be seen from the report of the Public Health Commitee at Krugersdorp, for which we are indebted to our contemporary the Krugersdorp Standard, the Town Council has now decided not to expropriate the buildings in the Indian Location, the only reason being that their own valuator has put a higher valuation on the buil dings than the original valuation arrived at by the Town Council and that Mr. Barnett, who valued the buildings on behalf of the Indians, has placed a yet higher valuation thereon.
('3', 487, 3, 8, 1118932) The buildings, therefore, that were only a few days ago considered “disgracefully insanitary” and a menace to the public health of the town, have suddenly ceased to be so and are to be allowed to remain where they are.
('3', 487, 3, 9, 1119151) It is, there fore, a question purely and simply of money.
('3', 487, 3, 10, 1119209) But, although they are now to be allowed to remain the property of the British Indians and are not to be destroyed, the Town Council has decided that the Indians are not to re inhabit them until they have provided buildings in accordance with the building regulations of the town.
('3', 487, 3, 11, 1119490) We do not know what this means.
('3', 487, 3, 12, 1119522) If it means that the Indians have to pull down the buildings and re inhabit them until they have provided buildings in accordance with the building regulations of the town.
('3', 487, 3, 13, 1119695) We do not know what this means.
('3', 487, 3, 14, 1119727) If it means that the Indians have to pull down the buildings and re build, it certainly is an easy way of depriving the of their property without the Council having to pay a single penny.
('3', 487, 3, 15, 1119915) Whether such a piece of jobbery would be just or not is evidently no concern of the Town Council.
('3', 487, 3, 16, 1120013) The decision of the Town Council, however, opens up a serious question; how far, if at all are the build ings really in an insanitary state?
('3', 487, 3, 17, 1120154) To what extent are alterations or im provements required and what is, generally the authority of the Town Council with reference to the embargo placed upon the Indians?
('3', 487, 3, 18, 1120323) For we understand that the dispossessed inhabitants are still compelled to remain under canvas in a place far away from the town.
('3', 487, 3, 19, 1120453) We hope,
('3', 488, 0, 1, 1120462) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 489
('3', 488, 1, 2, 1120503) however, as there is absolutely no plague in Krugersdorp, and as it has generally died out in the Transvaal, the awkward situation will be ended and that the Indians will be allowed to re occupy their premises without having to question in a court of law the right of the Town Council to adopt the high handed procedure it evidently has.

('3', 488, 2, 4, 1120866) 321. THE LICENSING CASE IN THE TRANSVAAL
('3', 488, 3, 5, 1120907) The test case in connection with the trade licences for British Indians has been tried and, as was expected, judgment has been reserved.

('3', 488, 3, 10, 1121590) The Government, on the other hand, argued that residence included trade also, especially on the ground that the High Court of the late South African Republic placed that interpretation upon the term in the case of Tayob v.
('3', 488, 3, 11, 1121813) 1 It should be recollected that judgement was not unanimous.
('3', 488, 3, 12, 1121874) It is the irony of fate that, when the case was argued before the High Court of the late Republic, the British Goverment was represented before the judges, and it sought to uphold the contention on behalf of the British Indians.
('3', 488, 3, 13, 1122103) Times have now changed and so has the British Government.
('3', 488, 3, 14, 1122161) It is now on the platform occupied by Mr. Kruger’s Government, The British Government asks for dismissal of the case with costs.
('3', 488, 3, 15, 1122290) To the Indians the matter is of the utmost importance, indeed of life and death, and it is well what they have been able to retain on their behalf the very best legal talent.
('3', 488, 3, 16, 1122465) It will not, therefore, be for want of the best legal advice that they will have lost the case, if indeed they must.
('3', 488, 3, 17, 1122582) There is a very favourable opp ortunity in the Transvaal at present.
('3', 488, 3, 18, 1122651) The question of the constitution that could not be raised before the late High Court has been boldly raised by Mr. Leonard for the Indians.
('3', 488, 3, 19, 1122791) Sir Richard Solomon himself has confessed that he could not understand the judgment of the
('3', 488, 4, 20, 1122882) 1Vide “Notes on the Test Case”, 4 4 1898

('3', 489, 1, 2, 1122965) Republican judges.
('3', 489, 1, 3, 1122984) The Indians have, therefore, much in their favour, and it is to be hoped that the decision will be such as to settle the troublesome question once and for all, and in a manner that would enable hundreds of British Indian traders in the Transvaal once more to breathe freely.
('3', 489, 1, 4, 1123259) Should the British judges, however, feel bound by the decision of the majority of the judges of the late High Court, the British Indians have yet one more desperate chance, namely, appeal to the highest tribunal in the British Dominionsthe Privy Council.

('3', 489, 2, 7, 1123734) 322. IF THE PLAGUE BROKE OUT IN NATAL?
('3', 489, 3, 8, 1123773) Rats have been found to be dying at the Point in the block between McEwan’s premises and the Union Castle offices.
('3', 489, 3, 9, 1123888) It is stated that they have died of plague.
('3', 489, 3, 10, 1123932) The authorities have taken prompt precautions in order to prevent an outbreak in Natal, and we sincerely hope that their efforts will be crowned with success.
('3', 489, 3, 11, 1124091) Should, however, the plague break out, it will be a misfortune for the Indian community.
('3', 489, 3, 12, 1124180) It is struggling to be free from the effect of the visitaion in the Transvaal, and an outbreak at this juncture would simply fill to overflowing the cup of its woe.
('3', 489, 3, 13, 1124345) We cannot help, however, uttering a word of warning to the Indians.
('3', 489, 3, 14, 1124413) The slightest sickness, especially fever or pneumonia, should be attended to without any delay and, if necessary, reported to the authorities.
('3', 489, 3, 15, 1124556) There is, perhaps, too much laxity in dealing with such sicknesses, but especially at a time like this, it would be a great folly to treat lightly either fever or pneumonia.
('3', 489, 3, 16, 1124730) We would also ask them to completely isolate all such cases, so that the risk of infection may be minimised.
('3', 489, 3, 17, 1124839) Above all, however, it is imper ative that light and air should be allowed to have full play in the meanest of dwellings.
('3', 489, 3, 18, 1124961) All dirt should be banished from every home.
('3', 489, 3, 19, 1125006) And if these elementary precautions are taken by every individual, we have no doubt that the calamity will be averted.
('3', 489, 3, 20, 1125125) A very great deal has already been done in the way of improving Indian dwellings, and we see reforms in all directions.
('3', 489, 3, 21, 1125245) Redoubled efforts are, however, neces sary in view of the threatened visitation, and we hope that our remarks will be taken to heart by every Indian in the Colony.

('3', 490, 1, 2, 1125475) 323. A WELL DESERVED VICTORY
('3', 490, 2, 3, 1125504) So the Supreme Court has given judgment in favour of the plaintiff with costs in the Indian test case, 1 to which reference has been made in another column.
('3', 490, 2, 4, 1125661) We offer our hearty congratulations to our countrymen in the Transvaal on the successful ending of the case.
('3', 490, 2, 5, 1125770) The victory has been dearly won and is richly deserved.
('3', 490, 2, 6, 1125826) We can only hope that the Indian community will be allowed by the Government to enjoy the fruits of the victory.
('3', 490, 2, 7, 1125939) We think that, in this great and unequal struggle, the British Indians have behaved in accordance with their traditions.
('3', 490, 2, 8, 1126060) It was open to them to bring this case soon after British occupation, and we are aware that they were advised by the best counsel of the day in the Transvaal to adopt the course, but they thought otherwise.
('3', 490, 2, 9, 1126267) They felt that it was their duty at first, instead of challenging the Government, to get justice from them and to ask them to fulfil the promises made by the authorities in Downing Street.
('3', 490, 2, 10, 1126456) They also felt that they should approach the Chambers of Commerce and other public bodies who had taken up a hostile attitude towards the Indian traders and try to convince them of the injustice that was being done to the Indians owing to the refusal to grant licenses, they were prepared to accept a very reasonable compromise, and suggested, therefore, that all the existing licenses should be left untouched, and that their licenses to trade outside Locations should be renewed from time to time, and that other applicants might be dealt with on merits.
('3', 490, 2, 11, 1127013) This was rejected and the culminationg point was reached last December when practically every Indian trader was threatened with ruin.
('3', 490, 2, 12, 1127147) It was after every means to arrive at a compromise was exhausted that the community embarked upon the test case.
('3', 490, 2, 13, 1127260) The result could not well be otherwise, although having suffered so much, there was tremendous anxiety about it.
('3', 490, 2, 14, 1127373) There is however, a bright side to the sorrrowful picture of injustice, and this is that, in British Dominions, no matter how high prejudices may run, there is always a haven of safety in the highest courts of justice.
('3', 490, 2, 15, 1127592) Tradition has made the British judges practically invulnerable against prejudice or sentiment, and the
('3', 490, 3, 16, 1127695) 1 Habib Motan v.
('3', 490, 3, 17, 1127712) The Transvaal Government: The judgment held that the instructions given to the Licensing Officers to refuse licences to Indian traders to trade outside Location were illegal and that the plaintiff was entitled to get licence to trade as a general dealer in the towns of Pretoria and Pietersburg.
('3', 491, 0, 1, 1128008) 492 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('3', 491, 1, 2, 1128050) meanest subject can, if he has only sufficient means at his command, get unadulterated justice if the law itself allows it.
('3', 491, 1, 3, 1128174) The judges of the Supreme Court of the Transvaal have not hesitated to brush aside the judgment of the late High Court, and in spite of the stand taken up by Counsel for the Government, they have decided that every Indian is free in accordance with law 3 of 1885, as amended in 1886, to trade wherever he likes.
('3', 491, 1, 4, 1128486) This nullifies all the Government Notices and the action of the Government with reference to Indian license holders.
('3', 491, 1, 5, 1128603) It is our duty, however, to warn our countrymen against being too much elated by this success.
('3', 491, 1, 6, 1128698) Probably it means only the beginning of another struggle.
('3', 491, 1, 7, 1128756) Opposition will be raised up against them through out the country, and the Government may bring in a Bill to counteract the effect of the judgments of the Supreme Court.
('3', 491, 1, 8, 1128926) They will, there fore, have yet to work and to exercise patience and prudent restraint.
('3', 491, 1, 9, 1129014) The Government, unfortunately, is one thing and the Supreme Court is totally another.
('3', 491, 1, 10, 1129100) The former is swayed and affected by all the preju dices and sentiment, and, unfortunately, in the Transvaal, itself too weak even to do what is, in the words of Mr. Duncan, “purely elemen tary justice.” In spite of Lord Milner’s strong rule, and stronger will, His Excellency has succumbed to the anti Indian agitation and failed to protect the weaker party.

('3', 493, 1, 2, 1133042) stated that they had received notices to remove to Locations, which is the barest truth.
('3', 493, 1, 3, 1133131) The East London dispatch is less happy in justifying the procedure adopted by the Municipality.
('3', 493, 1, 4, 1133227) The facts according to the dispatch are that there is in all a population of six hundred Indians in East London, of whom only one hundred Indians live in the town; our contemporary adds: “under no municipal control”.
('3', 493, 1, 5, 1133444) Are the Ind ians free from the municipal regulations?
('3', 493, 1, 6, 1133498) We have gone through the whole of the regulations and we find no such freedom from liability to observe the municipal regulations on the part of the Indians.
('3', 493, 1, 7, 1133656) Is there the slightest necessity for removing a handful of Indians living amongst a European population of over twelve thousand?
('3', 493, 1, 8, 1133785) It should also be remembered that these men have been living there for several years.
('3', 493, 1, 9, 1133871) No charge of insanitation, so far as we are aware, can be laid against the men.
('3', 493, 1, 10, 1133951) The fact that over four hundred Indians are living in the Location also strengthens the position of the British Indians in that those who do not wish to live up to the Western standard of comfort of their own accord live in the Location.
('3', 493, 1, 11, 1134189) It is only a very fair inference, therefore, that the few who are living in the town are doing so under good sanitary conditions.
('3', 493, 1, 12, 1134319) The plague in the Transvaal has been brought into the argument, but, as we have already shown in previous issues, the large number of cases among the Indians are due entirely to the gross neglect on the part of the Johannesburg Town Council, and that, beyond Johannesburg and beyond the Indian Loca tion the Indians have not fared any worse than the other communities.
('3', 493, 1, 13, 1134688) Our contemporary acknowledges the Indian to be law abiding, and is good enough to admit that “his status as a civilised man from an intellectual point of view cannot seriously be called in question”.
('3', 493, 1, 14, 1134888) If, then, he fails in reaching the Western standard of sanitation, is it after all such a difficult thing to bend him to the reform without relegating [him] to a ghetto?
('3', 493, 1, 15, 1135058) And does not the experience of Cape Town, Dur ban, and other places where the Indians, having the opportunity, have not failed to learn lessons from the Europeans, belie any of the mis givings indulged in by our contemporary?
('3', 493, 1, 16, 1135284) We cannot help thinking that the East London Dispatch would have rendered a better service to the community, in whose interests it is published, if it had examined the position dispassionately, taken a correct view of the facts as they actually are, and supported the action of the Indian community in its endeavour to resist the unnecessary degradation to which the Muni cipality seeks to subject it.
('3', 493, 1, 17, 1135686) Indian Opinion, 14 5 1904
('3', 494, 0, 1, 1135712) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 495
('3', 494, 1, 2, 1135753) 325. THE PLAGUE IN JOHANNESBURG
('3', 494, 2, 3, 1135785) On the 29th April, so the public of Johannesburg has been informed, two Europeans were attacked with the bubonic plague in the market house in Johannesburg.
('3', 494, 2, 4, 1135942) Nothing was done by the Rand Plague Committee up to the 4th instant beyond removing the patients to the lazaretto at Rietfontein.
('3', 494, 2, 5, 1136072) They gave the market house the benefit of the doubt and inferred that, unless the contrary could be proved, the infection must have come from outside sources.
('3', 494, 2, 6, 1136231) Thus, the ordinary rule was reversed.
('3', 494, 2, 7, 1136269) For, speaking as laymen, we have always understood that, if a case of plague or any other infectious disease occurs in a particular locality, the first thing to do is to assume that the locality itself is infected and try to trace the infection to something in the place itself.
('3', 494, 2, 8, 1136548) Thus, in Durban, Cape Town, and other parts of South Africa as well as the rest of the world, wherever such cases have happened, the places have been locked up, put under quarantine, and disinfected.
('3', 494, 2, 9, 1136748) In go ahead Johannesburg, however, the much praised Rand Plague Committee reverses the method, and failing to trace the infection elsewhere, sets about finding if it is not, after all within the market house itself, and succeeds after four days’ search in finding that rats were plague infected.
('3', 494, 2, 10, 1137044) The committee then suddenly, in a theatrical manner, surrounds the market, on the 4th instant at noon, with a police cordon and places the premises under modified quarantine.
('3', 494, 2, 11, 1137219) All this certainly strikes the imagination of the people, creates a lot of stir and possibly brings praise, but we venture to think that it looks very much like locking the stable door after the steed is gone.
('3', 494, 2, 12, 1137429) For full four days after the discovery of the two cases, the infection is allowed to spread in the town through the market.
('3', 494, 2, 13, 1137553) The wonder undoubtedly is that the whole of Johannesburg is not now reeking with plague.
('3', 494, 2, 14, 1137642) The congratulations, however, for the general immunity from plague are hardly due to the Committee, in this case at any rate, but to the glorious weather and the high altitude of Johan nesburg which, in spite of the blundering of the Committee, prevent the plague germ from thriving.
('3', 494, 2, 15, 1137926) Indian Opinion, 14 5 1904

('3', 495, 1, 2, 1137994) 326. THE JUDGMENT IN THE TEST CASE 1
('3', 495, 2, 3, 1138031) JOHANNESBURG, May 16, 1904 You have no doubt seen the judgment given by the Chief Justice in the test case.
('3', 495, 2, 4, 1138139) The only question was that of interpreting the term “residence” occurring in Law 3 of 1885, and the Chief Justice, with the concurrence of his two colleagues, decided that it does not include place of business.
('3', 495, 2, 5, 1138350) So, after fifteen years’ hard struggle, the Indian position is vindicated and the Indians have the right to trade in any part of the Transvaal.
('3', 495, 2, 6, 1138494) You will notice, also, that the Chief Justice felt called upon to make some very strong remarks regarding the heartless and inconsistent attitude of Local Government, supported by the Colonial Office, namely, the going back on the position the Govern ment took up before the war.
('3', 495, 2, 7, 1138774) You will also notice that, in the opinion of the Chief Justice, to relegate Indian traders to Locations is tanta mount to deprivng them of the[ir] means of livelihood.
('3', 495, 2, 8, 1138942) As he said, it would be giving with the one hand and taking away with the other.
('3', 495, 2, 9, 1139023) So that every complaint that the British Indian Association has made regarding the operation of Law 3 of 1885 and the establish ment of Location has been proved to be fully justified.
('3', 495, 2, 10, 1139207) What, however, will be the outcome of all this is a very serious question.
('3', 495, 2, 11, 1139282) Ordinarily, the Indians should now be in a position to face difficulties, and rely upon the Colonial Office doing the rest, but, unfortunately, the Government here is too weak to do justice.
('3', 495, 2, 12, 1139473) The faint echoes of the clamour that would be raised against the Indians enjoying the fruit of their most dearly won victory have already begun to be heard, and it would not be at all surprising if the Government sought to rush through the Legislative Council a Bill, again robbing the Indians of the fruit of their victory.
('3', 495, 2, 13, 1139798) One thing however is, certain; there cannot be any justificaton on the grounds of the old law being unfavourable to the Indians as to their trade.
('3', 495, 2, 14, 1139945) We now know that the old law places no restriction on Indian immigration and trade.
('3', 495, 2, 15, 1140029) Indian immigration has been most
('3', 495, 3, 16, 1140062) 1 This is the text of a statement by Gandhiji edited and pulished in India as “Fr om a Correspondent”.
('3', 495, 3, 17, 1140165) He had sent a copy also to Dadabhai Naoroji, who quoted portions of it in his letter dated June 7,1904 addressed to the Secretary of State for the Colonies and the Secretary of State for India (C.O. 291, Volume 79, Individual—N).
('3', 496, 0, 1, 1140395) VOL. 3 : 1 AUGUST, 1902 21 MAY, 1904 497
('3', 496, 1, 2, 1140436) effectively stopped by the Peace Preservation Ordinance, and a new law under the Crown Colony would have to be brought in order to prohibit Indian trade, that is to say, a new disablity would be placed on the Indian, to which he was never subjected by law during the old regime.
('3', 496, 1, 3, 1140715) Such is the cruel irony of fate.
('3', 496, 1, 4, 1140748) Before the war, the British Go vernment granted protection to the Indians, although it was foreign domination then.
('3', 496, 1, 5, 1140864) Now, after the war, the all powerful British Govern ment refuses to protect one portion of British subjects simply because they are the weaker party.
('3', 496, 1, 6, 1141014) Will the Colonial Office now put its foot firmly down on any attempt to impose further disabilities on the British Indians?
('3', 496, 1, 7, 1141138) Will the Indian Government do its duty?
